HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Debate This!

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Let's get crazy for a moment and imagine that the two presidential candidates are actually going to devote one of their debates to foreign policy -- what would they talk about? Would Al Gore, Rick Lazio-like, thrust upon George W. Bush a map of the world with the country names spelled out phonetically (RUSH-ah, ee-ROCK, Grease)? Would Mr. Bush ask Mr. Gore to give viewers his insights on Buddhist temples? Nah. Doubt it.
Mr. Gore could, though, ask the Republican candidate to explain how is it that Mr. Bush's foreign policy advisers say the U.S. shouldn't be the world's global cop or 911, fighting wars around the world, while Mr. Bush's vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, says U.S. troops are woefully underfunded and underprepared. Put it together and the Bush position is that the U.S. military should be better prepared to do nothing and better funded to go nowhere. 
 Mr. Gore could also ask Mr. Bush why, if the Republicans are so serious about foreign policy, they allowed both the Senate and House foreign affairs committees to be run by Republican lawmakers, such as Jesse Helms, who had so little clue about the world that these two once-great committees have become more irrelevant than anytime in their histories.
Mr. Bush, for his part, could press Mr. Gore to elaborate on his call for more "forward engagement" in U.S. foreign policy, to quell crises before they erupt. For instance, Mr. Bush could ask Mr. Gore for a single example of where the Clinton team successfully forward-engaged. The Asian economic crisis? Haiti? Kosovo? Russia? Cuba? Iraq? Other than in North Korea, where the Clinton team deserves credit for defusing a very dangerous situation, this would be a short list.
But this forward engagement concept actually would be a good place to start a debate. Where would each candidate be working right now to defuse a crisis that could require costly U.S. intervention, and what tools would he use? Right answer: The most likely places for U.S. intervention in the next four years are five islands: Cuba, Taiwan, Indonesia, North Korea and Iraq -- the latter two being islands unto themselves.
On Cuba, eventually Fidel Castro is going to pass away, and when he does there will be enormous pressure from Miami Cubans to intervene in Havana when a power struggle breaks out there. Now is the time to be preparing a soft landing for Cuba. Regarding Taiwan, China's Jiang Zemin is expected to step down at the next party congress in 2001 and he will not want to leave office without having at least resumed the dialogue with Taiwan, or be seen to have taken some decisive, unilateral action to press unification. Because a war between China and Taiwan threatens so many U.S. interests, the next president should consider secret U.S. mediation between the two as soon as he's sworn in.
North Korea is a small basket case, whose hard-headed regime is also desperately in need of a soft landing, which the Clinton team has been working on, and Indonesia is a large basket case, whose soft-headed regime may be incapable of keeping Indonesia from splitting apart. Indonesia is a long way from Washington, but if the world's fourth-largest country, which sits astride the key shipping lanes of Southeast Asia, comes unglued, America will get drawn in.
Finally, U.S. fighter planes are in action over Iraq every day. It will take just one U.S. plane to be shot down inside Iraq for the next president to have his foreign policy agenda immediately dominated by what to do about Saddam Hussein. (Actually, we're already Saddam's hostages. With today's oil market so tight, if he takes just a few barrels off the market, gasoline could go to $3 a gallon.)
As for new tools, one place the next president could start is by revamping U.S. foreign aid, by both greatly expanding the foreign aid budget, so that America is no longer the world's cheapskate, and by making all U.S. non-military assistance or debt relief conditional. The condition would be that the recipient country put in place basic anti-corruption, rule-of-law measures and institutions that will attract private investors, who have replaced governments as the key source of capital for growth in the world. Aid or investment will not work in countries without institutions.
 As I said, just some crazy thoughts. No doubt the presidential candidates can, and will, get by without discussing any of them. The next president won't be so lucky.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 731 words

HEADLINE: What Local Control?

BYLINE: By Leon Botstein; Leon Botstein is president of Bard College.

DATELINE: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

 BODY:
The presidential candidates are taking their parties to new places with their education proposals: Al Gore has called for higher standards for teachers as well as higher pay, while George W. Bush has emphasized closing the achievement gap between rich and poor and holding schools accountable for student performance. Yet no matter who wins in November, there is little reason to believe that any serious improvement is in the offing.
This is because neither candidate is willing to confront the underlying obstacle to real change: the premise that the basic responsibility for education rests with communities and states, not the federal government. 
 Americans have become so accustomed to trashing Big Government that calling for Washington to take charge of education might sound absurd. Indeed, today's conventional wisdom points toward privatization -- the dismantling of large state education systems through vouchers and charter schools. But educational equity will only be possible through a national system that insures a minimum standard of excellence.
Consider the effects of our patchwork quilt of local governance. Our schools have become a battleground for local disputes over prayer in school, for example, and property taxes, issues that have little to do with education. School boards are notoriously unstable. The country has nearly 15,000 boards, and the average term of a member is less than four years. In New York state, one-quarter of the membership changes every year. As a result, superintendents are hired and fired too rapidly. In urban school districts, the average length of service is under three years; nationally, the average is six years.
Annual school board elections and voter approval of school budgets are among the last bastions of direct democracy, but noble as that citizen involvement may be, why should children frequently be the victims of voters' frustration over their own powerlessness in other aspects of politics? And why do we continue to finance schools primarily on property assessments in an age when real estate is no longer the dominant source of wealth?
The results of this system are all too clear. In August, the Department of Education released its latest report card, a three-decade survey of performance by 9-, 13- and 17-year-olds. Reading scores remained flat in all age groups. And they were not high to begin with. In science, 9-year-olds showed no improvement at all throughout the 1990's, and the scores of 17-year-olds today were lower than in 1969. At a time of rapid economic and scientific progress, learning in America stands still.
Every other developed nation has a national system of education. We too should insist that our students and teachers meet stringent national and international standards. The current supplemental grants from Washington are insufficent to bridge the gap between rich and poor districts: school spending should come primarily from the federal budget, based on income tax revenues.
And some improvements can be achieved without creating more federal bureaucracy. For example, as Gov. Gray Davis of California has suggested, we can use the tax code. We could in effect raise salaries by exempting teachers in public schools from state and federal income taxes.
And contrary to the claims of some, there is no constitutional objection to a larger federal role. The framers did not directly exclude education from the federal agenda.
If one wants a clear constitutional basis for rethinking the federal role, look to the interstate commerce clause. The Internet has made it plain that information and knowledge cross state lines. If that argument seems a bit too clever, consider that since we live now in the so-called global economy, contingent on scientific knowledge and high levels of literacy, should not education be deemed essential to the national defense and foreign policy? There are many precedents in constitutional interpretation that can permit a 21st-century America to abandon 18th-century practices.
As things stand now, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore can say anything they want about education, but in the end, they can't be held accountable. A real "education president" would be one who admits that our education crisis cuts across state lines, and that the solution is a federal system based on national standards and paid for with federal dollars.

HEADLINE: The Cost of Not Living On a $5.15 Minimum;
Little Impact Seen in Raising Wage Now

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: BURTONSVILLE, Md.

 BODY:
Four years ago, the last time Congress agreed to raise the minimum wage, Lynn Martins was quick -- though far from eager -- to respond.
On word that she would soon have to pay employees at her family-owned Seibel's Restaurant 50 cents more an hour, Ms. Martins printed up new menus virtually overnight, pushing the price of a basic hamburger up a dime to more than $3. 
 "I anticipated," she said. "I raised prices prior to the rise even taking effect" to try to blunt the impact on payroll costs that she knew was coming. Subsequently, Ms. Martins, who is very reluctant to lay anybody off, decided not to replace an employee who left, choosing instead to give a raise to another employee and ask that he do the work of two.
But not this time. Despite the near-certainty that a Congressional conference committee will work out differences between House and Senate versions of the minimum-wage legislation, most likely raising the federally mandated minimum to $6.15 in two annual 50-cent increments, Ms. Martins sees no need to hurry.
The labor market is so tight, at least in most urban areas, that many employers are already paying more than the $5.15 minimum to attract workers. In many cases, companies are already paying more than the proposed higher minimums. Except for high school students, unskilled help gets an average starting wage of about $7 an hour around here, in the suburban stretch between Baltimore and Washington.
"The market has lifted it well above the minimum wage even with the increases," Ms. Martins said. She said she did not expect actually to benefit from Republican pledges to offset higher wage mandates with more-generous tax breaks, which, in any case, would be less useful than cash.
Since she already pays as much as required by the prospective law, Ms. Martins said she could "probably sit out the winter" before raising menu prices or cutting the payroll. Besides, she added, her staff of 17 full-time and 30 part-time workers usually shrinks by half a dozen over the winter as business slows and more employees focus on school.
Restaurants and retailers have traditionally been among the sectors of the economy most affected by Washington's wage mandates. But they are expressing little alarm about the proposed increase.
Amazon.com, for example, the seller of books, music and video products over the Internet, said none of its 7,000 American employees, the bulk of them at some 10 distribution centers around the country, earn just the minimum. "The best reading I have from human resources is we're not affected by this," said Bill Curry, a senior spokesman for the company, which is based in Seattle.
Even the ailing Kmart Corporation, which has been forced into a major restructuring, expressed only mild regret at the prospect of a higher minimum wage. "We'd prefer, if it needs to be increased, that it not be increased immediately," said Mary Lorencz, the director of media relations. Since the company did not budget for an increase this year, she said Kmart would prefer that the rise be delayed until the company's new fiscal year begins on Feb. 1.
The version of the bill passed by the House calls for the first rise on Jan. 1, with the second 50-cent increment on Jan. 1, 2002. The minimum wage has been in place since 1938, when it was 25 cents an hour.
Nevertheless, today's prosperity seems likely to blunt only temporarily, not block, the economic forces that a higher minimum wage tends to unleash. Many companies may find profits eroded, in some cases to the point of failure, while hours are cut and prices are pushed up. Jobs may arguably be lost or the creation of new jobs slowed. The significance of these effects following previous increases in the minimum wage is a matter of debate, especially the effect on employment.
"The impact is very different, depending on who you talk to," said Lee Culpepper, senior vice president of the National Restaurant Association and leader of a multi-industry alliance devoted to the minimum wage issue called the Coalition for Job Opportunities.
Among the variables are whether a business is in a high-cost urban area or a low-cost rural one, whether employees are tipped or rely solely on wages and whether the enterprise is in one of the 10 states plus the District of Columbia that have their own minimums set higher than the federal one. In low-cost areas, employees are more likely to be earning the minimum than elsewhere, meaning that a mandated increase has greater impact.
Employees who make tips are entitled to be paid a wage of at least $2.38 an hour -- half the regular federal minimum of $4.75 that prevailed before the last increase in September 1997 -- and their employer must make sure that earnings, including tips, reach $5.15 an hour. In practice, tipped employees often earn much more.
Oregon and Washington, at $6.50, have the highest state minimums, followed by Connecticut, Rhode Island and the District of Columbia at $6.15. Connecticut is to go to $6.40 in January. In New York and New Jersey, the rate is set at the federal minimum.
Delaware's minimum is to climb to $6.15 from $5.65 on Oct. 1, posing an immediate problem for Robert E. Ashby, proprietor of McGlynns Pub and Restaurant in Newark, Del., who has 110 employees in two locations and is now conducting his annual review of menu prices.
"Our employees are already earning well above the federal minimum and we still have to go and give an increase," Mr. Ashby said. He said that the cost was magnified when the increase moved up the payroll ladder as he sought to maintain differentials for workers with more skills or seniority. And the impact can be quite subtle. In the last round of increases, for example, Mr. Ashby not only pruned staff hours but switched some setup work from morning, before the restaurant opened, to night. This saved him money because the employees involved had to be paid the full minimum when there was no opportunity for tips but could be paid only half as much if they did the same work at night while the restaurant was open.
Even in hindsight, the effects of increases in the minimum wage arouse intense feelings. Mr. Culpepper, of the restaurant group, pointed to "a price increase and a job impact" from the two-stage 90-cent rise in 1996 and 1997. He cited government figures showing, for example, that employment growth at eating and drinking establishments slowed to 129,100 in 1997 from 276,400 in 1995 and that menu prices, which had long trailed general inflation, suddenly began to outpace inflation beginning in 1997.
Those who favor higher minimums, however, question those conclusions. John Schmitt, an analyst at the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research organization, said he found no evidence of job loss other than that related to normal business-cycle fluctuations for either of two groups thought most vulnerable: teenagers and less-educated adults.
The industry's slackened job growth, he suggested, might reflect an inability of employers to find lower-paid workers. "In a booming economy, they have trouble competing with other sectors that pay better wages," Mr. Schmitt said.
In addition, a survey by the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College found that only 6.2 percent of 568 representative small businesses had their hiring or employment decisions affected by minimum-wage increases in 1996 and 1997.
In return for supporting this year's legislation to raise the minimum, the House Republicans are seeking to include various items of tax relief that would soften the presumed burden on business. Among these items are raising the deduction for business meals for everyone to 80 percent from 50 percent, accelerating full deductibility of health insurance premiums paid by the self-employed and nearly doubling the amount of equipment that can be expensed immediately rather than depreciated. In addition, the proposal would repeal a surtax on sellers of alcoholic beverages, extend a credit for hiring disadvantaged workers and allow people who sell their businesses to pay capital gains taxes in installments.
Further, the cash wage for tipped employees would be frozen at current levels in all states, and states would no longer be permitted to disallow credit for tips.
Yet neither Ms. Martins nor Mr. Ashby, who have made little use of an existing provision in minimum wage regulations to pay teenagers as little as $4.25 for the first 90 days of work, were much aware of the Republican proposals or took appreciable comfort from them.
Cash seemed paramount with Ms. Martins, whose revenue at Seibel's has just surpassed $1 million a year. She calculates that the proposed increase will cost her a relatively modest $2,400 in 2001 but a cumulative $30,000 in 2002.
Kevin M. Murphy, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business who has studied the minimum wage, has no doubts that there will be noticeable effects, showing up perhaps well before President Clinton signs the bill.
"It's probably not going to be as big as before, given the strength of the economy," he said. "But certainly it will be something."
Mr. Ashby, the Delaware restaurant owner, agreed. "I have to cut hours or increase prices," he said. "There's no other way of dealing with it."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
As Euro Slides, So Do Earnings Across the U.S.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The beleaguered euro continued its relentless decline yesterday as the impact of that currency's weakness spread across the American corporate landscape, cutting into sales and profits.
Gillette said that the drop in the value of several currencies, particularly the euro, would reduce the dollar value of sales by 6 percent in the third quarter, compared with a year ago. The news sent its stock down $2.19, or 7.3 percent, to $27.63. 
 Shares of DuPont, McDonald's, Colgate-Palmolive and other companies that do a major part of their business in Europe have also experienced declines after saying that they would be hurt by the weak euro. In trading yesterday the euro fell to a new intraday low of 85.10 cents and finished the day in New York at 85.46 cents.
Adding to the sales and profit problems of these multinational companies is the rising cost of oil and gasoline. It is sapping European spending power and, at the same time, raising corporate costs, a fact that has particularly hurt DuPont.
The decline in the value of the euro, or any other currency against the dollar, cuts into performance when sales and profits from abroad are translated into dollars. Hedging in currency markets can limit these impacts but can be expensive.
What is making the decline of the euro extra painful for American companies is that this was supposed to be the year the currency of 11 nations bottomed out and then began to rally, after falling 13.7 percent in its debut year of 1999. With that view in mind at the beginning of the year companies would naturally choose not to hedge to protect themselves against a further decline in the value of the euro. Instead, the euro has plunged another 15.1 percent this year.
"If you were expecting a bounce this year, you might not have hedged," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn.
Susan Stalnecker, the treasurer at DuPont, said: "The euro has not behaved the way people expected. I don't think, if you talked to anyone, they would be on the right side of this."
She said that DuPont's hedging strategy "only works when there is not a lot of volatility" in the foreign exchange market. "In volatile times you are more exposed."
DuPont says it will lose 2 cents a share in earnings for the second half of the year because of the weakening euro.
DuPont also showed the heavy impact that the rise in the price of oil was having. In its earnings warning on Sept. 7, DuPont's vice president for investor relations, Ann Gualtieri, said that 7 cents to 10 cents a share would be trimmed from earnings in the second half of the year because of higher energy costs.
According to some analysts, more companies also seem to have decided to ride out currency fluctuations, rather than aggressively hedge against them. This is because of losses suffered from attempts to hedge in the past and the belief that there would be less volatility in the currency market now that Europe has a single currency for 11 nations.
"Despite an increase in trade globally, there seems to be a reduction in the amount of hedging being done," said Robert White, executive vice president and treasurer at Standard Chartered Bank.
Eric Kraus, vice president for corporate communications at Gillette, said the company looked "for opportunity hedging -- but on a quarter-by-quarter, year-by-year basis, we don't do it."
"It is not a general practice," he added.
He also said that Gillette made a decision not to hedge against a further decline in the euro this year because it was thought that the euro was already near its bottom and was set for a rally. This view, he said, made hedging "an expensive undertaking at the time."
He also pointed out that it was not just the fall in the euro that was hurting companies with business in Europe this quarter. A sharp decline in the British pound is also cutting into sales and profits. Since the end of the second quarter in June, the euro is off 10.3 percent against the dollar while the British pound is down 7.1 percent. The average value of the euro so far this quarter, compared with the third quarter of 1999, is down 13.1 percent, which is the important comparison for year-to- year quarterly sales and profits. The average value of the British pound is down 7.4 percent so far this quarter compared with a year ago.
Mr. Kraus said that if the euro had held at 95 cents to the dollar at the end of June, then overall sales in the third quarter would be projected to rise 3 percent in the third quarter, compared with the third quarter of 1999, rather than the flat result now forecast. If the value of the euro held at the $1.05 of the third quarter of 1999, then the dollar value of sales would have been up 6 percent.
Edward Kerschner and Thomas Doerflinger of PaineWebber said in a commentary yesterday that the euro and oil prices would make it much tougher for companies with "heavy exposure to Europe" to meet current earnings forecasts for the third quarter. The report lists 100 companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index that have 18 percent or more of their sales from Europe.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Oil Prices Hit New 10-Year High on Fear of Persian Gulf Strife

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Oil prices surged yesterday to their highest levels in a decade, on fears that rising tensions between Iraq and Kuwait would disrupt the flow of crude oil from the Persian Gulf at a time when petroleum supplies around the world are extremely tight.
The cost of crude for delivery in October increased 96 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $36.88 a barrel at the New York Mercantile Exchange, the steepest price for oil since the Persian Gulf War. In London, the price of Brent crude oil for delivery in November also reached a 10-year peak, rising 99 cents, to $34.97 a barrel. 
 Oil prices have hovered near 10-year highs all month in the United States, largely because of growing concern about lower-than-usual supplies of crude oil and home heating fuel. Consequently, possible threats to the supply of oil easily spark increases in crude prices.
Traders seemed to be reacting to the last week's increasingly belligerent talk from Iraq about Kuwait's new oil projects. Iraq has accused Kuwait, which it once invaded and which it considers a puppet of the United States, of authorizing projects close to their mutual border that would permit Kuwait to tap oil deposits in Iraq. On Sunday, Saddam Hussein, the leader of Iraq, warned that "the superpowers will fasten their grip on oil-producing countries," according to the Iraqi press. Speaking at a cabinet meeting, he reportedly urged fellow members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to resist such pressure from the United States and Europe.
The United States responded with tough talk of its own, as Defense Secretary William S. Cohen warned Iraq not to take "any kind of aggressive action" against its neighbors. The dispute involving Iraq, Kuwait and the United States has stirred worries within the American oil market that another conflict in the Persian Gulf might limit oil supplies for winter, when they are needed the most worldwide.
But some analysts said Iraq's bellicosity masks a different threat to Middle Eastern oil exports. Rather than invade Kuwait again, Iraq has implied that it is willing to reduce or halt oil exports to apply pressure on the United Nations on the eve of a critical discussion about reparations Iraq must make to Kuwait, said Raad Alkadiri of the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting group based in Washington. Iraq exports about 2.3 million barrels a day, or about 4 percent of the world's daily consumption.
A United Nations commission on reparations will meet later this month to settle a $15.9 billion claim brought against Iraq by Kuwait. Iraq is slowly rebuilding its economy from the proceeds of moderate sales of oil permitted by United Nations sanctions. According to the Iraqi mission at the United Nations, the crude exports have brought in $31.6 billion since 1996, $9.5 billion of which has gone into a compensation account.
Analysts said Iraq was incensed at the idea of paying such large reparations to Kuwait. Moreover, Iraq fears that if this claim is successful, it will open the gates to others that would collectively ruin the country's economy and Mr. Hussein's regime.
"The votes are there" to compel Iraq to pay $15.9 billion to Kuwait, Mr. Alkadiri said. "So Iraq could suspend oil shipments to pressure the U.N." Iraq would be very upset to see a large amount of its revenues go to Kuwait, he said.

HEADLINE: Cohen Warns Indonesians To Disband Timor Militias

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen warned Indonesia today that this troubled country could face severe diplomatic and economic reprisals if it did not disband militia groups accused of killings and of causing havoc in the divided island of Timor.
In meetings here today with President Abdurrahman Wahid and other top officials, Mr. Cohen expressed grave disappointment that Indonesia had failed to disarm the pro-Jakarta militia that is accused of killing three unarmed United Nations aid workers, including an American, on Sept. 6 in West Timor. 
 Indonesia promised to move quickly to bring those responsible for the killings to justice. No arrests have been made, and none of the police officers and Indonesian military responsible for the security of the United Nations workers have been disciplined.
"Failure to do so will have consequences for Jakarta's relations with the international community, and could jeopardize continued economic assistance to Indonesia," Mr. Cohen said. "Indonesia faces a momentous decision."
Indonesia has been plagued by widespread violence in the last year, as it struggles to forge a new democracy after three decades of dictatorship under President Suharto, who stepped down in 1998. But with growing secessionist movements, a faltering economy, a rebellious military and recent bombings in Jakarta, the government has at times seemed overwhelmed by the task before it.
Frustrated that the police have failed to identify a single suspect in a series of bombings here, Mr. Wahid today dismissed the national chief, Gen. Rusdihardjo, and replaced him with his deputy, Lt. Gen. Bimantoro.
Mr. Cohen's remarks were the strongest yet by the United States about the militias, which last year waged a week of killing and rioting across East Timor after residents had overwhelmingly voted for independence in a United Nations-sponsored referendum. The vote freed East Timor from 24 years of harsh occupation by Indonesian troops, and the Indonesian military was accused of creating and supporting the militia groups to destabilize the situation.
Mr. Cohen said he had received assurances from Mr. Wahid and other leaders that the government would move swiftly to disband the militias, which operate on the side of the divided island that is still part of Indonesia. The militia groups are accused of harassing aid workers who are trying to repatriate some of the 120,000 East Timorese refugees who fled to camps in West Timor last year.
Asked what specific actions the United States would take if Indonesia failed to rein in the West Timor militia, Mr. Cohen, who is on a six-nation Asian tour, declined to speculate, but said:
"What takes place in the next few weeks will determine what the response will be. There cannot be delays or deferrals or in any way to seek to stretch this out. This is something that must be addressed in the immediate future."
But the Indonesian defense minister, Mohammad Mahfud Mahmodin, told reporters after meeting Mr. Cohen that Washington's decision to end military ties with Indonesia had deprived the Indonesian military of equipment that it needs to subdue the Timorese militias.
The United States ended military assistance to Indonesia after the East Timor rampage.

HEADLINE: Tentative Deal For Skyscraper At Former Site Of Alexander's

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A deal has tentatively been struck that would allow a 75-story skyscraper to be built in one of Manhattan's most valuable holes in the ground, the long-vacant and foreboding site of the old Alexander's department store at Lexington Avenue and 59th Street.
After two years of stop-and-go negotiations, Bloomberg, the financial information services company, has agreed in principle to be the anchor tenant for the proposed 1.3-million-square-foot tower, which would be taller than the Trump World Tower going up near the United Nations, executives on both sides of the negotiations said. 
 If a final deal is reached in the coming weeks, Bloomberg would move its headquarters and hundreds of employees one block from Park Avenue to a $400 million tower that is to be built on the Lexington Avenue site. A deal with Bloomberg, which would take about 450,000 square feet of space, would enable construction to begin on the long-awaited project by the developer Steven Roth.
The skyscraper would soar 900 feet, about 150 feet higher than the tallest tower in the Time Warner Center project at Columbus Circle that is being built by Stephen M. Ross, and 50 feet taller than Donald J. Trump's building, which is going up on First Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets.
Mr. Trump took comfort in the fact that he could still claim to have the tallest all-residential tower in the world.
The tower proposed by Mr. Roth, the chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, would mix office space with expensive retail stores, a five-star hotel and what real estate brokers are calling 200 superluxury condominiums.
Wendi Kopsick, a spokeswoman for Vornado Realty Trust, declined to comment, as did Chris Taylor, a spokeswoman for Bloomberg, and their broker, Barry Gossin, chief executive of Newmark & Company.
But executives from both sides, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that there was a breakthrough at a meeting on Friday.
"They seem to have come to terms," said one person who works with Vornado. "It's clearly been going on for a long time."
Cesar Pelli, the architect who designed the world's tallest buildings, the Petronas Towers in Malaysia, is finishing plans for the skyscraper on what is now a deep two-acre hole surrounded by a blue construction fence across the street from Bloomingdale's. Alexander's closed in 1992, and the hulking department store was demolished last year.
Local residents, who have spent the last year fighting Mr. Trump's project near the United Nations, were not enthusiastic about yet another huge building going up in the neighborhood.
Mr. Roth's tower, like Trump World Tower, is an as-of-right building that does not require zoning variances or city approval.
"We always knew it was going to be a mega-building," said Edward Rubin, a member of the local community board. "But we've gotten a little numb after the Trump building. These are two examples of what happens when you don't have the right zoning controls in place."
Mr. Roth's 200 condominiums, on the 28th through 75th floors, would compete directly with the 225 superluxury condominiums at Time Warner Center. The apartments in both buildings would sell for more than three times the average condominium price today: $2,000 a square foot, or $6 million for a 3,000-square-foot apartment.
It would be a dramatic turnabout for the vacant site, which sat like a gray hulk in one of the wealthiest neighborhoods in the country, much to the dismay of its neighbors. Mr. Roth has long wanted to build his own major skyscraper there, but for one reason or another, he had failed to strike a deal over the years with a string of blue-chip tenants, including Sotheby's, Christie's and Ritz-Carlton.
The pending deal with Bloomberg nearly fell apart in July, said one person involved in the negotiations, when Mr. Roth tried to increase what the company thought was an already exorbitant rent.
"Steve is a very hard guy to make a deal with," he said. "He wants to get every ounce of blood. You can't live that way."
The tactic also fueled the opposition of one of Bloomberg's financial advisers, who had not favored the Vornado project. But, two executives said, Michael Bloomberg, chairman of the company he founded, was determined to close a deal at what he thought would be a signature, if expensive, skyscraper.
In a compromise of sorts, Bloomberg decided recently to take more space in the building, but at the agreed-upon rent, nearly $70 a square foot. The asking rent in Midtown today is $61 a square foot.
"This was never about economics," said one top real estate broker who knows Mr. Bloomberg.
A deal with Bloomberg would bring to an end a long travail for Mr. Roth, the irascible one-time suburban shopping strip king who has become a major commercial landlord in Manhattan. He gained control of the ailing Alexander's in 1991, killing the department store chain in favor of the real estate beneath the buildings.
In the early 1990's, Mr. Roth tried to find a partner among the city's real estate families, but they found his complex financing plan too exotic.
He spent nearly two years negotiating with A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's, about building a new home for the auction house with an apartment tower above it. As his plans evolved, Mr. Roth dropped Sotheby's in favor of its biggest rival, Christie's. Frustrated with Mr. Roth, Christie's ultimately moved to Rockefeller Center.
Mr. Roth eventually opened negotiations with Bloomberg and hired his fourth architect for the project. Earlier this year, the dormant site came alive when Mr. Roth started pouring the foundation for a skyscraper to try to beat the deadline for a proposed zoning change that would have permitted a building of only half the height he wanted.
But Mr. Roth's talks with Bloomberg dragged on as the terms seemed to shift almost daily.
In June, Mr. Roth seemed to be sending a bare-knuckled message to Bloomberg to accept his deal or else, when he filed preliminary plans for the tower with the City Buildings Department.
The plans detailed only four floors of office space, instead of the six that Bloomberg needed. According to those who know him, Mr. Roth delighted in saying that in New York's booming real estate market, the site gained in value every day he failed to build anything.
But it now appears that the two sides are striking a deal.
"He's taken the gun out of his holster," said one investment banker who knows Mr. Roth well. "Now he's got to pull the trigger."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
2 Time Warner Mergers Facing Peril in Europe

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Antitrust regulators at the European Commission are threatening to block the $165 billion merger of Time Warner and America Online, as both sides prepare to negotiate a possible settlement over the next week.
European officials in Brussels have drawn up proposed rejection language, according to a person close to the discussions, arguing that the merger could choke off competition in the distribution of music and entertainment over the Internet. 
 The move by the European Commission, the day-to-day administrative arm of the European Union, is to a great extent procedural and the basis for the bargaining that is expected to take place. People on both sides have made it clear that they are ready to talk.
But the commission's threat to block the merger is not just a negotiating strategy. By forbidding combinations of European businesses, the commission has the power to effectively stop big corporate deals even if the parent companies are not European. On previous occasions, including mergers of two American companies, European regulators have used that power to make companies divest themselves of businesses or change their conduct.
In an antitrust review related to the Time Warner-AOL deal, European officials are coaxing concessions in the merger proposed between Time Warner and EMI, the big British music distributor.
EMI executives said today that they would offer proposals to the commission on Tuesday, though they refused to say what compromises they had in mind.
Amelia Torres, a European spokeswoman on competition issues, would not confirm that officials had proposed a rejection of the AOL deal.
But she said it was "normal" to recommend that a merger be prohibited "when you are in the second phase of an inquiry and when the companies are not forthcoming in addressing the concerns."
Last week, European officials circulated a similar draft rejection of the merger between Time Warner and EMI. Among other things, they are concerned that the EMI deal will reduce the number of major music distributors worldwide to four companies from five now.
With AOL and Time Warner, officials are worried that the combined companies' store of entertainment programming and access to online customers will give them unparalleled bargaining power with both producers and consumers.
The AOL merger is related to the EMI deal in European minds because AOL has its own agreement to distribute music from the Bertelsmann Music Group.
European officials are already hostile to a merger that would unite EMI with Warner Music. They are even less happy about adding Bertelsmann to the mix.
In a joint statement today, AOL and Time Warner insisted that they remained confident about winning approval for their deal. "This is a normal part of the process with the E.U.," the companies said. "We are totally comfortable with where we are at this stage of the negotiations. We have made excellent progress and are confident the talks will conclude successfully. As we have said, we are on track to close in the fall."
Investors seemed unfazed by the European Commission's threat. The shares of both companies rose on the New York Stock Exchange today, with Time Warner up $1.44 to close at $81.25, and AOL rising 41 cents to $55.56.
The Federal Trade Commission in Washington is also skeptical about the Time Warner-AOL deal, but its concerns differ from those in Europe. American officials are primarily worried about the ability of America Online's rivals to gain access on Time Warner's cable television networks as cable systems are more heavily used as high-speed links to the Internet from individual homes.
The two companies have pledged to provide open access, and have argued that is in their interest to carry all popular content providers on their networks.
But other media companies, led by Walt Disney, contend that the merger would further strengthen what Disney executives call the "walled garden" of AOL's proprietary part of the Internet.
European officials are primarily worried about the overwhelming power the companies could have through the linking of three of the world's five big music distributors -- EMI, Warner and Bertelsmann.
The European Commission is required to issue a final decision on the EMI merger by Oct. 18 and on the AOL deal by Oct. 24. Under the commission's rules, EMI must submit proposed remedies on antitrust concerns by Tuesday and AOL before next Monday.
Mario Monti, the European commissioner for competition, has already prevented several big mergers. Earlier this summer, he blocked the combination of WorldCom and Sprint. In March, he stopped the proposed $7 billion merger between Sweden's two big truck manufacturers, Scania and Volvo. And the same month, he blocked the merger of three major aluminum companies.
Of the deals involving Time Warner, many experts think that the one with EMI faces the tougher resistance, because European officials seem intent on forcing EMI or Warner to sell some important record labels.
AOL executives have suggested ways of limiting their agreement with Bertelsmann Music, though the proposals so far have not impressed European officials. But if the Europeans block the deal with EMI, AOL executives think that their marketing link with Bertelsmann's music arm will appear less threatening to competition.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Let Candidates Do the Math On Education

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WITH education supposed to be the crucial issue, both New York candidates for the Senate are busy visiting schools and promising large sums of money. The figures sound impressive, but it might be useful if the candidates paused at the schools' blackboards long enough to work on a few problems:
Rick, a candidate for United States Senate, has proposed a total of $98 billion in new federal spending on education over the next decade. His opponent, Hillary, has proposed a total of $130 billion. 
 If there are 69 million students in America from kindergarten through university level, how much does each candidate propose to spend on each student per year?
If Rick fulfills his promises, the government will spend a grand total of $142.02 per year more on each student. Hillary's proposals would mean an additional $46.39. That will probably not loom large to anyone who has paid a tuition bill.
It's not that Rick Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton are fiscal conservatives. They're proposing hefty budget increases. But the federal government provides a mere 9 percent of the money spent on education in America, so the increases don't make much difference. National politicians love to talk about schools, but the bills are paid by parents and local and state governments.
The average New Yorker sends $5,676 to Washington in taxes each year. Washington sends $4,840 back in spending programs. If there are 18 million New Yorkers, how much are they losing? And is there any reason they would want to give Washington another excuse to spend their money elsewhere?
In all, the state gets back $15 billion less than it sends to Washington each year, as computed by Jay H. Walder and Herman B. Leonard of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. New Yorkers pay above-average taxes and get below-average returns, so on the whole they would be better off with tax cuts than with new spending programs.
But the state doesn't do badly in all areas. While New York ranks 48th in its per capita share of the military budget, it benefits from programs aimed at poor people. Because of its high poverty rate, it ranks first among states in its per capita payments from welfare programs, and it also does relatively well on education programs aimed primarily at the poor.
When it comes to overall federal spending on education, New York gets the 16th-highest per capita share, according to calculations by Dr. Walder. So there's something to be said for the enthusiasm of Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Lazio: if Washington is going to spend money, New York is better off having the money spent on education than on most other things.
BUT while New York is getting a little more than its share of the education pot, you have to remember who filled the pot. New York ranks 13th in the per capita share of taxes paid. So even when Congress sends some educational dollars this way, New York is essentially just getting back its own money, minus a few expenses in Washington.
Still, breaking even isn't bad, especially for city dwellers who look to Washington for redressing economic inequalities. Using federal tax collectors can be the most effective way to transfer money from affluent suburbanites to inner-city students, as New York City officials have found after fighting losing battles in Albany to redistribute the suburbs' wealth.
"The city schools often fare better in Washington than in Albany," said Stephen Allinger, the executive director of the office of intergovernmental affairs for the city Board of Education. "Some of the federal programs aren't fair to New York, but in general federal aid is far more focused on need than state aid is."
In theory, then, New York City could benefit if Mr. Lazio or Mrs. Clinton persuaded Congress to shift spending to education from the many programs that enrich other states. But that will be hard to do, given the most stubborn math problem of all.
The 1.4 million inhabitants of North Dakota and South Dakota pay a total of $6 billion in annual federal taxes. The 18.2 million inhabitants of New York pay $103 billion. Suppose the money is pooled and stacked on a table in a Senate committee room. New York's two senators want to spend it on education. The four senators from the Dakotas want to spend it on agricultural assistance.
What are the odds that wheat farmers will be driving new John Deere tractors next spring?

HEADLINE: Job Growth Sets a Record In the Region

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Private employment and job creation in the New York region hit an all-time high in 1999, surpassing the national rate of job growth for the first time in nearly two decades, according to an annual economic study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The findings, to be released today, are surprising because the region has lagged behind the nation -- and behind many other areas of the country -- in most economic indexes during the boom of the 1990's. But in posting a growth rate of 2.8 percent in private jobs last year, the New York region surpassed the national average -- 2.4 percent in 1999 -- for the first time since 1983. And the report said the trend was expected to continue through this year. 
 While most of the new hiring came in the region's dominant service sector, including support jobs in industries like finance, advertising and technology, last year's growth was more diversified than that of past years, with significant gains in construction, retail and wholesaling, and securities.
The Port Authority report also noted that with the most recent surge of new jobs, the region had finally managed to make up for the 600,000 jobs it lost in the recession of 1989-92. Job creation in the years since thenmade the New York region No. 3 last year among the 10 most populous metropolitan areas, behind Atlanta and Dallas-Fort Worth, in the rate of job growth, and No. 1 in the number of new jobs created.
"The New York-New Jersey region closed out the 20th century with an economic boom," Robert E. Boyle, executive director of the Port Authority, said yesterday.
Another reason the findings are notable is the fact that job creation is usually driven by population growth, which has plodded in the New York region and in the rest of the Northeast. Eugene Spruck, the chief economist for the Port Authority, noted that the New York region averages an annual population growth of 0.3 percent, compared with a national average of 1 percent.
"Generally you can't expect this region to have the population growth of other areas," Mr. Spruck said, "and so that is why this development is so notable."
He said the 17-county region examined in the report had benefited as a leader in the areas where American job growth has been strongest: finance, construction, new technology and the Internet.
Another recent report on New York City seems to echo the Port Authority study. The city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, noted in a report released last month that as of June, New York had enjoyed 30 consecutive quarters of private job growth, surpassing the record of 20 quarters set in the 1980's.
The Port Authority study examined economic indicators in the five boroughs of New York and in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties. Also included were eight northern New Jersey counties: Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Middlesex, Morris, Passaic, Somerset and Union.
In raw numbers, the region ended 1999 with 190,300 more jobs than it had in 1998. But more impressive, Mr. Spruck said, is the fact that from 1992, when the recession ended, to 1999, 768,400 jobs were created. The region posted a total of 7.737 million jobs last year, a record and the highest figure since the months before the recession struck in 1989, when there were 7.62 million jobs.
Job growth in 1999 included a 4 percent increase in the service sector; a 2.7 percent increase in Wall Street brokerage firm jobs; a 2 percent in finance, insurance and real estate jobs; and an 8.9 percent surge in construction jobs.
New York City's job growth rate was 2.8 percent in 1999, while the New York suburbs' was 3.5 percent and northern New Jersey's was 1.8 percent.
"This tells me that we are working as a region, economically," said Mr. Spruck, pointing out that much of the business, consulting and support services around Wall Street and the advertising industry were spilling out into suburbs. "There is a lot of county-to-county commuting in addition to city-to-county and county-to-city commuting."
Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority, said that because of the strong economy, the agency was accelerating its capital spending to nearly $1 billion in the region's airports, river crossings, rail systems and shipping channels.
While the agency's study did not examine how wages rose or fell in 1999, Mr. Spruck speculated that an overall increase was likely because the region's service sector jobs were "high-value jobs."
There probably were pay increases in low-wage jobs as well, he said, because low unemployment has forced employers to pay more than the minimum wage.

HEADLINE: WEST'S GOVERNORS BACK CLINTON PLAN FOR FIGHTING FIRES

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Governors from Western states that have been devastated by wildfires this summer strongly endorsed a Clinton administration firefighting plan today that would place a new emphasis on prevention and local decision-making.
After a meeting here with Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, the governors said the proposal would be the first step in helping vast natural forests and grasslands, much of them in the West, avoid the same fate as 6.7 million acres that have been scorched by fires this year, one of the worst years on record. 
 The governors also praised President Clinton for asking Congress in his final budget to support the plan with $2.8 billion, more than double the $1.2 billion that is now allocated for wildland fire programs, even if it took a disastrous fire season to prompt the administration to act.
"We've reached a meeting of the minds, which is remarkable," said Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming, referring to a proposal that Mr. Babbitt and Mr. Glickman presented to the president just 10 days ago. "I certainly endorse it."
But even the amount Mr. Clinton is seeking will only go so far. More than half of the additional $1.6 billion requested is needed to repay emergency funds that were tapped for fire-fighting efforts this year.
That would still leave more than $700 million for the states as they develop their individual plans, assuming Congressional approval. Aides to the governors were expected to begin working out details with administration officials this week.
Today's meeting, coming just seven weeks before the November elections, was notable as much for its style as its substance. Five of the six governors who met with the cabinet secretaries are Republicans, including several, like Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana, who have been highly critical of the administration's firefighting policies.
Yet by standing together at the Governor's Mansion here, administration officials supporting Vice President Al Gore and governors with loyalty to the Republican nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, provided a rare picture of bipartisan achievement and civility.
The Republican governors -- Mr. Geringer, Mr. Racicot, Gov. Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho, Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota and Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah -- and the lone Democrat, Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon, were unanimous in backing a proposal that would shift many of the decisions regarding the health of forests to locally based state and federal officials, something the Republican governors said they had been insisting upon for years.
"History may show this to be one of the more significant meetings to occur, relating to fire management in the West," Mr. Leavitt said. "These changes will have lots of implications down the line."
The meeting was also significant for what the secretaries and the governors did not talk about. As a ground rule for their talks and impetus for getting the proposal before Congress, they agreed to set aside several issues that divide them, including what role, if any, timber harvesting should play in efforts to maintain the health of a forest.
The group also agreed not to discuss the administration's proposal to set aside an additional 43 million acres of roadless areas, which would effectively mean the land could not be mined or logged.
However, the report to Mr. Clinton explicitly states, "The administration's wildland fire policy does not rely on commercial logging or new road building to reduce fire risks."
Republicans have favored a greater role for logging than have Democrats and many forestry experts, who argue that removing large trees does more to fuel fires than suppress them. Many Republicans also object to setting aside more roadless areas because of the impact it has on resource industries, recreational opportunities and state economies.
But in the context of the administration's proposal, Mr. Racicot said asking how much to log was "the wrong question."
"We have got to get away from tree harvesting and focus on forest health as the issue," Mr. Racicot said.
Mr. Babbitt agreed. "We have to sidestep the temptation to turn this into a political debate about logging and roadless areas," he said. "They are not central to the issue of forest restoration."
The proposal was developed as a blueprint for how to prevent the kinds of wildfires that have burned so much of the West this summer. As Mr. Glickman told the governors, the administration is seeking to make firefighting programs more preventive, like national defense, than reactive, like the work of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Past policies have focused on fighting fires long after they have broken out. In recent years, the administration has shifted the emphasis to include controlled fires and preventive clearing. The new plan expands on controlled burns and the thinning of underbrush and shrubs.
But the proposal seemed to be written broadly enough to have a little something for everyone, which could be helpful in an election year. Besides the administration's new strategies, the proposal also underscores the need for coordination among all levels of government. That is an element that the governors especially favor, in that it allows for local officials to make decisions about such things as how to use controlled burns, how much thinning to do and how to protect native wildlife. These have become particularly important decisions in the growing areas throughout the West where people live close to fire-prone forests.
As the proposal says, "Each team will work closely with local communities to identify the best fit for each community."
Environmental groups say they generally favor Mr. Clinton's proposal but only if it holds the line against logging as a tool for fire prevention. Most environmental groups oppose any incursions -- even increased recreational activities that many Americans favor -- that alter the pristine nature of forests.
"This is, in part, the way to go," said Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club. "It's not the whole picture. They still have to add money for controlled burning and for educating people of the role fire plays in controlling the health of a forest."
Both Mr. Babbitt and Mr. Glickman said they believed that the scope of damage caused by fires this year -- 77,893 fires affecting 6.7 million acres so far -- had created enough urgency that Congress would act before the elections.
"This shifts the model of the management of public lands," said Mr. Racicot, who is viewed by many Republicans as a possible successor to Mr. Babbitt in a Bush administration. "We have committed ourselves to actions in the short-term and a long-term study of restoration. This is a moment of opportunity to move the agenda forward."

HEADLINE: United Way Faces Crisis As President Plans to Leave

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Betty S. Beene resigned last night as president of the United Way of America as it grappled with its worst crisis since 1992, when a former president was found to be stealing charitable funds.
Mrs. Beene announced her resignation to the United Way of America's executive board as it met behind closed doors in Alexandria, Va., to deal with a power struggle with a number of large United Ways, including those in San Francisco, Chicago, Boston and Washington. 
 The large local United Ways operate regional centers that process pledges made by workers at major corporations. Processing these payroll gifts, and doling out money to small United Ways as well as individual social service charities, enhanced their power.
Mrs. Beene had championed a national pledge-processing center, which would have undercut regional operations. But the national processing center, built by Cap Gemini Group, Europe's largest information technology consulting firm, failed in its first test last November.
Partly as a result, Mrs. Beene said in June that she would leave her post in December 2001, a move she said was designed to ease friction and encourage support for higher standards among the local United Ways.
In March, leaders of the large local United Ways had sought Mrs. Beene's ouster. But United Way of America directors, meeting in Chicago, unanimously supported her.
Mrs. Beene will now leave on Jan. 31, 11 months early.
"I urge each of us to affirm that the United Way system is more than the sum of its parts," Mrs. Beene wrote in an e-mail letter sent last night to local United Way leaders that was intended to heal the breach. "Our United Way system is a national treasure that can continually renew itself to build a stronger, healthier, more compassionate America, community by community."
Mrs. Beene, 53, had sought to impose national standards on the 1,300 local United Ways that included requiring a rigorous and public self-examination of their effectiveness every few years. The move drew intense opposition from some local United Way organizations. Several of the big United Ways have been holding back part of their dues to the national organization. The United Way in Rochester, the nation's most prosperous, even obtained the legal right to alternative names, like the organization's former brand, the Community Chest, in the event the United Way broke up.
Since 1987, the United Way movement has been losing market share as the number of its donors shrank by more than 20 percent. But since Mrs. Beene was appointed in January 1997, donations had begun to rise faster than the rate of inflation.
For two decades, charity watchers have been raising questions about whether there is a future for the United Way.
Under Mrs. Beene, the United Way had slowly been gaining ground following the 1992 scandal in which one of her predecessors, William V. Aramony, had stolen charitable funds.

HEADLINE: U.S. Asks Putin Not to Sell Iran A Laser System

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The United States has been pressing Russia not to proceed with plans to sell Iran laser technology that Washington says can be used to make fuel for nuclear weapons, according to Administration officials.
Officials said that since July President Clinton has raised the prospective sale of laser technology at least two times in meetings with President Vladimir V. Putin. The most recent occurred this month at the United Nations summit meeting. 
 Mr. Putin assured Mr. Clinton then that Russia would work with Washington to resolve the dispute, officials with knowledge of the discussions said. American officials said they were encouraged by that pledge.
But they also called the response ambiguous, because Russian and American technical advisers disagreed with each other over whether the equipment could help Iran in what Washington contends is a secret program to acquire nuclear bombs.
The administration officials said that Russian sales of nuclear technology to Iran had been a longstanding concern, but that the administration grew particularly worried about the laser equipment after an American private fuel provider abandoned the product, deciding that it was not economically competitive in a civilian nuclear program. And given America's own troubles in trying to develop a cost-efficient laser technology, the United States is said to believe that Iran was more likely to want to make weapons than to develop commercial plants. The United States apparently believes that the technology is too expensive for refining nuclear fuel for commercial uses and is mostly suited to producing fissionable material for bombs. As a result, the United States has been working for three months to dissuade Russia from letting a center associated with the D. V. Efremov Institute of St. Petersburg, part of the Atomic Energy Ministry, from proceeding with a contract to sell the technology to Iran.
Mr. Clinton raised the prospective deal with Mr. Putin in July in private talks at a Group of 8 meeting in Japan. The contract has also been raised by Vice President Al Gore and Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, with their counterparts.
Officials said the issue was also scheduled to be discussed over the weekend by Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, who met on Sunday with the Russian atomic energy minister, Yevgeny O. Adamov, at a meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency. That organization helps states that rule out nuclear weapons and monitors their civilian nuclear centers to ensure that they are not being used for military purposes.
American allegations that Russia provides critical technology to Iran has roiled their relations for years. American intelligence agencies have long believed that Iran has a secret program to develop nuclear weapons, as well as biological and chemical weapons, dating from the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, which ended with the 1979 revolution. Given its ample oil and gas resources, Iran's desire to generate electricity with nuclear power, the analysts argued, was automatically seen as suspicious.
Russian nuclear contacts with Tehran have expanded since 1995, when cash-strapped Moscow signed a contract with Iran to complete the Bushehr nuclear power station, which its German builders abandoned in 1979, at the onset of the revolution. Despite pressure by the Clinton administration and sanctions by Congress, which halved foreign aid to Russia's central government in the last two years, Russia has refused to abandon the project.
American officials reportedly do not regard Bushehr as a source of nuclear material that could be diverted to a bomb-making program. But the administration apparently fears that the project will train an entire generation of Iranian physicists and engineers in nuclear technologies, thus enhancing the nuclear scientific base, including any program to develop nuclear weapons.
Russian and Iranian officials argue that Iran has ruled out nuclear weapons and has put the Bushehr plant under the international agency's rules and safeguards.
Russia has refused to forgo revenue from Bushehr and future reactor sales, each of which could run up to $1 billion. But former President Boris N. Yeltsin pledged not to expand nuclear cooperation with Iran beyond Bushehr, which plans up to four reactor and turbine units.
Last spring, however, the United States learned that the Science and Technology Center of Microtechnology, a unit of the Efremov Institute, had signed a contract to provide the laser equipment to Iran. Separating isotopes is costly, intensive in time and energy and essential to making nuclear bombs or fuel for light water civilian reactors to generate electrical power.
To make a nuclear bomb or reactor fuel, uranium 235, whose atoms are used in chain reactions, has to be separated from the dominant uranium 238 isotope. The United States uses gaseous diffusion. Some Europeans and Russia use centrifuge technology to separate the U-235 from U-238, which is not good for making weapons.
The United States has developed at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory a third method, laser isotope separation, that can be used to separate fissile isotopes from both uranium and plutonium, both of which can be used in nuclear bombs.
The United States also had an extensive program to develop the laser isotope separation technology, known as Atomic Vapor Laser Isotope Separation, or Avlis, for commercial purposes. It hoped that Avlis reactor fuel could be enriched with one-tenth as much electricity, a boon to the nuclear power industry.
But after having invested almost $2 billion in the technology, the United States Enrichment Corporation, America's privatized nuclear fuel provider, abandoned the technology last year, saying the method was too expensive to commercialize and would probably always be so.
With that experience, Washington reacted with alarm to intelligence reports from multiple sources indicating that Iran was trying to buy such technology from Russia.
That is only the latest point of tension between Russia and the United States in terms of Iran.
In February, Russia promised to stop making plutonium out of fuel from its civilian power reactors as part of a $100 million joint research and aid package from Washington. The administration put a condition on the part of the package most attractive to Moscow, namely the $25 million for joint research into new reactors. Washington insisted that Russia had to stop all new sales and transfers of nuclear technology to Iran that could be used in a nuclear weapons program.
But Mr. Adamov, the atomic energy minister, has said since then that Russia would not stop competing to sell light water power reactors to Iran.
The Russian Foreign Ministry declined to comment today on the dispute. A spokesman for Mr. Adamov said he was traveling and could not answer questions.
A spokesman for the Iranian mission to the United Nations said Iran's cooperation with Russia posed "no threat of proliferation." Iran "does not seek a nuclear weapon and has exercised utmost transparency with regard to its program," he said.
But the spokesman added, "We do not accept any country's deciding in an arbitrary manner what type of peaceful technology we can or cannot have."
As a member of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Iran was "entitled" to technology "for peaceful purposes," the spokesman said.
"If the U.S. has any complaints," he added, "the proper forum is the I.A.E.A."
Administration officials said Washington and Moscow would continue talks. Otherwise Washington could decide to reduce the more than $250 million a year that the Energy Department gives Russia to support its hard-pressed nuclear sector and secure its arsenal from theft and accident.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Bush Says Plan on Taxes Would Aid 2-Job Parents

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush began his bid today to gain the allegiance of the middle class, arguing that his tax-cut plan would relieve the pressure on parents who were forced to hold more than one job to make ends meet.
Mr. Bush used the issue of tax cuts to open a six-day, nine-state drive to showcase proposals that his campaign said would help middle-income Americans from "cradle to grave." His first stop was in President Clinton's home state of Arkansas, which polls show to be a tossup. 
 In a line he repeated throughout the day, Mr. Bush said his plan for a $1.3 trillion tax cut over the next decade would give tax relief to all Americans while Vice President Al Gore's proposal for $500 billion in "targeted" tax cuts would leave out millions of taxpayers.
"My plan gives people options, not orders," Mr. Bush said, adding that "there's a lot of fine print" in Mr. Gore's plan.
"It's so targeted that it misses the target," Mr. Bush said. His drive to court the middle class came as opinion polls showed Mr. Gore edging ahead in the presidential race, making inroads with voters in households earning $50,000 to $75,000 a year and also making gains with women.
Hoping to stem Mr. Gore's advance, Mr. Bush has put a new focus on fighting Mr. Gore head to head on the issues. At a Catholic hospital in Little Rock, Ark., Mr. Bush said it was an "important week in this campaign, a week that speaks to the aspirations and hopes of middle-class families all across the country."
His running mate, Dick Cheney, and his aides continued efforts today to hammer away at Mr. Gore's credibility. Karen P. Hughes, Mr. Bush's communications director, distributed an article from The Boston Globe that challenged Mr. Gore's assertions that his mother-in-law paid nearly three times as much for the same arthritis medicine that was used by his ailing dog Shiloh.
The article said that the figures Mr. Gore used came from a House Democratic study and that Mr. Gore's aides could not say for sure whether his mother-in-law and dog actually took the drug, Lodine.
Ms. Hughes noted that reporters had focused on how Mr. Bush sometimes mangles words, and said, "This is not a case of mispronunciation. This is a case of direct misstatement of facts."
Kym Spell, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gore, called the Bush campaign's focus on the article, "the latest sign the Bush-Cheney ticket is very, very desperate." And she said the campaign had verified that both Mr. Gore's mother-in-law and dog had used the same drug.
Despite Mr. Bush's desire to focus on issues, he also made it clear that he would continue to raise questions about the vice president's character and credibility.
"I would rather fight the fight on issues and on philosophy," Mr. Bush said in an interview with Fox News, "but I'm not going to squander the opportunity. I will not let this man distance himself from the previous administration."
His aides said that in large measure, his drive this week was focused on women. While Democrats in recent campaigns have done better among women than Republicans, Mr. Bush had made headway earlier this year by stressing education.
But the traditional "gender gap" has reopened. Ms. Hughes said the gap had occurred because Mr. Gore had "misrepresented" the governor's record and "that also he's managed to unfortunately muddy the waters on the issue of education."
Mr. Bush toured the maternity ward at St. Vincent Doctors Hospital in Little Rock at his first stop today and delivered his speech standing next to two families with babies. Later this week Mr. Bush will appear on Oprah Winfrey's syndicated television program in Chicago and on the Regis Philbin show, both programs that appeal to women.
The governor's wife, Laura, was campaigning with him today. Asked about her husband by an audience member in Little Rock, Ark., she said, "his best character quality is his good heart." "I see that every day in the way he relates to our children, to our pets even," Mrs. Bush said.
Mr. Gore also kept up his courtship of women today, talking about health care in Las Vegas.
In a speech at the University of Nevada, Mr. Gore said: "The issue today is whether or not we will have a president who stands up and fights for families who need health care, for the women who need health care, for the children, all of whom should have health care, and against the H.M.O.'s and insurance companies that are always standing in the way!"
He also spoke to health care workers at the university and was joined by the tennis star Andre Agassi, whose mother and sister have been diagnosed with breast cancer.
Mr. Bush's emphasis on the financial problems of the middle class seems to draw inspiration from the success of Mr. Gore's recent appeals.
Nearly two weeks ago, Mr. Gore released an economic blueprint with broad social goals including eliminating the national debt, increasing personal savings and homeownership and reducing poverty.
The Bush campaign countered with a 16-page booklet, "Blueprint for the Middle Class," which summarizes Mr. Bush's domestic agenda. Mr. Bush held the pamphlet aloft. "This pamphlet here outlines exactly what I'm talking about," he said.
Later in in Kansas City, Mo.,, he credited Ronald Reagan for the current economic expansion saying the "growth of today is occurring because of the tax cuts of the 1980's."
Mr. Bush told Fox News in the interview that he would speed up tax cuts in a recession.
"I'm from the school of thought that it's important during a recession to give people their money back faster," he said. "That may cause us to run a short-term deficit but the fundamental question is how to cause the economy to grow."
He said that middle-class families were suffering from a time crunch. "The issue facing America today is that many of our middle-class families work three jobs: his, hers and the joint responsibility of raising children," he said.
"I strongly believe that the tax burden on American families makes it harder for families to realize their responsibilities, to do their duties," he said.
Tonight, Mr. Bush flew here and was honored by the local Fraternal Order of Police. In the group's union hall, Mr. Bush kneeled and held a microphone for Jim Mullen, a former police officer who was shot and paralyzed from the neck down in 1996 and is now in a wheelchair.
Mr. Mullen had trouble speaking, but he gasped out praise for the governor. When he finished, Mr. Bush leaned over and kissed him on the forehead.
