HEADLINE: Day 3 of Los Angeles Transit Strike Is a Work-Day Headache for Poorest Angelenos

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Compton Chester stood on Wilshire Boulevard, squinting in the morning sun, craning his neck for the bus that never came.
"I don't have a clue what I'm going to do," said Mr. Chester, a 29-year-old office assistant for an entertainment company who has no car and depends on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus for his 45-minute commute from Koreatown to West Los Angeles. "I feel foolish standing here. It's like waiting for Godot." 
 Mr. Chester was hardly alone this morning as the third day and the first work day of a countywide public transportation strike left half a million commuters in the nation's second-largest city stranded without regular bus and subway service and dependent on a catch-as-catch-can network of smaller regional bus lines, car pools, taxis and their own tired feet. Transportation officials reported a 5 percent increase in morning rush hour freeway traffic, taxi drivers said business had doubled and streets were clogged.
But unlike New York, for example, where commuters of all socioeconomic groups depend on public transportation and are affected in a strike, Los Angeles has a transit system used primarily by the poorest residents, including the legions of maids, janitors, nannies and service workers who commute from East Los Angeles to the gated enclaves of the Westside. Nearly 70 percent of the system's riders here have household incomes under $15,000 a year, nearly three-quarters of bus riders are black or Hispanic, and half do not have a car, truck or motorcycle in their household.
"It's sad," said Kelly Taylor, 23, a security guard trying to get from midtown to Universal City in the San Fernando Valley to pick up his paycheck at his company's headquarters. He said he might give up and go home, but was worried about how he will get to his job at a Jewish school near Beverly Hills on Tuesday. "I'd have to call my sister and get a ride," he said. "I can't really miss work."
Some 4,300 bus drivers and subway and light rail operators walked off the job Friday night in a strike against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the regional agency that administers a public transit system covering 1,400 square miles with 2,000 buses, the nation's second-largest fleet after New York's, plus 59 miles of subway and light rail track. About 1,800 mechanics and 650 clerks honored the picket lines. Among the major sticking points was a plan to cut overtime pay for senior drivers and to require some 400 drivers to work four 10-hour days without overtime in an effort to help close a projected operating shortfall of $430 million over the next decade.
"Our members deal with the riders every day and they care about them," said Goldy Norton, a spokesman for the United Transportation Union, which represents the drivers. "But you can't expect that in the greatest boom we've had in years our members should take what amounts to an average 15 percent pay cut."
The average driver earns about $50,000 a year, but $7,000 of that typically comes from overtime and working holidays and weekends, and union officials say the agency's proposed wage increases of 8.1 percent over three years would not make up the difference in lost overtime. The unions have sought 4 percent increases for each of three years.
But Marc Littman, a spokesman for the Transportation Authority, said the agency was willing to drop the overtime proposal if the union came up with other ways for saving an estimated $2 million a year in overtime payments out of the agency's $2.5 billion annual budget. Labor accounts for 70 percent of the agency's costs. The authority also is seeking the right to hire more part-time workers and newer drivers at lower wages, which the union also resists.
"If they don't like our ideas, then come up with some of their own," Mr. Littman said. "They've got to give us something."
Union officials said this morning that they were waiting for a formal invitation from state mediators before resuming talks at a Pasadena hotel. But late today, the transit authority said the union had agreed to return to the bargaining table on Tuesday morning.
The bus and subway system here has about 1.5 million boardings a day, compared with about 6 million a day in the New York City system, and virtually none of it was operating today. The agency had hoped to operate five "lifeline" routes along major arteries using private contractors, but those drivers honored the union picket lines, and the plan fell through. The separate Metro Link regional commuter rail system and bus lines in surrounding cities like Santa Monica were unaffected, and some were providing extra service to help take up the slack.
But most regular riders were out of luck, and Mayor Richard J. Riordan last week implored residents to "open up their hearts" and pick up people stranded on street corners. Caltrans, the state transportation agency, announced that it would suspend highway repair work during peak travel periods for the duration of the strike.
The transit strike is the seventh in Los Angeles in the last 28 years, what is believed to the be the highest number among big city transportation systems. The last was in 1994 and lasted nine days.
Brian Taylor, an associate professor of urban planning and associate director of the Institute of Transportation Studies at the University of California at Los Angeles noted that transit ridership in Los Angeles was much higher than public perception would have it.
"It can be almost callous to say, how does a strike affect the regional economy," Professor Taylor said. "The significant effect is obviously on the people who are living at the margin. They're mostly going to make do. In poorer neighborhoods, there are extensive systems of car-sharing and informal taxi service." But, he added, "Unlike auto workers and car owners, here you have an unusual situation where the consumer of the product is on average much poorer than the operator, and there really is a cost to the population served by this system."
Mr. Chester, the commuter, who cannot come close to affording a daily cab ride of $20 each way, said he sympathized with the drivers' concerns to a point.
"It's really put me in a bad situation," he said. "I understand that they have to maintain their standards of living and keep their heads above and whatever. But when something like this happens, it also really shows how close people like me are to the edge."

HEADLINE: Remedial Program Refuses to Die;
Revamped SEEK Remains Path for Poor Into CUNY

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Martha Bell remembers bursting into tears when the Board of Regents voted to allow the City University of New York to end remedial instruction for bachelor's degree students.
Such instruction was at the heart of the program for poor students known as SEEK that CUNY started two generations ago to give black and Hispanic students a chance at a college education they could not get under the admission criteria, at a time CUNY was almost entirely white. 
 "That's the end of SEEK," Dr. Bell, who runs Brooklyn College's branch of the program, remembers thinking. "I went round and round on how could we provide the experiences our students desperately need. I thought about retiring. My gut reaction that day was to close up."
She did not resign, nor did her program close up. Instead, after battles on campus and appeals to state legislators and an overhaul of the curriculum, the program has emerged with a new and tougher look. Rather than effectively ending SEEK (which stands for Search for Elevation, Education and Knowledge), the ban on remedial instruction has given the program a new life, when its very reason for being seemed unclear in a university at which more than half of CUNY's students are black or Hispanic, and many are poor and academically unprepared.
As CUNY again tightens admissions to its senior colleges, the program has once again become a way onto campus for poor students who cannot demonstrate their readiness for college-level work.
"We have become the only opportunity in town," Dr. Bell said. "It brings us closer to our original mission of providing access where there wouldn't be any."
What she has done to get around CUNY's ban on remedial instruction is to provide students at Brooklyn, one of the 11 senior college campuses where the program for poor students is offered, with a longer and more intense summer session and more challenging courses for the fall.
In one reading class in August, Nancy Vighetti introduced students to Sophocles' "Antigone." For many, it was strange territory. They stumbled over unfamiliar names (like Eteocles and Polynices, Antigone's brothers), unfamiliar words (like carrion birds that eat dead flesh) and unfamiliar concepts (like stoning someone to death). "They still stone people to death in parts of the world today," Ms. Vighetti said.
The summer session was an academic boot camp that covered many skills the students never picked up in high school. Ms. Vighetti lectured to the students just so they would learn to take notes. She made them keep journals so they would get used to writing.
"In high school, I never read a book, but I had good grades," said Gisele Melendez, an 18-year-old with long pink fingernails from Sheepshead Bay. Referring to Sheepshead Bay High School, she said: "They asked you questions, but questions they answered in class. Here, I have to read the book to have my own ideas."
Many professors prefer to deal with the academically elite, but Ms. Vighetti is one of the corps within CUNY that finds rewards in working with the poorly prepared.
"At a certain point, you can see the light bulbs go on," she said.
Historically, SEEK students were unable to meet the university's standards for entering freshmen when they were admitted, and many were still unable to meet those requirements after a summer of intensive remedial instruction. In previous years, they would simply have taken some additional remedial work without credit in fall and spring semesters.
But the university's new policy said the senior colleges could offer no remedial courses during the regular school year, only tutoring or workshops. To meet the new policy, Dr. Bell shifted more math into the summer because, she said, "There was no way to say that arithmetic and algebra were college-level math."
For university students still weak in reading or writing, the main solution was to put them into compensatory courses that covered college-level texts but more slowly, with more hours of class per week, than regular classes, for the same number of credits.
Learning to read analytically and develop ideas are central themes in Brooklyn College's program. Dr. Bell has developed a remedial program at Brooklyn that has drawn more than $1 million in federal grants and is a model for about a dozen other public and private university campuses.
More than 360 new freshmen entered Brooklyn this fall through the program, roughly double the number last year and more than a quarter of the college's freshman class. (Across CUNY, the number of freshmen in the program rose 1.5 percent, to 2,368, or 17 percent of the freshmen entering the 11 senior colleges.)
To qualify, students must meet criteria for being both economically and educationally disadvantaged. At Brooklyn this year, the average total SAT score for such students was 790, well below the 1,060 average for the freshman class. More than 90 percent of the students came from families with annual incomes below $20,000.
Last year, about 44 percent of the university's SEEK students were Hispanic, 30 percent black, 15 percent Asian and 12 percent white.
Besides free tutoring and counseling throughout college, these students receive $250 a semester to help pay for their books, and their fees are waived. The students are also allowed 10 semesters of financial aid, compared with 8 for other students.
Herman Badillo, the university's chairman, said he had supported the program when it was created in the mid-1960's under an act of the Legislature, several years before open admissions began. But, he added, "I have a sense that it has been a big problem and that it has not been implemented as I intended." Still, he said, he did not intend to shut it down.
One criticism is that students in the program have always graduated at lower rates than other students. According to the most recent data available, 26 percent of students who entered it in 1991 earned a CUNY bachelor's degree within eight years, compared with 44 percent for non-SEEK students. Supporters assert that is because students in the program have started farther behind educationally.
At the Brooklyn program, the students' academic success rates have risen since 1995, when Dr. Bell began to overhaul her program. In 1998, 99 percent of Brooklyn's SEEK students passed the university's proficiency tests in reading and mathematics within a year, up from 84 percent four years earlier. Similarly, 93 percent of these students passed the core curriculum courses they took as freshmen in 1998, up from 72 percent four years earlier.
Although the CUNY colleges have begun to receive stronger students since 1995, as they raise their entrance requirements, Dr. Bell said the educational preparation of the SEEK students had not changed significantly in that period.
Still, the program's reputation as a haven for less prepared students has frightened some families away.
"Some parents call and say they don't want their children in the program because they will be stigmatized," said Nancy Jean-Baptiste, a Brooklyn graduate who was a counselor in the program this summer.
Margarita Eguizabal, a 28-year-old graduate from El Salvador, said many students thought that students in the program were allowed to take easier courses. "They think that SEEK students are getting a free ride, but that's not true," she said.
For most of the students, the starting point is the upgraded summer immersion program. Since 1995, the university has required all SEEK students to attend summer classes. But Dr. Bell now offers them three summer sessions totaling 11 weeks, and many of them attend at least two.
Christine Kessler, who taught Extreme Writing this summer, hoped to demystify essay writing so her 22 students could pass CUNY's essay exam. On the first day of class, she gave them a quick diagnostic spelling test of 50 words followed by tips for improving their spelling.
She was not surprised that many did poorly. The class was like a mini-United Nations. The 22 students came from 15 countries, including Russia, China, the Dominican Republic, Turkey, Nigeria and Haiti.
Ms. Kessler introduced them to mnemonics -- memory aids -- and urged them to look for rhymes, acronyms, pictures and songs to help them remember. Acknowledge, she showed them, was easy if they remembered "the A.C. (air-conditioner) you KNOW goes on the LEDGE." Believe is simple, too, she said, if they remembered "never beLIEve a LIE."
"This is the way students in schools across the United States learn to remember information," she assured them. "The next time you go to your doctors, ask them how they remember the bones in the arm."
In another class, Margaret M. Waters was also starting with basics, even though her students had already passed all of the university's entrance exams. While the students did not need remedial work, she wanted to introduce them to the kind of analytical thinking they would be required to do in September.
The starting text was "Jack and the Beanstalk." Unlike "Antigone" (which they would get to later), there was nothing unfamiliar about the story. But, as Professor Waters showed them, it was a parable with layers of meaning, and she hoped to give them tools they could use to tackle more complex material later.
"Does Jack plan to steal?" she asked. "Is Jack a thief? Or an opportunist?"
One student jumped in with a theory: "All he wanted to do was to make his mother happy. He feels he let her down."
Professor Waters pressed him, "I think you're nicer than I would be."
She read from the text about how Jack was sitting in the attic and suffering. "He was thinking of himself," she said.
"Yeah," the student acknowledged. "He was thinking of himself."
A student near the door embroidered the thought. "He just got plain greedy."
Soon, they were deep into deconstructing text.
By the end of the summer, 150 of the students had still not passed all of the university's entrance requirements, and will receive extra support through workshops and tutoring.
But even the 215 who were ready to plunge into regular freshmen courses, including freshman English and mathematics, will continue to be watched over closely. They will take two of their freshman courses and a counseling seminar together, and Dr. Bell and her colleagues will provide extra support.
"I don't have a magic pill," Dr. Bell said. "If students come in needing reading and writing and maybe math, they can't learn it all overnight."

HEADLINE: THE CROWDED CITY;
OFFICE SHORTAGE IMPERILS GROWTH IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Lost in the noisy ebullience over New York City's thriving economy is a problem that some economists and elected leaders say could undermine the city's prosperity and cost thousands of jobs at everything from Internet companies to garment manufacturers.
The problem is a severe lack of office space in Manhattan and the surrounding boroughs. According to a growing number of urban planners, corporate executives, developers and political officials, it is already posing a serious challenge to the city's ability to attract new business and to stop more companies from following the lead of Chase Manhattan Bank, U.S. Trust and more than 20 other companies that have agreed to move across the Hudson. 
 In contrast to the New York of the early 1990's, when companies fled Manhattan amid a gloomy recession and doubts about the city's primacy as a corporate and financial center, New York today suffers from the perils of its success, the experts say. Wall Street is booming. Companies want a New York address once again, and job growth last year edged ahead of the national average for the first time in at least a decade. Page B1.
Yet there is little vacant space available and, despite the demand, little new construction.
As a result, landlords in Manhattan have been able to raise rents to record levels; rents in Midtown rose nearly 30 percent on average over the last year alone.
"We should be growing at a faster rate with a more diverse group of industries that make this their world capital," said Senator Charles E. Schumer. "New York is in great demand by many types of businesses. Unfortunately, with real estate prices so high, we're at risk of losing some of those businesses. And the No. 1 reason is a lack of space."
At the same time, the fabric of the city is being rewoven. Once-dowdy but vibrant industrial areas are being transformed, as advertising agencies and Internet and telecommunications companies plunge into the garment district south of Times Square, the printing district north of TriBeCa and even Long Island City in Queens and southern Brooklyn, pushing rents well beyond what many manufacturers in those areas can afford.
And the psychological chasm that once separated Manhattan from what many considered the backwater New Jersey waterfront has closed. Companies as diverse as John Wiley & Sons, which has been publishing books in Manhattan since Thomas Jefferson was president, and Chase Manhattan Bank, one of the city's financial pillars, decided to move all or part of their operations to New Jersey, where there is room to grow and costs are lower. Each new defection makes the western bank of the Hudson River that much more viable as a corporate haven.
"In the long run, the present market is bad for New York City," said Douglas Durst, who heads one of New York's prominent real estate families. "It's pushing companies outside the city and showing them they don't have to be here."
No economist would dispute the fact that losing companies to New Jersey has quantifiable effects on New York, including a loss of jobs and tax revenues. But some say that taking a wider view of the regional economy, there is little difference if a company is in Lower Manhattan or a mile away in Jersey City, where land and construction costs and taxes are lower. New York, after all, has always functioned as an incubator for new businesses that move to new locations as they grow.
In January, Mr. Schumer formed a panel of corporate executives, state and city officials and urban planners to make recommendations to try to solve the problem. That a senator would seize on a mundane local issue like land use was seen by many urban planners and developers as a rebuke of city and state officials for having failed to do so.
Robert M. Harding, the deputy mayor for economic development, said the Giuliani administration was well aware of the problem. The mayor and City Council recently increased the level of tax breaks and other incentives for companies that leave Manhattan for the other boroughs, a measure that they say makes Queens and Brooklyn more competitive with New Jersey. Joseph B. Rose, director of city planning, is leading an effort to rezone Long Island City and the far West Side of Manhattan to encourage new offices.
"When you outpace the nation in job growth, you're doing something right," Mr. Harding said. "We're exploding at such a record clip that we have to identify areas for development outside of Manhattan."
But until recently, the Giuliani administration relied primarily on offering tax breaks to major corporations -- like Credit Suisse First Boston, Merrill Lynch and Time Warner -- that threaten to move outside Manhattan. Not enough has been done, critics say, to promote areas that have some land available for less expensive back-office development, like the Metrotech Center in downtown Brooklyn or near the Citicorp tower in Long Island City, or to build a transportation network that would make those areas competitive with the New Jersey waterfront. The Queens West complex on the East River, for instance, lacks convenient public transportation to Manhattan.
Although Mayor Giuliani addressed the issue in a speech last January, some corporate executives and relocation advisers say that he has not focused on the problem.
"We haven't had a physical development policy for the city since the Koch administration," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "Instead, we're building minor league stadiums on Coney Island and Staten Island and failing to encourage the development of major league office buildings."

A Quick Recovery
From a Glut To a Shortage
The dearth of office space is a relatively new phenomenon for New York. For much of the last decade, the city suffered from a severe hangover from the last real estate boom. The city lost 300,000 jobs during the recession in the early 1990's, leaving many new skyscrapers empty and bankrupt. The average vacancy rate rose to 18 percent in Midtown office buildings, while one out of every four floors sat empty downtown.
In 1995, in response to an outcry from the real estate industry, the Giuliani administration instituted a series of zoning changes and tax incentives in Lower Manhattan that were intended to spur the renovation of old office towers and the conversion of outmoded commercial buildings into apartment houses. The program took hold, and as the economy improved, office space filled up and rents began inching upward.
Wall Street also expanded and tenants once again began looking for space downtown, where rents by comparison were cheaper and space more plentiful. The real estate market there improved so quickly that in 1997, carpenters were putting up walls for apartments at 10 Hanover Square in Lower Manhattan when Goldman, Sachs & Company suddenly leased the entire 22-story building for office space.
But there has been little new construction to ease the pressure, in part because of the memory of the 1980's, when so many speculative buildings, erected without a commitment from tenants, failed. Today, only a handful of lenders are willing to provide construction loans, and they demand that the developer have a major tenant lined up and provide cash up front, say $150 million for a $400 million skyscraper.
The problem is made worse by the scarcity of development sites left in densely packed Manhattan. As a result, only a single major office tower has been completed in the last eight years, the Conde Nast building in Times Square.
As any pedestrian can attest, there are skyscrapers under construction in Midtown for Reuters, Ernst & Young, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Bear Stearns, Random House and Time Warner. Two others are in the planning stages for The New York Times and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. In each case, the towers would primarily be for single tenants and would be built on sites whose development in the 1980's was delayed by the recession.
Most corporate tenants, however, are not big enough to justify a million-square-foot tower. New York developers and executives said that they would have little trouble filling speculative buildings with smaller tenants if only they could find the financing and development sites.
"The memory of unfinished projects and bad loans lingers on," said David Tobin, a director of the Carlton Group, a commercial mortgage banker. "Given what lenders are demanding today, developers are less inclined to build."
Last month, the vacancy rate downtown stood at 5 percent, while the annual asking rent hit $42.73 per square foot, up from a low of $25.57 in 1995, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial real estate broker. (When adjusted for inflation, the low point was $27.92 in 1997.) In Midtown, the average rent topped $61 per square foot, nearly double the rate seven years ago, and the vacancy rate is only 3.1 percent. For a law firm or a publishing company leasing 400,000 square feet of space, that is a difference of $12 million a year from the rate in 1993.
"This market kind of snuck up on people," said Stephen B. Siegel, president of Insignia/ESG. "I don't think anyone anticipated how strong it was going to be."

A Transformation
Internet Businesses Displace Industries
In the last two years, advertising agencies and Internet and telecommunications companies hunting for cheaper space have pushed into longtime industrial neighborhoods like the garment district, Chinatown, the printing district, Long Island City and even the Brooklyn waterfront from the Brooklyn Bridge south to Sunset Park. Bates North America, an advertising agency, led the charge when it leased a former garment showroom at 498 Seventh Avenue and 37th Street. Screaming Media and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia took space in the old Starrett-Lehigh factory building on 11th Avenue and 26th Street.
The 70-year-old printing district around Varick, Hudson and Canal Streets has all but disappeared as landlords rent to higher-paying white-collar tenants. More than two dozen garment factory buildings in Chinatown were converted to office and retail space in the last two years. At 150 Lafayette Street in Chinatown, Mad Science, an Internet company, shares a floor with a garment factory. As the jostling for space continues, some Manhattan developers say that the garment and printing districts no longer belong in Manhattan.
But urban planners point out that some of the city's valuable and otherwise viable manufacturing jobs are in jeopardy throughout the city. Peter D. Colahan, president of the Colahan-Saunders Corporation, said that in the nine months since he moved his printing company from Varick Street to Long Island City, he had seen rents around him jump as Internet companies began vying for the same buildings as manufacturers.
"The city has responded to the growth of the dot-coms," said Fred Siegel, a professor of history at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in Manhattan, "but it hasn't responded to the secondary effects of the dot-coms on other districts."
Manufacturers who pay $8 a square foot in rent cannot compete with the Internet and telecommunications companies willing to pay two or three times that amount.
"Space in the area is getting more difficult to find for manufacturers," Mr. Colahan said, "and more expensive."

The Competition
Lately, New Jersey Seems a Lot Closer
After sitting fallow for much of the 1990's, the New Jersey waterfront has become a genuine alternative for New York corporations. Since July 1998, more than 20 major corporations have signed deals to move some of their operations from New York to more than 5.5 million square feet of space in Jersey City, Hoboken and Weehawken -- the equivalent in square feet of more than half the entire World Trade Center.
The tenants include U.S. Trust, the Cigna insurance company, Lord, Abbett & Company and the Insurance Services Office. Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch have bought major development sites at the former Colgate toothpaste factory in Jersey City.
William J. Pesce, the chief executive of Wiley, who signed a deal last month to move the 197-year-old publishing company and 900 employees to Hoboken, said the company was loath to cut its deep New York roots when it began looking two years ago. It was already paying top dollar to rent its building at Third Avenue and 40th Street and was facing a steep rent increase in 2003.
Wiley was prospering, Mr. Pesce said, but the company wanted to improve its profit margins and invest in people and technology.
He said he rejected a move to Baltimore, which would have cut his real estate costs by two-thirds but cost him many employees. He found a rare block of space in a factory near the Holland Tunnel, but there was little room to grow.
So after some sharp debate among the directors, Wiley decided that the company's best choice was to move to a new building in Hoboken that would allow the publisher to nearly double its space and save money. Wiley expects to move in late 2002.
Recently, Chase Manhattan made a similar decision, agreeing to move about 2,500 employees from 13 floors at 55 Water Street in Lower Manhattan to a building that the developer Samuel J. LeFrak is building at his 600-acre Newport complex in Jersey City. Unlike Wiley, Chase was looking for a quick, low-cost alternative.
According to those involved in the search, Chase considered a new tower at Queens West, a project in Long Island City sponsored by the city, the state and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. But the executives said it was unclear when commercial development would begin at that site, which they thought did not have good transportation links to Manhattan. But as with Wiley, city officials did not urge the bank to reconsider Queens West, or to expand at Metrotech in Brooklyn, where Chase has back-office operations and 4,500 employees, though they did offer a tax break if the employees remained in New York.
New Jersey officials were only too happy to give Chase an even more generous set of subsidies. More important, said executives involved in the decision, Mr. LeFrak offered to build the bank a new building within 18 months, a startlingly brief time by Manhattan standards.
"The Wiley and Chase deals are as much a product of the lack of space in New York as pure price," said Stephen Siegel of Insignia/ESG.
During the 1980's, New Jersey tried to lure New York financial companies to the waterfront in Jersey City by building PATH train and ferry links to Manhattan and offering a broad array of tax breaks. New York officials condemned the effort as poaching, and few companies took the bait. But many investment banks routinely threatened to move to New Jersey before extracting tax incentives from New York.
In the last two years, however, the New Jersey waterfront has seemed a lot closer for corporations looking for office space, especially since it is as much as 30 percent cheaper. Potential sites in Queens and Brooklyn "seemed out of the way and ill located," said one lawyer who has advised dozens of corporations on relocation issues.
"One reason we chose Jersey City over a more remote location is that it is accessible to people who live in New York City," said Tom Block, a senior vice president for government affairs at Chase Manhattan, which has kept its headquarters and thousands of employees in New York. "It would have taken six years to renovate our space at 55 Water Street versus building a state-of-the-art building in Jersey City in 18 months."
It is an open question whether New York could have held on to the Chase jobs. But corporate executives, urban planners and some city officials say that the city's fast-growing Internet ventures and other companies may stay and expand if there are alternatives in New York. Otherwise, they said, New York could become the equivalent of a one-crop economy in which the city's fortunes are tied exclusively to the wealthy international financial companies that can afford the rents in Manhattan.
"I think New York City has an opportunity to look at how it's going to sustain the current economic prosperity," said Mr. Pesce. "It would be a shame to lose the diversity of businesses in New York City as a result of our company and others leaving."

The Potential
Steering Developers To Open Territory
Senator Schumer and others have called for a public-private partnership to develop swaths of land for office development through zoning, incentives and condemnation. In addition, they say that the sites need good transportation to Manhattan and high-speed telecommunication links, amenities that would require major government investment. Analysts like Jonathan Bowles of the Center for an Urban Future say that the city also has to develop a policy to deal with manufacturing.
There is also some agreement about where the city might steer new development.
"It's crucial to the city's ongoing prosperity that we identify new growth corridors for commercial activity," said Mr. Rose, director of the city's planning department. "The most obvious locations are Long Island City, downtown Brooklyn and the West Side of Manhattan and parts of Hudson Square," which is the area between West Houston and Canal, west of Varick.
After years of preparation, Mr. Rose said that the city expected to certify a rezoning plan for Long Island City within the next month. The city and state, however, are at odds over development on the West Side of Manhattan and the expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Office development there could also conflict with preparations for the city's bid for the 2012 Olympics. Community advocates are also worried about the effects rezoning would have on existing businesses and neighborhoods.
Barry Gossin, chief executive of Newmark & Company, a real estate company, contends that the city needs to focus on a small number of areas for development rather that taking a scattershot approach. "The city should focus on an area, create a critical mass, and build the infrastructure and attract the restaurants and other amenities that go along with it," he said. "Jersey City has accomplished so much because they have finally achieved critical mass. Brooklyn never did it."
Developers contend that they also need subsidies and tax abatements in order to set rents at competitive levels and to make projects economically viable. But Stephen J. Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, acknowledged that it would be politically difficult to create a major incentive program when the economy is still generating new jobs.
Ron Shiffman, a former city planning commissioner, and Adam Friedman, executive director of the New York Industrial Retention Network, an advocacy group, warn that any effort to encourage commercial development in Long Island City or Brooklyn could also pose enormous problems for manufacturers.
"We have to be careful that in looking to retain the Wileys we don't push out manufacturers who are quite viable and provide important jobs," Mr. Shiffman said. "The real issue is how we maintain a healthy balance in the kind of jobs the city needs and ensure that physical improvements are distributed equitably throughout the city."
Despite the renewed focus on what many are calling a commercial space crisis, developers and urban planners say little will happen unless there is a concerted effort on the part of the city's political leaders.
"If they want to provide a place where people can grow in a friendly environment where rents are not as high as Manhattan," said Richard LeFrak, president of the LeFrak Organization, "they have to have the political will to identify specific sites and make them a genuine alternative."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
Killer Toys and Wonder Woman: When a Soft Sell Is a Big Deal

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER SMITH; Christopher Smith is a regional reporter for The Salt Lake Tribune in Utah.

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
HIS angular ivory face framed by the upturned collar of a black magician's cape, Gary Norcigian cut a monochromatic figure amid the technicolor of the convention floor. It was as if Grandpa from "The Munsters" somehow wandered onto the set of "The Wizard of Oz."
Mr. Norcigian attracted a small knot of conventiongoers, goatee-wearing software developers with sleepy eyes and overloaded tote bags. Ambushing a bystander, he used the man's wristwatch for an overly dramatic series of sleight-of-hand tricks. Then the crowd dispersed among the exhibits. 
 "The only thing that counts is stopping traffic next to your booth," said Mr. Norcigian, who works dozens of trade shows and conferences each year. "The best traffic-stopper you can get is a female contortionist. People find it perversely interesting and can't resist staring."
No contortionists here, but a cluster of female impersonators wandering among the 4,000 attendees of the conference sponsored by I.B.M. had the same mesmerizing effect. It was an extravaganza that seemed to cross-pollinate graduate-level computer science courses with equal parts hospitality suite and Lollapalooza rock concert.
"I'm here to create visual excitement," said John Gonzales, who was flawlessly dressed as Wonder Woman and handing out coupons for a digital music player giveaway to attendees huddled around steam trays of meatballs. "Honestly, I don't even know what an MP3 player is," he added.
Bungee jumps. Poetry slams. Radio-controlled model car races. Holographic projections of severed heads beckoning passers-by to a booth. This is trench warfare in the "attention economy," where companies vie to win fleeting consideration among software developers who will determine the architecture of electronic commerce.
"Back when the people making purchasing decisions were the chairmen of banks, Wall Street firms, insurance companies, manufacturers, you tried to look like them and be of their culture," said Bob Timpson, who started at I.B.M. more than 30 years ago, when employees were required to wear suit jackets at their desks. "We're doing the same thing now. Today, those decisions are not being made by C.E.O.'s and C.I.O.'s. They are being made down in the depths of organizations by people of this software culture. You have to talk to them where they live, on the Web, and then draw them out to places where they can mingle."
Hence, this "real world" creation of I.B.M.'s software developer Web site, a spectacle-saturated conference highlighting technology from I.B.M. and its business partners at the MGM Grand Hotel unabashedly dubbed "No Limits: Building the Open E-Business Universe." Between training sessions with arcane titles and keynote speeches from techno-dreamers and specialized "evangelists," attendees were treated to rock guitar solos, belly dancers, disco parties, salsa bands, comedians and performance artists decrying computer hardware that "has the life expectancy of wooden stirrers at Starbucks."
"These computer trade shows look nothing like they did five years ago," said Albert Segars, director of the Institute of Technology and Strategic Change at the University of North Carolina.
"They now look more like Cirque du Soleil, with trapeze artists, mimes, magic," Mr. Segars said. "It's all about who can outhype the other, who has the biggest celebrity, who has the coolest giveaways."
In the $84 billion-a-year commercial exhibition business, high technology ranks third among major industries that allocate a large part of their marketing dollars to trade shows and conferences, according to the Center for Exhibition Industry Research in Chicago. At 18 percent, high technology trails health care at 21.3 percent and manufacturing at 18.6 percent. But on the hype meter, high-technology trade shows bury the needle.
But Mr. Segars cautioned that companies hoping to solicit business through gimmicks or attractive "booth bunnies" must be able to deliver more than "vaporware," much-promoted applications that are months or years from release.
"These exhibitors have to retain an underlying theme of credibility because the kids in software development can see right through the smoke and mirrors," he said.
These days, he said, companies are staffing exhibits with people knowledgeable about the products.
"I've noticed the saleswomen now at these shows," Mr. Segars said, "seem to be more like pharmaceutical reps, with an attractiveness or appeal, but lingering behind that is real industry expertise."
As part of a campaign for "relationship acquisition" among software engineers, I.B.M. hired a cultural anthropologist to create psychological profiles of how the fiercely independent developer community thinks.
"They're primarily male, and, because they are smart, as a whole they have paranoid tendencies," said Chris Bahr, who directs I.B.M.'s Developer Works, a Web site that offers software entrepreneurs tools and techniques for creating applications. "They are very hard to fool and almost impossible to market to. If they feel they are being sold to, they are out of here."
They are also merciless in their critiques of traditional brick-and-mortar corporations, including the magnanimous host that has courted them with T-shirts, backpacks and a perpetually open bar. The longest commentary string on the conference computer network billboard is a diatribe over the slow speed and unreliability of the I.B.M. system on site. The original posting described it with an expletive, and subsequent replies went downhill from there.
"They are not restrained in showing their opinions," Mr. Timpson of I.B.M. said. "We're willing to subject our technology to flame mail, harsh and adverse criticism, so that we can create the best of the breed. There's a lot of extreme hype out there, but at the end of the day, people respect performance and results."
And honesty. When Al Zollar, president and chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation, which I.B.M. bought in 1995, opened an address by saying, "This is a developer crowd, and I know you don't like talking to people," heads in the audience nodded in agreement.
But human interaction seems to be the primary desire at these county fairs for denizens of the faceless digital economy. There is an air of high school prom expectancy about the gatherings, where gangly, awkward e-business chief executives wander around hoping to chat up a "rock star V.C.," venture-capitalist speculators who bankroll start-ups.
"What happens in a lot of these dot-com cases is the head of the company is more socially challenged and really doesn't like to be at these events, but they know if they don't learn those skills, they may ultimately fall back into the role of chief technical officer," Mr. Segars said. "When the V.C.'s get involved, if they have someone in charge of the company who doesn't have good business sense, knowing what to say when, they usually shuffle them back into the C.T.O. role and bring in a new C.E.O."
In the argot of Silicon Valley, participating in computer conferences helps stimulate "deal flow," the progression from idea to initial public offering.
"I can't tell you how many deals I've gotten from people who heard me speak at MacWorld 10 years ago," said the chief executive of Garage.com, Guy Kawasaki, a former Macintosh computer guru whose company helps dot-com enterprises find start-up capital.
Yet the booming popularity of these bacchanal computer conferences and trade shows is not solely for profit's sake. On another level, they fill a need for face-to-face contact among a notoriously isolated workforce.
"Geeks need community, too," Mr. Bahr said.
And no matter how flush with vested stock options, developers apparently still need to fill suitcases with giveaway trinkets that are the signature souvenirs of trade shows.
"Nowadays, people attending these shows expect to be entertained and go home with a ton of freebies," said Susan Ratliff, author of "How to Be an Exhibit Expert" and president of a Phoenix firm that creates trade show displays. "They act like kids."
Within two hours of opening the doors of the hangar-sized exhibition floor, the "killer toy" had been identified by a stampede of techies. It was a palm-sized foam rubber locomotive with a sound card that emits "choo-choo" noises when squeezed, the most prized of dozens of similar rubber statuary passed off as "stress relief" devices by vendors.
"These are the bonus items," said Curtis Cartmill, a Canadian software engineer, revealing the contents of his goody bag like a triumphant trick-or-treater. "We are acquiring knowledge here, but we are also acquiring a few projectiles."
Stephen Waespe, a colleague, added: "Someone at work will yell 'war' and you've got to have projectiles to retaliate. This is like an arms show for cubicle wars."
 
Some Survival Tips For E-Conventions
UNMUZZLED exhibitry can be intimidating to rookies. Here are a few tips on survival:
"Remember, look like you have purchasing authority," advised Benn Konsynski, a business professor at Emory University. "And don't make eye contact. It's a sign of weakness."
Do say you "forgot" your business cards. "That way, no one can bug you after the conference," said Nancy Anderson Smith of MQ Software. Follow-up contact avoidance is more difficult for vendors. "If you're an exhibitor, remember 10 percent of the population is plagued by mental illness."
Do ask others at the show for attraction advice. "Every show has five 'must see' innovations and word gets out after the first day where these are," Mr. Konsynski said.
Don't hesitate to grab the shiny giveaway baubles without enduring a sales demonstration. "The sales reps want you to take them because if you don't, they have to lug them back home on the plane," said Albert Segars, an e-commerce researcher at the University of North Carolina.
 CHRISTOPHER SMITH

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
Where, Oh Where Has My Shopping Bot Gone?

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI; Lisa Napoli is the Internet correspondent for MSNBC.

 BODY:
KATIE the audio technician and I were sitting in the Staples Center in Los Angeles, waiting patiently for our next assignment at the Democratic National Convention, when I asked her to participate in a little experiment.
"Do you need to buy anything?" I asked, even though I had just met her and some people might have found that question too personal. 
 She looked at me quizzically for a moment, and I could see the brain scan going.
"Yes, in fact, sure," she said. Her eyes lit up. "A bomber jacket."
"Good," I said, and asked her to join me at the computer to test bots.
"What's a bot?" she asked.
A bot is a digital version of a personal assistant, I told her, which scans shopping sites and spits out lists of items and prices.
It is sort of like visiting several stores, but only going into one. This seemed particularly alluring because we were stuck in the convention hall, close to lots of hot air but nowhere near a good shopping mall.
"Neat!" Katie said.
Personally, I was wondering whether bots could still be as worthless as the last time I tried them.
Bots were all the rage last Christmas, hyped by the technology media at every turn, jamming the airwaves with commercials, but they seemed like vaporware to me -- overpromoted and underperforming. The bots I had tried were cluttered and unfriendly and usually produced too much information, all of which turned out to be worthless.
I also wondered, as I often did with the Internet, how bots could ever be a viable business. To be of any use to a consumer, they had to scan as many sites as possible, and surely not every site would pay for the referral. So how did I know I could trust the information I was getting from a bot?
The theory behind the technology was great, but the reality was a different matter. A bot did not necessarily give you unbiased, comprehensive information.
E-shopping experts seemed to agree with me. "I haven't found a bot yet that grabs every single bit of related information, or every single site," said Steve Haskin, managing editor of Botspot, a digital newsletter about bots. "I don't think there's one bot out there that does it all yet."
Ken Cassar, senior retail analyst with Jupiter Communications, said bots faced a fundamental economic problem.
"Consumers aren't willing to pay for the service," Mr. Cassar said. "As a result, they have to pursue advertising as a revenue model. The problem is, that creates potential conflict between their advertisers, and the way some bots have gotten around it is to provide a search for best price. They make their money from referrals, but they'll accept advertising from manufacturers."
That is why, he said, "the editorial integrity issue is one that's a bit dicey for the bots."
So, back to our shopping expedition. Katie and I, basking in the windowless workspace at the Democratic convention, started our search.
As a veteran of way too much online shopping, I knew that finding clothing might be particularly challenging. Because of the nature of the merchandise, much e-commerce has been focused on items like electronics, software and computer hardware -- goods you do not necessarily need to see or try on to buy.
Lately, that has been changing, said Josh Goldman, president of MySimon.com, a bot purchased by CNET in January for $700 million. "Frankly, we're amazed now at the breadth of categories," Mr. Goldman said. "Fashion and gourmet foods and high-priced bottles of wine. It's astounding to me that it's becoming mainstream."
Not mainstream enough yet, apparently. MySimon.com turned up just two bomber jackets for women, neither of which satisfied Katie.
Hotbot Shopping did not have any listings for "bomber jacket." Excite Shopping called up all sorts of bomber jackets, from panne velvet numbers to leather versions that offered no pictures for us to see. Several other bots we found listed on Botspot turned out to be defunct.
EAGER to spend some money and realizing that we were not getting anywhere, Katie remembered there was something else she had been wanting to buy: a copy of her son's favorite childhood book, "Muggins Mouse."
Bestbookbuys.com promised to search 14 different sites, but turned up 458 titles, not one of which was the one we were seeking. No luck at Bookblvd.com, and two other book bots, listed on Botspot, were out of commission.
This is where my surfing experience came to the rescue: I had found hard-to-trace books before on Bibliofind.com and Alibris.com, which search for old, used and rare books, so off we went. Katie did not want a $774 scarce, mint condition edition, but we did find a copy for $15 from a bookseller in Florida. Katie was delighted.
But technically, we had not used a bot.
Eager to put one to the test, I did try several to track down the price on a Nikon Coolpix 990, a camera that my fiance had recently bought and would have married if a man could marry a camera.
Another, different saga than the bomber search: I kept getting confusing lists, filled with lenses and adapters and other peripherals. Buried among them were prices on actual cameras, but more times than not, once shipping or member fees were added, the prices were virtually the same. Had I actually been buying the camera, I would have at that point gone to the online store I know and trust.
The experts said that I should not give up hope, that bots had just begun to evolve into what will be their eventual state.
"Long term, it will be something many, many different aggregators use in conjunction with coupons and reviews," Mr. Cassar of Jupiter said. "The problem is that right now since shopping bot functionality was developed to be used rather in a vacuum, it has not been integrated well with other types of content online."
Will it ever be? Mr. Haskin of Botspot thinks so.
"I still think we're dealing with maybe late Model T's. They haven't really begun to display the promise the computers have yet."
Maybe not. And maybe they will. But for now, the next time I need to buy something, I'm going to go direct to the stores I know -- online and off.

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
An Unusual Commute Leads to a Different Kind of Partnership

BYLINE: By JESSICA STEINBERG; Jessica Steinberg is a freelance business writer based in Jerusalem.

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan

 BODY:
THE drive from here to Tel Aviv is only 75 minutes, shorter than the ride from San Francisco to San Jose, in California. But Omar Salah is certainly the only Internet entrepreneur making it regularly.
It is a trip that always leaves Mr. Salah, 34, who built a string of factories that makes batteries and bras before stumbling into e-commerce, a bit stunned. 
 Although he had realized early on that Israel was crucial to economic development in the region, Mr. Salah never expected to be working with Israeli investors.
But he does, and it has led to TaskMail, Mr. Salah's Internet start-up, and the reason for his cross-border commute. He is developing an e-mail filing system with the help of $3.5 million from Israel Seed partners, a venture capital firm in Jerusalem.
TaskMail, which operates in a high-technology industrial park near Tel Aviv, expects to release its product by the end of the year.
The company is run by its chief executive, Ezer Baum, an Israeli expert on Lotus Notes. Mr. Salah is the company's enthusiastic chairman, sharing words from his favorite how-to-be-a-millionaire self-help books and keeping in constant contact by phone and e-mail message.
The project's genesis came from Mr. Salah's industrial investment firm, Century Investment Group, which was founded in 1995 and owns six factories in Jordan that produce a range of products, from cellular batteries for Motorola to underwear for Gap Inc., Victoria's Secret and Calvin Klein Inc.
To better manage the factories and their 4,000 employees, Mr. Salah, an engineer educated at Purdue University, had developed software as a method for collaborating through e-mail, allowing colleagues to assign tasks and follow up on projects.
The software essentially acts as an electronic agent, which will not only verify that an e-mail message has been received but also check that the recipient is acting on it.
In 1998, a couple of years after he developed TaskMail, Mr. Salah attended the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. There, he met Yossi Vardi, the technology guru who had backed his son and three other Israelis in developing instant e-mail messaging, which was later bought by America Online for $400 million.
Mr. Vardi encouraged Mr. Salah to turn his e-mail software into a business venture, but Mr. Salah was reluctant.
At the same forum, Mr. Salah met Jacob Davidson, an Israeli entrepreneur. It was Mr. Davidson who persuaded Mr. Salah to use venture capital, rather than his own money, to start TaskMail, helping him refine his marketing pitch while teaching him to be less apprehensive about working with Israelis.
"Every once in a while, Omar and I catch our breath and realize just how extraordinary our relationship is," said Mr. Davidson, who acts as an informal adviser and networking consultant to Mr. Salah. Through Mr. Davidson, Mr. Salah met his investors.
TaskMail is nearing the end of its first development stage and is being tested in two high-technology companies in Israel. Mr. Salah and Mr. Baum plan to introduce TaskMail by the end of October, at which point the company will follow the traditional Israeli model of setting up headquarters in the United States, with research and development centers in Israel. TaskMail is unique in that it will also have a research and development center in Jordan.
So far, testing has gone well, the company said, with users praising the tool's ability to push tasks to completion, particularly customer service requests.
"We get really good feedback from people who are frustrated with their e-mail tools," Mr. Baum said. The plan is to integrate TaskMail with existing software platforms, first using the tool for e-mail and instant messaging applications and then adding voice mail.
For Mr. Salah, doing business with Israelis has become second nature while earning him criticism from Jordanian associates who have avoided ventures with Israeli investors. Nevertheless, he has forged ahead, with tacit approval from King Abdullah of Jordan and with the cooperation of Mr. Salah's colleagues in Israel.
Even when Mr. Salah was starting his business at age 28, he realized that his Israeli neighbors were crucial to the worldwide market.
"I had natural hostilities," said Mr. Salah, the son of a Jordanian contractor who spent most of his childhood and early adulthood in Britain and the United States. "But I saw that Israel was part of the path to our future."
At that time, 1994, a year after the signing of a peace agreement between King Hussein of Jordan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel, Mr. Salah had never been to Israel. No matter. He wheedled his way across the border, found a taxi to take him to Tel Aviv and settled in the lounge of the Hilton Hotel.
HE then cold-called several of Israel's industrialists, asking them whether they wanted to cooperate in joint venture plants near the Israel-Jordan border. They did. And that is how his factories were built in Irbid, Jordan's second-largest city.
Mr. Salah is also setting up an Arab-Israeli-American venture capital fund that would take successful Internet models from English-speaking countries -- like eBay and Amazon.com -- and set them up in the Arabic-speaking countries. He hopes to involve other Jordanians.
Why with Israelis?
"We're looking to fill obvious voids in the new Arab economy," he said. "If Arabs can exploit Israeli resources -- the brains, finances and contacts -- and leverage it, it could create so much value. These are the dividends of peace."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
Automated Advice Sites Turning Up the Heat on Planners

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
MOST of his peers look at the Internet and see a threat to their livelihood, but Frank Armstrong sees a medium for spreading the gospel of financial discipline to those he could not reach otherwise.
When he is not managing the finances of his wealthy clients from his office in Miami, Mr. Armstrong is serving as the chief investment strategist for DirectAdvice, an Internet company that says it is a low-price substitute for financial planners like Mr. Armstrong. DirectAdvice is one of several electronic services that have sprung up over the last year, offering investors advice on what to do with their money for as little as $50 a year. 
 Many financial planners dismiss these start-ups as one-size-fits-all answers to problems that require personal attention and custom solutions. They also worry that investors will be attracted by the much lower fees these new services are charging.
Clients can be dazzled by the speed and sophistication of the computerized tools these sites offer and begin to question why their planners charge so much more and do not offer them the tools as well. Most planners charge fees of 0.5 percent to 2 percent of their clients' assets.
"There is no possible way I can take on a client relationship for $75 a year," said Mr. Armstrong, the president of Managed Account Services, whose clients typically have at least $1 million to invest. "All those people who can't afford to come in and put $1 million on the table at this office still need advice."
The electronic feedback they could get from DirectAdvice for an annual fee of $75 or $100 may seem colder and more impersonal than the help they would get in face-to-face sessions with a human adviser, but it is still fairly sophisticated. These sites have graduated from the simple calculators that are available free throughout the Internet.
Most take the same approach: they start by asking clients to fill out detailed electronic forms that outline their finances and their plans for spending and saving. In short order, they spit back suggestions of how to spread their money among stocks, bonds and mutual funds. Some, including AdviceAmerica and Financial Engines, recommend certain mutual funds to buy.
AdviceAmerica, which is offering its services directly to consumers and through online brokerage firms, started out this year offering a one-year subscription to its online advisory service for just $49. That is half the price it plans to charge starting Oct. 1.
Financial Engines, founded by the Nobel Prize-winning economist William F. Sharpe, was the first of these electronic services to throw a scare into financial professionals. It offers a free financial plan for subscribers, followed by an unlimited number of updates on their progress, for as little as $55 a year. So far, the service is limited to tax-deferred retirement savings accounts, like 401(k) plans.
Michael McNamara, a consultant with Datamonitor in New York, said that these services were "very useful at a basic level." He said that most of them seemed to provide smart advice on how investors should spread out their money, though some do not give detailed guidance on which stocks or mutual funds to buy.
They may be good sources of advice for people with less than $100,000 to invest, Mr. McNamara said, but they cannot compete with brokers and planners who specialize in managing money for wealthy people. "Things do become too complicated for any type of automated response," he said. "The golden rule of brokers is 'know your customer.' But it's impossible for these types of services to really know you. They just know that you fit in Category D or Category A."
Even so, most financial planners feel threatened by these new competitors and the technology behind them, said Ed McCarthy, a retired financial planner and editor of the Financial Planning Association's Yourbiz Web site. "The concern is the clients are going to look at them as not being on the cutting edge," he said. "Clients are starting to request services that they are seeing online that the advisers might not have considered offering."
Mr. McCarthy said that planners were frequently hearing questions from clients about Monte Carlo simulations. Normally, any mention of Monte Carlo would cause a planner to shudder, fearing that a client might gamble away his retirement savings. These inquiries make planners shudder for a different reason: a Monte Carlo simulation is what number crunchers call a program that calculates the likelihood that a client's retirement-savings plan will support his dreams for his golden years. Users can ask for a recalculation based on different variables, like a higher inflation rate or a lower savings rate.
As sophisticated as they are, these tools are popping up on more and more Web sites, where they can often be used at no charge. Their easy availability is just one more factor that is contributing to the pressure on financial planners to make use of the Internet and other new technology or risk losing clients. Even advisers who do not think these electronic services are necessary or even helpful are providing them for fear of seeming too stodgy.
With a tone of resignation, Michael Howard, the president of Emery & Howard Portfolio Management in Burlingame, Calif., said his firm was preparing to grant clients the ability to electronically check on their accounts whenever and as often as they choose.
"Most savvy investors don't want information that rapidly," said Mr. Howard, whose firm caters to multimillionaire entrepreneurs and executives in Silicon Valley. "A lot of people don't even look. But you get a few who always look."
He dismisses the prospects of Internet-based companies, like MyCFO.com, a start-up backed by the Netscape founder Jim Clark, that hope to use a technological edge to lure wealthy clients away from traditional financial advisers. The financial lives of most affluent people are too complicated to be satisfied by impersonal, electronic systems, he said.
But in running his own business, Mr. Armstrong has been surprised at how many people will turn over management of large sums of money to somebody they have never met. He said only about 20 percent of his clients lived in the Miami area. The rest are scattered worldwide, some as far away as China, and he communicates with them mostly through e-mail.
For example, Mr. Armstrong said, most of his clients no longer listen in on periodic conference calls that he conducts to share his views on the financial markets. Now they can dial in to his Web site and hear and see the presentations when they want.
Instead of a threat to his livelihood, the Internet "is a humongous opportunity," he said. "One hundred percent of my business comes from the Internet and my entire e-commerce initiative costs $58 a month."
Mr. Armstrong sees electronic advisers as a way of bridging the growing gulf between investors who can afford planners like Mr. Howard and the masses.
As competition has squeezed prices, advisers have set their sights on richer clients whose fees will cover the costs of running their operations. Those costs include computers and servers to stay in constant touch with the brokerage firms that execute and process their trades, and software that manages bookkeeping and creates account statements.
In raising their account minimums, Mr. Armstrong said, "We've left orphan the entire middle class. The people who serve and build and make this country run."
AdviceAmerica estimates that almost 75 percent of American households do not have financial advisers. That is only in part because of the high cost, which can run into thousands of dollars a year.
"There are a lot of people with a lot of money who will never pay a financial adviser," Mr. Armstrong said. "I'm surprised at the number of people with real wealth who use the DirectAdvice model. We get clients with amazing amounts of wealth."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
Step Right Up and Buy a Megawatt!

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
MANY Web sites scream about what they will sell you for next to nothing, or less. But how about a site that pays you not to buy?
A strange notion, but one that has more solid economic underpinnings than many of those desperate give-it-away dot-coms. Then again, the commodity in question is not the typical stuff of e-commerce transactions, like a plane ticket from Cincinnati to Nashville next Thursday or a vintage Barbie doll or 20,000 widgets of a certain shape. This promising new business is using e-commerce for a commodity that absolutely everybody needs: electricity. 
 As it turns out, one kilowatt may look like another, but its price may vary by a factor of more than 100 in a single day. At night a kilowatt-hour -- the amount of electricity needed to light 10 100-watt bulbs for an hour -- may sell for a penny or two, because most of the generating capacity is unused. But on a hot afternoon, in places where the market is deregulated, the same amount of power could cost $1 or $5, or even more.
Traditionally, though, utilities charge most customers pretty much the same price for the kilowatt-hour no matter what they pay to buy it or if they generate it themselves. Even companies with time-of-day rates are charging a price that varies by only a few pennies from peak to off-peak.
But as California approached a summer of tight electricity supplies this year, Pacific Gas and Electric started an e-commerce marketplace where customers could be paid not to buy. In theory, the system would work with any customer, but it is only practical with big consumers, mostly businesses, because otherwise the number of transactions becomes hard to manage.
As the state danced on the edge of rotating blackouts, the company quickly applied to regulators for permission to expand its program, called E-Bid. The system works like this: every afternoon, the utility gets an estimate of what power will cost on the wholesale market the next day. When the price is high, the utility notifies big customers that have signed up for its program, alerting them to log on to a secure Web site.
There, according to Ronald K. Lowe, a company spokesman, the estimated price is posted. If the customer, generally a factory, is willing to cut its consumption 20 percent from its normal level, then it accepts the bid, and the utility pays the customer the posted price, minus the normal retail cost per kilowatt-hour. If the bulk price is $250 a megawatt-hour, for example, that makes electricity 25 cents a kilowatt-hour, compared with a typical price to the factory of 5 cents or so. For every kilowatt-hour that the factory does not use on the next day, the company pays 20 cents.
The transaction has two functions. It cuts the risk of the grid running short of power and causing a blackout. And by reducing the peak demand, it takes a few buyers out of the market and makes the price lower for the remaining buyers. As the summer ended, proponents of this kind of marketing said that the unanticipated price swings, especially in places like San Diego, where some customers faced bills that had tripled, showed the necessity for making hourly prices obvious to electricity users, so that they would not blithely continue with normal consumption patterns at times of extraordinary price spikes.
But the California program is still small; on one tough day this summer, July 31, 29 customers participated, cutting demand by 40 megawatts, compared with a peak demand of 21,000 megawatts.
Pacific Gas and Electric charges customers $600 to enter the program and requires that they be able to cut demand by at least 500 kilowatts, which is enough to run about 100 big houses. But it has applied for permission to cut the entry fee to $100 and take applicants who can cut demand by only 250 kilowatts.
Such transactions are only possible through electronic commerce, but by setting just one price in a 24-hour period, P.G.& E.'s system is hardly taking full advantage. Wisconsin Electric Power began a more flexible system this summer in which it invites big customers to log on to a site, where it offers a price per kilowatt-hour not used. If it does not attract enough bidders to meet its needs, it can post a new bid price a few minutes later.
Such transactions could apply the market forces that already exist at the wholesale level to the level of the electricity user, possibly even a homeowner.
"There's been a whole lot of debate over the years as to whether or not an average consumer will ever shift consumption based on price principles," said Scott A. Weiner, a senior vice president of Sithe Northeast, an independent power producer. "On the other hand, people who run large office buildings or factories can get those price signals in a very strong way," said Mr. Weiner, a former environmental commissioner for New Jersey.
BUT, he said, at the moment, there is a supply curve -- a changing level of the amount available, depending on the price offered -- but no real demand curve, because the buyers do not know what the price is and thus cannot respond. Demand is therefore not affected by price.
"In the absence of a demand response, nobody can ever say, 'The price is too high, I'm not going to pay that,' " Mr. Weiner said. "As load response programs come into development, it's clear the Web will play a very vital part of making that real and accessible."
A second form of e-commerce is emerging on a business-to-business model, and it's one of the few forms that the government has required. It is called Oasis, for Open Access Same-Time Information System, ordered by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Oasis gives companies that build free-standing power plants a way to market their power and for companies that consume electricity a way to see the market. Oasis systems are increasingly operated by new entities called Independent System Operators, which have been formed on the East Coast and in California to run the transmission grids that were formerly controlled by electric utilities.
The systems vary from place to place, but are supposed to show the price of electricity, sometimes broken down by location, to take account of transmission bottlenecks.
At the California Independent System Operator, William H. Simmons, the manager of market applications, development and support, said that some aspects of electricity trading existed years ago on electronic bulletin boards. But the ability of users to identify available transmission links and schedule their use depended on the Web. "It could not have happened if it were not for the Internet," he said. The Independent System Operator works with the California Power Exchange to arrange delivery of the power that generators and customers contract for on the exchange.
Both Oasis and programs like E-Bid have the potential to adjust electricity use to reflect costs, experts say, and that would be one way to hold down peak demand and thus make the system less prone to overload.
Eric Hirst, an energy consultant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., and a former scientist at the national laboratory there, speaking at a conference in Washington this spring on reliability problems, said the result would contrast with the former pattern of electricity use. When people know the price of a product they are consuming, they behave differently, economists say; in the case of electricity, they will consume it in relation to its seasonal price or even hourly price.
As Mr. Hirst said, "When people used to pay 5 cents a kilowatt-hour, it didn't matter to them whether electricity was free or $2 a kilowatt-hour."

HEADLINE: ONE YEAR LATER;
Nuts, Bolts and Bumps in the Road

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, W. W. Grainger Inc., which distributes manufacturing valves, maintenance products and replacement parts for industry, had established itself as a pioneer in electronic commerce.
Grainger, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., set out in 1995 to build more than just a line of defense against its competitors in the equipment and services industry known as M.R.O., or maintenance, repair and operations. 
 The company, which had revenue of $4.45 billion in 1999, wanted to use Web technology to become an even stronger force in the industry.
That is still the goal, but there have been growing pains. The homegrown technology used for Grainger.com, its first e-commerce site, was unable to support the features customers wanted, like a pop-up list as soon as they signed on showing supplies they usually buy or a procedure that required orders above a specific amount to be authorized. So Grainger was forced to slow down and move to a more flexible platform developed by BroadVision Inc.
Customers also showed little enthusiasm for Orderzone.com, an electronic marketplace that Grainger had set up where customers could order not just the 220,000 products it carried but products from distributors in other businesses like laboratory supplies and factory safety equipment.
In June, Grainger switched course, giving Orderzone.com and $21 million to Works.com of Austin, Tex., an Internet purchasing service for small and midsize businesses seeking office equipment and supplies, in exchange for a 40 percent stake in Works.com.
"Orderzone taught us it is very difficult and expensive to build a stand-alone brand on the Internet," said Richard L. Keyser, Grainger's chairman and chief executive.
For all that, Grainger's revenue from its e-commerce ventures is expected to reach $400 million this year, compared with $101.5 million last year.
Although only a small percentage of Grainger's 1.4 million customers are participating, the company is generating more Internet business than all of its competitors combined, said Jon Econiak, who follows e-business for Piper Jaffray, an investment company.
Mr. Econiak said Grainger was playing catch-up on the technology front to newcomers like IndustrialAmerica, a procurement site scheduled to begin this fall.
Grainger, for its part, thinks it will be more difficult for newcomers to duplicate the quick service and reliability of its 370 branch offices than for Grainger to match any online innovations. Grainger is investing $120 million this year in e-commerce initiatives, up from $100 million last year.
"Our highest priority is to create a seamless linkage between bricks and clicks," Mr. Keyser said.
"You can't fax motors," he added. "You have to be able to get them there in short order."
Mr. Econiak said it could be a couple of years before Grainger or any other company provides what customers truly want: a Web-based process that integrates all of the functions involved in buying industrial supplies, including a procedure for returns.
Most of Grainger's e-traffic -- about 6 percent of its total sales -- came from longtime customers who switched from calling or faxing orders to using its Web site. Grainger's research suggested that customers using the Internet increased their business with the company by 17 percent from 1998 to 1999. For customers who stayed with traditional channels, the growth rate was 8 percent.
Grainger's growth is also receiving a lift from FindMRO.com, a Web site the company started in November that helps customers find items it does not handle. By August, revenue was almost $6 million a month.
After setting up FindMRO, Grainger moved on in April to an even more ambitious project called TotalMRO.com.
TotalMRO tries to provide large companies that buy supplies from different distributors a single place where they can find prices, determine product availability and make transactions. This is somewhat akin to stuffing most of the M.R.O. universe into a single catalog.
Grainger said it needed about 100 nationwide distributors to provide customers with access to some 15 million products. By early August, about 15 distributors dealing in 3.5 million products had signed on, and Earthgrains, the nation's second-largest baker, had become the first client.
