LENGTH: 1215 words

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
As Brazil's Market Grows, So Does the Free Access Dispute

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO

 BODY:
WITH 170 million people and more than 10 million computers, five times the number in use five years ago, Brazil is the most promising Internet and e-commerce market in Latin America.
Brazil accounted for 80 percent, or about $400 million, of e-commerce sales in Latin America in 1999, according to recent market studies. But e-commerce in Brazil is still in its infancy -- only 6 percent of the country's 500 largest companies have complete e-commerce sites, according to a survey conducted earlier this year. 
 With online sales expected to double this year and again in 2001, dozens of access providers are competing to find the best strategy to lure consumers to the Internet.
Bradesco, Brazil's largest private bank, started the battle late last year when it began offering free Internet access to attract customers and promote its site, www.bradesco.com.br, which sells products ranging from books to car parts. Other banks soon followed and quickly found themselves joined by start-up providers that consider free access the surest path to profitability.
"Free access to the Internet is the model most appropriate for the reality of Brazil and, for that matter, most of the rest of Latin America," said Nizan Guanaes, the director of iG, an Internet provider. "In a society like the United States, paid access may be the way to go, but here people can't afford it, and so we have to create a different system."
IG, which stands for Internet Gratis, or free Internet, opened six months ago and said it now had 2.5 million users and 11 million daily page views. Mr. Guanaes said that the number of users was growing by more than 10,000 a day, and he predicted that the Sao Paulo-based service would be profitable "by the end of next year."
The site carries advertising and earns a commission on sales. It also plans to use its broadband and cell phone services to subsidize its Internet service.
The market leader has been Universo Online, or UOL, a venture between two media groups -- Folha, which publishes Folha de Sao Paulo, the largest newspaper in Sao Paulo, and Abril, the largest magazine group in Brazil, which also has a cable network.
UOL, of Sao Paulo, said it had 780,000 subscribers, up 50 percent from last year, and charges $11 to $22 a month for access to www.uol.com.br, which provides stock quotes, news, sports and entertainment information and offers products for sale.
"It is mathematically and logically impossible for the free access model to prevail in Brazil, for one simple reason," said Caio Tulio Costa, the director general of UOL. "You can't possibly turn a profit that way, and the behavior of the market, not only here but elsewhere, is already showing that advertising alone does not provide enough revenue to make money."
Conspicuously missing from the list of major players is America Online, the online leader in the United States. AOL, working with Cisneros Group of Venezuela, entered the Brazilian market late. When it did arrive, it found that its domain name already belonged to a small provincial provider, and it was forced to adopt the cumbersome name of www.americaonline.com.br. Then a disastrous start in November led to the departure of its president.
As is the case in other countries, none of the providers in Brazil are making money, and the market is cluttered with providers who are not expected to survive. UOL recently announced its second-quarter results, and despite a 28 percent growth in revenue, it posted a $45 million loss.
Though the number has fallen from a peak of more than 600 in 1997, there are still about 150 providers, including several with free access, like Terra Networks and StarMedia, whose focus is the Spanish-speaking Latin American market, rather than Brazil, where most people speak Portuguese.
Like other countries in Latin America, Brazil faces infrastructure problems that are slowing development.
Though the number of fixed phone lines has nearly tripled since 1994, to 35 million from 13 million, and cell phone ownership has soared to 15 million from 800,000, half the population still does not have a phone line, according to the Brazilian Institute of Public Opinion, a market research firm.
In addition, even with the privatization of the telephone system over the last two years, per-minute rates are high. So the more the Internet is used, the higher the phone bill, with charges for cell phones, often promoted as an alternative to reach the Internet, being even more expensive.
"If you stay online all day, you're going to end up with a considerable phone bill at the end of the month, and that is not the way to make access viable to the lower classes who see the computer as a promising tool," said Luis Carlos Boucinhas, the executive director of Globo.com, the site operated by Rede Globo, the country's largest television network. "We're already a broadband provider, and we are betting that, along with wireless access, is where the future lies."
Some of the obstacles to e-commerce are not online. People who buy goods online must trust a hit-or-miss postal system. Private courier services like Federal Express, United Parcel Service and DHL are booming, but countries like Brazil, which is larger than the continental United States, and neighboring Colombia and Peru have areas that are too remote for conventional transportation systems.
Yet the main barrier to e-commerce here, as in the rest of Latin America, is economics, not infrastructure. Only 10 percent of Brazil's population has an income of $300 a month or more, and it is that group that accounts for more than 80 percent of the country's five million Internet users.
"Until costs associated with accessing the Internet come down significantly, so that people in lower income brackets can get online, the B-to-C market in Brazil will never be large enough to justify overly optimistic expectations," Maria Carolina da Costa of Intellifact International wrote recently in an essay for InfoBrazil.com.
In hopes of reversing that trend, low-cost initiatives intended to expand use of the Internet are being created. Some post offices now offer 15 minutes daily of free access to customers willing to wait in line, and a pilot project in the city of Campinas allows users to call a telephone number and receive or send e-mail messages, for 25 cents a minute.
Globo.com has signed an agreement with a government bank to extend $890 million in low-interest loans to help poor families buy computers.
Many market analysts predict that it will not be long before the bulk of the population has access to the Internet through devices that can be bought and installed at home, whether an inexpensive computer, WebTV or Palm hand-held units.
"The price of computers is dropping and cellular use is exploding," Mr. Guanaes said. "I believe that by 2005 Brazil will be one of the three top Internet markets in the world."
But others are more cautious.
"In 1995, every bank and investment research company in Brazil predicted that there would be more than 10 million pay-television subscribers by 2000," Mr. Costa said. "But that figure has been stuck at 2.5 million for the past three years, which just goes to show that you have to view every prediction about this market with skepticism."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
Why This Consumer Giant Isn't About to Sell to Consumers

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI

 BODY:
AS consumers gravitate to the Web, more and more are expecting retailers to deliver highly specialized packages -- books, clothing, compact discs, software -- to their doors.
Some consumers would even pay a premium for delivery of groceries. 
 So you might think a giant like Procter & Gamble, with a $40-billion-a-year stable of popular brands like Scope, Tide, Pampers and Crest, would be rushing to get in on the action -- to reinvent itself as a dot-com, bypassing retailers and going directly to consumers through the Internet.
Think again. Companies like P.& G. are keenly aware of the need to be in cyberspace (or anywhere their customers happen to be), and they know that home delivery is a fast-growing part of the market. But few experts said that online commerce would ever replace bricks and mortar -- especially for unglamorous staples like hair spray, soap and toothpaste. Instead, they expected companies like Procter to invest more heavily in business-to-business applications.
"Our estimates are that there'll never be more than 10 percent of groceries sold online," said Evie Black Dykema, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "There'll be lots of specialty items online -- Indian spices and Pepperidge Farm cookies. But Bounty paper? Not a chance."
Consumers are also searching for more information on the products they use or intend to use and that is forcing everyone, including consumer product giants, to have a presence on the Web.
Here at Procter & Gamble's sprawling headquarters, officials said that for all its promise, the Internet held nothing compelling enough to justify destroying relations with retailers or overhauling a colossal distribution system.
Instead, executives have concluded that the best route to continued success is to travel as many high-technology roads as possible. When it comes to the Internet, the company's motto might be "Experiment, experiment, experiment."
So over the last year, Procter has moved aggressively to forge relationships with the online grocers Webvan Group Inc. and HomeGrocer.com Inc. It has also created its own venture capital arm to invest in Internet start-ups, allowing it to tiptoe into new product lines.
Procter is teaming up with popular Web sites, like iVillage.com and Women.com, to promote its beauty and health care products. It is rolling out new brands online, seeking consumer reaction before the items reach store shelves. And it is using the Web to gather information about consumers.
Procter has also joined other consumer-products giants, like Coca-Cola and Sara Lee, in a business-to-business Internet exchange that seeks to use their combined weight to reduce the costs of buying materials and shipping goods.
And the company is using the Internet to induce better cooperation among its 8,500 researchers and scientists, who spend about $1.8 billion a year on research and development.
In rejecting the idea of shipping directly to consumers, executives and analysts cited buying patterns and market relationships that they said were too durable to be displaced by the Internet.
It would be suicidal, they said, to spend billions of dollars to build distribution networks to compete with the likes of Wal-Mart, Kmart and Target, just for the privilege of wrapping $3 and $5 items individually and shipping them to consumers.
"P.& G.'s primary customers right now are the big mass retailers, and so if you go direct you compete with them," said William Steele, a consumer products analyst at Banc of America Securities. "Wal-Mart has 2,800 stores. If you decide to ship case one of Tide directly to consumers, you get yourself thrown out of 2,800 stores. Why would you do that?"
Procter & Gamble's distribution system is geared to shipping in bulk to warehouses and retail outlets. To overhaul that system in favor of one that is more splintered would be inefficient and costly, executives said. Nor is there evidence that consumers are clamoring for the service.
"We've done extensive research," said Stephen N. David, the company's chief information officer. "We find consumers want aggregation; they don't want a box of Tide coming in the afternoon."
Of course, companies like Procter know that change is constant and that technological developments could someday force them to go straight to consumers.
Executives worry that the Web's interactive and open format could give a big advantage to more nimble and inventive competitors.
So like other companies, Procter is hedging its bets. It is investing heavily not just in working with Web companies but also in creating and tracking Web developments.
IVentures, the venture capital fund Procter started this year, has bought stakes in half a dozen companies, typically with investments of $2 million to $5 million. The idea is to find additional outlets for products and to help Procter better understand where the Internet is headed.
"This is also helping change the culture of P.& G. because start-ups are leading edge," said Richard Kiley, the head of iVentures. "We're putting general managers and vice presidents on the boards of companies so they observe."
One of Procter & Gamble's biggest forays onto the Web came a year ago, when it invested $35 million in its own Silicon Valley start-up, Reflect.com, devoted to creating custom beauty products.
The company goes where Procter is not ready to go: not only does it manufacture products, it also ships them to consumers. The way executives at Reflect.com explain it, the company is almost the antithesis of its parent.
"When a consumer-products company does testing on a new product, it has to meet the needs of a large group; they throw out what doesn't meet the broad needs of people," said Richard Gerstein, a vice president for design and marketing at Reflect.com in San Francisco. "With us, a woman comes online, answers a set of questions, and then we help her create a product just for her."
Reflect.com is a kind of laboratory for Procter & Gamble, a window into an online future in which the cosmetics industry could shift from generic, mass-produced scents, colors and brands toward more expensive, highly individual ones.
It is even possible that biotechnology will enable companies to use a person's genetic blueprint to match skin, body and hair types with the right product.
Executives at Procter said that for all the emphasis on the mass market, on shipping truckloads of one-size-fits-all products to the Wal-Marts of the world, they were preparing for a day when custom products are more than a niche market. It is a possibility that could upset some of their moves toward greater efficiency through giant manufacturing plants and distribution depots.
In the last year, Procter & Gamble has introduced two products on the Web: Physique, a line of shampoos, conditioners, gels, mousses, creams and lotions; and a Crest whitening strip that bleaches teeth. Both products were started with Web sites, advertising and free samples.
The company said that the Web was an ideal tool for direct marketing and communicating with consumers who want to know about new products or ask questions about existing ones.
"Why spend time pushing at consumers who aren't interested?" asked David Worth, the associate director for information technology.
But for Procter & Gamble, which is basically a business-to-business company selling to big retailers, the Web's most promising aspect may lie in the savings that could result from teaming with other companies to create a more efficient procurement and distribution network.
The network, Transora, is to begin operating this year. Its members -- including Coca-Cola, Sara Lee, Kraft, PepsiCo and Gillette, along with Procter & Gamble -- will try to leverage their size in obtaining better prices for raw materials and share data to find less expensive and more efficient ways to ship products and track inventory. And they are expected to work more closely with retailers to root out inefficiencies.
"Billions of dollars are wasted in inefficiencies every year," said Judith Sprieser, the chief executive of Transora, which is based in Chicago. "There are estimates that we carry too much inventory in our supply chain because we don't know what's going to be purchased."
The alliance shows that online commerce is changing the rules of the marketplace even if most consumers never abandon their supermarkets and shopping malls.
"The winner in the future is going to be the one who can mobilize the best access to information and make the best use of it," Ms. Sprieser said. "And they'll all have fewer clerks correcting invoice errors."

HEADLINE: The 'Tequila Crisis': Take It With a Grain of Salt

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19

 BODY:
For a while there, if you believed the rumors, the headlines and the desperate cries of some New York bartenders, you might have thought that the world's supply of tequila was about to dry up.
Yes, a temporary shortage of blue agave, the gigantic lily from which the liquor is made, forced a few small distilleries to close their doors. And the perception of a crisis allowed big producers, which appear to have enough agave to weather the tequila tempest, to raise their prices 20 percent or more. One Manhattan bartender even invented a substitute called the "rum-a-rita." 
 But is there a tequila crisis of glass-shattering proportions? Not really, inquiries from here to Margaritaville indicate.
"There is no crisis," said Jose Luis Sanchez, vice president of the National Chamber of the Tequila Industry in Mexico. "There is no such thing as this alleged crisis."
It is true, however, that trouble has been brewing in and around Tequila, the town in central Mexico that makes millions of gallons of the drink that made it famous. Indisputably, large forces are at work: the cycles of nature, the laws of supply and demand, the thirst for margaritas. But for the increasing number of people in the United States who sip premium tequila or swill agave-scented slush, the glass may be half full, not half empty.
Making tequila -- a drink as Mexican as Champagne is French -- has been a rough-and-tumble business since the days of the conquistadors. The Aztecs figured out how to make a brew called pulque out of agave more than 1,000 years ago. The Spaniards refined the process. But no one ever smoothed over the eternal enmity between the farmers who grow agave and the businessmen who distill tequila.
"The growers and distillers of tequila are historical enemies," said Robert Denton, an American tequila importer. Their warring has led to the present state of affairs.
Eight years ago, there was a glut of agave. The big producers pressured farmers to sell below market prices, for less than 4 cents a pound, driving some out of business or into other crops.
Agave takes at least eight years to mature. Today, there are roughly half as many agave plants in the ground as there were a few years ago. Fungus and freezes, as well as greed, have taken their toll.
And in those past eight years, tequila's popularity exploded in the United States. Like single-malt whisky and specialty bourbon, premium tequila, made from 100 percent blue agave, is handmade, with subtle variations, a rich history and a complex taste. And like those other spirits, it began to command staggering prices in the 1990's: $100 -- or more -- for an artfully made bottle. Jose Cuervo recently introduced 1800 Coleccion at $1,000 a bottle.
Fueled by that trendiness, the booming stock market and the eased trade rules of Nafta, production and export of the top-end premiums more than quadrupled from 1995 to 1999. The more popular brands of tequila, which are as little as 51 percent agave and used for mixing margaritas, also took off, with production and export increasing roughly 40 percent. Industry statistics vary and are sometimes suspect. But figures from Mexico's Tequila Regulatory Council, formed in 1994 to oversee production and quality, show a 48 percent increase in tequila drinking north of the Rio Grande since 1995.
With less agave growing and more tequila flowing, it doesn't require a Ph.D. in economics to understand the consequences: prices are up 20 percent or more for the popular brands, and demand threatens to overtake supply.
"It was a while in coming, and it couldn't have happened without the stupidity of the tequila manufacturers and the not-so-watchful gaze of the Mexican government," said Agustin Barrio Gomez, who is trying to sell his small premium distillery, Suave Patria, to avoid going broke. The Mexican government did not intervene, as Washington might have, to provide price supports or bailouts for farmers.
But despite the temporary agave shortage, the major tequila producers, which control more than half the global market, do not seem to be running dry.
"For the big boys, there isn't really a crisis," said Alan S. Dikty, an expert on spirits and an editor at Tastings.com, the Web site of the Beverage Testing Institute in Chicago, which conducts consumer reviews (and sounds like a pleasant place to work). "All the large distillers either own their own fields or have contracts lined up with growers. They're covered."
But for the smaller ones, who buy agave from independent plantation owners, "there is a crisis," he said, adding, "There is going to be a winnowing out."
Today, Mexico has 72 tequila distilleries, double the number five years ago. But a dozen or more of the smaller new ones have closed or seem likely to soon because they can't compete with companies that have bigger reserves and more buying power. The smaller distillers have to buy agave on the open market, where prices shot above 60 cents a pound this summer.
Answering their pleas, the government threatened the big distillers this summer with an antitrust action. But the threat came too late and in any case never materialized.
If it had, it could well have become an international incident. Foreigners have a big stake in the most famous names in tequila. Allied Domecq, the British company that also controls Dunkin' Donuts and Baskin-Robbins, owns Tequila Sauza, the second-largest brand. Diageo, the British conglomerate that owns Burger King and Guinness, controls 45 percent of Jose Cuervo, the largest-selling tequila. American, Canadian and French companies like Brown-Forman, Seagram and Remy Martin are also in the global cantina.
Last month, the government brokered a deal between the distillers and the growers. They agreed to set the price of agave at 45 cents a pound, to try to bring the supplies of agave back up, and to try to bring the price of tequila back down.
The deal was too late to save Mr. Barrio Gomez's distillery, and he fears it might have come too late to maintain tequila's soaring popularity abroad.
"It's a shame," he said. "Tequila was the fastest-growing product in the spirits market." Then the "greed and poor coordination" of big tequila companies "broke the market momentum," he said. "Once you kill the fad, it's hard to regain."
But the thirst for tequila remains, though the price may stay high -- for a while. In the town of Tequila, "they're overplanting now," Mr. Denton said, with a sigh born of two decades in the business, adding, "So, six or eight years from now, there'll be a glut again."

HEADLINE: New Home Construction Rises 0.3%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Construction of new homes increased in August for the first time in four months as lower mortgage rates renewed interest from buyers.
Housing starts rose 0.3 percent last month, to an annual rate of 1.53 million units, after falling 2.9 percent in July, the Commerce Department said. 
 The increase in August came after declines in five of the previous six months, as mortgage rates climbed to a five-year high in May. Rates on 30-year fixed mortgages fell in the last four months and have averaged 7.93 percent in September, the lowest this year.
As a result, mortgage applications rose this month to the highest level since the week the Federal Reserve started raising interest rates in mid-1999. "It looks as if the worst is behind us" for the housing industry, said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
That suggests housing will help sustain the economic expansion, which is now in a record 10th year. "It seems as if the housing market has been able to pull off a soft landing," Mr. Naroff said, just the sort of slowdown for the economy as a whole that Fed policy makers have been seeking.
Residential construction is on course this year to total 1.62 million units, which would match the number of houses built in 1998. That was the second-best year -- after 1999 -- for builders during the current expansion.
The rebound in construction comes after an increase in sales of new single-family homes in July to the fastest pace in four months. Construction of single-family homes rose 4.6 percent in August to the highest level since April. Permits for construction on new houses rose 2.1 percent last month, the first increase since March, suggesting a further pickup in home building.
Construction of apartments and other multifamily housing fell 15.9 percent last month after a 6.7 percent drop in July. Permits plunged for multifamily homes.

SECTION: Section A; Page 3; Column 1; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Milosevic, Trailing in Polls, Rails Against NATO

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sept. 19

 BODY:
In his race for re-election, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is running against NATO and the United States, not against his democratic opposition.
He is not entirely mistaken to do so. The United States and its European allies have made it clear that they want Mr. Milosevic ousted, and they have spent tens of millions of dollars trying to get it done. 
 Portraying himself as the defender of Yugoslavia's sovereignty against a hostile, hegemonic West led by Washington, Mr. Milosevic and his government argue that opposition leaders are merely the paid, traitorous tools of enemies who are continuing their war against him by other means. In March 1999, NATO began a 78-day bombing campaign to drive Serbian forces out of Kosovo.
The Yugoslav elections are on Sunday, but there has hardly been a day since the bombing began that state television news has not railed against "NATO aggressors."
With the campaign at its height, the government has spread its attacks to include all opposition political parties, independent newspapers, magazines and electronic media, the student organization known as Otpor -- or Resistance -- and any nongovernmental organization working to promote democracy, human rights or even economic reforms.
While Mr. Milosevic is trailing the main opposition leader, Vojislav Kostunica, in opinion polls, the anti-Western campaign is having an impact. The money from the West is going to most of the institutions that the government attacks for receiving it -- sometimes in direct aid, sometimes in indirect aid like computers and broadcasting equipment, and sometimes in suitcases of cash carried across the border between Yugoslavia and Hungary or Serbia and Montenegro. Most of those organizations and news media could not exist without foreign aid in this society, which is poor and repressive and whose market is distorted by foreign economic sanctions.
Even with foreign aid, government restrictions on newsprint supplies and high and repeated fines after suspiciously quick court cases make it hard for the independent news media to reach their natural market.
As for the opinion polls that show Mr. Kostunica in the lead, the information minister, Goran Matic, charges that the polls are orchestrated and manipulated by the Americans and the Central Intelligence Agency, who help pay for them. According to Mr. Matic, Mr. Milosevic is actually far ahead of Mr. Kostunica, and the polls simply serve as a vehicle for the opposition to claim that the government stole the election once Mr. Milosevic wins.
Mr. Matic asserts that the Atlantic alliance has come up with various scenarios, such as infiltrating soldiers wearing Yugoslav Army and police uniforms, to make it possible for the opposition to start civil unrest in the streets after the election while claiming that the police and the army are actually on their side.
Mr. Matic has attacked various nongovernmental organizations, including the Center for Free Elections and Democracy, which is trying to monitor the fairness of the election, as paid instruments of American and alliance policy. Many such organizations have been raided by the police, who confiscate computer files and also appear to be gathering evidence about foreign payments.
"President Milosevic will win this election," said Ljubisa Ristic, the president of the Yugolav United Left party, founded by Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic. "This is not Hollywood." Washington and the West, she said, "are like little kids, wanting something to happen so much they're fooling themselves."
Mr. Ristic said the alliance's war produced a new solidarity among Yugoslavs and "killed many illusions people had about the West and about their own opposition leaders, who went to the countries that were bombing us to seek their support."
The issues, Mr. Ristic said, are clear now. "It's a decisive time," he said. "This is not an election so much as a referendum, a decision on being an independent country or a colony. People see what's happened in Kosovo, what happens when NATO troops enter the country, and they are not going to allow the alliance's hand-picked candidates to win."
Even before the Kosovo war, the United States was spending up to $10 million a year to back opposition parties, independent news media and other institutions opposed to Mr. Milosevic. The war itself cost billions of dollars. This fiscal year, through September, the administration is spending $25 million to support Serbian "democratization," with an unknown amount of money spent covertly to help the failed rallies of last year, which did not bring down Mr. Milosevic, or to influence the current election. For next year, the administration is requesting $41.5 million in open aid to Serbian democratization, though Congress is likely to cut that request.
Independent journalists and broadcasters here have been told by American aid officials "not to worry about how much they're spending now," that plenty more is in the pipeline, said one knowledgable aid worker. Others in the opposition complain that the Americans are clumsy, sending e-mails from "state.gov" -- the State Department's address -- summoning people to impolitic meetings with American officials in Budapest, Montenegro or Dubrovnik, Croatia.
But there is little effort to disguise the fact that Western money pays for much of the polling, advertising, printing and other costs of the opposition political campaign -- one way, to be sure, to give opposition leaders a better chance to get their message across in a quasi-authoritarian system where television in particular is in the firm hands of the government.
While that spending allows the opposition to be heard more broadly, deepening the opposition to Mr. Milosevic, it also allows the government here to argue that it has real enemies, and that the Serbian opposition is in league with them.
Just today, in the state-run newspaper Politika, a long article used public information from the United States -- including Congressional testimony and Web site material -- to show that the United States is financing the opposition.
" 'Independent,' 'nongovernmental' and 'democratic' are the standard phrases the C.I.A. uses to describe organizations established all over the world to destroy the governments and the societies that the U.S. government wants to colonize and control," the paper wrote.
The Congressional testimony, from July 29, 1999, cited American officials then involved with Yugoslav policy, like Robert Gelbard and James Pardew, telling Senator Joseph Biden of Delaware about their projects. They describe the creation of a "ring around Serbia" of radio stations broadcasting into Serbia from Bosnia and Montenegro, the spending of $16.5 million in the previous two years to support "democratization in Serbia," and another $20 million to support Montenegro's president, Milo Djukanovic, who broke away from Mr. Milosevic in 1998.
The testimony listed some of the recipients of American aid here, including various newspapers, magazines, news agencies and broadcasters opposed to Mr. Milosevic, as well as various nongovernmental organizations engaged in legal defense and human rights and projects to bring promising Yugoslav journalists to the United States for professional training.
All such projects are portrayed by Politika and state television as a way to undermine the legal government, and the recipients are labeled traitors to their country.
Opposition leaders like Mr. Kostunica regard such tactics by the government as crass propaganda, but even he is skeptical of American intentions in paying for nongovernmental organizations, some of whom, he believes, are even unconsciously working for American imperial goals and not necessarily Serbian values.
Other democratic leaders, like Zoran Djindjic and Zarko Korac, regard such attacks as an indication of Mr. Milosevic's desperation and anxiety on the eve of the first election he is likely to lose in his entire political career. Given the stakes for Mr. Milosevic, they believe that he will do all he can, including the wholesale stealing of votes, to ensure a victory in the first round of voting.
"The stakes are fundamental for Milosevic," Mr. Korac said. "These elections are crucial, not necessarily for the immediate handover of power, but because for the first time Mr. Milosevic will be delegitimized in the eyes of his own people. He was an elected dictator, with popular and legal legitimacy. But from now on he's a true dictator, and he will only be able to rule by force -- that's a big step for Serbia."

HEADLINE: Sophie Davis, Executive and Philanthropist, Is Dead at 74

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Sophie Davis, a successful businesswoman whose backing helped create the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education at the City College of New York, died on Saturday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 74.
The cause was breast cancer, her son Alan said. 
 Mrs. Davis helped her husband. Leonard, found the Colonial Penn Group of insurance companies, and they gave millions of dollars to art, dance, music and Jewish philanthropic causes, including the Holocaust Museum in Washington.
But one project in which she took the most pride was the medical program at City College, which helps place economically disadvantaged students into medicine with the understanding that they will practice for at least two years in low-income communities.
Students in the seven-year accelerated medical degree program take three years of undergraduate work at City College, two years of medical training at Sophie Davis and their final two years at one of six cooperating medical schools, including New York University and SUNY/Downstate. The graduates are known as "Sophies."
The Davises' first gift, $1.2 million, to the school, which began as an experimental program, was given anonymously in 1972. Five years later, Mrs. Davis agreed to have her name attached to the school.
When the school gave her an honorary degree at that time, she brought a phalanx of friends and relatives to the ceremony to see her in her academic cap and gown; she had dropped out of City College to get married.
Mrs. Davis was born in 1926 in the Bronx to Isadore and Esther Kesten, immigrants from Minsk, Russia. After skipping a grade in high school, she attended City College at night; there she studied accounting and met Leonard Davis, whom she married in 1945. He survives her.
In addition to her husband and her son Alan, of San Francisco, Mrs. Davis is survived by another son, Michael, of Belvedere, Calif., and four grandchildren.
While Mr. Davis worked as an accountant and later in the insurance business, Mrs. Davis worked at his side, organizing the office, handling the bookkeeping and serving as his sounding board. She was also a director of the Colonial Penn Group, which they founded in 1963, until they sold it in 1984.
"I always discussed everything with her," Mr. Davis said. "We made the decisions jointly, based on which one of us felt the strongest. Sometimes we had to figure out which of us that was."
He said that the company avoided borrowing money, for example, because Mrs. Davis violently opposed it.
But he prevailed on the issue of buying a magazine that later merged with Modern Maturity, the magazine of the AARP, which he helped found. "She was opposed, and she got the other senior members of my staff to oppose it, too," Mr. Davis recalled. "But I felt very strongly about it, so we bought it."
The Sophie Davis medical school was one of many projects the couple supported at City College. They also provided funds for a performing arts center, Aaron Davis Hall, named after Mr. Davis's father. Mrs. Davis helped choose some of the resident performers, and she and her husband often entertained them after performances.
As the Davises began to spend more and more time in Palm Beach (although they kept their Fifth Avenue apartment), they played a similar role as impresarios, establishing the Regional Arts Foundation, with Mrs. Davis as president, in the early 1970's. The foundation brought performers like Isaac Stern, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and the New York City Ballet to southern Florida, then considered by some a cultural wasteland.
"She felt a responsibility to bring music and dance to this area," said Judith Mitchell, chief executive of the Kravis Center for the Performing Arts in West Palm Beach, which took over the performance series in 1994.
The Davises also became involved with the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach. Mrs. Davis served as a trustee and spearheaded the drive to build a new wing.
But even from Florida, she kept in touch with the medical school named after her. She and her husband gave the school another $2 million for an endowed scholarship fund in their names. And last year, when she attended the graduation ceremony, the students stood up and started chanting her name: "Sophie! Sophie! Sophie!"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Honda Warns the Owners Of Over 500,000 Vehicles

BYLINE: By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company today became the third major Japanese company in the last month to issue an extensive product recall, warning owners of 551,924 vehicles that they might have potential oil leaks or audio wiring flaws that could cause fires.
The recall was announced against a background of heightened sensitivity in corporate Japan about defective products. Earlier this month, the Transport Ministry punished the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation for systematically concealing consumer complaints about its cars and trucks for more than 20 years. 
 Honda said the recall had no relation to Mitsubishi's scandal, which resulted in the recall of one million Mitsubishi vehicles. "It's just that the timing of the announcement came at this moment," Honda said through a spokesman. "It's best to do it fast, but we had to study and assess the case before submitting it."
Honda, the No. 2 Japanese automaker behind Toyota Motor, said the recall affected vehicles sold mostly in Japan but included some Accord models sold in the United States.
The company said wiring in audio equipment supplied by Alpine Electronics for 320,710 of its 1991-97 models that include the Accord, Prelude and Legend could overheat and cause speakers to ignite. Eleven instances of flare-ups or burning had been reported since June but no deaths or injuries.
Honda said a defective oil seal that could cause leaks affected 231,214 of its 1993-95 models that include the Odyssey minivan and the Accord. No deaths or injuries were associated with the problem.
Recalls are considered particularly embarrassing to Japanese manufacturers, historically known for their quality products.
Automotive recalls in particular have been rising in Japan for years. According to the Ministry of Transport, there were 45 recalls in 1995 involving 150,000 vehicles. By last year, there were 132 recalls affecting 1.85 million vehicles.
Takaki Nakanishi, an automobile analyst with Merrill Lynch in Tokyo, said the growth in recalls also reflected efforts by manufacturers to cut costs. "They may use the most economic materials or cut certain phases of physical tests," he said. The surge in recalls, he said, "are the flip side of the coin."

HEADLINE: Autumn of Teachers' Discontent Is Dawning

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Minutes before the fourth-period bell rang, Kathy Aborn, a computer sciences teacher at East Boston High, laid into school district officials about their contract offer, saying the city's teachers were dead serious in threatening to go on strike next month.
"I think their offer is pitiful," she said. "They're trying to take away the few extra privileges we have." 
 Ms. Aborn complained that the school district wanted to eliminate many of the privileges that the most senior teachers had in choosing where they taught and had proposed a wage increase of less than 10 percent over three years. She says teacher salaries have lagged far behind those of other professionals.
Tensions are running so high that Boston's 6,500 public schoolteachers narrowly defeated a motion to go on strike on the first day of school. Instead, they set Oct. 11 as a strike deadline and adopted a "work to rule" strategy that calls for doing nothing beyond what the contract specifically requires.
"I would say teachers are the angriest I've ever seen them," said Edward Doherty, president of the Boston Teachers Union.
But the anger, part of which may well be a negotiating tactic, is not limited to Boston. It is a tense autumn in school districts across the nation, including in three of the nation's largest cities, New York, Los Angeles and Philadelphia, where teachers' contracts have expired or are about to expire.
Teachers, feeling left behind by the economic boom and emboldened by the teacher shortage, are pushing for large raises. School boards, swept up in the nationwide push for educational reform, are pushing back, demanding far-reaching changes to improve performance, including merit pay, longer school days and an end to seniority.
In Buffalo, 4,000 teachers went on strike for two days, while 21,000 Philadelphia teachers are threatening a walkout later this week. In Los Angeles, teachers have also warned of strikes if negotiations break off, while in New York City, the 80,000-member teachers' union is already holding demonstrations, even though its contract does not expire until November.
There have been teacher strikes in half a dozen smaller communities, including Hamilton, N.J., Punxsutawney, Pa., and Richmond Heights, Ohio. While there are fewer strikes this fall than was the case a decade ago, this is largely because state officials have made clear to teacher leaders that they will be jailed or fined if they spearhead strikes.
Teachers say that the nature of the negotiations is more complex than in many previous rounds. In New York, Philadelphia, Boston and Los Angeles, officials are seeking large-scale change in the face of louder and louder calls for charter schools and vouchers. As a result, while negotiations in the 1990's often focused on details like whether a raise should average 2 percent a year or 2.5 percent, this time around school officials have more ambitious goals.
In New York, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed that teachers be paid based on the test results of the students in their classrooms. In Philadelphia, the school board is also demanding performance-based merit pay, adding 75 minutes to each school day, adding five days to each school year, and getting rid of some of the seniority preferences that base school staffing not on what a principal thinks is best, but on how much seniority a teacher has.
"Some of the reforms that bear on teachers are beginning to gain some traction on the ground, and teachers' organizations don't like that at all," said Chester E. Finn Jr., an education expert at the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research organization.
Many teachers say that after they accepted salary freezes or low pay increases during times of recession and budget deficits, in today's prosperous times, negotiations should focus on giving teachers large raises and increasing starting salaries, usually just above $30,000, to attract the two million new teachers the nation will need over the next decade.
Sandra Feldman, president of the million-member American Federation of Teachers, said, "I think you're seeing teachers feeling that they're being totally left out in a period when the economy is booming and when there are surpluses at every level of government, when demands on them are greater than ever and when they go to the bargaining table, all anybody wants to talk about is merit pay."
"It's like everything we won over the years they just want to take it away," said Marie Ann Adduci, a first-grade teacher at William E. Russell Grammar School in Boston's blue-collar Dorchester neighborhood.
The teachers at that school, cited last year as one of Boston's best, say they are angry that after putting in so many extra hours to improve the school, the school district wants to place restrictions on their daily preparation time and add up to 30 extra hours onto their school year.
"On the Richter scale, I'd say the tensions are about an 8," said Jim Fay, an elementary school math teacher for the past 31 years. "A lot of teachers feel funny that their children in their entry-level jobs are earning twice what they do."
Thomas W. Payzant, superintendent of Boston's schools, said his negotiating goals were not to squeeze teachers but to improve education. And he and several other school officials acknowledged that if they wanted to persuade state legislatures to increase financing for their financially strapped districts, they needed to push for some of the changes that legislators wanted.
"There is great pressure on public schools here and across the country to improve, and that means we've got to focus on the things we do well and change those things we don't do well," Mr. Payzant said. "We have to find a way to be flexible and nimble in schools to compete with charter schools and those who are advocating vouchers."
For example, he said loosening seniority rules would make it easier for principals to assemble a faculty that they believed to be most appropriate for their schools.
Pedro Ramos, president of the Philadelphia School Board, said: "This isn't just about modifying 35 years of work rules. This is about the future of public education in Philadelphia. We know that if all we do is keep the status quo, the school district will not survive financially or academically."

LENGTH: 1558 words

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: All the World's a Campus;
Top Business Schools Have No Borders

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The University of Chicago's newest classroom building seems like a riddle unto itself.
It is not actually new; it originally opened in 1885. It features not gargoyles and spires, as the university's neo-Gothic campus does, but gold-plated carvings and hand-painted tiles. And it is not anywhere near Chicago. In fact, it sits directly across the street from the offices of the current president of Singapore. 
 But sure enough, some 84 students filed into the building -- a former plantation house owned by a Chinese spice merchant who lived in Singapore -- this week to start a two-year M.B.A program that is part of Chicago's Graduate School of Business. The students, mostly executives in their 30's, represent the new campus's first class, and they personify the expansionist dreams of the best-known American business schools.
Imitating the companies they study, some of the business schools are spending millions of dollars to set up satellite operations around the globe. The schools' rationale for expansion mimics the goals of international companies as well: they hope to find new sources of revenue, establish a brand name in far-away places and learn lessons about how other markets function.
Chicago's Singapore building is modeled after one in Barcelona that the school built in the 1990's. Last month, Duke began offering classes in Frankfurt and will open a campus there in January. The Harvard Business School has set up research centers in Hong Kong and Buenos Aires and plans to add another in Europe. Northwestern and the University of Pennsylvania are collaborating with McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, to create the Indian School of Business in Hyderabad next year.
Some of Europe's top schools have undertaken similar initiatives. The London Business School and Columbia are accepting applications for the first class of an M.B.A. program they will jointly run. Meanwhile, not far from Chicago's Singapore campus, Insead, a 40-year-old business school based in Fontainebleau, France, opened its own M.B.A. program at the start of 2000.
"If you're going to be a major business school," said Gary D. Eppen, a deputy dean at Chicago who oversees the Singapore program, "we think it's important that you be represented in the major economic cities of the world."
Much of the activity is in Asia, where there is no internationally known M.B.A. program but where thousands of students want the degree. "There's going to be a great talent pool to tap," said Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, who sits on the advisory board of the Indian School of Business along with the top executives of DaimlerChrysler, GE Capital, Royal Dutch/Shell and other large companies.
"These economies are changing rapidly, and we all need business leaders who understand the dynamics of technology-driven global marketplaces within the context of their own business realties," Mr. Paulson said.
For the universities, the new campuses also represent one of the most elaborate experiments yet undertaken in so-called distance learning -- the use of the Internet to teach classes. The new M.B.A. programs are something of a middle ground between traditional on-campus courses of study, which require students to live near one another and their professors, and the less expensive online-only degrees now being offered by for-profit schools like Jones International University.
Instead, at most of the foreign outposts, students spend a week or two studying with professors who have flown in from the home campus to teach them. They then take about a month off from classes, return to their jobs and do homework at night and over the weekend. They use e-mail to bounce ideas off one another and to pose questions to teachers living thousands of miles away.
In essence, the schools are betting that there is a substantial number of managers in other countries who are willing to pay a large premium to receive a prestigious American degree, rather than attending a local school that awards M.B.A.'s.
Jeanette Wong is a typical customer. A native of Singapore who has worked for J. P. Morgan the last 14 years, she runs its office there and helps manage its foreign exchange, bond and other markets-oriented businesses. But Ms. Wong still thought she needed the kind of detailed training that rarely comes on the job.
"The world is changing so fast," she said. "I'm looking for fresh insights."
Given her experience, she was not sure she would learn enough at any of Singapore's local M.B.A. programs to justify the time it would take to earn the degree. Traveling to Hong Kong or another city for a part-time program was out of the question, she added, because she and her husband have 10- and 12-year-old sons.
So Ms. Wong applied to the first class of Chicago's new program -- largely because of the school's reputation for quantitative rigor, she said -- and is paying out of her own pocket $65,000 for the two-year program. The tuition is more than twice what another program in Singapore would have cost, she said.
Yet in contrast to students in those other programs, Ms. Wong will have only limited access to her teachers. Once every six weeks, two Chicago professors will fly to Singapore to teach five days of intensive classes in marketing or finance and then return to the United States.
That schedule, which is similar to Chicago's in Barcelona and Duke's in Frankfurt, contains potential problems for both the students and faculty members. The students will have much less of an opportunity to have impromptu discussions with their teachers -- and each other -- than they would at a full-time program. Schools, meanwhile, have to convince their professors to fly halfway around the world every year to keep the programs afloat. Otherwise, they must rely on part-time teachers and can no longer credibly say that the programs are similar to the American versions.
The programs can become a large new revenue stream for the schools, however. Because companies often pay the tuition bills for their executives, business schools are sometimes able to charge considerably more for part-time programs than they do for full-time programs.
Deans say most of the difference covers additional lodging and technology costs. Still, the numbers can quickly become attractive for academic institutions with modest budgets. For example, Duke will take in about $15 million this year solely from the students in its two international programs, one that meets both in Frankfurt and on the Duke campus in Durham, N.C., and the other that meets in several cities around the world over two years.
There are intangible benefits, too, deans say.
In the United States, the combination of a strong economy and a relatively small number of people in their 20's has caused applications to full-time M.B.A. programs to drop at most top schools the last two years. Without the continuing boom in foreign applicants, particularly from Asia, the drop would be even steeper. By building campuses overseas, the schools tap new pools of students who do not want to move to the United States for a full-time M.B.A. program and also broadcast their names to those who are considering a move.
In addition, the new programs force faculty members to put their research in the context of another country. "We can't just take our notes and use them in Europe or Asia without any changes," said Robert S. Hamada, Chicago's dean.
This is not the first time that business schools have looked overseas. About a decade ago, as students and corporate executives were criticizing M.B.A. programs as too focused on the United States, some schools began offering classes abroad, too.
One of the first was the University of Michigan, which began teaching M.B.A. classes in Hong Kong in 1991. It limited enrollment to the executives of a small group of companies that had agreed to support the program. Other schools, like Northwestern, have signed partnerships with foreign schools and award degrees jointly. But the Asian financial crisis delayed some of the most expensive projects, like Chicago's Singapore campus.
Arguably the most ambitious of the current round of efforts is the Indian School of Business. Conceived by Rajat Gupta, a native of India who is McKinsey's managing director, the school plans to open next year in Hyderabad, a technology-heavy city in the south-central part of the country.
The program will last one year and, unlike the Chicago and Duke programs, and will require students to quit their jobs to enroll full time. For faculty, the Indian school will rely on other universities -- mainly Northwestern and Pennsylvania -- for half of its teachers and hire its own professors for the other half.
Tapping the local talent pool helps solve one of the biggest problems facing the globalization of the American business school: a decided lack of wanderlust on the part of some research-minded professors. "The main challenge is how do you get your faculty to go to these locales year after year," said Russ Winter, a professor of marketing at the University of California at Berkeley's Haas School of Business, who is on a committee now trying to decide whether the school should start a program in Asia. "Two weeks or three weeks in a foreign locale is not conducive to research productivity."

HEADLINE: Mayor Disputes Threat From Lack of Space

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that an article in The New York Times yesterday was unfair to New York because it created an impression that the city's future economic growth was imperiled by a shortage of office space.
The article said that a severe lack of office space was posing a challenge to the city's ability to retain companies and attract new businesses. Although Mr. Giuliani did not dispute any facts in the article, he said during a news conference that the city's growth was not in danger. 
 "Since I've been in office, there've been 27 projects totaling 25.5 million square feet of new office space completed or under way," the mayor said. He added that the amount of office space created in New Jersey for Manhattan businesses moving across the Hudson River was minuscule compared with new construction under way in New York City.
"Yes, there's growth in New Jersey," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's a healthy thing. We can't handle everything. We have limited space. And at this point there are some people who feel we're too crowded in terms of the number of buildings we have, the office space we have, and what we're producing for our economy. And our economy is doing better than it's been doing in about 40 years.
"However, the article also gives the impression that we're not staying ahead of the curve," he added. "That also is not true."

HEADLINE: Judges' Group Opposes Bill to Limit Seminar Participation

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The judges who set policy for the federal court system voted today to oppose new limits on the ability of judges to attend privately sponsored seminars and educational programs.
The vote by the Judicial Conference of the United States, a 27-member group that held its semiannual meeting at the Supreme Court today, came in response to a recent Senate bill to prohibit federal judges from accepting "anything of value" -- meaning reimbursement of expenses -- "in connection with a seminar." 
 Such a ban was "overly broad" and raised "potential constitutional issues," including the prospect of government censorship, the Judicial Conference said in a resolution adopted during its regular closed session. The resolution said the bill, sponsored by two Democratic senators, John Kerry of Massachusetts and Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin, could have the unintended effect of keeping judges from taking part in programs of bar associations and law schools.
The two senators introduced the bill on July 27 after a report by Community Rights Counsel, a public interest law firm here, criticized federal judges for attending expense-paid seminars on economic and environmental issues sponsored by private groups that oppose much government regulation. The bill would increase financing for the Federal Judicial Center, an arm of the court system that conducts research and training, to reimburse judges for the expense of attending seminars conducted in a manner that maintains "the public's confidence in an unbiased and fair-minded judiciary."
At a news conference today at the Supreme Court, Chief Judge Ralph K. Winter Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, said the bill would require the center to examine not only the content and source of money for all seminars but also the "litigation activities" of the sponsor and anyone on the program.
Judge Winter, the chairman of the Judicial Conference's executive committee, said the proposal appeared to call for "explicit content regulation," which would "very much alter the institutional role of the Federal Judicial Center" and impose "a very draconian ban in one of the most sensitive areas of our public life, the marketplace of ideas."
In a report accompanying the resolution, the executive committee said the bill was a hasty and "inappropriate response to a highly complex question" that Congress should not address without holding hearings and inviting public participation. "This is not a time for hasty legislation that may well be more dangerous than the concerns it is designed to allay," it said.
Judge Winter also said the Judicial Conference would not necessarily oppose all Congressional intervention but that the judges could not respond to proposals that had not been made.
The Judicial Conference concluded two years ago that judges should not participate in seminars if the sponsors or underwriters were involved or likely to be involved in litigation. Judges are required to report reimbursements as gifts on their annual financial disclosure forms.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Nasdaq Increases Sharply In a Technology Rebound
Technology stocks, under pressure for much of September, moved sharply higher, driving the Nasdaq composite index to its biggest one-day gain in more than three months. A good day in the bond market and a dip in oil prices provided a positive backdrop for stocks.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 139.12 points, or 3.7 percent, to 3,865.64. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.39 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,459.90, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.23 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,789.29. Page C10. 

More Deaths Are Cited in Tire Case
Federal regulators said that since Aug. 31 they had received complaints of 15 more deaths attributed to Firestone tires on sport utility vehicles and pickups, raising to 103 the number of deaths under review. But officials cautioned that they had not determined how many of the complaints involved tires that had failed. C2.
 
Sun to Buy Web Appliance Maker
Sun Microsystems said that it had agreed to acquire Cobalt Networks, which produces Web appliances, in a stock swap valued at $2 billion. Acquiring Cobalt lets Sun address a fast-growing portion of the market that could not be reached readily with its own typically more expensive and more complex products. Shares of Sun gained $2.44, to $117.69, while Cobalt increased $16.06, or nearly 40 percent, to $57.19. C9.
 
U.S. Antitrust Chief to Step Down
Joel I. Klein, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division and chief architect of the government's case against Microsoft, announced that he would step down. C2.
 
Ads Bolster Retail Sales of Drugs
Advertising to consumers has stimulated a surge in retail spending on prescription drugs, the fastest-growing item in the nation's health care budget, a new study says. A18.
 
Concessions Made for Joint Venture
Time Warner and EMI Group proposed what they called "substantial" concessions that might include selling some of their record labels in an effort to keep European regulators from blocking their plan to merge their music businesses into a joint venture. C9.
 
Japan Prepares Spending Package
Japan is preparing another package of supplemental spending aimed at propping up the economy, which has failed to gain enough momentum on its own despite several previous injections of money. C4.
 
American Works the Puzzle of China
Being the general manager of Xerox's operations in China has required Howard Holley to make adjustments in the way he does business. But the business challenges are no greater than other puzzles he has faced there. Shanghai consistently exceeds expectations, he says. It's a city of dichotomies -- the extremes of China all rolled into one. He relishes the challenge. The Boss. C8.
 
Death on Plane Ruled a Homicide
A passenger who tried to break into the cockpit during a Southwest Airlines flight was killed by passengers who restrained him, and not by a heart attack, as had been reported. A medical examiner ruled the death a homicide, but the authorities decided that there was no evidence of criminal intent and declined to bring charges. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C5.
 
Price of E-Book Device Set at $300
Thomson Multimedia has priced its hand-held devices for reading electronic books. At about $300, they are unlikely to speed the adoption of e-books by the mass market. C5.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE REPUBLICANS
 
BRASS FOR BUSH
Gov. George W. Bush, who has sharply criticized the Clinton administration's defense policies, has picked up the endorsement of several retired military leaders, including senior officers who served in influential positions under President Clinton. The list, to be announced today by Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, in Lancaster, Calif., includes Adm. Jay L. Johnson, who stepped down as the Navy's top admiral in July, and Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf, who also retired this summer. Others include two former commandants of the Marine Corps, Gen. Charles C. Krulak and Gen. Carl Mundy Jr.; and two former chiefs of the Air Force, Gen. Ronald R. Fogelman and Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, all of whom served under President Clinton. The officers are part of a new group called "Veterans for Bush-Cheney." Steven Lee Myers (NYT) 

THE RUNNING MATES
 
RUNNING FOR ECONOMIST
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said yesterday that Gov. George W. Bush showed a flawed understanding of the national economy when he said this week that he would not retreat from a tax cut in the middle of a recession but would cut even more, even at the risk of creating a "short-term deficit." That approach might worsen a recession, Mr. Lieberman said at a campaign stop in Fresno, Calif. "We can't afford that," he declared. "Deficits lead to higher interest rates, and what does that mean? Higher mortgage payments. Higher car payments. Higher student loan payments." He predicted that Mr. Bush's plan for a $1.3 billion tax cuts over the next decade would lead to deficits and noted that even Republican leaders in Congress had not advocated so large a cut. Vice President Al Gore has proposed a $500 million package of tax cuts. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT)
 
SEE DICK RUN. SEE DICK FISH.
Dick Cheney is an avid, even fanatical, fly fisherman. His Secret Service code name is Angler. On the stump he often talks wistfully about forgoing the fall fishing season in order to campaign for the vice presidency. So he looked more than pleased on Monday when he took a break from policy speeches and led his entourage and motorcade to Kaufmann's Fly Fishing, just outside Portland, Ore. After looking over the fly boxes, $600 rods and all-weather gear, he picked up a rod and reel and headed out to the parking lot to show off a few graceful casts, nearly landing a television camera crew. Then he headed back to dry reality, a Chamber of Commerce speech. Michael Cooper (NYT)
 
THE HOUSE
 
TAKE MY MONEY, PLEASE
Sometimes candidates raise more campaign cash than they can use and start giving the excess to candidates who have come up short. So when Representative Peter R. Deutsch, a four-term Democrat from Florida's 20th Congressional District, at the tip end of the state, offered to give some excess cash to the Democratic National Committee to help elect Al Gore, there was no great surprise. He had almost $2.5 million in his kitty and essentially no place to spend it because his only challenger in November is a write-in candidate, Ed Kopanski of Key West. Besides, Mr. Gore is scrambling hard to snatch Florida away from Gov. George W. Bush, whose brother Jeb is the state's governor. Then the check came in, for a whopping $250,000. Democratic fund-raisers say the contribution may be the largest of its kind ever from a member of Congress to a national campaign. Mr. Deutsch, who campaigned for Mr. Gore during the primary season and held a fund-raiser for him in April that pulled in more than $400,000, says he sent in his big check because while the Gore-Lieberman ticket has made good progress in recent weeks, it still lags in fund-raising. (NYT)
 
THE GREEN PARTY
 
NOT WORRIED ABOUT SOCIAL SECURITY
Ralph Nader said yesterday that the Social Security retirement program is sound and all those cries of crisis by other presidential candidates are nothing but political propaganda that is needlessly scaring voters. "The idea that Social Security is going to run out of money is simply nonsense," he told reporters in Washington yesterday. "Panic fueled by opportunistic politicians and investment firms poses the only serious threat to the program." He derided suggestions that the country consider privatizing all or parts of the program or financing it with money from other government programs and sources. The plan as is will pay reasonable benefits at least for the next half-century if the economy stays healthy, he said, adding that any unlikely shortages that might crop up could be handled by taxing things like stock transactions, options and executive bonuses. He then proposed increasing benefits for widows and low-income workers. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: OPENING TO CHINA: NEWS ANALYSIS;
New Realism Wins the Day

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Senate's overwhelming vote today to give permanent trade benefits to China ended a clash between America's global economic interests and the notion that the United States could use the annual threat of trade sanctions to change Beijing's behavior.
In the end, it wasn't even close -- and behind that lies a new reality in how the United States deals with China, the world's most populous nation. 
 Despite the huge margin by which President Clinton won today -- 83 to 15, his biggest legislative victory in the foreign policy arena since the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993 -- the reversal of policy toward China cemented into law today was hardly assured, given all the impediments over the years.
During the last four years alone, it looked like the effort to normalize trade relations could be derailed by allegations of Chinese meddling in American elections, by accusations that Chinese spies had stolen American nuclear secrets, by considerable evidence that China still ships missiles to Pakistan, by Chinese threats against Taiwan.
Indeed, the measure passed today despite the State Department's recent conclusion that China's human rights violations have, if anything, grown more egregious this year. And it passed precisely seven weeks before a presidential election, even though labor unions viewed the accord as a threat to their jobs and strongly hinted that they would punish Democrats who supported it.
Yet every time a crisis erupted and receded, China's economic and political role in the world seemed to loom ever larger, from Motorola plants in Illinois to farms in Iowa. Over time it became clear that Congress' periodic threat that it would refuse to renew China's annual trade status was empty, and the Chinese came to dismiss it as saber-rattling.
Meanwhile, American business became more energized about stabilizing the economic relationship with China -- and therefore preserving their ballooning investments there -- than on any other issue in recent legislative history.
So today senators of every stripe ended up voting for the trade bill. That included Fred Thompson, the Republican from Tennessee who conducted the campaign finance investigation and last week derided the "little people" in the business community who "need to be taken down a notch" because they orchestrated the defeat of an amendment to the trade bill that would have punished China for the spread of arms.
Now, though, the hard part starts.
Arguments still rage about whether the North American Free Trade Agreement helped or hurt the booming American economy. In the case of China, the facts are different: all the trade concessions were on China's part, the price of entering the World Trade Organization. Nonetheless, it can be expected that China will begin to drag its heels on carrying them out, for fear that letting in American steel will wipe out huge state-owned industries or letting in Japanese and American cars will threaten China's efforts to become the next industrial behemoth.
But the real test will come as America tries to use its deepening trade relationship as leverage to open China's political system.
Mr. Clinton won the battle over trade with China by first convincing himself, and then helping convince Congress, that rejecting normal economic ties with the world's most populous country would hurt the American economy, and benefit Japanese and European competitors. Then he gradually elevated the argument from the economic to the strategic, making the case that rejection would also help political hard-liners in China who are certain that America's real agenda is to contain growing Chinese power.
"The argument that made the difference in the Yellow Oval Room had to do with what happens if this didn't pass," said Samuel R. Berger, the president's national security adviser, referring to the room in the White House residence where Mr. Clinton twisted arms. "We would undermine China's reforms, scare the daylights out of our allies, and send a message to the world that at the pinnacle of our power we are in retreat."
Mr. Clinton today celebrated his victory with a line he used often during those nighttime sales pitches, telling reporters this afternoon, "We will find, I believe, that America has more influence in China with an outstretched hand than with a clenched fist."
And in the next breath, as eager as always to repair the breach with unions and environmentalists and others who believe they were sold out by the White House, he insisted that opening China to more commerce with shrink the control of the government. "It will strengthen those within China who fight for higher labor standards, a cleaner environment, for human rights and the rule of law," he said. Maybe he will be proven right, maybe not -- it will be years, maybe decades, before anyone can judge. As Mr. Clinton himself acknowledged today, "none of us should think for a moment that any of these outcomes are guaranteed."
But what makes the experiment interesting is that only eight years ago both the Congress and Mr. Clinton were headed in precisely the opposite direction.
In 1992, when memories of the 1989 Tiananmen massacre were still vivid, Congress made the annual renewal of China's trading rights conditional on a range of changes in Beijing. President Bush vetoed the measure. The Senate fell just short of the two-thirds vote needed to override him -- which would have essentially terminated China's trading privileges with the United States -- by a vote of 60 to 38.
Within months, Mr. Clinton was charging Mr. Bush with "coddling dictators." It was not until he arrived in the White House, and spent a year unsuccessfully trying to link trade with China's human rights record, that Mr. Clinton ended a fierce fight within the White House and reversed himself. He became a passionate adherent of Mr. Bush's policy -- and took it several steps further.
"This was a case where Clinton's new position gathered momentum slowly," said Lee Hamilton, the former Indiana congressman who spent much of his career dealing with China issues. "Tiananmen seems like a long time ago. Then the business interests started lobbying this very hard. And good economic times have been a factor: People are now persuaded that trade has a lot to do with our prosperity."
But not everyone is persuaded -- not by a long shot. Those who voted "no" included a hardy band of China's strongest critics on the left and right, liberals like Paul Wellstone, the Minnesota Democrat, and Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Then there were the disillusioned, but resigned, human rights advocates. Mike Jendrzejczyk, a top official of Human Rights Watch, noted that the timing of the vote "is particularly unfortunate, just as human rights conditions are worsening."
"Beijing is closing down all channels of political dissent -- including the Internet," he added, "even while it is opening its economy."
Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, who finished the 13-year negotiations with China over the rules under which it would enter the World Trade Organization, said in an interview this week that she learned two major lessons from the roller-coaster effort to negotiate the huge accord.
"The first is that you need an economic agreement whose advantages are beyond any doubt," she said. In fact, one of the differences between this debate and the arguments over the North American trade pact is that few, save for the most ardent union leaders, argued that the China trade deal would send American jobs overseas. ("No one ever made that case to me," Mr. Berger said. "I was amazed.")
But the second argument, Ms. Barshefsky said, is that, "You can only get trade agreements this big if you put them in a broader security framework, and link it to the security of the United States, or peace in Asia." That, of course, is the hallmark of Mr. Clinton's foreign policy: The linkage of trade to broader diplomatic goals. Essentially, he is betting that China cannot open its markets without also opening its political system. It cannot let in Amazon.com, he believes, without also letting any Dissidents.org broadcast their message around China. The Chinese leaders also believe that their entry into the W.T.O. will bring about change, ushering in foreign technology and foreign capital. But they think it is change they can manage and control.
Today's vote has cemented in place the Clinton imprint on American foreign policy, the use of economic engagement to foster political change. But the judgment about whether he has created a second opening to China depends, in the end, on what China's leaders do with the economic and political opportunity.
