HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Play of the Weak

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Alas, poor euro! Europe's new currency, proudly introduced less than two years ago at a value of $1.17, has fallen to a humiliating 85 cents. And things look rotten in the state of Denmark, where next week's referendum -- to be or not to be part of European monetary union, that is the question -- looks likely to result in defeat for the pro-euro forces.
Over the weekend, when finance ministers from the major industrial nations meet in Prague, the slumping euro will surely dominate the discussion. Europeans would very much like the United States to join them in intervening -- that is, buying euros and selling dollars -- to drive up the euro's value. By all accounts, America won't go along. But it should. 
 Let me admit that I have come around to this view only with great reluctance. As a general rule, big economies like the United States or the European Union can and should be relaxed about fluctuations in exchange rates; I regarded the wailing as the euro sank from $1.17 to $1 as much ado about nothing. Furthermore, attempts to manipulate currencies through intervention have a bad track record; they usually fail, and when they fail the currency and the credibility of the government plunge in tandem. (Prime Minister John Major tried to prop up Britain's pound in 1992; the embarrassing failure of that attempt is one of the main reasons Tony Blair is prime minister today.)
But there are times when general rules don't apply, and this looks like one of them. Yesterday Michael Mussa, chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, put it this way: "Circumstances for intervention are very rare, but they do arise. One has to ask, if not now, when?" Indeed.
Why is intervention usually a bad idea? Because foreign exchange markets are immense -- so immense that even a huge government intervention will be blown away if it tries to stand in the way of firmly held market sentiment. The Major government threw some $50 billion into the defense of the pound in 1992; the market, convinced that the pound had nowhere to go but down, swallowed that sum with hardly a burp, and the pound kept falling.
But sometimes a run on a currency is driven not so much by economic fundamentals as by herd mentality. When the herd is running, there is a case for what people at the Fed call "slap in the face" intervention. Basically, by ostentatiously buying a currency that is plunging for no good reason, the authorities pull investors up short, forcing them to consider if they really want to bet against the finance ministries and the central banks. If all goes well the market in effect shakes its head, says "Thanks -- I needed that," and returns to its senses.
And the fall in the euro now looks very much like herd behavior. To justify the euro's current weakness you have to believe not only that America's "new economy" will keep delivering spectacular growth indefinitely, but that Europe will never experience a comparable surge of its own. And that just isn't plausible. The extraordinary weakness of the euro is possible only because investors, focused on the short term, have stopped thinking about tomorrow -- or maybe the day after tomorrow. That's exactly the kind of situation in which intervention is likely to succeed -- but probably only if the United States joins in.
Should we take that risk? No question, there are risks: The intervention might fail, damaging our own credibility; or it might succeed too well, sending the dollar into free fall. But there are also risks in not intervening.
America, after all, has some direct interest in seeing a more reasonable euro: the weakness in Europe's currency has reached the point where it is starting to hurt the bottom line of the many U.S. corporations for whom Europe is an important market. But the really compelling reason to help Europe now is to set a precedent. Despite its shambolic start, the euro is not going to vanish -- indeed, it will be one of the world's two great currencies in the years ahead. And while it may seem hard to imagine in these days of the almighty dollar, there will someday come a time when we would like the Europeans to support our currency. Let's do unto others now as we would have them do unto us then.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate: For Skyscraper Museum, A Home at Ground Level;
Space Donated in Battery Park City Tower

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The Skyscraper Museum finally has a skyscraper to call its own.
Since 1997, in exhibitions, books, lectures and Web pages, the museum has chronicled buildings: old buildings and new buildings, famous buildings and common buildings, razed buildings and planned buildings, slender buildings and jumbo buildings. 
 Only one thing has been missing. A building.
Without a permanent home, the embryonic institution has bounced from 44 Wall Street to 16 Wall Street to 110 Maiden Lane (its last whereabouts as of yesterday evening), depending on the kindness of landlords and the brief availability of empty retail space for temporary rent-free quarters.
So it was with particular satisfaction that Carol Willis, the founding director of the Skyscraper Museum, bicycled up to the curving concrete shell of the 38-story Ritz-Carlton hotel and condominium apartment tower, now rising at Battery Park City, and pointed to the ground-floor space.
"This is my corner right here," Ms. Willis said.
At least it will be late next year, when the museum opens, a month or so after the completion of the $200 million Ritz-Carlton project, developed by Millennium Partners on a 70-year land lease from the Battery Park City Authority.
Through Philip E. Arons, a principal in Millennium and a museum board member, the developers will donate 5,800 square feet to the Skyscraper Museum, space that Mr. Arons estimated would be worth $3 million were it put to retail use.
Bidders for the hotel site, the southernmost parcel on the 92-acre Battery Park City landfill, were encouraged by the authority to include a public amenity in their plans.
"One of the reasons Millennium Partners were selected was because of their partnering with the museum," said Timothy S. Carey, president and chief executive of the authority. "We're in essence creating a museum district."
Directly across Battery Place from the site of the Skyscraper Museum is the Museum of Jewish Heritage: A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, which opened in 1997 and is planning an addition. One block north, Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed the Museum of Women: The Leadership Center. The authority will request development proposals for that site early next year, Mr. Carey said.
Battery Park City was not what Ms. Willis had in mind when she asked Mr. Arons to join the board. She met him in the 1980's when he and her husband, Mark A. Willis, worked in the Koch administration. And she admired the developer's interest in the arts.
One day in 1997, she recalled, Mr. Arons telephoned. "He said: 'Hi, Carol. I'm putting the museum in my proposal for Battery Park City. Is that O.K.?' Of course, he knew it would be. It was that simple."
But there is nothing simple about trying to tell the towering story of the skyscraper in space the size of a bistro or a duty-free shop.
That challenge led Roger F. Duffy, an architect in Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, to propose what may be the museum's most striking feature: polished stainless-steel floors and ceilings, a vertical hall of mirrors. Because the display cases will be flush with both surfaces, they will appear to extend limitlessly overhead and under foot; reflection in reflection in reflection.
"Skyscrapers are always getting bigger, taller, higher," Mr. Duffy said. "Our reflection gives you infinity. There's nothing bigger than that. The vitrines that house the artifacts also become skyscrapers of improbable proportion and infinite height."
To keep the ceiling surface uninterrupted, Mr. Duffy is incorporating ambient lighting in the display cases. Cooling and ventilating may take advantage of submarine technology, he said, with conditioned air expelled from high-pressure ducts in the display cases rather than through ceiling diffusers.
As far as the effect on the floor of foot traffic, Mr. Duffy said visitors might be given scuff-proof booties to wear. "We're going to make you polish the floors," he said.
The reflective theme will be carried over to a 15-foot-long display area on the mezzanine level that will, if the Buildings Department approves, cantilever over the sidewalk. With a two-way mirror at one end and a one-way mirror at the other, this room will give the impression of infinite space.
Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, which is otherwise busy designing the new New York Stock Exchange, the new Pennsylvania Station and the Time Warner Center on the site of the New York Coliseum, donated its services, worth $300,000 to $400,000, to the Skyscraper Museum.
Not everything comes free. Ms. Willis is hoping to raise $3.5 million to complete the space and to design and install the permanent exhibition and $2.5 million for an endowment to cover operating expenses on a continuing basis.
Ms. Willis, 51, a Columbia-trained art historian and an adjunct professor in Columbia's School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, said the design was "perfectly, poetically fitted" to the museum, of which she also happens to be curator.
"The overall idea is breaking the boundaries about a subject that is too large for its space," she said. To Ms. Willis, the museum is a starting point, an orientation center for the city's collection of skyscrapers. Owners of landmark towers may expect to hear from her in coming years, as she would like to install vitrines in buildings around town that tell the story of the host structures and, of course, alert viewers to the Skyscraper Museum.
The museum's identity will be tied not only to its real estate at First Place and Battery Place -- critical though that is for getting into guide books and attracting donors -- but also to its curatorial approach.
Instead of focusing exclusively on architecture, the museum concerns itself with economics, technology, engineering, personalities, politics and marketing techniques, which also shape the skyline. Looked at this way, a tenant roll can be just as important as a blueprint, a photograph of a typical office module more insightful than a view of the ornate boardroom.
The first exhibition in 1997, "Downtown New York: The Architecture of Business/The Business of Buildings," was held in space at Wall and William Streets that is now a Charles Schwab brokerage branch. "Building the Empire State" (1998-99) and "Big Buildings" (1999) were held in a soaring, wood-paneled banking hall at Wall and Nassau Streets that is now an Equinox health club.
For the moment, the exhibition "Design/Development: Times Square" is in a utilitarian former bank branch at Maiden Lane and Pearl Street that the Rudin family has set aside until they sign a paying tenant. (Even after the museum moves out, it can still be found at www.skyscraper.org.)
"We are happy to provide the space," said William C. Rudin, the president of Rudin Management Company. "New York City should definitely have a Skyscraper Museum."
The Rudins are not alone in falling under Ms. Willis's persistent and persuasive spell, as she struggles -- sometimes, it seems, by dint of willpower alone -- to create a new cultural institution out of thin air.
"The museum lives and breathes because she's devoted her time and energy and has worked for years without any remuneration," Mr. Arons said, "and in my opinion has created an institution of extraordinarily high standards."
He said Ritz-Carlton executives were as enthusiastic as he was about the prospect of a museum on the ground floor. "This might be the kind of thing that would draw people to the hotel on weekends and holidays," Mr. Arons said.
The Ritz-Carlton Downtown will occupy the lower 13 floors of the tower, with 298 rooms. It will have a restaurant, lobby lounge, bar, fitness center and ballroom. The hotel will offer its services to the 122 apartments in the high-rise tower, which will be called the Residences at the Ritz-Carlton. These range in size from 809 to 4,300 square feet and in price from $600,000 to more than $6 million. About 50 have been sold.
Clearly, for the Skyscraper Museum, institutional adolescence is nearing an end. "It started with, 'Hey, kids, let's put on a show,' " Ms. Willis said. "Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney in a barn. On Wall Street."
"We're jumping," she said, "to a whole new scale."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: INDIANA SEAT;
Lugar Challenger, Underdog of Underdogs, Battles as If He's in a Race

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
Trailing badly in statewide polls and outspent 3 to 1, David Johnson, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate here, figured the odds against his longshot campaign could not get much worse.
Of course, that was before his Republican opponent, the incumbent Richard G. Lugar, was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize in August for his work to help reduce Russia's nuclear arsenal. 
 In the annals of underdog Senate races, Mr. Johnson's challenge is bobbing near the top. He picked his first political race to take on Mr. Lugar, a four-term senator, former presidential candidate and perhaps the most popular politician in Indiana history. An Indianapolis Star poll in early September had Mr. Lugar up by 50 points, with even Democrats narrowly favoring him.
But none of this seems to faze Mr. Johnson, 48, a smart, affable corporate lawyer and political adviser, who dismisses talk that he has been offered as a sacrificial lamb by party leaders to keep Mr. Lugar from spending too much time and money helping other Republican candidates here.
Mr. Johnson is running a spirited, if somewhat anonymous, campaign on the theme that Mr. Lugar, 68, has lost touch with what ordinary Hoosiers care about: education, health care and Social Security. With crop prices dropping, Mr. Johnson has also attacked the Freedom to Farm Act that Mr. Lugar championed to overhaul farm programs.
Poring over his rival's record since 1994, Mr. Johnson found that Mr. Lugar voted 83 percent of the time with Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the staunch conservative Republican, and repeatedly voted against new school financing and prescription-drug coverage for the elderly. "This is a guy who has just been missing in action, and at every opportunity has voted with the Jesse Helms wing in the Senate," Mr. Johnson said. "This is not that kind of state."
Mr. Lugar scoffs at the criticism, first noting that he has visited all 92 counties in the state this campaign and then dismissing attacks on his record as selective procedural votes cooked up by Democrats to embarrass Republicans. Mr. Lugar, for instance, has proposed a plan for Medicare recipients to join a drug-buying club that would offer steep discounts.
"If you're going to argue about being in touch, you have to offer some visible evidence that you've been to the communities, that you've met the leaders, that you know anybody," Mr. Lugar said. "I've been there. He has not."
Mr. Lugar, despite his commanding lead, seems to be nervously peeking over his shoulder at his upstart's challenge, and says he is not taking the outcome for granted.
Mr. Lugar has raised more than $4 million -- compared with $1.5 million for Mr. Johnson -- and has scheduled several fund-raisers through October. Mr. Lugar skipped the Republican National Convention this summer to stay home and campaign.
"I spent almost the entire month of August in Indiana to make absolutely sure that each of these counties was as secure and strong for our candidacy and other Republicans as possible," Mr. Lugar said.
In one of his television advertisements, Mr. Lugar is running away from his own party, taking credit for his defense of the popular federal school lunch program against efforts by House Republicans to slash it.
In the candidates' first televised debate in August, Mr. Johnson's attacks flustered the normally soft-spoken, unflappable senator. "The thought that Senator Helms and I are somehow in bed together there in the Senate is just ludicrous on the face of it," said Mr. Lugar, clearly agitated.
Mr. Johnson's big problem is that he is not well known. On paper and in person, he is an attractive candidate: son of a Presbyterian minister, Harvard Law School graduate, former Africa specialist on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and, like Mr. Lugar, a Rhodes Scholar.
But with Election Day fast approaching, Mr. Johnson is trying to accomplish in less than two months what Mr. Lugar has done over a quarter-century of public service: build a statewide name and reputation.
Only recently did Mr. Johnson air his campaign's first television advertisement. The Democratic National Committee spent $250,000 on a television commercial criticizing Mr. Lugar's record on education and health care, but it never mentions Mr. Johnson by name.
Mr. Johnson's struggle was evident when he recently attended services at the Eastern Star Baptist Church, the state's largest African-American congregation. As more than 500 parishioners filtered into an elementary school that served as a makeshift sanctuary, Mr. Johnson shook hands and drew blank stares.
"I haven't heard of him," said Crystal Crumes, a 34-year-old Internet recruiting specialist who considers herself a staunch Democrat.
Political analysts are skeptical that there are enough compelling issues to give Mr. Johnson's campaign the boost it needs. The state's economy is booming and the unemployment rate is around 3 percent, below the national level.
Nor is there any whiff of scandal to taint Mr. Lugar's respected record as a foreign policy expert, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee and one-time mayor and school board member in Indianapolis.
"In any other state, David Johnson would be an A-list challenger," said Rachel Gorlin, a media consultant who produced the Democratic Party advertisement. "But here, David's got to do everything right, and then have a lot of good luck."
Indeed, Mr. Johnson is clinging to the coattails of the state's popular incumbent Democratic governor, Frank L. O'Bannon, who is expected to be easily re-elected. While no Democratic presidential candidate has carried Indiana since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, Democrats have controlled the governor's mansion here since 1988.
The only advantage to a 50-point deficit in the polls, Mr. Johnson says cheerily, is that there is nowhere to go but up. If he can close that gap and generate momentum, Mr. Johnson said, a large Democratic turnout could propel him to an upset.
"When I got into this race, people thought I was delusional," he said. "But it's entirely a question of being able to have a sufficiently amplified voice to get the message out that people have a choice this year."

HEADLINE: In Clinton's Words: 'An Outstretched Hand'

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Following is President Clinton's statement today in the White House Briefing Room on the Senate vote on trade relations with China, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.
Today the Senate voted to pave the way for permanent normal trade relations between the United States and China. This landmark agreement will extend economic prosperity at home and promote economic freedom in China, increasing the prospects for openness in China and a more peaceful future for all of us. 
 When we open markets abroad to U.S. goods, we open opportunities at home. This vote will do that. In return for normal trade relations, the same terms of trade we offer now to more than 130 other countries, China will open its markets to American products, from wheat to cars to consulting services. And we will be far more able to sell goods in China without moving our factories there.
But there's much more at stake here than our economic self-interest. It's about building a world in which more human beings have more freedom, more control over their lives, more contact with others than ever before, a world in which countries are tied more closely together and the prospects for peace are strengthened.
Trade alone won't create this kind of world. But bringing China under global rules of trade is a step in the right direction. The more China opens it markets to our products, the wider it opens its doors to economic freedom and the more fully it will liberate the potential of its people.
When China finishes its negotiations and joins the W.T.O., our high-tech companies will help to speed the information revolution there. Outside competition will speed the demise of China's huge state industries and spur the enterprise of private-sector involvement. They will diminish the role of government in people's daily lives. It will strengthen those within China who fight for higher labor standards, a cleaner environment, for human rights and the rule of law. And we will find, I believe, that America has more influence in China with an outstretched hand than with a clenched fist.
Of course, none of us should think for a moment that any of these outcomes are guaranteed. The advance of freedom ultimately will depend upon what people in China are willing to do to continue standing up for change. We will continue to help support them.
Peace and security in Asia will depend upon our military presence, our alliances, on stopping the spread of deadly weapons. Some will continue. So we will continue to be a force for peace, and we will not rest in our efforts to make sure that freer trade also is fairer trade.
These are some of the most important issues that our nation faces. That's why this vote was so important and, for many, so difficult. I want to thank Senator Lott and Senator Daschle, Senator Roth, Senator Moynihan and Senator Baucus, as well as those who led our effort in the House, and everyone within this administration who worked so hard to achieve this important milestone.
But I also want to acknowledge those who raised important questions about this policy and say to you this is not the end of the story. It is the beginning. We have a chance -- not a certainty, but a chance -- to strengthen our prosperity and our security and to see China become a more open society. Now our test as a nation is whether we can achieve that. I hope and I strongly believe that we will.

HEADLINE: OPENING TO CHINA: THE OVERVIEW;
SENATE VOTES TO LIFT CURBS ON U.S. TRADE WITH BEIJING; STRONG BIPARTISAN SUPPORT

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
After a long and often tumultuous struggle, a bill to remove restraints on trade with China passed the Senate today in a strong bipartisan vote, giving President Clinton what he considered one of his crowning foreign policy goals.
Coupled with approval by the House in May, the vote today ended the annual Congressional review of China's trade status, a ritual for 20 years that Beijing considered degrading but that critics argued was necessary to force China to improve its record on human rights and religious freedom. 
 After the historic vote, which passed with little debate today, Mr. Clinton told reporters, "This landmark agreement will extend economic prosperity at home and promote economic freedom in China, increasing the prospects for openness in China and a more peaceful future for all of us." Transcript and roll call, Page A16.
The broad margin of the victory, 83 to 15, was all the more remarkable coming less than two months before the presidential election, and after nine months of passionate debate. It demonstrated how a foreign policy issue could retain bipartisan backing even in the heat of a campaign.
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican presidential nominee, has supported the legislation. After the vote, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, Ray Sullivan, said, "This measure will help open markets to American products and help export American values, especially freedom and entrepreneurship."
Although Vice President Al Gore feared losing the support of allies in organized labor who opposed the measure as a threat to union jobs, he voiced qualified support for it today. But he stressed that American workers' rights must be protected. "We must combat unfair trade practices abroad when they harm our working families," Mr. Gore said.
Senate supporters hailed the deal, which will expand a vast overseas market for American goods, as a path-breaking step toward a new economic and security relationship. Senator Fred Thompson, a Tennessee Republican who tried unsuccessfully to amend the bill to penalize Chinese companies that export advanced weapons, voted for it but said he would continue to press China to curb its arms trafficking.
"Generally, free trade leads to freer markets, and freer markets can lead to more open societies," Mr. Thompson said in a statement. "I will keep pushing to hold the Chinese accountable for their actions."
Passage of the measure ensures that the United States will benefit fully from a market-opening accord that Washington and Beijing negotiated in November to slash Chinese tariffs on a range of farm and industrial products and removes barriers to American service providers, like banks and telecommunications companies. Almost everything from apples to wine will have a better chance of getting into the Chinese market.
The November agreement paves the way for China to enter the World Trade Organization, the 135-member group that sets the rules for global commerce. China will join the organization, probably later this year, and would have done so regardless of the vote today. But without Congress's blessing, China could have withheld some trade benefits from the United States that it extended to other members of the group.
"For U.S. farmers, businesses and working people, this agreement opens up a range of opportunities in China across all sectors and all fields of a magnitude unprecedented in the modern era," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. Some parts of the pact have taken effect, she said, noting that orange exports to China from Florida and California, for instance, have risen 100-fold since May.
Dave McCurdy, president of the Electronic Industries Alliance, said, "From semiconductors to circuit boards, from PC's to cell phones, China is simply the most dynamic international market for U.S. high-tech exports."
Overall, the United States bought $82 billion worth of Chinese-made goods last year, $69 billion more than the value of what it sold to China. The trade deficit, America's second-largest, was slightly smaller than the one with Japan.
The bill's supporters warned that several challenges remain in dealing with China, most immediately resolving disputes over some agriculture tariffs and how Taiwan will join the Word Trade Organization at the same time as China. "We've got a lot of work ahead of us," said Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana.
The outcome of the vote today was never in doubt. The fierce lobbying that pitted corporate America against labor and religious groups before the House's approval of the measure in May, by a vote of 237 to 197, never materialized in the upper chamber because all sides knew the question in the pro-trade Senate was never if the measure would pass, only when and by how much.
But supporters still faced a delicate procedural and political balancing act in the Senate, where lawmakers zealously guard their prerogatives and a lone senator has the power to delay the most popular bill.
Backers of the legislation said it was essential to press for a measure free of amendments because there was not enough time to reconcile an amended Senate bill with the House version before Congress adjourned for the year. "We knew we had the votes, but what was difficult was that there was no margin for error in the Senate," said Steve Ricchetti, a deputy White House chief of staff who was Mr. Clinton's point man for the bill in the Senate. "It had to pass exactly as it passed out of the House."
So supporters adopted a low-key strategy aimed at leaching from Senate consideration all of the volatile politics that enmeshed the House vote. Tactically, that meant having Mr. Clinton -- who eight years ago was on the opposite side, criticizing President George Bush's policy of engagement with China -- project enough support to show that he still cared deeply about the bill, but not raise the debate temperature high enough to prompt some foes to take the bill hostage to delay it.
When Mr. Clinton's original point man on the bill, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, left the Cabinet in June to head Mr. Gore's presidential election campaign, some supporters worried that momentum was slipping away.
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, balked at scheduling a vote before the July 4 recess, arguing that the Senate had more pressing business in wrapping up many of the 13 must-pass spending bills that keep the government running. "If we go into September, our chances for passage drop precipitously," Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, warned in late June.
And for a while, critics seemed to have a point. Just as the vote in the House created unusual political alliances between liberal labor groups and conservative religious organizations in opposition to the bill, the Senate bill produced odd political couplings. Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, perhaps the Senate's most liberal Democratic member, teamed up with Jesse Helms of North Carolina, one of the staunchest Republican conservatives, to back amendments on human rights, religious freedom and prison labor.
But the gloomy predictions proved wrong. Mr. Lott and Democrats agreed in late July to bring the bill up for a final vote after the five-week summer recess. Despite its long-simmering tensions with Taiwan, Beijing heeded private warnings from administration officials to avoid any diplomatic or military provocations that could fuel opposition to the bill.
The trade bill never became a political football, partly because pro-trade Republicans were loath to antagonize their corporate benefactors in a hotly contested election year, and labor leaders never believed that they could win enough Democrats.
One after another, 20 different amendments to improve human rights, religious freedom and labor standards in China fell by lopsided votes, not because senators opposed them on merit but because of their potential harm to the underlying bill.
A similar fate awaited the most popular amendment, sponsored by Mr. Thompson and Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, to penalize Chinese companies that trafficked in nuclear, chemical or biological weapons and long-range missiles. The measure struck an especially strong chord with lawmakers who had grown increasingly alarmed by intelligence reports of Chinese arms exports.
In the vote, all but 7 Democrats and 8 Republicans supported the bill. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut Democrat who is Mr. Gore's running mate, was campaigning in California and Ohio and did not vote. Senator Daniel K. Akaka, Democrat of Hawaii, also did not vote.
Supporters said the agreement would benefit American business and values. "The Senate has cast an epic and overwhelming vote today," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. "By so doing, we bring China back into the trading system that it helped to establish out of the ashes of the Second World War."
But opponents criticized the measure as one that would undercut America's moral authority in the world, and reward a government that threatens its neighbors, persecutes its citizens and sells advanced weapons to America's enemies.
"The safety and security of the American people come first," Mr. Helms said. "That safety and security will be ensured ultimately not by appeasement, not by the hope of trade at any cost, but by dealing with Communist China without selling out the very moral and spiritual principles that made America great in the first place."

China Applauds Bill's Passage
By The New York Times
SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- China's Foreign Ministry today heralded the Senate's approval of the bill removing restraints on trade as paving the way for more stable relations with Washington.
At the same time, China criticized clauses in the bill intended to maintain pressure on Beijing to improve its human rights record. Hu Chusheng, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation, reiterated irritation at the human rights monitoring panel in the trade bill, saying it "still contains certain clauses that are irrelevant to trade and are intended to interfere in the internal affairs of China."

HEADLINE: Peru's President, Cheered by Supporters, Vows to Stay in Office Until Next Summer

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 19

 BODY:
In his first public appearance since he called for new elections and the dismantling of the National Intelligence Service, President Alberto K. Fujimori entered the Palace of Government tonight to the cheers of supporters and assured the nation that he was in full control and would remain in office until his successor is sworn in next July.
After climbing atop the palace gate and waving to the crowd, he went inside to give a televised address in which he said his decision last Saturday was a moral obligation to ensure stability and one that he made after a videotape surfaced that showed his close aide and intelligence chief apparently offering a $15,000 bribe to an opposition congressman. 
 The aide, Vladimiro Montesinos, has not been seen since Mr. Fujimori's announcement, and opponents have worried about the possibility of a coup, given Mr. Montesinos's close ties to high-ranking officers and the continued silence of the military.
"I am not saying goodbye yet," Mr. Fujimori said during an address that was by turns animated and jovial. "This message does not signify my immediate resignation. I am in full function."
He also insisted that he enjoyed the support of the commanding generals.
"There is no power vacuum," he said. "We will keep working intensively until the last days. The country is at peace and there is liberty for demonstrations and freedom of expression."
He was emphatic in saying that he arrived independently at his decision to call for new elections in which he would not run. He denied that he had been under pressure from the United States government, which along with other nations had questioned Mr. Montesinos's role in his government.
"I never received a call from anyone, and the United States does not act in that manner," he said. "We have good communication. We have been in dialogue and cooperation. But absolutely no calls or insinuations. Nothing. Zero. These decisions were the sovereign decisions of the President of Peru."
But when asked about Mr. Montesinos's whereabouts, Mr. Fujimori passed the microphone to the cabinet ministers who flanked him. Several times, the ministers said they did not know Mr. Montesinos's exact location, but added that he was in Lima and not under arrest. They said that he was still receiving official protection, given his role in combating terrorism and illegal narcotics, and that he was also entitled to due process regarding any criminal charges.
Mr. Fujimori also criticized his opponents, who he said had attacked him despite his success in fighting terrorists and improving the economy.
Earlier in the day, several of his opponents said that while they were willing to resume talks with his government to find a solution to the political crisis, they also had more videotapes with evidence of official misconduct. They had previously conditioned participation in such talks on Mr. Montesinos's arrest.
Their change of heart came one day after Mr. Fujimori instructed his cabinet to submit to Congress the necessary bills to have a new election.
The day's events came against a backdrop of deepening mystery about the whereabouts of Mr. Montesinos, and a continued silence from the military about the changes in government.
"There is a real situation of emergency and misinformation, so we can no longer remain on the margins," said Fernando Olivera, a congressman with the Independent Moralizing Front Party. "This does not mean we withdraw our demand for the arrest of Vladimiro Montesinos. What would happen is, it would be put on the table for discussion so together we can make the correct decision."
Opposition groups had been taking part in talks with the Fujimori government under the aegis of the Organization of American States, which was trying to bolster confidence in Peru after Mr. Fujimori won a controversial third term this year.
It was unclear today if the main opposition leader, Alejandro Toledo, who withdrew from the presidential race after accusing the government of rigging the election, had agreed to new talks. On Monday night he was acting like a candidate as he addressed a crowd of 10,000 cheering supporters at Plaza San Martin to propose a transitional government.
Mr. Olivera said today that this was not the time to campaign, but to find solutions, hoping that talks would bring about elections soon.
Yet Mr. Olivera, who set off the crisis when he made public the incriminating videotape, also tinged his overture with its own mystery when he announced that he had other damning videotapes. His assertion was backed up by Susana Higuchi, an opposition lawmaker and Mr. Fujimori's former wife.
"Obviously the military is pressuring Fujimori so there would not be a coup," she said at a midday news conference. "That is why we do not plan to release the other videos, because there would be chaos."
A senior Clinton administration official, however, said he did not think there was much appetite among officers for a coup in support of Mr. Montesinos.
The opposition released more details today about how Mr. Montesinos responded to the first videotape. Mr. Olivera said Mr. Montesinos's emissaries contacted him soon after the videotape was leaked and urged Mr. Olivera to reach an accommodation or face the possibility of a coup that would sweep away him and other opponents.
"We did not accept any pact," he said. "We are sure that no military adventure, no matter how bloody, would last for more than 24 hours."
He said the videotape had been given to him by "a patriot" who had risked his life and now had a bounty on his head. "Even to this day he is risking his life because he knows the methods they use to take reprisals," Mr. Olivera said.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Decreeing The Trains On Time

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
A FARMER living on the RussianUkrainian border reads in the newspaper that national boundaries are about to be rejiggered in the postSoviet era. As a result, his village, in Russian territory all his life, will be considered part of Ukraine.
"Great news!" he says to his wife. "Now we wont have to go through another miserable Russian winter." 
 This joke came to mind after hearing that New York City Transit officials want to change the method used to grade themselves on whether the buses and subway trains run on time. Under the proposed change, they would look pretty good.
The share of trains deemed to be running on schedule, put most recently at 80.7 percent, would rise under the new system to 89.5 percent. The gain in bus service would look even better. Its reliability rating, now 56.4 percent, would soar to 76.7 percent.
On some routes, the improvement would be almost magical. Take the M101 bus, which runs up and down Third and Lexington Avenues. Voil! Faster than Clark Kent can turn into Superman, its positive rating of 33.8 percent would become 68.7 percent.
 Not only that, but the trains and buses would be deemed cleaner. Instead of 44 percent of subway cars being judged litterfree, as now, the figure would rise to 67 percent.
O.K., enough with the numbers. They will only make your head hurt. They also mask the fact that absolutely nothing will change for the most important person of all: the rider. That much is readily acknowledged by Albert W. OLeary, New York City Transits chief spokesman.
"The trains are not going to come any faster or slower, and they are not going to be any cleaner or dirtier," he said. So what's the point?
"We want a change that helps us manage better," Mr. OLeary said.
On one level, you have to sympathize with the subwaymeisters. They now judge how they're doing by way of a measurement called "service regularity." It is defined as follows:
"The percentage of intervals between trips departing from all scheduled timepoints, not including terminals, which is within plus or minus 50 percent of the scheduled interval (for all scheduled intervals less than 10 minutes), or, within plus or minus five minutes of the scheduled interval (for scheduled intervals of 10 minutes or more)."
Did you catch all that?
We didn't think so.
Here's a CliffsNotes version. A train is now considered on schedule if it arrives within 50 percent of the allotted time between it and the previous train. If Train B is supposed to pull into the station four minutes after Train A, it is on time as long as it shows up anywhere between two and six minutes later.
This system is way too complicated, subway officials say. They want to shift to something called "wait assessment." (Don't look for plain English here.) It would impose a basic three-minute rule. A train would be declared on time as long as it turned up no later than three minutes after its scheduled arrival. That same Train B would be on time even if it arrived not four but seven minutes after Train A.
ONCE all the numbers are crunched, mediocre efficiency ratings are transformed --poof! --into passable grades. Yet passengers will feel not a whit of difference as they tap their feet waiting for overdue trains.
"It's like grade inflation," said Gene Russianoff of the Straphangers Campaign, a riders advocacy group. The mass-transit managers, he said, will look better on paper, when what they should do is add trains and buses to handle increased ridership. Similar points were made by Michael T. Doyle, associate director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Mr. OLeary rejects any suggestion that flim-flam may be afoot. "If we were going to cheat, would we announce it?" he said.
Fair enough. But you have to wonder about a bureaucracy that defines three minutes late as on time. Three minutes can loom large. Let a rush-hour No. 4 train be that late, and thousands of riders will be stranded all along the line.
It is enough to make one pine for the Tokyo subway, where precise, to-the-minute schedules are posted on every platform. Riders can see right away for themselves if the trains are running smoothly. In my five years of living in Tokyo, they always were. Not once did I see a train come even a minute late.
Of course, if you expect that kind of efficiency in New York, you probably also think that Russian farmer will be basking in a mild Ukrainian winter.

HEADLINE: TURF;
Lessons on Shopping In a Confusing Market

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
FOR once, real estate experts are speechless.
"I'm at a loss to characterize this market," Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate, said this week. "It's kind of like a tornado, where one house is blown to smithereens and the next one remains intact. There might be two apartments that we thought were similar: one will sell immediately for more than the asking price, and the other one will sit on the market for four months. I can't explain it." 
 Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, a large appraisal company, is also mystified. In the last month, he said, "the market has been inconsistent: one apartment sells instantly, and there's very little activity on another."
Over all, the experts stress that the current market is still strong -- it's just that the frenzy has disappeared. "The overheatedness is gone," said Alan J. Rogers, chairman of Douglas Elliman, the city's largest residential real estate brokerage. "The crazy bidding wars are gone." During the summer, he said, prices appear to have stabilized.
This week, Clark Halstead, of the Halstead Property Company, said that there are now more properties on the market -- perhaps 10 percent more -- than there were last March, one of the hottest months for apartment buying in New York history. Some sellers are putting their co-ops on the market, he said, because "in their wisdom, they've decided to get out while the getting is good."
He paused. "And that means it's a great time to buy."
In addition, brokers report that while a lot of people are looking, some are choosing to wait longer before signing a contract. Others are deciding to rent -- though the rental market may be at a peak -- until prices fall, said Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York.
"Many of my clients are telling me they're afraid to buy at the top of the market," said Mark E. Zimmerman, a real estate lawyer at a Midtown firm.
It wasn't always so. "In March, people were agreeing to terms that I, as their attorney, was telling them not to agree to," Mr. Zimmerman said. That desperation is gone, he added. But there is still buyer's anxiety, or the fear that if a deal isn't made, the buyer won't be able to find something else.
These are the days of mixed signals: people don't want to pay the peak price, but they don't want to lose out, either.
Experts advise apartment hunters to use the new breathing room to research a purchase thoroughly, resulting in less buyer remorse, or the feeling of being pressured into either buying the wrong apartment or paying too much for the right one. Last spring, second thoughts ended in a string of broken deals.
Buyers worried that the market may fall after they move in can protect themselves by buying an apartment with an unusual, sought-after feature, said Mr. Miller, the appraiser. "Historically, apartments with unique features tend to be less volatile," he continued. "Look for outdoor space, a view, a well-done renovation."
Other experts advise the opposite: to find a rare bargain, they say, look for an apartment that has a flaw. Overlooks an air shaft? Has no elevator? "In this market, anything that is remotely perceived to have a flaw may sit on the market," Mr. Peters said. So make an offer.
Just recently, a couple were worried about having just bought a walk-up downtown, said Stuart Saft, chairman of the New York Council of Co-operatives and Condominiums. He added, "I told them they paid less because of it -- and if the market goes up, they'll make quite a profit."
Anyone who has fallen in love with an apartment but wonders if it is overpriced should pay close attention to similar apartments sold in the same building or nearby. Prices have soared until this spring, and though this summer saw a tapering off of the hysteria, prices are still high. Thus, buyers should concentrate on the most recent sales, brokers said.
The old rules still apply. Buyers should take time to sound out the building's financial health, Mr. Saft said. "If the board has raised the maintenance 10 percent every year -- in these times of relatively low inflation -- you might ask why."
A buyer's accountant or lawyer can help evaluate the underlying mortgage. Is it disproportionately large, based on the number of units? What is the interest rate? When will the mortgage come due?
Finally, bank on a good neighborhood, Mr. Saft said. "If the market goes down," he noted, "properties in a marginal neighborhood will suffer first."

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1213 words

HEADLINE: To Market, With a Digital Movie and a Dream

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
"I think of us as the garage bands of the year 2000," Eva Ilona Brzeski said over a cup of coffee. Across the street at the Angelika Film Center, other young directors like Ms. Brzeski were screening their films at the IFP Market, a combination film festival and workshop this week in Lower Manhattan. Like Ms. Brzeski's "Last Seen," an 87-minute feature about the disappearance of a high school volleyball player, many of the films have been shot, wholly or partly, on digital video.
Organized by the Independent Feature Project, an alliance of moviemakers and distributors, the market gathers directors, producers, distributors, agents, broadcasters, Web site operators and all manner of provocateurs on the independent movie scene to view new work, finished or in progress, and make connections that will help filmmakers find development money and outlets. 
 Of the 400 projects being screened, 43 percent were shot on digital tape, which records information as electronic impulses rather than images. Relatively economic to shoot and produce, digital video has thrown open the filmmaking doors to all comers. Economy doesn't equal quality, of course. But plenty of good material is being turned out by small, low-paid (if they are paid at all), hard-pressed believers in the digital way.
At the market, hope surges in the hearts of every garage band. Todd Solondz's "Welcome to the Dollhouse" was discovered at the market, as were Richard Linklater's "Slacker," Michael Moore's "Roger and Me," Edward Burns's "Brothers McMullen" and the Academy Award-nominated documentary "The Farm," by Jonathan Stack and Liz Garbus. They weren't wielding digital video cameras, however.
Nontraditional filmmakers still cope with traditional means of distribution: the theater run, home video, cable, satellite and broadcast television. Here the avenues, as any agent or distributor at the market will attest, are as narrow as ever. Once broadband technology brings delivery up to speed, the Internet may become a huge pipeline for feature films, which can be shown on the Web now but are too long for satisfactory transmission. Distributors say that should happen in three to five years.
"We're at the infancy stage right now," said Gary Zeidenstein, a founder of Alwaysi.com, a Web company. His site shows both shorts and features and awaits the day when broadband will accelerate distribution of full-length movies. Meanwhile his company represents all kinds of independent films and filmmakers, listing them on its site and promoting them in the marketplace.
This week he is patrolling the market for both film and video, though he is guarded about video. "Ninety-eight percent of what we have is film," he said. "We don't have a lot of digital product on-site. Digital will revolutionize the industry, but it depends on the production value and the story line. I worry that a lot of people are going around making any kind of movie they want to make."
Many digital video filmmakers say that freedom is exactly the point. "The technology means that you can try something you wouldn't get funding for from a studio," Ms. Brzeski said. "It's exciting that filmmakers burdened by the complexity and expense of our art form can now take a risk. It comes closer to painting or writing; you have a more direct way to express your ideas."
The market guide describes "Last Seen" as "darkly funny, haunting and strange." Ms. Brzeski, whose short films have won awards at many film festivals, combined 16-millimeter film and digital video, relying on a small crew of believers who worked for turkey sandwiches instead of money.
"We got it in the can for $10,000," she said. Then she honed the results on an old Avid editing machine she bought for her company, Apple Valley Pictures. The Avid is also digital. "For my style of filmmaking it was such a good match, because it allows you to try things out fast, manipulate the images, create textures," she added.
Then there is the video look. Many digital video directors embrace -- or are resigned to -- the hand-held rush of "The Blair Witch Project," whose incredible success left moviemakers weak in the knees. Shot on video, "Blair Witch" was transferred to film. But the average video production does not present itself as an obvious candidate for the big screen. Ms. Brzeski said she would like "Last Seen" to be transferred to 35-millimeter film for a theater run before moving to video and television and into the foreign market, where she said she thought it would do well. "The Germans like weird views of America," she said.
Meanwhile she stands with what she has made. "A lot of people use digital video to make Hollywood-type films on a smaller budget," she said. "But we take the form for what it has to offer. It's cinematic without making apologies for being on video. We're not trying to be anything else."
By contrast, Elyse Couvillon recruited the cinematographer Allen Daviau ("E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial," "Bugsy," "Avalon") for her five-minute video short "Sweet," described in the market guide as a "brief but intensely sensual ride through the rapture and realities of love." Ms. Couvillon, who has worked as a camera assistant for the directors Barry Levinson, Peter Weir and others, said she had gone both ways with video production. "You shoot with the digital look, like 'Blair Witch,' " she said. "Put the DV in the backpack. Let the camera run, get great performances."
For "Sweet," she took the opposite approach and opted for the controlled 35-millimeter style. "We had storyboards and scanned them by computer," she said. "It's not a video look at all."
For his first feature, "Virgil Bliss," which is being screened today at the Angelika, the director Joe Maggio takes the "Blair Witch" approach. In principle, though, he said he agreed with Ms. Couvillon. "The biggest fear is how we set ourselves apart, letting DV get ho-hum," he said. "We say we shot on DV and we get this look from people -- 'Oh, well, you're just another one of those DV films' -- like we're a genre."
His film is about a career criminal with an explosive temper who relies on a troubled relationship to put some meaning into his life. So far, counting postage, the cost stands at $12,000. "We decided we had to make do with a picture suited for the DV format, turn our liabilities into assets," he said. The film moves around a lot, takes the rides at Coney Island, wanders around the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where Mr. Maggio lives, and includes a halfway house in the area.
Like Ms. Brzeski, he would like to transfer his movie to 35-millimeter film eventually, but his immediate goal is to attract festival programmers and perhaps a cable outlet like the Independent Film Channel. A television-quality tape is adequate for that purpose.
Still, the question remains: If digital video opens the floodgates, who will want all the output? "There is a huge demand for content targeted at specific audiences," said Dennis Young, president of Reelplay.com, another Web company that lists and promotes films on its site, including all 400 projects at this year's market. "Studios make mass-appeal products. They don't make niche products. Specific content equals independent features."
Shot on DV, perhaps.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Over Saddam's Barrel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nervous Nellie is worried about the strike by gas-gouged truckers in France and the panic buying of petrol by drivers in Britain. Nellie's fears are compounded by the rising price of gasoline in the U.S.
Be calm, replies Rosie Scenario. The tripling of the price of oil to $35 a barrel will soon be rolled back by increased production from our sensible friends in OPEC. 
 Nervous Nellie presses: What if Saddam Hussein crosses everybody up and reduces his sale of almost three million barrels a day, thereby punishing the West by pushing prices even higher?
That would be foolish of him, Rosie replies. Turning off the spigot would further impoverish the Iraqi people.
But that never bothered him before, counters Nellie. And by keeping oil prices up, he would greatly please the Russians, whose economy is being saved only by the high price of their main export. Russian technology and scientists in Iraq already help make it possible for inspection-free Saddam to build weapons of mass destruction and buy missiles to deliver them.
Relax, says Rosie, a little testily. Even if the price of oil stays sky-high, that does not mean it would cause inflation, triggering higher interest rates, then a stock market drop followed by recession.
Nellie: But isn't that what happened last time?
Rosie: That was then, when we were all hung up on the business cycle. Rest assured that the New Economy can withstand oil shocks, bursting bubbles and all the ills that flesh is heir to.
Nellie: But there has to be something the president can do. What if October gets cold in Connecticut and the price of heating oil is out of sight?
Rosie: No problem -- we dump our strategic oil reserve on the market and call it the Lieberman solution. Good quick fix that gets us past the election.
Nellie: But what about a war shock on top of an oil price shock? Saddam is saying that OPEC should defy superpowers, and claims that Kuwait is stealing his oil by drilling slantwise. Isn't that what he said last time, just before he started the gulf war?
Rosie: It's a bluff. Here is a statement from Gen. Paul Mikolashek of the U.S. Central Command, an unbeatable force stretched from Pakistan to Egypt. "I see a lot of rhetoric . . . Saddam's armed forces have been degraded." Not to worry. "Degraded" is Pentagonese for "hurt" and shows that the jargon of our military mind is invincible.
Nellie: Like how many troops do we have there? It took over half a million to stop Saddam last time.
Rosie: We have 4,500 troops in Kuwait, a couple of Patriot batteries, an Apache helicopter unit, plus an air base to patrol the no-fly zone. Maybe 15,000 more troops floating around nearby.
Nellie: That's going to stop the whole Iraqi Army? Apaches that couldn't take off in Kosovo?
Rosie: Look, if Saddam miscalculated again, we'd reassemble the Grand Coalition, call up our reserves, and send in CNN's Bernard Shaw to narrate the bombing of Baghdad -- the whole nine-yard megillah.
Nellie: Bill Clinton would do that?
Rosie: All from upward of 50,000 feet, with not one U.S. casualty.
Nellie: But what if Saddam says he has the Bomb? And says he's willing to commit suicide but would take Tel Aviv or New York along with him? It may be a bluff, but he's had years to build a nuclear or biological bomb in secret, and I'd hate to be the president to take the chance. We have no defense against a single missile, you know.
Rosie: Get over your nightmares. After we call his military bluff, we'll get next week's G-7 meeting to demand the oil cartel cut prices to $20 a barrel. Then it's world prosperity as far as the ear can hear.
Who's right, Rosie Scenario or Nervous Nellie? I say we should hope for the best and prepare for the worst. That means asking this president and the candidates to take his place: What if? Are we ready?
Let each cool-headed debater say during those 90 unforgiving minutes how he would deal with Saddam's economic and military threats. As Kipling never wrote: If you can keep your head while all others about you are losing theirs -- perhaps you don't understand the seriousness of the situation.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Industrial Nations to Confront the Sagging Euro and Costly Oil

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The slumping euro and fuel price inflation quickly took over as the dominant themes today in advance of a meeting of some of the world's top finance officials, with the European currency weakening to a record low and oil prices reaching another 10-year high.
French leaders, alarmed at the soaring cost of oil and gasoline that has aroused protests across Europe, demanded a unified stand for lower fuel prices when they meet here this weekend among the Group of 7 leading industrial nations. The top official of the International Monetary Fund also warned of the risks of high oil prices and, in unusually blunt remarks, urged the Group of 7 countries to intervene in the currency markets to strengthen the euro. 
 The remarks by Horst Kohler, the I.M.F.'s managing director, put pressure on the United States and its partners to attempt their first global currency intervention since their rescue of the falling Japanese yen two years ago.
The combination of a weak euro and expensive oil is considered especially perilous in Europe just as new signs are emerging that the region's vibrant economy may be slowing. Today, for instance, Italy reported an unexpected slowdown in its quarterly growth rate, and a widely watched indicator of business confidence in Germany fell for the third consecutive month.
In France, Finance Minister Laurent Fabius asked other big oil-importing nations to jointly demand that oil exporters lower what he called "the massive and brutal rise in prices." He spoke as the commodity price of a barrel of crude oil reached an intraday high of $37.80, settling in New York trading later in the day at $37.20. page C13.
Mr. Kohler, speaking to reporters here in the Czech capital, called the euro "heavily undervalued" and urged that central bankers take steps to increase its exchange rate against the dollar and the Japanese yen. "In my mind it is clear that intervention cannot be a taboo," he said. "My advice is to get the euro back to values based on economic fundamentals."
Mr. Kohler's comments reflected growing worries in Europe not only about the euro's value but also its viability as the region's common currency.
When 11 West European nations, led by Germany and France, introduced the currency in January 1999, some European leaders thought it might soon displace the dollar as the world's preferred storehouse of value.
Virtually the opposite has happened. The euro slipped from $1.17 at the start and is now suffering the worst rout of its 20-month life, touching a new low in European trading today of 84.44 cents, then rising somewhat in New York to 84.72 cents.
Along with the increasing price of oil, which Mr. Kohler said had put growth prospects in many importing countries at risk, the I.M.F. has stressed that the weak euro could undermine generally optimistic prospects for the global economy.
The euro's diminished value means that much of the Continent must pay more for imported goods, pushing up inflation and potentially forcing the European Central Bank to raise interest rates. That would slow growth in the region, which along with the United States economy has contributed to the strongest world growth in more than a decade.
Even more disconcerting for European policy makers, the currency's tumble comes a few days before Denmark is scheduled to vote on whether to adopt the euro. New polls show that Danes have turned decidedly negative on the euro as their Sept. 28 referendum approaches, a serious blow to proponents of the single currency, who hope to expand its domain to include other European nations, especially Britain.
The weak euro also has an impact in the United States by strengthening the relative value of an already strong dollar. Though the dollar has been a cornerstone of America's long economic expansion, import-loving Americans have helped amass a huge trade deficit, now 4.3 percent of the gross domestic product, a level many economists consider too high.
"There is a serious psychological bubble that has pushed the euro way down and the dollar way up," said C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, "and it could do some serious damage. My conclusion is that the only way they are going to turn this around is with a positive psychological shock" -- concerted intervention.
Mr. Bergsten said the leading powers should repeat their rescue operation of the sagging Japanese yen during the Asian financial crisis, in 1998. At that time, the United States, Europe and Japan coordinated an effort to buy yen and scared off speculators who had been driving the yen down. The yen rebounded, rising by almost a third against the dollar and has remained largely stable.
When the Group of 7 finance ministers meet this weekend, they will face the issue of whether -- and how -- to grapple with the euro.
The markets are betting that they will debate over words more than deeds. The customary joint communique at the end of the meeting will be scrutinized for semantics, especially any official endorsement of the idea that the euro has fallen below its fundamental value. It is also possible that they will emerge with an agreement, possibly secret, to sell dollars and buy euros at an opportune moment -- though that is regarded as less likely.
Several senior European officials have signaled that they favor intervention, but Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers has so far shown no interest in joining them. Without American participation, any intervention will carry a high risk of failure.
Mr. Summers reiterated today that the United States policy favoring a strong dollar remains in force. He has often said that he prefers to allow the market to set currency values. He seems especially unlikely to alter that philosophy with the presidential election ahead.
Any intervention could fail, embarrassing the Clinton administration. Or it could work too well, pushing the euro up sharply at the expense of the dollar and making the American trade deficit -- now projected at $354 billion this year -- unsustainable, weakening the economy and hurting Vice President Al Gore's campaign.

HEADLINE: Anti-Euro Britons Feeling Vindicated;
But Nation's Currency Isolation Is Still Seen as Threat by Many

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: SHERWOOD PARK, England

 BODY:
When Europe's single currency was introduced in 11 countries last year Britain stood aloof, refusing to abandon its venerable pound. It brushed aside domestic critics and business leaders who said their land might be setting misplaced nationalism ahead of the opportunity to participate in the Continent's greatest financial revolution.
Now, 21 months later, with the euro staggering against the American dollar, the European currency's misfortunes seem only to have strengthened those convictions. Still aloof -- and proud of it -- many Britons seem to feel vindicated in their belief that the smart money was on abstention after all, while the costs of isolation from the euro-zone have been limited. 
 "We have moved against the grain of European opinion for centuries," said Lord David Owen, one of several political grandees linked with business groups opposed to Britain's joining the euro at this stage. "It's been happening over a long period of time, and we mustn't be afraid of it."
It is not only politicians who sense that the euro is out of favor here. Business and financial interests were once largely united in favoring the euro. But a survey in mid-September by Merrill Lynch found that for the first time a majority among British fund managers had "lost their enthusiasm" for the euro, arguing that it would not be in the country's long-term economic interests to join. As recently as March 1999, the survey said, 60 percent of British fund managers had favored British membership. That figure slid to 40 percent in early September.
Not only that, Denmark, which rejected the treaty establishing the single currency several years ago, is set to vote again on whether to join the euro in a referendum on Sept. 28. With opinion among Danes shifting against membership, the British fund managers said a Danish "no" would not only make British membership less likely but perhaps damage the currency throughout Europe.
"An upset in Denmark could be the next shock that triggers euro selling," said Trevor Greetham, global strategist at Merrill Lynch in London.
Business groups skeptical of the euro -- assembled in a newly begun campaign called "Euro No" that depicts the European currency as a set of handcuffs -- declared in full-page newspaper advertisement: "Our economy hasn't been so healthy in our lifetime."
The debate is intensely political and emotional, with few indisputable economic facts to sway the argument either way in what is by far the largest of three holdouts against the euro -- Britain, Denmark and Sweden. Greece, which was left out originally because of its weak economy, is scheduled to join the euro in January.
While Britain's trade with the Continent has started to suffer, the nation has nonetheless survived a hint of recession with flying colors. It has also suppressed inflation and achieved more robust growth than Continental Europe largely because the Bank of England, free of the euro-zone's control by a ponderous and indecisive European Central Bank in Frankfurt, has been able to massage interest rates to shield the economy from its own boom-to-bust history.
From that perspective, said Ian Stewart, an economist with Merrill Lynch in London, "the benefits of being outside outweigh the benefits of being inside."
The City of London, Europe's financial district, has made brisk business from the euro, both in the eurobond market and from Europe's record-setting wave of cross-border consolidations. "This is one area where there has been no sign of any losses," said Alasdair Murphy, a director of the pro-euro Center for European Reform.
On the other side of the ledger, as the British pound has strengthened mightily against the euro, it has made British exports to Continental Europe -- half of its trade -- far more expensive. That has inflicted pain on manufacturers, who have shed hundreds of thousands of jobs since the euro's inception.
Still, despite complaints from auto industry giants like Ford, BMW, Nissan and Toyota about the pound's strength, Britain has maintained its lead as the principal target for foreign corporations seeking a toehold in Europe's 15-nation single market. Government figures released in July showed that Britain's attractiveness has pushed the total value of overseas investment here to $382 billion, up a stunning 25 percent from a year earlier.
Those arguments form pillars of the anti-euro case. But more distant horizons seem less sparkling. Many overseas investors have come to Britain not just for its low labor costs and easy hire-and-fire laws, but because they assume that sooner or later Britain will join the euro.
Indeed, with the pound weakening against the dollar, and long-term interest rates in Britain and the euro-zone looking set to converge, some economists argue that Britain is heading for a de facto alignment with the euro-zone that would make its membership simpler to achieve economically, if not politically.
"The assumption is that we will be in at some stage, so there's no need to take short-term measures or to start rethinking strategic considerations," said Graham Bishop, an independent economic consultant.
But if Prime Minister Tony Blair's tentative schedule to call a referendum on joining the euro within the next couple of years begins to slip -- as it now might with Mr. Blair's government facing a sudden loss in popularity -- "then that begins to make people nervous," Mr. Bishop said.
Lodged, moreover, between Europe and the United States -- more by economic culture than by geography -- Britain has in recent months suffered a double whammy of volatile exchange rates, with the strength of the United States economy pushing the pound to 14-year lows against the dollar just as sterling's strength against the euro makes British exports more expensive to sell in leading European markets.
The peril of high oil costs, a strong dollar and a weak euro is troubling European business as a whole, of course. But in Britain that confluence of economic forces has once again illuminated the fault line running through Britain's economy. While the bulk of Britain's wealth is rooted in the quick-paced service-driven economy around London, a traditional manufacturing sector further north is grappling not only with its own historical decline but with the difficulties of exporting into the euro-zone from factories that count their costs in pounds.
Consider, for instance, a small company like Autofil Worldwide, a manufacturer of yarn used in car upholstery, with a cavernous plant perched on a blustery hill in this industrial park north of Nottingham in the British Midlands. With annual revenue of $22 million, 80 percent of its sales of yarn are conducted in euros. It does the bulk of its business with suppliers, including those in Britain, in euros as well. The euro, Anthony Ullmann, a co-managing director, said, "is a fact of life for us."
This tale of euro-centricity, though, has a flaw. While most of its revenue is in less valuable euros, Autofil's wages for 130 employees and its utility bills are fixed in pounds. Its main raw material, polyester derived from petroleum, is priced ultimately in dollars, pushing up the company's own costs. To counter these forces, the company has been forced to trim its profit margins.
"We have the worst of both worlds," said Michael Heck, the other co-managing director.
Mr. Ullmann is convinced that this division must be erased to ensure the competitiveness of British industry. "The question of losing the pound is an inevitability," he said. "It's a question of when rather than if."
In the meantime, though, companies like Autofil say sterling's volatility has cost them dearly. This year, for instance, Mr. Heck said, the company will increase sales by 30 percent, but earn no more than it did last year. And, Mr. Ullmann said, his European competitors "don't do what I do when I get to the office every morning: check the price of the euro" to work out how to adjust for currency shifts. "It's very time consuming," he said.
For all the economic disputes, however, the decision on joining the euro will ultimately be a political one. Mr. Blair's government, which is guardedly in favor of the euro, has promised that it will not move until after the next election, and will hold a referendum on joining the currency before abandoning the pound. And, alarmingly for those who support the euro, Mr. Blair's Labor Party has suddenly and surprisingly been overtaken in the opinion polls by the staunchly anti-euro Conservative opposition, raising questions about the government's fortunes at the next election for Parliament, which it is expected to call next year and cannot delay past May 2002. The mood swung against Labor over its handling of blockades by protesting truckers and farmers that threatened to paralyze the economy; sentiment could well swing back again before the vote is held.
But Labor's loss of support could have wider ramifications. The Conservatives have placed their visceral and now united opposition to the euro at the center of a populist election campaign that can only become stronger if Labor is unable to win back popularity at home. And the anti-euro forces could gain further ground if other omens abroad -- particularly the Danish vote and the euro's swoon on foreign exchange markets -- reinforce their argument that the single currency is turning into a failure.
In setting out the arguments for and against, hard economic data is scarce and ambiguous, hinging thus far on three questions. Has Britain's isolation from the euro damaged foreign investment? Has it been a setback for the City of London as one of the world's mightiest financial centers? And has Britain suffered from the swings in the euro's value against the pound?
Only in the latter category can manufacturers and exporters trace losses that have cost jobs -- 200,000, according to Kitty Usher, the chief economist of the pro-euro Britain in Europe group. Against that, though, Britain's overall unemployment figures have declined since the introduction of the euro, suggesting that other jobs have been created over the same period.
Among foreign investors, particularly the vocal Japanese automakers who have established major operations in Britain, the picture remains murky. Honda has announced a doubling of capacity at its plant at Swindon, west of London. But Toyota is set to open a new factory in France next year, and Nissan could move production of a new subcompact to the French installations of its partner, Renault.
BMW and Ford both cited the pound's strength against the euro as reasons for their decisions to close assembly lines in Britain.
That could deepen what some pro-Europeans see as a trend.
"Globally, our share of foreign investment is falling," Ms. Usher said, arguing that while still at a record level, Britain's overall slice of the world's accumulated foreign investment had declined to 24 percent from 28 percent.
Three million jobs, or one in nine, are directly or indirectly linked to exports to the euro-zone, Ms. Usher said. "Those jobs could be affected by anything that would weaken our trading links with the euro-zone," she said.
Indeed, she added, it did not really matter whether the exchange rate was defined by the euro's weakness or the pound's strength. "It's all semantics," she said, "if you are the person whose job is threatened."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit at Record in July, Pushed by Cost of Oil Imports

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit widened to a record in July as demand for autos, oil and Chinese toys and clothes pushed imports to their highest level ever, government figures showed today.
The deficit in goods and services rose to $31.9 billion from $29.8 billion in June, the Commerce Department said. The previous record was $30.4 billion in March. 
 Record shipments of higher-price oil helped increase imports 0.6 percent, to $121.6 billion, in July after a 3.6 percent gain in June. Exports fell 1.5 percent, to $89.7 billion, as shipments of aircraft, automobiles and consumer goods slowed, reversing part of the 4.8 percent rise in June.
The July trade gap with China rose to a record $7.6 billion, up from $7.2 billion a month earlier and $6.3 billion in July 1999.
Demand for imported goods is likely to remain strong, a regional economic survey released today by the Federal Reserve suggested. The economy showed solid growth in late August and early this month, according to the Fed survey, known as the beige book. Several districts reported that consumer spending, which slumped in the second quarter, picked up in early September.
The trade report showed that oil imports rose 4.3 percent in July, to $8.4 billion, the highest ever. The volume of oil imports reached a record 301 million barrels, and the average price rose to $27.76 a barrel.
The trade deficit totaled $206.3 billion for the first seven months of 2000, up from $140.7 billion in the 1999 period, according to the Commerce Department. The July number puts the annual deficit on track to reach $354 billion, which would surpass the record $265 billion set in 1999.
