SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 41; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1128 words

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Time Warp of Two Asias in One Place

BYLINE: By FRANK GIBNEY; Frank Gibney, author of "The Pacific Century" and other books, is president of the Pacific Basin Institute and professor of politics at Pomona College in California.

 BODY:

THUNDER FROM THE EAST
Portrait of a Rising Asia
By Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn
Illustrated. 377 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50.
The blacktop road was sleek and new. Modern cars and trucks whizzed past clean shops and restaurants, a far cry from the Java countryside he had last visited 10 years before. All the more shocking when this correspondent for The New York Times, on a trip reporting the 1997 Asian economic crisis, found his way blocked by a procession of young men on motorcycles cheered on by excited villagers, proudly carrying the head of a newly murdered "sorcerer" on a pole. The sorcerers, the ninja, were the guilty ones, he was told. Islamic vigilantes had killed them and more would be killed to destroy their magic. 
 This story begins the first chapter of a book written by two Times correspondents, Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, describing the turmoil in Asia at the century's end. (The co-authors, who are a married couple, wrote alternate chapters.) I can think of no better way to epitomize the contrasts between modern, often dazzling economies and half-hidden ancient folkways that continue to bubble up throughout the Asian countries. Historical time-change may be the best way to describe the differences between tradition and technology, new education and old religion, emergent nationalisms and top-down globalization.
Unlike geographical time-change, which is at least marked by watch settings and disturbed circadian rhythms, historical time-change is ever-present and unpredictable. It is the inescapable byproduct of assorted Asian "miracles" in which intellectual and economic pressures condensed within decades the modernizations that Europeans and Americans took centuries to achieve.
In their book, challengingly subtitled "Portrait of a Rising Asia," Ms. WuDunn and Mr. Kristof have taken upon themselves the daunting task of explaining How, Why and What Next. On the whole they have made a good job of it. From regional plans of the International Monetary Fund to local education systems, from war crimes to environmental problems to the changing status of women, they give the reader a handy Baedecker on an increasingly confident continent and on East Asia in particular. They show a good sense of history in sketching Asian backgrounds.
But most of all this is a reporter's book in the best sense of the word. The pace of the writing is a bit breathless -- taking a quick run barefoot over an entire continent would leave any writer a bit winded. The authors' views of countries and conditions are anchored in their searching interviews with the people who live and work there. These range far and wide. We hear the story of a failed big-time developer in Thailand, a rickshaw owner in Indonesia, a child prostitute in Cambodia, a battered wife in Korea, a computer tycoon and a hard-pressed local factory owner in Japan. What characterizes almost all of the interviewees is their dedication to work and their patience and perseverance in the face of adversity (for this the authors use the classic Japanese term, gaman).
About the Asian economic crisis of 1997-98 they are very good indeed. They underline three major factors: 1) the lopsided ratio of short-term economic loans against foreign exchange reserves; 2) the neglect of regulatory infrastructures and legal safeguards; and 3) the disastrous self-confidence of Asian tycoons, bankers and governments. They also point out the faults of Western bankers and international organizations -- the I.M.F. in particular -- in not making accurate assessments of the crisis and discounting the hardships of those injured by it.
I agree thoroughly with their first major argument: the Asian economic crisis was the best thing that could have happened to Asia. It entailed a terrific human cost, but it is also helping to destroy much of the cronyism, protectionism and government regulation that had burdened Asian business. It helped start a political, social and economic revolution and forced a greater reliance on markets, democracy and the rule of law.
I have some major problems with their second argument, which is that partly because of this forced restructuring, Asia is likely to wrench economic, diplomatic and military power from the West over the coming decades. The first problem concerns geographic reach. Except for some brief sketches of a recently opening India, South Asia goes largely unreported. If we narrow the authors' focus to East and Southeast Asia, the similarities and parallel advances they cite make abundant sense, bringing closer to fulfillment the early prophecy of the Japanese writer Okakura Tenshin: "Asia is one." Their reports on villagers dying of pollution are sobering. (The environment is one of the bleakest prisms through which to view Asia.) Equally shocking are the interviews of friendly old Japanese veterans about their World War II atrocities.
Mr. Kristof and Ms. WuDunn's economic comparisons tell us much about generally underreported countries like Indonesia and Thailand. I question some of their political and social assumptions. Their analysis of China is wise if equivocal. Their analysis of Japan is something else again. Despite a wealth of reportorial recall, including their own experiences with Japanese schools, and good analyses of the banking system's collapse, their reading of Japan's current society and politics is quite shallow. For one thing they say surprisingly little about the roots of Japan's current malaise: the one-party rule of the Liberal Democratic party -- with the possible exception of the Communist Party of China the most pervasively corrupt and crony-ridden apparatus in the region.
In fact the disastrous prevalence of dominant single parties -- Indonesia's Golkar and Malaysia's Umno also come to mind -- are as much a regional characteristic as ingrown national bureaucracies.
For all that they speak of changes over decades, the authors seem to underrate the political undertow that in so many places threatens to roil the rising tides of progress. Unquestionably Asia's demography will ultimately prevail, but it will be a long time in coming, punctuated by reverses. And economic, diplomatic and military power will rarely come together. Meanwhile, Asia's historical time zones remain very, very far apart.
Such cavils aside, Mr. Kristof and Ms. WuDunn have given us an impressive and well-researched study of the world's most important area. Their insights are illumined by their good reporting. It will be a long time before I forget the mortally sick Chinese villagers, the riches-to-rags-and-back Thai entrepreneur and the sturdy citizens of Omiya, not to mention the happy motorcyclist holding up the severed head.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES;
Another Drama Beneath the Sea

BYLINE: By Dave Kehr 

 BODY:
Topicality isn't what Kathryn Bigelow had in mind when she began development on "K-19" four years ago. The plot outline of the film, about a Russian submarine trapped at the bottom of the sea, sounds alarmingly similar to the plight of the Russian sub Kursk, which held the world breathless last month.
But "K-19," which Ms. Bigelow will begin filming in March, is based on another incident, though one equally tragic and equally true. 
 "This is the story of two men," Ms. Bigelow said over breakfast at the Toronto Film Festival, where her most recent film, the historical thriller "The Weight of Water," had its world premiere, "Nikolai Zateyev and Vladimir Yenin, who were Russian submarine captains at the height of the cold war in 1961. On the maiden voyage of Russia's first atomic ballistic nuclear submarine, it had a malfunction in its reactor at the bottom of the North Sea and began to melt down. This was off the coast of Norway, about a mile from where there was a NATO base."
Kept secret at the time, the incident became public only when glasnost made it possible for Zateyev to publish his memoirs.
Ms. Bigelow, whose work includes the science-fiction film "Strange Days" and the police drama "Blue Steel," has never restricted herself to anything resembling traditional "women's pictures," and "K-19" (the title comes from the name of the sub) doesn't sound like an exception.
"Over the next few days," she said, "these two men -- Zateyev, the commander, and Yenin, the executive officer -- managed to avert what could have been a Chernobyl-like disaster. It was a truly extraordinary situation that elicited courage in a way almost unthinkable in the face of certain, catastrophic disaster and miraculously did manage to have some survivors."
The script, by the New York playwright Chris Kyle, is based on original research and interviews, notably with Zateyev's widow. "One of my technical advisers in St. Petersburg happens also to have been very, very close with several of the officers on the Kursk," Ms. Bigelow said. "The Kursk incident was an incredibly emotional experience for me and the people I am working with on this, because of how close I've become to this project and the individuals involved, and of having actually met some of the survivors of the K-19.
"But in a way what happened with the Kursk further impelled me to make this film. 'K-19' examines the courage and the prowess of these men. This will be the first major American motion picture in which Russians are the heroes, and I guess I have lofty intentions for it.
"Right now I'm afraid that the Russians are deeply embarrassed, that their pride is shattered. I feel I want to give them their pride back, but without the arrogance, and without the cold war disinformation. I don't want them to think they're having their face rubbed in the Kursk incident. I want them to see that they're being actually revered. There's a unique stamina and resilience in their psychology, and when you read Tolstoy and Pushkin, you see it all. It's an amazing mind-set, very, very different from our own."
 
Factory and Family
The plot line of Laurent Cantet's social drama "Human Resources" hangs on the attempt to impose a 35-hour workweek in France, a measure intended by the Socialist government to create more jobs in a country that urgently needs them.
But, Mr. Cantet said by phone from his Paris office, "I noticed that when I was presenting the film in Sundance that the first question that journalists from the U.S. and Canada asked me was, 'Is it true that in France you only work 35 hours a week?' And a lot of them added, 'Like that, you can have two jobs at once.' So there you see a very, very wide gap between our different ways of conceptualizing things."
In a restrained, documentarylike manner Mr. Cantet's film tells of Frank (Jalil Lespert), a young man from the working class who returns from business school to take a job as a junior executive in the factory where his father works. At first he hopes to use his new position to improve the lot of the workers by conducting a survey to see how the employees would like to see the 35-hour week structured. But when the smiling boss (Lucien Longueville), who has taken Frank under his wing, uses Frank's statistics as an excuse to reduce the work force, the young man finds himself caught in a classic conflict.
"The point of departure was the family story," Mr. Cantet said, "I wanted to explore the links that necessarily exist between intimate affairs and politics. Private life is never really private. Everything we experience has to take the social environment into account.
"In the family there is a natural hierarchy between the father and the son. The idea of the film was to look at the workplace, and see how that hierarchy could be reversed."
"Human Resources" was cast almost entirely with nonprofessional actors, many of whom Mr. Cantet found by visiting government unemployment offices. "I met five or six hundred people and did tests of them all and made my choices."
Danielle Melador, who memorably plays a feisty union representative, really is a union representative, and is "just as combative in life as she is in the film." The boss is played by an actual boss who took time off from his factory in a Paris suburb to appear in Mr. Cantet's movie.
"Human Resources" was shot in a working factory in Normandy that produces parts for cars, but in the film its product remains somewhat mysterious.
"I wanted something abstract, just a bit of twisted metal really," Mr. Cantet said. "The idea was to show that the father was attached to his work for work's sake, not out of an artisan's pride in a well-made object."
 
Sanity Clause
"They were dear to me," said Kitty Carlisle Hart, speaking of her famously unruly co-stars in "A Night at the Opera," the 1935 film she made with the Marx Brothers. "They didn't play any tricks on me, and they liked me, because we became friends forever after that."
Ms. Hart will appear at a members' screening of "A Night at the Opera" on Oct. 1 at 1:30 p.m. at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street in the South Village, and answer questions afterward.
"I saw it recently at a benefit I did in Santa Fe," she said. "And it was the first time that I'd seen it in a long, long time on a proper screen. Let me tell you something: It's no good on TV. But on a big screen it is hilarious. I enjoyed it very much."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Airways and KLM End Merger Talks

BYLINE: By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
British Airways and KLM abandoned their merger talks today after months of discussions failed to produce a workable blueprint for what would have been one of the most ambitious airline combinations.
Numerous regulatory and operational hurdles, in the end, were too much for the bargaining powers of the two companies to overcome. "We always recognized that this would be a complex transaction, involving not only commercial and economic issues, but also aeropolitical, regulatory and other matters. Although we made considerable progress, it has not been possible to resolve these," said Rod Eddington, chief executive of British Airways, and Leo van Wijk, chief executive of KLM, in a joint statement. 
 The talks and their collapse leave a trail of uncertainty about the future of consolidation in the airline industry in Europe and the United States.
"The regulatory hurdles in place are hard to overcome," said Martin Borghetto, an analyst with Morgan Stanley. "The process wouldn't have been solved within weeks or months."
British Airways had been betting on substantial savings from a KLM merger to help it return to profitability after registering losses last year for the first time last year since its privatization 13 years ago. But to achieve such a goal, British Airways executives had insisted on control over the merged airline, people close to the negotiations said.
Obtaining that control would have threatened the antitrust immunity KLM receives as part of the so-called open skies agreements negotiated between the Dutch and American governments, an executive close to KLM said. That immunity, contingent upon a certain percentage of KLM remaining in the hands of Dutch nationals, allows KLM to share sales, pricing and operational details with its United States partner, Northwest Airlines.
British Airways is not currently protected by similar immunity, and is more restricted in the information it can share with its partner in the United States, American Airlines. The British and American governments have been working toward such an accord, and the latest talks are scheduled for Oct. 18-19.
Roger Maynard, director of investments at British Airways, said the company had devised a structure that it believed would have allowed KLM to retain its antitrust immunity status. It had called for KLM to place existing route rights in a Dutch holding company that would operate as a subsidiary of the merged British Airways-KLM airline.
KLM, however, balked at becoming a subsidiary.
Without a structure for the combined company, British Airways and KLM were unable to agree on price, people close to the negotiations said.
Other issues that still needed resolution included disposals of certain hubs necessary to meet antitrust approval. It is also unclear which U.S. alliance would have remained intact.
Moreover, British Airways and KLM would have faced the problems of integration that confront many mergers. Some analysts said the companies remained as incompatible for merging now as they were in 1992, the last time they discussed merging.
Since then, British Airways has been repositioning itself as a premium carrier by focusing on first-class and business-class passengers. KLM, has been battling with other European carriers for lower-fare passengers.
Some analysts said that the collapse of the negotiations diminished the likelihood of such mergers in the future.
"When you merge, you have to take a lot of costs out of the business to make it worthwhile," said Chris Tarry, an analyst with Commerzbank. "And that always entails more risk."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
'Trust' Theme Turns to Taxes

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, began broadcasting two 15-second television advertisements statewide yesterday. This one, "Taxes," criticizes his Democratic opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, accusing her of supporting tax increases over the years. The other, "Scores," paints a negative picture of her record on education as the first lady of Arkansas.
 
TITLE -- "Taxes" 

PRODUCER -- Murphy Pintak Gautier Hudome Agency
 
ON THE SCREEN -- A small picture of Mrs. Clinton in a red box next to a banner that says "Clinton." Below the banner is the phrase "Record on taxes." As the narrator speaks, the word "Expensive" flashes on the screen in gray, and then "supported 15 tax increases" and "higher taxes on Social Security" pop up. The closing scene is a picture of Mrs. Clinton in the center of a black screen over the words: "Hillary Clinton. You just can't trust her on taxes."
 
THE SCRIPT -- "What's Hillary Clinton's record on taxes? Expensive. Hillary Clinton has supported 15 tax increases, including higher taxes on Social Security benefits. Hillary Clinton. You just can't trust her on taxes."
 
ACCURACY -- To back up its claims, the Lazio campaign released a list of tax increases enacted by the federal government through President Clinton's 1993 tax legislation and by the state of Arkansas when she was first lady there in the late 1980's.
The Clinton campaign responded with a list of tax cuts Mrs. Clinton has proposed to spur the economy upstate. They also pointed out newspaper and magazine accounts quoting Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as crediting the 1993 plan with helping to stimulate the economy.
 
SCORECARD -- The negative commercial, as with several others questioning the trustworthiness of Mrs. Clinton, comes as two polls this week suggested that voters were developing a negative perception of Mr. Lazio, based in part on his performance in last week's debate. But, although people generally say they abhor them, negative commercials have been effective. This ad, though short on visual panache, offers reinforcement to Mr. Lazio's base of conservative supporters who despise tax increases almost as much as they despise Mrs. Clinton, and it may raise questions among elderly voters concerned about the fate of Social Security.

HEADLINE: Deadly Statistics: A Survey Of Crime and Punishment

BYLINE: By FORD FESSENDEN 

 BODY:
In its analysis, The New York Times examined homicide rates in two groups of states: the 12 states without the death penalty and the 36 states that passed laws within 10 years of the Supreme Court's 1972 Furman v. Georgia decision, which overturned all existing death penalty statutes. (New York and Kansas did not adopt the death penalty until the 1990's.)
The analysis found that homicide rates have not declined any more in the states that instituted the death penalty than in states that did not. 
 In fact, year after year, homicide rates in states with death penalties roughly mirrored the rates in states without capital punishment, with death penalty states 48 percent to 101 percent higher. That trend, criminologists say, provides evidence that something besides enactment of capital punishment laws drives homicides.
"It's clear that the states with the death penalty may want it more because they have more homicides," said Alfred Blumstein, director of the National Consortium on Violence Research at Carnegie Mellon University. "But it's not clear that it does them any good in terms of reducing homicide."
Even after executions resumed, homicide rates appeared unaffected, the analysis found. In the 21 states that carried out their first executions by 1993, homicide rates declined a collective 5 percent over the four years after the execution. But rates declined 12 percent in states that had not had executions in the same years.
The Times also looked at contiguous and demographically similar states, and found no pattern that differentiated death penalty states from those without capital punishment. Massachusetts and Rhode Island, with no death penalty, had homicide rates of 3.7 per 100,000 and 4.2 per 100,000, respectively, from 1977 to 1997, while Connecticut, a death penalty state, had a rate of 4.9 per 100,000.
The survey by The Times is similar to the type of analysis criminologists used in the years before the Supreme Court's Furman decision to conclude that state homicide rates were not affected by death penalty laws. The review by The Times confirms that those patterns appear to continue under the new era of capital punishment statutes.
Some researchers still contend that the death penalty has a measurable deterrent effect. "The statistics involved in such comparisons have long been recognized as devoid of scientific merit," Prof. Isaac Ehrlich, of the State University of New York at Buffalo, said of the analysis by The Times. He said that if variations like unemployment, income inequality, likelihood of apprehension and willingness to use the death penalty are accounted for, the death penalty shows a significant deterring effect. Most criminologists, however, discount Professor Ehrlich's work.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Comparing Four States"
The homicide rates in four states with different approaches to the death penalty follow a largely similar trend. The states are Texas, with by far the most executions since the death penalty was reinstated; California, with the largest death row population but relatively few executions; New York, with a small number of death row inmates and no executions, and Michigan, which has no death penalty.

HEADLINE: Clinton Focuses on Access Of Disabled to Computers

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich., Sept. 21

 BODY:
President Clinton gazed at a computer screen today at a community center for the disabled and -- using only the movement of his eyeballs -- haltingly typed out a two-word message: "Good morning."
Never mind that it was well past noon or that the computer repeatedly misread the president's stare. By experimenting with the innovative technology, the president sought to draw attention to the possibilities that computers present to those with disabilities. 
 Mr. Clinton, accompanied by administration aides who are disabled, said hooking up more handicapped people to the World Wide Web would integrate them into the economy and enable them to live fuller lives.
"We all know that not everyone has shared in the American economic renaissance," the president said in a speech at Mott Community College. "We all know there are people and places who have been left behind, including millions of Americans with significant disabilities who want to go to work, but whose path is blocked and who could work and contribute, not only to their own lives, but to the rest of us, as well."
As part of his continuing effort to bridge what the White House has labeled the digital divide, the president announced a variety of modest initiatives aimed at increasing the number of disabled people with access to computers.
He said 45 technology companies had pledged to do more to make their products and services accessible to the disabled. And he announced that the Department of Education would provide $16 million in grants to make cyberspace more accessible.
Studies show that only 24 percent of the country's 54 million people with disabilities have access to a computer, compared with 52 percent of those without disabilities. And a review of state and federal government Web sites by Darrell M. West, a Brown University professor, found that only 278 of 1,813 sites provided disability access.
One site that has received positive reviews is the White House home page. Susan Scheer, executive director of the Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York, said two disabled people, one blind and one with a head injury, reviewed www.whitehouse.gov recently and "both thought that it was very, very good."
White House aides said they chose to come to Flint because of an innovative computer center for the disabled here, not because of an embarrassing episode involving Vice President Al Gore this month.
Mr. Gore apologized to Chad Swiatecki, a local reporter who uses a wheelchair, after the journalist wrote an article saying he was unable to cover a Gore campaign event because it was not accessible to the handicapped.
Today, five wheel-chair-accessible vans were added to the motorcade to carry a few journalists and guests who were disabled.
On his tour of the nonprofit Disability Network, Mr. Clinton tried the EyeGaze system that allows eye movements to control a cursor.
"It's hard to do but if you train you can get it down," he said.

HEADLINE: Edward S. Gordon, 65, Is Dead; Founded Real Estate Firm

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Edward S. Gordon, a commercial real estate broker who built one of the largest real estate service companies in the New York metropolitan region, died yesterday at his home in Water Mill, N.Y. He was 65 and lived on Long Island and in New York City.
The cause was colon cancer, said his wife, Cheryl Gordon. 
 Mr. Gordon was known as an executive whose dealmaking skills allowed him to complete transactions in the complex real estate industry of New York and as one who could turn problem properties into assets.
He was also able to recruit high-powered commercial brokers to work for his company, which he founded in 1972, rather than for more established organizations. Before founding the company he was a broker at the firm of Huberth & Huberth.
By the time it was sold in 1996 for $74 million to the publicly traded Insignia Financial Group, the Edward S. Gordon Company rivaled such companies as Cushman & Wakefield in the number of leases arranged each year.
After his company's acquisition by Insignia, Mr. Gordon remained as a member of the office of the chairman as the company grew nationally and internationally. It now has offices in Chicago, Atlanta, San Francisco and London. The number of employees has grown from about 500 to approximately 3,500 in that time, a company spokesman said.
Last year, Insignia/ESG handled 130 of the 480 leases for space of more than 10,000 square feet in the New York area, compared with 92 for Cushman & Wakefield, according to CoStar, a real estate data collection company.
Mr. Gordon's clients included the Sony Corporation of America, for which he arranged to lease of the former AT&T building at 550 Madison Avenue, Chase Manhattan Bank, The New York Times Company, Viacom and the developer Donald J. Trump.
One of Mr. Gordon's most successful efforts when his company was new involved a building at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, a 44-story skyscraper at 45th Street that was completed in 1974 as the city was heading into a financial crisis and the demand for office space was evaporating. The building sat vacant for four years, resulting in tens of millions of dollars in losses to the owners and their lenders.
In 1978, Mr. Gordon persuaded the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and what was then the New York Telephone company to buy the structure, with New York Telephone occupying about half its 1.6 million square feet of space. The next year, he leased the remainder of the building to the International Paper Corporation, assuring the profitability of the property.
Both transactions received the Innovative Deal of the Year award from the Real Estate Board of New York.
Mr. Gordon was also involved in the rehabilitation in the late 1970's of the Chrysler Building, a landmark site that had been neglected by its previous owners. Part of his marketing campaign was a series of newspaper advertisements that showed the building rising from the bottom of the page on successive days, symbolizing its renovation.
Associates said Mr. Gordon brought an intensity to leisure activities as well as to business. Although he was not initially a golfer, he grew interested in the game while participating in the development of the Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton Mill on Long Island, which opened in 1992. Afterward, he built his own nine-hole course on his 60-acre estate across Scuttle Hole Road from the club and used it to help complete deals.
When he was called to active duty in the Army Reserve in 1961, Mr. Gordon took the departure from the family importing business as an opportunity to learn how to fly an airplane. He continually upgraded his skills, including learning how to fly jet aircraft. In the mid-1980's he made a solo flight over the Atlantic Ocean, according to Stephen B. Siegel, president of Insignia/ESG.
"He hired a band to meet him at the airport outside London where he landed," Mr. Siegel said.
Mr. Gordon was raised in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, one of two sons of a family whose business was the sale of imported novelties and hardware. He participated in the business during his teenage years, adding new lines of products. He switched to real estate after his tour of military service.
He is survived by his wife, the former Cheryl Gruetzmacher; his mother, Laura Gordon of Hallandale, Fla.; a brother, Allan Gordon of Greenwich, Conn.; a son, Kenneth, of New York City; a daughter, Robin, of Harrison, N.Y.; and four grandchildren. A daughter, Paula, died in 1986.
Mr. Gordon was previously married to the former Joan Grossberg, who is the mother of Kenneth and Paula. He was also married to the former Ellen Galowitz, who was the mother of Robin, and who died in 1993.
Andrew Farkas, the chairman of Insignia Financial Group, said he first encountered Mr. Gordon while he was still a college student and Mr. Gordon was the president of his own company. "I was building an econometric model of commercial real estate in Midtown Manhattan and I needed data," he said. "Eddie said I could have the data, but said that I had to give him the model if it worked. So the day after graduation, I did."
Mr. Farkas said Mr. Gordon resisted participating in various investment vehicles he subsequently promoted, but when Mr. Gordon decided to sell his company, he called Mr. Farkas first. "We did the deal over lunch," Mr. Farkas said.
Mr. Gordon sponsored advertisements promoting the achievements of New Yorkers. One was the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, now named for Intel, a contest that often had a disproportionate number of New York students as winners. One year when city students did especially well, he devised an advertisement with the headline, "It must be something in the water."

HEADLINE: Pentagon Says North Korea Is Still a Dangerous Military Threat

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Despite recent signs of a diplomatic warming on the Korean peninsula, a new Pentagon report has concluded that North Korea remains a dangerous military threat, pouring its limited resources into a buildup of conventional forces and the development of short- and long-range missiles.
The report, required by Congress and sent there last week, offers a far more pessimistic assessment of North Korea than many Clinton administration officials have expressed since the summit meeting between the North and South Korean leaders in June. 
 Even as the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, has pursued a string of diplomatic initiatives, the Pentagon's report warns that the North Korean Army has deployed "large numbers" of rocket launchers and artillery batteries along the demilitarized zone between the North and the South.
North Korea has also stockpiled chemical weapons and has continued developing its missiles, though it has honored its pledge to American negotiators last year that it would not test them, the report says. That finding echoes a broader intelligence report completed last summer that warned that North Korea's ballistic missiles remained a threat to the United States.
"While the historic summit between the North and the South holds the promise of reconciliation and change, no evidence exists of the fundamental precursors for change," said the report, which has not made public. "There is little or no evidence of economic reform or reform-minded leaders, reduction in military, or a lessening of anti-U.S. rhetoric."
Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, visiting South Korea today, appeared to underscore many of the report's findings. "North Korea's chemical, biological, nuclear and long-range missile programs continue to pose a threat to South Korea, the U.S. and other countries," he said at a news conference.
After meeting with South Korea's defense minister, Cho Sung Tee, Mr. Cohen said North Korea needed to take concrete steps to reduce tensions -- something American officials have said would include reducing the troops and weapons along the demilitarized zone. He added that the roughly 37,000 American troops stationed in South Korea would remain "for the indefinite future."
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and other senior administration officials have voiced strong support for the Korean diplomatic efforts. American officials have stepped up their own talks with the North Koreans, including a new round set to begin in New York City next week that will focus on the North's missile programs, its weapons sales and what the United States believes is its support for terrorism.
The Pentagon's report reflects a far more skeptical view in the administration about the motives behind Mr. Kim's surprising opening. The report said it was not yet clear whether the North Korean leader was truly committed to a peaceful resolution along what is called the last front of the cold war.
The report -- written by American commanders in South Korea, defense intelligence officials and policymakers at the Pentagon and signed by Mr. Cohen -- says that in the last year North Korea's military has continued "to grow in both conventional and asymmetrical forces," meaning nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, as well as the missiles to launch them.
The pessimism on North Korea's missile programs reflected a similar conclusion reached by a broad review by American intelligence agencies earlier this year when President Clinton was considering whether to move ahead with a limited national missile defense. Mr. Clinton postponed a decision last month but warned that the missile threat from countries like North Korea was real and growing.
The report says North Korea has more than 500 shorter-range Scud missiles and continues to make and field No Dong missiles able to strike American forces based in Japan. The report also warns that North Korea has "produced munition stockpiles of several types of chemical agents" and has the ability to produce biological weapons, using anthrax, smallpox and bacteria that cause cholera and the plague.
Despite economic hardships that have ravaged North Korea for the last 10 years, the report says, the government has allocated "precious resources" to its military forces, buying new fighter aircraft, making improvements in defenses and conducting its largest winter training exercises ever.
North Korea "maintains a dogged adherence to a 'military first' policy even against the backdrop of a nation facing severe economic and social challenges," it concludes.
The Pentagon's report acknowledges the North-South summit meeting and other diplomatic advances, as well as divisions among American experts about their significance.
One military officer who closely follows North Korea said today that the Pentagon was underestimating the potential for a breakthrough and resisting changes in its forces in South Korea that could ease tensions further. "The U.S., in my opinion, is obsessed with the status quo," he said.
But the report's overriding conclusion is that diplomacy has so far done little to alter the perceived threat. Economic and internal security problems, as well as "the specter of continued brinkmanship" by North Korean leaders, it says, "could contribute to regional instability and result in renewed military aggression by the North."

HEADLINE: In Testimony, Firestone Puts Onus on Ford

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Firestone began an unusually explicit attack on the safety of Ford Explorers in testimony before a House subcommittee today as the two companies criticized each other's products and executives from both companies tried to explain internal documents that committee members found incriminating.
Firestone said that operating a Ford Explorer with its tires inflated to the pressure recommended by the automaker, 26 pounds per square inch, provided a smaller "margin of safety" than existed for the Chevy Tahoe, Jeep Cherokee and other competing sport utility vehicles. Ford said that Firestone tires on 1996 Explorers were involved in fatal rollover accidents at a rate 15 times that of Goodyear tires on the same vehicle. 
 At one point, Helen O. Petrauskas, vice president for environmental and safety engineering at Ford, told Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, who presided at the hearing, that the 26 pounds per square inch her company recommended was not only the optimum level for handling, ride comfort and tire endurance, but was also well within the guidelines of the Tire and Rim Association, an industry group based in Akron, Ohio.
She was interrupted by John Lampe, executive vice president of Bridgestone/ Firestone Inc., who said that "26 is the minimum for a speed-rated tire, Congressman."
Most tires sold for vehicles that use highways are speed rated, a measure that gives the maximum speed at which they can operate. Mr. Lampe seemed to be suggesting that tires meant for highway use needed a minimum inflation of 26 pounds per square inch. Some tires sold for off-road use are not speed rated.
The Tire and Rim Association publishes a table that lists the carrying capacity of tires based on their air pressure, which does, in fact, go down to 20 pounds per square inch, although the significance of extending the table that far is not clear, with most highway vehicles carrying inflation recommendations of 26 pounds or higher.
"The only reason it does is that's how much room there is on the page," said an executive at another tire company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The carrying capacity of the Explorer is an issue because if the tires are overloaded, they overheat and may fail. Firestone agreed a decade ago with the 26-pound recommendation, but Mr. Lampe pointed out today that at 30 pounds per square inch, a level of inflation that his company has been recommending since August, the Explorer can handle 400 more pounds.
A table distributed by Firestone shows that the 2000 Explorer, with tires inflated at Ford's recommendation of 26 pounds, would be safe. But if the pressure fell by 7 pounds -- as is common, Firestone said, because many people fail to check their tire pressure -- the four-door, four-wheel- drive model would reach its carrying capacity. And if the pressure fell any further, it would be overloaded even if the weight of the passengers and cargo was within Ford's limits. The comparable "margin of safety" figures for models with two doors, or two-wheel drive, run from 8 to 12 pounds per square inch.
In contrast, according to Firestone, the Chevy Blazer and Tahoe, Dodge Durango and Jeep Grand Cherokee Laredo have margins ranging from 14 to 18 pounds per square inch.
Mr. Lampe, in his turn to testify, struggled to explain how a 1996 test of scores of tires at the company's Decatur, Ill., plant, where most of the faulty tires were made, managed to show a substantial number of failures in which treads separated from tires, the failure now blamed for about 100 deaths in cases in which Explorers have rolled over.
A Firestone document turned over to Congressional investigators described the test of 239 tires from the factory, some of them prototypes but 129 of them regular tires from the production run. Of those, investigators say, 15 failed; the company said it was 11; 6 had tread separations.
"That's more than acceptable, isn't it?" asked Bart Stupak, a Michigan Democrat, who said he wanted to know why the company did not notify Ford and federal officials.
Mr. Lampe replied that the test used was "very abusive" and far more severe than those required by the government. And he added, "In every case, we retested tires again; we didn't close our eyes; we didn't walk away from a problem."
But he did not say in testimony what the company did about the problem, other than test additional tires. He declined to answer the question in a session with reporters after his testimony, conducted in a hallway outside the hearing room.
Mrs. Petrauskas, in her testimony, tried to convince the members of the committee that it made no difference that the vehicle that Ford had used to test the Firestones at 26 pounds per square inch was not an Explorer, as the company had initially said, but an F-150 pickup truck rigged to mimic an Explorer's weight distribution. The company had previously said it used an Exporer for the tests.
The committee, struggling to complete its hearing and move on to work on legislation stiffening reporting rules, managed to hold its members' opening statements to 61 minutes, compared with more than two hours at its last hearing. Ideas varied, though, on what the law should say. Rodney Slater, the Secretary of Transportation, showed up late and endorsed criminal penalties for "egregious violations" of existing laws.
Committee members varied on whether instituting criminal penalties would be helpful. Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said it would probably encourage corporate executives not to cooperate with investigations, so as not to incriminate themselves. But the Senate Commerce Committee unanimously approved a bill on Wednesday that would provide such penalties.
Another issue is whether to allow the Transportation Department to establish a measurement of vehicles' tendency to roll over, and publish the data for consumers. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration would like to do so but has been blocked by Congress; today several committee members said they favored such an index.
There was still no clarification of why the tires fail. Mr. Lampe of Firestone, who said on Sept. 12 that his company had brought in an outside expert to determine why the tires had failed, said today that the expert had actually started work a couple of days ago.

HEADLINE: 'SOFT MONEY' BAN CALLED A PROBLEM FOR MRS. CLINTON

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton has become so dependent on soft-money donations to promote her candidacy that it will not be easy for her to forsake them. She would have to rely solely on financing from her official campaign committee, which has lagged in its fund-raising in recent months even as it spends at a marked rate.
The Clinton campaign had spent $14.9 million as of Aug. 23, according to its most recent disclosure filing to federal regulators. Only $4 million of that, or 27 percent, went to commercials, perhaps the most crucial item in a campaign budget. 
 Several political consultants not involved in the New York Senate race said they were surprised that so little of her money had been used for commercials. As a general rule, a campaign should spend 50 to 80 percent of its budget on them, the consultants said.
With most of the Clinton campaign's money consumed by salaries, travel and direct-mail solicitations, Mrs. Clinton has turned to advertising financed by soft money that she collected in league with Democratic allies in Washington and Albany.
Mrs. Clinton's reliance on soft money helps explain why her opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, has pressed in recent weeks for an agreement to prohibit it in the contest. Yesterday, the managers of the two campaigns met at a Midtown hotel to negotiate one, with no success.
The Democrats have channeled at least $5 million into soft-money advertisements praising Mrs. Clinton and attacking Mr. Lazio, campaign records show.
Mr. Lazio has not collected soft money, but some political committees and advocacy groups have bought commercials to aid him. Mr. Lazio's aides say those commercials cost a total of $350,000; the Clinton campaign puts the figure at $750,000.
Donations to candidates' campaigns, so-called hard money, are limited to $1,000 for a primary and $1,000 for a general election per person, with unions and corporations barred from contributing. Soft money is collected by the political parties, and anyone can give, in any amount.
The parties are supposed to use soft money for voter drives and other activities to build general support; technically, it cannot be spent directly to help candidates. The parties have increasingly sidestepped this rule by spending soft money on commercials that promote or criticize candidates without urging viewers to vote for or against them.
Mrs. Clinton appeared cautious yesterday in her comments about an agreement to prohibit soft money. She has said she will not renounce soft money until the Lazio campaign can guarantee that Republican and Conservative Party committees, as well as outside advocacy groups, stay out of the race.
Asked whether her interest in an agreement was genuine, Mrs. Clinton said she had broached the issue before either of her Republican opponents, Mr. Lazio or Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who dropped out of the race in May.
"I'm the one who called for it months and months ago," she said after an event in Buffalo yesterday. "I called for it when the mayor was in the race, and I called for it as soon as the congressman got in the race. We're just going to see how it develops."
The Clinton campaign later released a statement saying that the talks would continue today but noting that it had "real questions" about how such an agreement would be enforced. During the negotiations, the two sides discussed appointing prominent politicians or campaign finance experts as monitors.
The Clinton campaign is not alone in questioning whether an agreement can be enforced, given its voluntary nature. Some experts say these agreements often fall apart, and note that politicians often use them to posture, rather than to bring about real change.
Mrs. Clinton's aides defended her spending, saying that her campaign was not typical. They noted that she had been on the trail for more than a year and as a first lady had attracted enormous attention from the public and press. As a result, the campaign had to hire an extensive staff.
"Nobody has ever been through a campaign that has been at this level and intensity for this long," said Mandy Grunwald, a senior adviser to Mrs. Clinton.
Ms. Grunwald said she was not concerned that the campaign would run short of money for commercials in the final weeks before Election Day. "We will have the money that we need to do the job we want to do," she said.
Political consultants not involved in the race said the spending on commercials by the campaign was unusually low. "It's a lot of money to have been raised without having put that much on the air," said Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic consultant in New York City who is not involved in the Senate race.
While Mr. Lazio has not harvested soft money, fund-raising by his official campaign committee has flourished, in part because he has been able to reach out to donors around the nation who dislike Mrs. Clinton. In a seven-week period over the summer, he raised $10.7 million in hard money, while she took in $3.3 million. On Aug. 23, he had $10.2 million in the bank, while she had $7.1 million.
Since entering the race in May, Mr. Lazio has spent $9.5 million. Of that, $3.5 million, or 37 percent, has gone to commercials. While that amount is also relatively low, Mr. Lazio had to spend much of the money he raised at first to set up his campaign.
In Congress, Mr. Lazio supported legislation to ban soft money, but did not earn a reputation as a die-hard reformer. Democrats have noted that before becoming a Senate candidate, he raised soft money for Republican political committees in Washington.
In seeking an agreement, Mr. Lazio's aides acknowledged a tactical advantage: it would cut off a vital source of money for his rival. That is one reason the Lazio campaign has swiftly tried to counter any objections to an agreement from the Clinton campaign.
On Wednesday, Mrs. Clinton's aides pointed out that the New York Republican State Committee had indicated it would not abide by any agreement between the two candidates to bar spending by committees and groups outside their campaigns.
By yesterday, after prodding from the Lazio campaign, the Republican State Committee announced that it would refrain from spending soft money on the race while the two campaigns negotiated an agreement. The committee has produced just a single soft-money radio commercial.
Meanwhile, the New York State Democratic Committee, which has produced several soft-money television commercials to help Mrs. Clinton, released two more. One, to be shown in upstate markets, criticized Mr. Lazio's views on the upstate economy. The other, to be shown in New York City, seeks to link Mr. Lazio to former House Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Campaigning last night in Schenectady, Mr. Lazio called the party's actions "shameless."
"It is the worst possible statement about their sincerity in terms of coming to an agreement," Mr. Lazio said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Campaign Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

 BODY:

THE DEMOCRATS
 
A SHOW OF SUBSTANCE -- All year, Vice President Al Gore has campaigned as the candidate of substance and detail (sometimes numbing detail), while portraying Gov. George W. Bush of Texas as fuzzy on substance and detail. Now Mr. Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, is following suit. Yesterday while visiting a computer chip plant in Florida, a major swing state, he delivered the first in a series of speeches that his aides said were designed to reinforce the image that the Democratic ticket is one of substance and detail. For 45 minutes he spoke on the "new economy" and the glories of high-tech training and research, and by the time he finally finished he had also touched on the uses of steam engines in the 18th century, the computing capacity of electronic gadgets like Palm Pilots and the need for the government to pay down debt to keep interest rates low. "We are literally at what might be called the big bang stage of the information technology universe," he said. Richard Perez-Pena (NYT) 

THE AD CAMPAIGN
 
SWIPE AT DIVERSITY DISAVOWED -- Democrats called it race-baiting this week when a conservative group started broadcasting a television advertisement in Missouri, a swing state, that features a white woman saying that she pulled her son out of public school because there was "a bit more diversity than he could handle." And after taking a look at the ad, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, Jim Nicholson, condemned it, "forcefully and without equivocation," as he put it. At the same time, Mr. Nicholson charged that a pair of Democratic advertisements in 1998 were similarly racist and demanded that the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Joe Andrew, condemn them. Mr. Andrew did not immediately respond. The latest ad, which shows a multiracial group of teenagers milling around as the woman speaks, concludes with a "Vote Republican" plea and is sponsored by a group that calls itself the Republican Ideas Political Committee. Republican officials say the group has no ties to the party. (NYT)
 
THE GREEN PARTY
 
NADER'S 'CATCH-22' -- Though he has little chance of participating in the presidential debates, Ralph Nader, the Green Party candidate, says he plans to attend the three forums in Boston, St. Louis and Salem, N.C. as a "commentator," if any reporters want his analysis of the give-and-take. He says, too, that ABC and the Fox Network are still considering his proposal for additional debates that would include him and Patrick J. Buchanan, the Reform Party candidate. Asked why he has not won the 15 percent poll ratings needed to qualify for the three debates, Mr. Nader replied: "It's a Catch-22. If you don't get mass media, you don't go up in the polls. If you don't up in the polls, you can't get mass media." James Dao (NYT)
 
THE INTEREST GROUPS
 
N.A.A.C.P. WEIGHS IN -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is spending $9 million on political advertisements and door-to-door organizing to increase black voter turnout in a dozen states in which the presidential race or one or more Congressional races are rated tossups. Run through a new organization, the N.A.A.C.P. National Voter Fund, the effort has registered 21,000 new voters and signed up 2,345 volunteers to help get black voters to the polls, said Julian Bond, the association's board chairman. The group will also run advertisements about the candidates' stands on particular topics without urging viewers to vote one way or the other. As a group, black voters have favored Democrats. The targeted states are Arkansas, Georgia, Illinois, Kentucky, Michigan, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Wisconsin. (AP)
 
THE TRAVEL LOG -- Yesterday was the kind of day that saw Gov. George W. Bush don a blue-on-blue Regis Philbin ensemble to go "Live With Regis," where he talked of strengthening Social Security and cutting taxes. It was also the kind of day that led Al Gore to suggest that Mr. Bush must have thought he was on Mr. Philbin's other show, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," given his views on taxes and retirement money. HEADLINE: Web Retailer To Bring Jobs To the Bronx

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
A huge building in the South Bronx that has been largely vacant for several years is to be taken over by a major Internet retailer in a move that will provide 900 jobs in the area, city officials said yesterday.
The decision of the company, Webvan Group Inc., to move to Hunts Point comes as Internet and telecommunications companies are rediscovering former manufacturing areas in the city as ideal solutions to their space needs. 
 "This is a huge deal for the South Bronx," said Fernando Ferrer, the borough president. "It is the largest single shot of jobs in the borough during my public service, which goes back 20 years." And many of the jobs, he said, would be fairly well paying: $30,000 and more a year.
Webvan plans to move into a nearly 10-acre single-story building at 331 Tiffany Street and use it as a distribution center for the groceries and other consumer items it ships to customers who place their orders over the Internet. The building was a distribution center for the Alexander's department store chain from the 1970's until it went out of business eight years ago.
As part of the expansion into the northeast, Webvan, which is based in California, is also building a distribution center in North Bergen, N.J., a company spokesman, Bud Grebey, said.
Although Webvan signed a lease for the 400,000-square-foot building in April, and despite the deal's economic benefit to the South Bronx, it had not been publicly disclosed because of problems in scheduling an announcement by city and state officials whose agencies played a role in bringing the company to the site by offering it incentives, one official said.
Mr. Ferrer said that the city's Economic Development Corporation played a major part by "coming up with a package of incentives" for the company.
John Melia, a spokesman for Mr. Ferrer, said the agencies had agreed to provide benefits worth about $11 million to the company in the form of city and state sales tax abatements and reductions in property taxes.
In addition, the company will get tax credits for every person it hires who lives in the area, he said, and the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, an affiliate of the borough president's office, will use its job data bank to help Webvan hire nearby residents. He said the workforce would initially number 500 and eventually grow to 900.
The company's decision to move to the Bronx comes as the borough continues to enjoy an economic revival after the lean years of the 1970's and 80's, when it lost population, jobs and housing and became a national symbol of urban decay.
"The addition of 900 jobs goes a long way to extending the Bronx's revival," Mr. Melia said. "Attracting a company that is part of what many consider the new economy is a demonstration that the hard work that's gone into turning around the South Bronx is paying off."
Webvan's planned move to the area also illustrates how much in demand old industrial buildings have become for Internet-related and telecommunications companies.
The old Bush Terminal on the waterfront in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, for example, is being converted into a technology campus. Other dot-com and telecommunications companies have been moving into industrial buildings in the Brooklyn waterfront area known as Dumbo and in Long Island City, Queens.
Webvan has signed a 10-year lease for the entire Bronx building, with options to renew, said Lawrence Smith, an executive vice president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot, the real estate firm that represented both Webvan and the building's owner, the Feil Organization, in arranging the lease. Mr. Smith would not disclose the rent.
Renovations have already started. But while local officials said they expected Webvan to move in early next year, Mr. Grebey, the company spokesman, said, "We have not announced a timetable."
Mr. Grebey said that he did not know the average salaries that would be paid at the Bronx operation, but that the highest-paid workers would be the couriers delivering the ordered goods, who would be paid about $41,000 in their first year. All employees will receive stock options, he said.
While complaints of truck traffic have been increasing from residents of Hunts Point, Mr. Ferrer said he did not see that as a problem with Webvan's operation. He said that the company's site was a "straight shot" from nearby highways and that "the truck impact will be negligible in the residential area" of Hunts Point.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: IN WASHINGTON STATE;
Bill Gates's Senator Confronts Upstart Internet Challenger

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 21

 BODY:
Just as Henry M. Jackson was once known as the Senator from Boeing, Washington State's Slade Gorton is delighted to call himself the Senator from Microsoft, a man whose pit-bull advocacy for the software giant in the nation's capital has earned him the corporation's gratitude and campaign contributions from William H. Gates and other company officials.
But as he runs for a fourth Senate term this fall, Mr. Gorton finds himself in a fierce race against a Democratic opponent, more than 30 years his junior, who has even closer ties to another large software company in the Northwest. 
 She is Maria Cantwell, a top executive at RealNetworks, a Seattle company that pioneered audio and visual technology on the Internet and that in just a few years helped her accumulate a personal fortune her campaign estimates at $40 million. Ms. Cantwell, a 41-year-old former congresswoman, vows to spend "whatever it takes" to unseat Mr. Gorton.
That RealNetworks and Microsoft happen to be rivals has only added spice to the Senate race here, and Ms. Cantwell herself is a highly noteworthy candidate in several respects. While other high-tech millionaires have run for the Senate, she is the first from the Internet industry. And, as the Center for American Women and Politics at Rutgers University puts it, no woman in the country's history has spent a greater amount of money earned entirely by herself on a race for major elective office.
After spending $5 million and decisively winning Tuesday's Democratic primary over the state insurance commissioner, Deborah Senn, Ms. Cantwell is generating huge attention here for one more reason: she might just win in November.
Several recent statewide polls have shown her close to -- or in one case, dead even with -- Mr. Gorton. And aside from her money and relentless pitch as the candidate of the "new economy," several other factors have helped to tighten a contest that now offers Democrats a solid chance to pick up a Senate seat that had once seemed safe for the incumbent after several better-known Democrats, including Gov. Gary Locke, passed on the race.
For one thing, at 72 years old and a fixture of public life here for more than 40 years, Mr. Gorton finds himself facing eerie parallels in Ms. Cantwell's themes to those he invoked in 1980, when he ended the 44-year Congressional career of Senator Warren G. Magnuson, then 75.
For that race 20 years ago, Mr. Gorton pointedly jogged to the state Capitol in Olympia to file papers for his candidacy. And in one TV spot, showing him running through a park in Spokane, an announcer asked viewers to imagine a senator "who is still in the prime of his life."
Now Ms. Cantwell is stressing this time-for-a-new-generation theme. She reminds voters that Mr. Gorton has been in elected office for about as long as she has been alive, and says it is time for a "vigorous" senator with "new ideas."
She has also picked up on environmentalists' continuing ire over a legislative maneuver by Mr. Gorton last year. In attaching a rider to a bill providing aid to Kosovo war victims, he assisted a Texas company's bid to open a gold mine in rural Washington which would use a cyanide-leach process that could pollute the area's rivers. Ms. Cantwell accuses Mr. Gorton of advocating "19th-century solutions to 21st-century problems."
In response, Cynthia Bergman, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gorton's campaign, said that Ms. Cantwell has "got new money, but old-style government solutions."
Officials at Microsoft describe Senator Gorton as a leader on high-technology issues. He has been a vehement critic of the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the company, and his ties to Microsoft have been further strengthened by several daylong visits to the corporate campus in Redmond, where he has received detailed briefings on how Microsoft products work.
To judge by federal election records, there is little question that Mr. Gorton is Microsoft's candidate. The corporate political action committee has given him $10,000, and Mr. Gates, the chairman, as well as Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive, have each contributed the maximum of $2,000 for this election cycle. All told, Microsoft employees have contributed $97,925 through Aug. 30, according to the nonpartisan Campaign Study Group of Springfield, Va.
Ms. Cantwell has received just $8,500 from Microsoft workers, none of them top officials. But she has received $47,300 from RealNetworks employees. And the company's billionaire founder, Robert Glaser, has held fund-raisers for her.
Far more important, Mr. Glaser did the favor of hiring her as one of the company's first employees shortly after she was voted out of Congress in the Republican tide of 1994, a move that ultimately turned her into a multimillionaire. Starting as vice president of marketing, she rose to become senior vice president for the consumer and e-commerce divisions. She is now on leave from the company to pursue the Senate seat.
Ms. Cantwell was considered a rising star when she was elected to the state legislature at the age of 28 and to Congress six years later, in 1992. But she lost re-election from a suburban Seattle district that happens to include the Microsoft campus.
Despite her millions, or perhaps because of them, Ms. Cantwell has taken pains in the campaign to portray her life as unassuming. Never married, she lives in a modest suburban home with her mother and their dog, Chuck, a Yorkshire terrier that the campaign describes as diabetic.
The supporting campaign roles by Seattle's cybertitans are intriguing. Mr. Glaser, who once worked at Microsoft, earned its wrath when he testified in Congress in 1998 that Microsoft had tried to cripple his technology with code written into a competing software program, a charge Microsoft stoutly denied.
Even so, it is unlikely that Ms. Cantwell, if she wins, will call herself "the Senator from RealNetworks" -- or poke her finger in Microsoft's eye.
She opposes the Justice Department's proposal to break up the corporation. And officials at both companies say that they agree on a wide range of legislative issues, like electronic privacy laws and expanded immigration visas for foreign workers, and that they have been partners on some business projects.
"Even before RealNetworks existed, Maria was an effective and outspoken advocate in Congress for Microsoft and the technology industry," said Alex Alben, RealNetworks' vice president for government affairs.
If Ms. Cantwell becomes a senator, said Vivek Varma, a Microsoft spokesman, "we'd work fine with her. We worked well with Maria when she was in Congress. But Slade has been a real leader on all the issues affecting Microsoft, and he's earned our strong support."
Mr. Gorton also says Washington State needs his seniority and influence in Congress -- a point Mr. Magnuson invoked before Mr. Gorton beat him in 1980.
Still, money is a big issue in this campaign -- both Ms. Cantwell's, and that of several Native American tribes, who have feuded with Mr. Gorton for years and vow to spend $2 million or more to defeat him.
Mr. Gorton said he had a "secret weapon" of thousands of grass-roots supporters who would help him win re-election, though Democrats, depicting him as a patron of corporate interests, scoff at the claim.
"When someone like Slade starts talking about his grass-roots appeal, you know he's in real trouble," said Cathy Allen, a Democratic political strategist in Seattle.
Republicans, meanwhile, said they were confident they could use Ms. Cantwell's largely self-financed campaign, and her short career in Congress, against her. Brett Bader, a Republican consultant here who, like Ms. Allen, is not directly involved in the race, said Ms. Cantwell had "showed up as a starry-eyed freshman and signed onto Clinton's agenda, and the voters in a moderate, swing district dumped her."
"There is only one reason she is given such a chance right now," he added. "It's simply her checkbook. And that's not enough to get her across the finish line."
Mr. Gorton has accused Ms. Cantwell of trying to buy the election, and his campaign offers a pie chart depicting how little money the Democrat is taking in from "Real People" as opposed to "Herself."
Ms. Cantwell shrugs off such criticism. "The public," she said, "would rather have me spend my own money than get my money from special interests."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Questions on Spending

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:

The New York State Democratic Committee began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement yesterday.
 
PRODUCER -- Axelrod & Associates
 
ON THE SCREEN -- As with several previous advertisements supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton, this one focuses on Representative Rick A. Lazio's tax proposal and his stand on Medicare. The spot opens with white words on a black screen that ask whether Mr. Lazio can be trusted. He is shown standing at a lectern with Newt Gingrich, then sitting next to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas at a meeting. This is the first time that a Democratic commercial has used an image of Mr. Bush in this Senate campaign. During both scenes, the narration criticizes Mr. Lazio's economic policies. The advertisement ends by repeating the two images of Mr. Lazio next to Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Bush. 

THE SCRIPT -- "Can we trust Rick Lazio to fight for us? He helped write the Gingrich budget slashing Medicare. Now Lazio's trying to hide the true cost of his trillion-dollar tax plan. Like the Bush plan, experts say Lazio's would eat up the surplus, leaving no money to pay off the debt and extend the life of Social Security and Medicare. Hillary's plan? Affordable tax cuts, to help families pay for college and long-term care, and to help small businesses create jobs. Tell Lazio he's not fighting for us. Not then. Not now."
 
ACCURACY -- This commercial, like several others produced by supporters of Mrs. Clinton, tries to hold Mr. Lazio responsible for supporting Mr. Gingrich's plan to slash $270 million from Medicare. But Mr. Lazio voted to cut the rate of growth of Medicare, not the actual budget, as his campaign has repeatedly pointed out. The advertisement also castigates Mr. Lazio's tax plans by saying the proposals would leave no surplus. In fact, those plans would leave several million dollars of surplus, his campaign aides say. Although Mr. Lazio initially said his plan would cost $775 billion over 10 years, people have pointed out that it would be closer to $1 trillion.

SCORECARD -- The first line in the commercial raises the question of trust, one that Mrs. Clinton's campaign has been trying to raise with Mr. Lazio. It takes a swipe at a Lazio advertisement saying he is "one of us." By associating Mr. Lazio with Mr. Bush and Mr. Gingrich, the spot seeks to project the image of conservative politicians whose policies could spell economic disaster for middle-class New Yorkers. EDWARD WONG

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ENERGY ISSUE;
Plan to Tap Oil Reserve Strikes Some Experts As Temporary Answer

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE and DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
When the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was created in the 1970's, it was seen as a defense against supply disruptions that threatened national security -- not as a political tool to manage price disruptions.
But now economists, oil traders, refiners and politicians are divided about whether current high prices and low supplies of petroleum constitute a new kind of crisis that should be addressed by tapping the reserve. And beyond the debate about intervening in the market, one big question looms: Would dumping a big supply of oil on the market work to lower prices? 
 In the market for crude oil, where prices are set on the limited quantities of oil sold in so-called spot markets, a decision to tap the reserve is likely to drive down the price of oil in the short term. Crude oil for November delivery closed yesterday at $34 a barrel, down $1.24 from the day before at the end of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil prices also dipped, but much less, largely on the prospect of a release from the reserve.
But it is unclear whether a move by the administration would have more than a temporary effect on prices. And it is doubtful whether the new supplies would reach the market soon enough to overcome potential shortages in heating oil that loom if the weather turns cold prematurely.
At the same time, other experts worry that tapping the oil from the reserve in response to higher prices would merely lessen its impact if a more serious supply disruption occurred.
"Using the reserve for price manipulation is dangerous business," said Ian Shepherdson, chief domestic economist with High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "If they release enough of it, the price will go down. The problem is that you can't do this forever, and fairly soon you will want to rebuild the reserve."
What troubles policy makers and economists this fall are the low supplies of heating oil, as both the cold weather and the presidential vote approach. The Northeast consumes most of the heating oil in the country. But this year, inventories of heating oil in New England total only 6 million barrels, compared with 16.3 million barrels a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Supplies proved inadequate when a cold snap struck in late January, causing heating oil prices to spike. Lower inventories of heating fuel this winter could leave the region even more vulnerable to price volatility and possible shortages. As a result of tight supplies, heating oil prices have jumped 70 percent over the last year.
Tapping the reserve "is really a short-term policy targeted at home heating oil," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former chief economic adviser in the Clinton White House who is now the dean of the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.
"It's not an attempt to change the overall market dynamics," said Ms. Tyson, who has been advising the Gore campaign on economic issues. "That's perfectly consistent with the formulation of the reserve."
Since last autumn, Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, has tried to convince the Clinton administration to use the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, arguing that the reluctance on the part of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to provide more crude called for the government to step in to halt spiraling prices. Although Mr. Schumer had proposed that 30 million barrels be released, he said he believed the Gore proposal was a fair first step, and more important, a sign that the administration may be closer to unlocking the oil.
"The administration is clearly concerned about prices," Mr. Schumer said. "So far, it is more of a price issue, but any kind of problem that created a disruption in supply would create real problems. We are definitely on the edge."
Stored in salt domes along the Gulf Coast, the 570-million-barrel petroleum reserve was established after the first Arab oil embargo in 1973-74 to shield the country against similarly severe breaks in supply. The only time it has been used was in 1991, during the Persian Gulf war that followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. At the time, the government wanted to sell about 30 million barrels but issued 17.3 million instead, because the bids it received from oil traders were too low. Oil prices, which had been climbing after Iraq invaded Kuwait, fell sharply on the news of the release.
If President Clinton authorized a release, getting more heating oil into the low stocks of the Northeast would take about 40 to 50 days, experts said. The petroleum reserve's office in New Orleans would review bids for the oil and ship it to buyers, all within 15 days. Then the oil would travel another week to two weeks to the Northeast and another 10 days would be required to refine it into heating oil.
Critics of tapping the reserve point out that a greater supply of crude may not help overcome the potential shortages. And even if prices fall in the spot market, consumers would not necessarily see much of an effect at the retail level.
Industry experts estimate that the price of as much as half the oil that is delivered responds to those fluctuations from daily trading, or the spot market. The remaining oil is priced based on long-term contracts, which provides a steady supply and protects buyers somewhat from the daily price fluctuations. But even those supplies are determined by formulas based on the spot prices. There is no fixed price contract for oil.
Heating oil stocks fell to perilously low levels in April, as a series of cuts in crude oil production by OPEC shrank the supply of oil to refiners. At the same time, demand for petroleum products has been high because of the robust economy.
Since the spring, refineries in the United States have been playing catch up to produce more heating oil and are now running at about 95 percent of their full capacity. Refineries are actually producing more heating oil now than they did a year ago, but it is not been enough to restore inventories.
As a result, more oil from the reserve may bolster crude inventories but do little to relieve the bottleneck at refineries.
"We're like every other refinery," said Bill Greehey, chief executive of Valero Energy Corporation, a major refiner in San Antonio. "We're running at 100 percent and maximizing our output of heating oil. These crude inventories won't do anything to create fuel oil. It just sounds good, sounds like a quick fix."
If the Clinton administration moves to issue oil from the reserve, most industry analysts expect it to be after next week's summit in Caracas, Venezuela, of leaders of the OPEC countries. Officials said that Saudi Arabia, the cartel's de facto leader, was aware that the White House might use the reserve and that its leaders approved of the move.
"The Saudis welcome some help from us," said one industry expert close to the Saudis. "They don't want this oil from their own back and they want some help with the price, because everyone thinks it's too high."
