SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2594 words

HEADLINE: Williamsburg Rethinks History

BYLINE: By KATHERINE ASHENBURG; KATHERINE ASHENBURG is the author of "Going to Town: Architectural Walking Tours in Southern Ontario" (McFarlane, Walter & Ross).

 BODY:
TO begin, a confession: Mobcaps embarrass me. When I visit a restored house, an interpreter in historical costume makes my heart sink. The hair and makeup are modern, the shoes are usually all wrong; the interpreter looks uncomfortable and I feel doubly so. On the other hand, an old building furnished as it was originally is one of the best windows into the past that I know.
So I approached my second trip to Colonial Williamsburg, the restored capital of pre-Revolutionary Virginia, with ambivalence. The first was more than 30 years ago, when I was a college sophomore. I dimly remember touring the Governor's Palace and the powder magazine, and eating hominy for the first time. When it came to 18th-century architecture and history, I was pretty much a blank slate, and I thought Williamsburg was terrific. 
 Since then I've learned some architectural history and visited restorations on three continents. I've also read the redoubtable Ada Louise Huxtable's blistering attack on Williamsburg in "The Unreal America: Architecture and Illusion." In that 1997 book, Ms. Huxtable, a former architecture critic for The New York Times, fingers Williamsburg as the ancestor of Disneyland and theme parks in general. An inaccurate prettification of a pioneer society where things were often unjust as well as asymmetrical, it is, she said in an interview, "as phony as a nine-dollar bill."
Scholarship supports some of Ms. Huxtable's judgments. The beneficiary of John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s intense patriotism, Colonial Williamsburg was created in the 1920's and 30's as a hymn to democracy and neo-Classical good taste. Restoration was in its infancy and Williamsburg's architects and historians relied on some documentation and a lot of speculation and wishful thinking. They sculptured topiaries where the settlers had kitchen gardens. Trained in the Beaux-Arts school of impeccable regularity, the architects gave the reconstructed Capitol a symmetry it never knew. They fabricated a pastel world populated by white male gentry.
The real town was ruder, dustier and more impermanent-looking. Half its Revolutionary-era population of 1,800 were slaves, a fact largely ignored until the 1970's. Since then, Williamsburg's staff of historians and curators has been trying to redress the early misconceptions. Some of them are easier to fix than others.
But first, the mobcap issue. I am happy to report that Colonial Williamsburg made me eat my prejudice against the floppy cotton women's cap ubiquitous in the 18th century. The costume department is doing something brilliantly correct when it comes to panniers and breeches. The colors are appropriately faded or bright depending on status, the fabrics convincing, the result almost never embarrassing.
For three sultry August days, I toured Williamsburg, standing in line to enter the wigmaker's shop or the printing press or a clapboard house, following an interpreter's lantern around town in the dark while he told local ghost stories, visiting its three museums devoted to folk art, archaeology and the decorative arts. At its least demanding, Williamsburg is a sure-fire family vacation, with abundant opportunities to dress up in costumes, learn to shoot cannons, watch playlets up and down the main street and shop for replicas of Colonial stuff. At its most demanding, it's an open university of the 18th century. I was particularly curious about three things: the adjustments made to the buildings and furnishings, the gardens and the depiction of minorities.
Williamsburg's exterior has changed, but subtly, in the direction of reality. The main street is now punctuated with horse droppings; the paint on houses and picket fences has been allowed to weather. Admittedly, there's little that can be done about the Capitol's mistakenly symmetrical facade, and very few visitors will come armed with the relevant scholarly articles, so well-versed interpreters are crucial. Unfortunately, when I asked our apparently knowledgeable guide to the Capitol about the building, he assured us it was "the exact duplicate of the one built in 1699."
There are lots of things at Williamsburg that make the purist swallow hard, particularly the seamless mixing of real and reproduction. (There are 53 original buildings, commingling with 16 diabolically clever reconstructions.) But Williamsburg sees itself primarily as a history museum, a place to experience some crucial days in the 1760's and 70's, as Virginians shifted from being loyal Britons to Americans. Those who care whether a building is 250 or 50 years old (I think everyone should, but that is not a universal view) can always look in the Official Guide to Colonial Williamsburg ($6.95), where the original buildings are marked with an asterisk.
Furnishings are easier to adjust than buildings, and since the redecoration of the Governor's Palace in 1981, Williamsburg has been startling visitors who associate the 18th century only with pastels and daintiness. The Palace's elaborate antiques, brocades and Oriental rugs were replaced by less ornate furniture, brightly checked slipcovers and oilcloth floor coverings. The governor's formerly frosty bedroom was repainted bright yellow. It's a much more vivid, less predictable look, attested to by scrupulous research. Similarly, in the George Wythe House, on the Palace green, the hall has been repapered in an authentic, downright gaudy turquoise, and a wonderful upstairs bedroom is papered in big, bold purple and cream stripes.
Fascinating as these changes are to me, they don't loom large in the interpreters' remarks: Their emphasis is political and social history. After I'd peppered the interpreter in the Palace with questions about color and fabrics, she suggested I visit the DeWitt Wallace Decorative Arts Museum. Good advice. The museum, devoted to English and American decorative arts, is a treat. Here would be a fine place for a permanent exhibit about the redesigning of Williamsburg, with documentation, archaeological evidence and plenty of before-and-after photographs.
Restorations inevitably reflect their own time, and the original Colonial Williamsburg could be described as Virginia in the 1770's, seen through the lens of the 1930's. The easiest way to experience that is to visit Carter's Grove, an 18th-century plantation six miles from Williamsburg. Redesigned and enlarged by Archibald and Mollie McCrea in the 1930's, it was given to Williamsburg in the 1960's.
The original idea, to restore the house back to its 18th-century condition, was gradually relinquished. Not only would it have been horrendously expensive, but Williamsburg's curators were also increasingly dubious about the value of such restoration. The McCreas' interpretation of the 18th century was a fine example of the Colonial Revival, a historical moment in its own right. So the plantation today is a 1930's and 40's version of the Colonial period, with the entrance hall's superb woodwork stained instead of painted white as would have been done in the 18th century, with midcentury telephones and radios, and a huge Colonial fireplace in the kitchen installed by the McCreas.
When I visited Carter's Grove, an actress portraying Mrs. McCrea was playing solitaire in the smoking room. I remarked that it looked as if it were furnished in a melange of 18th-century pieces and good reproductions, and she replied, in character, that not all her guests were as bold as I was, but that was correct. Then she proceeded to point out pieces that ranged from Jacobean to Victorian.
Like the buildings, only more so, Williamsburg's gardens were spun from facts, guesswork and romance. As Arthur Shurcliff, the mastermind of Colonial Williamsburg's landscaping, began his work in 1931, the wife of the town's mayor complained to her diary that the man had "boxwood on the brain." Indeed he did, and his elegant topiaries and hedges rely more on English and North Carolinian precedents than the actualities of Colonial Virginia.
The jewel in his crown, the gardens of the Governor's Palace, contains a holly maze for which the Williamsburg historians insisted there was no evidence. But Shurcliff won (he usually did), and the maze has been a favorite with visitors. His creations were enormously influential in the history of American gardening, and today, while some of their extravagances have been scaled back, they remain indubitably beautiful.
Because the official guide is very short on horticultural information, I bought "The Gardens of Colonial Williamsburg," by Gordon W. Chappell and M. Kent Brinkley, both Williamsburg landscape architects. Its $29.95 price was more bearable than its hardcover, 9-by-12-inch format (a portable paperback version would be welcome), but I toted it bravely on a morning's perambulation. It proved a wise investment, teaching me about the original town's formal Anglo-Dutch gardens and Shurcliff's embroideries on that theme.
THE gardens range from a schematic design that borrows from 17th-century "physick" gardens (the John Blair herb garden on Duke of Gloucester Street) to the lush, interlocking symmetries of dahoon holly and boxwood at the Bryan House (also on Duke of Gloucester Street).
The Elkanah Deane garden (on the Palace green) is a good example of a Shurcliff design that has been downscaled. Originally it included perennial borders, bulbs and numerous topiaries too ambitious for an Irish coachmaker like Deane, so the flowers have been de-emphasized. It's now a peaceful, shady garden starring eight linden trees and relaxed-looking parterres of myrtle and boxwood.
As I walked and read, like Arthur Shurcliff, I became besotted with boxwood. Although it accommodates itself to the Alice-in-Wonderland shapes of the topiary carver, left on its own in Virginia's balmy climate it grows and grows, billowing and mounding itself into cloudlike forms that can reach 12 feet high and 8 across.
Happily lost in the Brush-Everard garden's vast, 19th-century hedge, I heard men's voices near the house, which is on the Palace green, arguing the rights and wrongs of rebellion against the English and what it might mean for them. Through a gap, I could see three "slaves," their debate watched by a smattering of visitors. Eavesdropping on the Revolution, as it touched some of society's humblest members, while shielded by venerable boxwood -- it was a uniquely Williamsburg moment.
An encounter like that represents the more visible side of Williamsburg's ongoing revision, compared with the quieter fine-tuning of its buildings and gardens. Some of the rethinking of the town's social history does show up in buildings, notably the Public Hospital and the slave quarters at Carter's Grove. In the Public Hospital, visitors enter the world of the mentally ill, via a punitive 18th-century cell and a more cozy 19th-century one. A 1985 reconstruction of America's first institution devoted to mental illness, built in 1773, the hospital traces two centuries of treatment, from the ducking chair and bleeding instruments to gardening and fishing excursions.
The chink-and-daub (wood and a combination of mud, shells and grass) slave quarters at Carter's Grove -- two small rooms meant to sleep four to six slaves each, and a slightly superior foreman's house -- were recreated in 1989. On the morning I visited the dark, smoky quarters, an interpreter in work clothes gave my group a bleak introduction to, as he put it, "not just a society that owned slaves, but a society organized around slavery."
Most of Williamsburg's new attention to the non-elite comes through the interpreters and the playlets and educational programs that happen in and around the buildings all day. (Playlets and programs are listed in the daily guide, but no one visitor is likely to see them all.) The white "maid" showing us around the Raleigh Tavern was asked by a visitor if the innkeeper's slaves worked for room and board. She corrected that briskly: "They work because they're his possessions," emphasizing the last word.
The interpreters stay resolutely in character, expecting a modern audience to see 18th-century beliefs for what they were. I dropped in on a question-and-answer session with the "schoolmaster" of the local school for Indian boys, and heard him matter-of-factly describe their "typically Indian" lack of punctuality, ambition and modesty. No doubt a just representation of the 18th-century attitude, but I hoped the parents of three raptly listening boys sitting near me would clarify that afterward.
Later that day, I went to the Secretary's Office next to the Capitol, where a staff historian (not in costume) discussed the tightening vise of 18th-century slavery laws. The attendance was standing room only, a perspiring room full of whites and blacks, some with school-age children.
They could have been shopping, drinking lemonade, or touring the print shop. Instead, they were listening to a university-level lecture and asking penetrating questions about the creation of a slave society. It may not have been exactly what John D. Rockefeller Jr. intended, but it looked as if Williamsburg's commitment to democracy didn't end in the 1770's.
 
When wild boar was fast food
For hotel and restaurant reservations, admission tickets and information on Colonial Williamsburg, call (800) 447-8679.
Admission tickets, covering one to five days, range from $30 to $45. Tickets for ages 6 to 17 cost $18 and are valid for up to a week; children under 6 admitted free.
 
Hotels
The Colonial Williamsburg Foundation offers lodgings at several price levels.
The most economical, Governor's Inn, is three blocks' walk or a free shuttle bus from the Historic Area, with an outdoor swimming pool and a game room. A good-size double room rents for $91.
The Colonial Houses are rooms in a variety of buildings in the Historic Area, from taverns to a laundry. A charming room in the reconstructed Brick House Tavern, on Duke of Gloucester Street, has good reproduction furniture and a fireplace, along with air-conditioning, for $135.
The Williamsburg Lodge, just outside the Historic Area, has large rooms decorated with reproductions from the nearby Folk Art Center, several restaurants and bars, and a fitness center. Doubles: $205.
The Williamsburg Inn, the most luxurious of the foundation's lodging choices, is partly closed for renovations; reservations should be made well in advance. Doubles are $425 a night.
 
Restaurants
Colonial Williamsburg has four pleasant reconstructed Colonial taverns, with the occasional entertainment and sing-along during dinner. Unfortunately, they offer better reading than eating: the 18th-century menus are diverting, but the food only middling to good.
Dinner for two with wine at Shields Tavern on Duke of Gloucester Street, featuring scalloped crab and cornbread-stuffed quail and wild boar sausage for entrees, would cost $75. Lunch for two at the King's Arms, also on Duke of Gloucester Street, featuring a fried oyster sandwich or Norfolk pottage pie as typical main courses, washed down by cider, is about $25.
For a non-Colonial dining experience, Trellis, on Duke of Gloucester Street in Market Square, (757) 229-8610, is cleanly modern. The food is equally contemporary and a better bet than in the Colonial taverns. A typical entree is Key lime-marinated yellowfin tuna for $23.95. Their chocolate desserts are notorious, and the wine cellar is extensive. Dinner for two with wine is in the $110 range. KATHERINE ASHENBURG

SECTION: Section 6; Page 70; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1770 words

HEADLINE: Two Cheers for Sweatshops

BYLINE: By Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn; Nicholas D. Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn, who received a Pulitzer Prize for their coverage of China, are the authors of "Thunder From the East: Portrait of a Rising Asia" (Knopf), from which this article is adapted.

 BODY:
It was breakfast time, and the food stand in the village in northeastern Thailand was crowded. Maesubin Sisoipha, the middle-aged woman cooking the food, was friendly, her portions large and the price right. For the equivalent of about 5 cents, she offered a huge green mango leaf filled with rice, fish paste and fried beetles. It was a hearty breakfast, if one didn't mind the odd antenna left sticking in one's teeth.
One of the half-dozen men and women sitting on a bench eating was a sinewy, bare-chested laborer in his late 30's named Mongkol Latlakorn. It was a hot, lazy day, and so we started chatting idly about the food and, eventually, our families. Mongkol mentioned that his daughter, Darin, was 15, and his voice softened as he spoke of her. She was beautiful and smart, and her father's hopes rested on her. 
 "Is she in school?" we asked.
"Oh, no," Mongkol said, his eyes sparkling with amusement. "She's working in a factory in Bangkok. She's making clothing for export to America." He explained that she was paid $2 a day for a nine-hour shift, six days a week.
"It's dangerous work," Mongkol added. "Twice the needles went right through her hands. But the managers bandaged up her hands, and both times she got better again and went back to work."
"How terrible," we murmured sympathetically.
Mongkol looked up, puzzled. "It's good pay," he said. "I hope she can keep that job. There's all this talk about factories closing now, and she said there are rumors that her factory might close. I hope that doesn't happen. I don't know what she would do then."
He was not, of course, indifferent to his daughter's suffering; he simply had a different perspective from ours -- not only when it came to food but also when it came to what constituted desirable work.
Nothing captures the difference in mind-set between East and West more than attitudes toward sweatshops. Nike and other American companies have been hammered in the Western press over the last decade for producing shoes, toys and other products in grim little factories with dismal conditions. Protests against sweatshops and the dark forces of globalization that they seem to represent have become common at meetings of the World Bank and the World Trade Organization and, this month, at a World Economic Forum in Australia, livening up the scene for Olympic athletes arriving for the competition. Yet sweatshops that seem brutal from the vantage point of an American sitting in his living room can appear tantalizing to a Thai laborer getting by on beetles.
Fourteen years ago, we moved to Asia and began reporting there. Like most Westerners, we arrived in the region outraged at sweatshops. In time, though, we came to accept the view supported by most Asians: that the campaign against sweatshops risks harming the very people it is intended to help. For beneath their grime, sweatshops are a clear sign of the industrial revolution that is beginning to reshape Asia.
This is not to praise sweatshops. Some managers are brutal in the way they house workers in firetraps, expose children to dangerous chemicals, deny bathroom breaks, demand sexual favors, force people to work double shifts or dismiss anyone who tries to organize a union. Agitation for improved safety conditions can be helpful, just as it was in 19th-century Europe. But Asian workers would be aghast at the idea of American consumers boycotting certain toys or clothing in protest. The simplest way to help the poorest Asians would be to buy more from sweatshops, not less.
On our first extended trip to China, in 1987, we traveled to the Pearl River delta in the south of the country. There we visited several factories, including one in the boomtown of Dongguan, where about 100 female workers sat at workbenches stitching together bits of leather to make purses for a Hong Kong company. We chatted with several women as their fingers flew over their work and asked about their hours.
"I start at about 6:30, after breakfast, and go until about 7 p.m.," explained one shy teenage girl. "We break for lunch, and I take half an hour off then."
"You do this six days a week?"
"Oh, no. Every day."
"Seven days a week?"
"Yes." She laughed at our surprise. "But then I take a week or two off at Chinese New Year to go back to my village."
The others we talked to all seemed to regard it as a plus that the factory allowed them to work long hours. Indeed, some had sought out this factory precisely because it offered them the chance to earn more.
"It's actually pretty annoying how hard they want to work," said the factory manager, a Hong Kong man. "It means we have to worry about security and have a supervisor around almost constantly."
It sounded pretty dreadful, and it was. We and other journalists wrote about the problems of child labor and oppressive conditions in both China and South Korea. But, looking back, our worries were excessive. Those sweatshops tended to generate the wealth to solve the problems they created. If Americans had reacted to the horror stories in the 1980's by curbing imports of those sweatshop products, then neither southern China nor South Korea would have registered as much progress as they have today.
The truth is, those grim factories in Dongguan and the rest of southern China contributed to a remarkable explosion of wealth. In the years since our first conversations there, we've returned many times to Dongguan and the surrounding towns and seen the transformation. Wages have risen from about $50 a month to $250 a month or more today. Factory conditions have improved as businesses have scrambled to attract and keep the best laborers. A private housing market has emerged, and video arcades and computer schools have opened to cater to workers with rising incomes. A hint of a middle class has appeared -- as has China's closest thing to a Western-style independent newspaper, Southern Weekend.
Partly because of these tens of thousands of sweatshops, China's economy has become one of the hottest in the world. Indeed, if China's 30 provinces were counted as individual countries, then the 20 fastest-
growing countries in the world between 1978 and 1995 would all have been Chinese. When Britain launched the Industrial Revolution in the late 18th century, it took 58 years for per capita output to double. In China, per capita output has been doubling every 10 years.
In fact, the most vibrant parts of Asia are nearly all in what might be called the Sweatshop Belt, from China and South Korea to Malaysia, Indonesia and even Bangladesh and India. Today these sweatshop countries control about one-quarter of the global economy. As the industrial revolution spreads through China and India, there are good reasons to think that Asia will continue to pick up speed. Some World Bank forecasts show Asia's share of global gross domestic product rising to 55 to 60 percent by about 2025 -- roughly the West's share at its peak half a century ago. The sweatshops have helped lay the groundwork for a historic economic realignment that is putting Asia back on its feet. Countries are rebounding from the economic crisis of 1997-98 and the sweatshops -- seen by Westerners as evidence of moribund economies -- actually reflect an industrial revolution that is raising living standards in the East.
Of course, it may sound silly to say that sweatshops offer a route to prosperity, when wages in the poorest countries are sometimes less than $1 a day. Still, for an impoverished Indonesian or Bangladeshi woman with a handful of kids who would otherwise drop out of school and risk dying of mundane diseases like diarrhea, $1 or $2 a day can be a life-transforming wage.
This was made abundantly clear in Cambodia, when we met a 40-year-old woman named Nhem Yen, who told us why she moved to an area with particularly lethal malaria. "We needed to eat," she said. "And here there is wood, so we thought we could cut it and sell it."
But then Nhem Yen's daughter and son-in-law both died of malaria, leaving her with two grandchildren and five children of her own. With just one mosquito net, she had to choose which children would sleep protected and which would sleep exposed.
In Cambodia, a large mosquito net costs $5. If there had been a sweatshop in the area, however harsh or dangerous, Nhem Yen would have leapt at the chance to work in it, to earn enough to buy a net big enough to cover all her children.
For all the misery they can engender, sweatshops at least offer a precarious escape from the poverty that is the developing world's greatest problem. Over the past 50 years, countries like India resisted foreign exploitation, while countries that started at a similar economic level -- like Taiwan and South Korea -- accepted sweatshops as the price of development. Today there can be no doubt about which approach worked better. Taiwan and South Korea are modern countries with low rates of infant mortality and high levels of education; in contrast, every year 3.1 million Indian children die before the age of 5, mostly from diseases of poverty like diarrhea.
The effect of American pressure on sweatshops is complicated. While it clearly improves conditions at factories that produce branded merchandise for companies like Nike, it also raises labor costs across the board. That encourages less well established companies to mechanize and to reduce the number of employees needed. The upshot is to help people who currently have jobs in Nike plants but to risk jobs for others. The only thing a country like Cambodia has to offer is terribly cheap wages; if companies are scolded for paying those wages, they will shift their manufacturing to marginally richer areas like Malaysia or Mexico.
Sweatshop monitors do have a useful role. They can compel factories to improve safety. They can also call attention to the impact of sweatshops on the environment. The greatest downside of industrialization is not exploitation of workers but toxic air and water. In Asia each year, three million people die from the effects of pollution. The factories springing up throughout the region are far more likely to kill people through the chemicals they expel than through terrible working conditions.
By focusing on these issues, by working closely with organizations and news media in foreign countries, sweatshops can be improved. But refusing to buy sweatshop products risks making Americans feel good while harming those we are trying to help. As a Chinese proverb goes, "First comes the bitterness, then there is sweetness and wealth and honor for 10,000 years."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 10; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2565 words

HEADLINE: Where All the Town's a Stage

BYLINE: By SHERRY MARKER; SHERRY MARKER lives in New England.

 BODY:
AT Strawbery Banke in Portsmouth, N.H., costumed role players and interpreters encourage visitors to eavesdrop on three centuries of daily life, from the first settlement here in 1630 to the museum's foundation in 1958. The 1630 settlement took its name from the wild berries that grew along the banks of the Piscataqua River, but the settlers were less interested in the site's sylvan pleasures than in its economic possibilities. In 1653 Strawbery Banke changed its name to Portsmouth, trumpeting that "We are at the river's mouth and our port is as good as any in the land." Today's Strawbery Banke, which calls itself an outdoor history museum, preserves the original spelling of the first settlement's name.
Throughout the 17th and 18th centuries, Portsmouth's sea captains sped cargos of lumber and cod across the Atlantic and throughout the Caribbean. Local carpenters made everything from the clipper ships to the boxes that held the cod. Prosperous sea captains and merchants built themselves handsome homes overlooking the waters that lapped the busy docks. But, when shipping declined in the 19th century, so did Portsmouth. As waterways silted up, and finally were filled in altogether, Portsmouth's oldest neighborhood was dismissively nicknamed Puddle Dock. 
 After World War II, greater Portsmouth perceived the proliferating junkyards and tenaments of Puddle Dock as unwelcome eyesores. By the late 1950's, the entire 30-acre neighborhood was scheduled for the wholesale destruction then euphemistically called urban renewal. Fortunately, some local citizens were incensed at the thought that the Revolutionary War-era houses visited by George Washington, Lafayette and John Paul Jones might be razed. The preservationists bought the 10 central acres of Puddle Dock, and Strawbery Banke was reborn as a history museum. Now, Strawbery Banke draws some 60,000 visitors a year, and has been an important factor in the revitalization of Portsmouth.
Strawbery Banke's 50 guides and six to eight costumed role players use everything from the leaded diamond-paned windows in the 17th-century Sherburne House to the gas chandelier in the elegant 19th-century Goodwin Mansion and the ration books in the World War II mom-and-pop Abbott Store to create "a neighborhood where the past is forever present." The 40 mostly wood frame buildings that line Strawbery Banke's unpaved streets range in color from white to deep green, red and slate blue, with a variety of yellows and browns. Nine buildings are furnished as 18th- and 19th-century homes; others contain crafts, architectural and archaeological displays, while yet others await restoration.
Gardens with 18th-century medicinal herbs, Victorian flower beds, and the Kentucky Wonder pole beans of a World War II Victory garden grow where archaeological evidence, family letters and memories say they originally grew. Gardens and buildings, ranging from the 17th-century timber frame Sherburne House to a 20th-century cinder block garage, flank the central green that was a deep cove lined with docks until the early 1900's.
When I visited Strawbery Banke last May, I particularly wanted to see two new exhibits: the Shapiro and Aldrich Houses. The Shapiro House, which opened in 1997, looks at the immigrant experience by focusing on the Shapiro family, which lived here in a late 18th-century house from 1909 to 1928. The Aldrich House, which reopened in May after two years of extensive restoration, recreates the atmosphere of the boyhood home of the writer Thomas Bailey Aldrich (1836-1907). I also wanted to revisit some of my favorite Strawbery Banke spots, so I allowed myself to wander the streets lined with flowering pear trees, stopping to watch a cooper making barrel staves at the Dinsmore shop, ogling the handsome slip-decorated stoneware made and sold at the museum pottery, and buying a copy of Aldrich's 1869 novel "The Story of a Bad Boy" at the excellent museum shop.
I couldn't resist stopping at the house that for me encapsulates Strawbery Banke: the Drisco House on Puddle Lane. Step through the front door of this 18th-century frame house and turn right and you find yourself in the 1790's Shapley Shop. Cross the hall, and you'll be in a 1950's parlor that recreates a home from the period when Puddle Dock became the Strawbery Banke Museum.
When I entered Mr. Shapley's shop, the costumed (and pigtailed) role player portraying the retired sea captain turned shopkeeper inquired where I had journeyed from that day. When I replied "Massachusetts," Mr. Shapley wanted to know whether I had sailed over from Boston. After we worked out the details of my journey, I expressed surprise at the lemons and limes for sale. Mr. Shapley asked whether I had not heard that a clipper had just put in from the Antilles.
As Mr. Shapley spoke, I realized that I could faintly hear the voices of my childhood idols Dale Evans and Roy Rogers. Sure enough, when I said good-bye to Mr. Shapley and stepped across the Drisco House front hall, I found myself in a 1950's living room, with Roy, Dale and Trigger on the screen of a substantial black and white television console. From the linoleum floor covering and huge ash trays on floor stands, every detail precisely evoked the era of antimacassars. When I told an interpreter that I could almost smell my grandfather's Old Gold cigarettes, she told me that the living room had been arranged so that everyone could see the television -- and have an ash tray within easy reach.
That 1950's living room gave me a severe case of nostalgia, so I headed along the dirt road to the World War II-era Abbott Store. There, I was greeted by a dead ringer for Rosie the Riveter, who told me that she was waiting for the bus to the Naval Yard. "My husband's not too happy about my working there," she confided, fiddling with her welder's goggles, "but there's four of us ladies there now with so many men away." When she saw me eyeing the Chiclets in a glass display case she said, "Guess that's the last we'll see of them. Now that the Philippines have fallen to the Japanese there's no more gum coming out to make Chiclets."
From the Abbott Store it was an easy stroll along Jefferson Street to the substantial 18th-century Thomas Bailey Aldrich House, which became Portsmouth's first museum house when the writer's widow created the Thomas Bailey Aldrich Memorial here in 1908. When the house had to be closed for structural repairs in 1998, Strawbery Banke made the decision to undertake a complete reinstallation. At present, the dining room and kitchen are complete, with the rest of the house to follow over the next few years. The undertaking is enormous: more than 600 items in the dining room and kitchen alone had to be removed, cataloged, cleaned and often repaired.
Before all those items could be returned to their original places, an important decision had to be made: should Mrs. Aldrich's original vision of the house be honored or should the reinstallation convey a more historically accurate version of the Aldrich House?
By all accounts (including her own) Mrs. Aldrich, a quintessential literary widow, tried in 1908 to recreate every detail of her husband's boyhood home, drawing on her own memory of the house and on Aldrich's heavily autobiographical "Story of a Bad Boy." And therein lies the problem, since much that Mrs. Aldrich restored may originally have existed only in the world Aldrich created for his scalawag hero.For example, the curator John Mayer suspects that the widow Aldrich may have allowed the strong forces of Colonial revivalism to persuade her to furnish a 19th-century kitchen with venerable Colonial cooking ware, including old-fashioned tin hearth ovens.
After much soul-searching, Strawbery Banke decided to honor and recreate the 1908 vision of the Aldrich House as an example of how people then saw, and wished to see, the past.
Already in 1908, Portsmouth was experiencing a wave of immigrants from southern and eastern Europe, and many long-time residents feared that the old ways were threatened. In short, not everyone would have been delighted at the news in 1909 that the Shapiros, a Jewish immigrant family from Russia, had moved into a late 18th-century white frame house virtually across the street from the Aldrich House.
The costumed role player who portrays Mrs. Shapiro looked up from grating horseradish and greeted me with a "Shalom" as I stepped into her kitchen. As she set her glass of tea aside and smoothed the apron that covered her house dress, she told me that she had just finished planting her lettuces and peas, soon to be followed by beets for borscht. She took a moment to show me her meat and her milk dishes, and to explain how she kept kosher, before turning to her massive cast-iron Beauty Hub coal stove.
"I must be careful making the applesauce not to leave it too long on a too-hot burner," she said. "If you're not careful, applesauce becomes apple butter -- not a problem unless you're making latkes and need applesauce."
As mothers will, Mrs. Shapiro told me about her daughter, Mollie, who was worrying her parents by objecting to speaking Yiddish at home. "My Italian neighbors have the same problem," she said. "Their children want only to be American and not learn the old languages that were good enough for us."
As other visitors entered the Shapiro House, I wandered off into the dining room, and listened to the audio recreation of the family's weekly Sabbath meal, and browsed upstairs, where I saw Mollie's collection of thumb-size china penny dolls, her toy coal stove and books for her Hebrew school lessons.
When I came back downstairs, Mrs. Shapiro was telling a group of schoolchildren about Mollie's household chores. "When my Mollie comes home from school," she said, "she'll take the pan of melted water from under the icebox outside for water for the chickens."
I was almost out the door, when I thought of one more question. "Those chickens," I said. "I haven't seen them or even heard a peep out of them."
Mrs. Shapiro was ready. "On a day like this when it's still a bit chilly, the chickens like to huddle under the porch. When it's hot, they go there to get out of the sun. One day a little boy asked the question you just asked, and when I told him about the chickens, he ran outside and crawled under the porch. When he came back in, he said, 'I saw them, I saw the chickens under the porch.' "
That ability to make the invisible visible, the past present, is what Strawbery Banke is all about.
 
Three centuries: barrel staves to ration books
 
Getting There
Strawbery Banke, (603) 433-1100, www.strawberybanke.org, in Portsmouth, N.H., is a five-hour drive from New York and an hour north of Boston. It is best reached by taking Exit 7 off Route I-95 and following the green Strawbery Banke signs.
 
Planning a Trip
The museum is open daily 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. through October. For the first time this year, from Nov. 1 to April 23, there will be guided walking tours beginning at the Dunaway Museum Shop; call the museum shop, (603) 433-1114, or the main number for times. Admission is $12 (off-season tours $7); seniors $11 (off season $6); ages 7 to 17 $8 (off season $4); family (two adults and two children under 17) $28. Tickets valid for two consecutive days.
Coming events include Decorating the Sukkah, Oct. 12; Grand Old Portsmouth Brewer's Festival, Oct. 14 and 15; Hogwart's Halloween, Oct. 30; Annual Candlelight Stroll, Dec. 2 and 3 and 9 and 10; and an American Girl's Christmas, Dec. 16 and 17 and 27 to 30. Next year's theme will be Parlors, Pantries and Parties featuring furniture and ceramics and their use in the social life of Portsmouth.
Visitors who find that Strawbery Banke whets their appetite for local history may want to buy the Portsmouth Harbour Trail guide, a historical walking tour of the town, and the Portsmouth Black Heritage Trail, each $2 at the Greater Portsmouth Chamber of Commerce, 500 Market Street, (603) 436-1118; open Monday to Friday, 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.
 
Where to Stay
The 202-room Sheraton Harborside Portsmouth, (603) 431-2300, (800) 325-3535, fax (603) 431-7805, is a 10-minute walk from Strawbery Banke. There's an indoor pool and some rooms have harbor views, while others overlook an interior courtyard or the parking lot and town. Doubles: $129 to $179.
Portsmouth has a number of pleasant bed-and-breakfast inns within easy walking distance of Strawbery Banke. The three-bedroom Oracle House Inn and Gardens, 38 Marcy Street, (603) 433-8827, is furnished with family heirlooms (the family has been here for 12 generations) and overlooks Strawbery Banke itself. Doubles $150.
The nine-bedroom Bow Street Inn, 121 Bow Street, (603) 431-7760, fax (603) 433-1680, is on the second floor of a restored 19th-century brewery that now houses the Seacoast Repertory Theater. Rooms overlook the harbor or the 19th-century St. John's Church. Doubles $119 to $155.
The Sise Inn, 40 Court Street, telephone and fax (603) 433-1200, is a Queen Anne mansion with marvelous oak woodwork, a Victorian parlor, fireplaces in most rooms, private bathrooms -- and Jacuzzi baths in several suites. Doubles $145 to $220.
There are several motels just outside Portsmouth, at the Interstate Traffic Circle at Exit 5 off I-95. The Wynwood Hotel and Suites, telephone and fax (603) 436-7600, has indoor and outdoor pools. Doubles from $89 through October and during the holidays; winter rates from $59. You will have to use your car to get in and out of Portsmouth, and may want to use the High-Hanover Parking Facility (50 cents an hour).
 
Where to Eat
Dinner prices are for an entree and a glass of wine or beer.
You can start eating right on the Strawbery Banke grounds, at The Cafe on the Banke, 61 Washington Street, (603) 436-8803, open daily 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., when the museum is open. The menu features sandwiches ($4.95), salads ($4.25) and snacks (pie or cake $2.95) that can be eaten indoors or at picnic tables.
Open daily from 11 a.m. to 11:30 p.m., the perpetually crowded Stock Pot, 53 Bow Street, (603) 431-1851, has great harbor views and serves pastas, fish and vegetarian dishes; fish and chips, with a draft Sam Adams, costs $13.65.
Roxanne's, formerly Karen's, 105 Daniel Street, (603) 431-1948, is open for breakfast and lunch Monday to Friday; brunch 8 a.m. to 2:30 p.m., Saturday and Sunday; and dinner 5:30 to 9:30 p.m. Thursday to Saturday. Terrific eggs Benedict; inventive pasta, fish and vegetarian dishes; indulgent desserts. There's an outdoor patio. Dinner for one with a glass of wine, from $20; reservations recommended for dinner.
The upstairs wine bar at Lindbergh's Crossing, 29 Ceres Street, (603) 431-0887, opens daily at 4 p.m. and the restaurant is open daily from 5:30 p.m. There's a harbor view upstairs, handsome brick and stone walls upstairs and down, and the entrees range from couscous with fruits de mer and seared duck breast to the somewhat eclectic free-range Southern fried rabbit with egg noodles and country gravy. Dinner for one with a glass of wine, from $25; reservations recommended.
Wherever you eat, save room for a vanilla and ginger ice cream cone ($2.20) at Annabelle's, 49 Ceres Street, (603) 436-3400, open 10 a.m. until about 10 p.m. to mid-November.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Oil Price Rise Heightens Dismay Over the Euro

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
TWO years ago, Americans arriving in Paris or Brussels or Frankfurt would routinely be shocked at the high cost of nearly everything: dreary hotels that cost nearly $200 a night; $10 to develop a roll of film; and clothes that often cost 50 percent more than in the United States.
But thanks to the seemingly endless decline of the euro, the common currency adopted by 12 European countries, things here are cheaper in dollars than they have been in years. The euro has lost more than 25 percent of its value against the dollar since its launch in January 1999, and it has repeatedly defied expert predictions that it was ripe for a rebound. 
 From its opening value of about $1.17, the euro has fallen to one record low after another, and was down to 85 cents early last week. Most of this is invisible to ordinary consumers, who will not be able to use euro bills and coins until 2002.
But the decline is very real, because national currencies like the French franc and Italian lira are locked to the euro and mirror its movements exactly.
On balance, the euro's decline translates into a huge discount for American travelers in Europe because their dollars are worth so much more. Major airlines report that their trans-Atlantic flights were packed solid throughout the peak vacation period as Americans appear to have jumped at the prospect of cheaper prices (in dollars) from Spain to Finland.
"For European tourism, it is the best we have had in years," said Walter Leu, executive director of the European Travel Commission in Brussels, an umbrella group of national travel organizations from Europe.
Mr. Leu estimated that 12 million Americans would visit Europe this year and spend about $25 billion. That is a 6 percent increase in the number of travelers and a 10 percent increase in the amount of money they are spending, compared with last year.
But as has become clear in the last few weeks, there is no such thing as a purely "good" exchange rate, even for American tourists. Thanks in part to the euro's weakness, the price of oil has climbed even more sharply in Europe than in the United States and led to protests that made gasoline hard to find in parts of England, France and Belgium.
Soaring gasoline prices caused widespread anger in the United States, too, of course. But the European problem was different in two big ways.
The first difference is that oil is priced and paid for in dollars on world markets. So when the euro declined at the same time that oil prices were surging, Europeans were faced with a compounded price increase because their currency bought far fewer dollars than before.
The second big difference is taxes. Across Europe, including Britain, gasoline taxes account for as much as 75 percent of the price that consumers pay. That is why Britain, which did not adopt the euro and has not seen the pound decline as much against the dollar, nevertheless produced the angriest gasoline protests in Europe.
But the protests are dying down, as governments have vowed to provide at least some relief to truckers and other key groups. Assuming the blockades continue to be disbanded, gas station supplies should return to normal.
To be sure, airline prices are starting to climb in Europe as a result of higher jet-fuel prices. KLM, the Dutch airline, recently said it would raise prices by 4 percent to offset higher fuel prices. But most of the big airlines have held back so far, in part because they are under increasingly intense pressure from scores of new budget-priced airlines.
For all kinds of products, prices vary considerably within Europe. Great Britain is more expensive than most parts of the United States, because the British pound is much stronger than the euro and because London is in the midst of a long-running economic boom as a financial center. Thanks to phenomenal economic growth for the last five years, Ireland has also experienced substantial inflation and is expensive, even though it is part of the Euro zone.
The big question is whether the euro will recover any time soon. Eighteen months ago, most economists were predicting that the euro would settle at well above $1.10. Now, few think it will get anywhere close to parity with the dollar in the next year, and some predict it will sink as low as 80 cents.
But given how wrong the expert predictions have been so far, anything is possible.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 9-24-00;
What They Were Thinking

BYLINE: By Catherine Saint Louis

 BODY:

Patrick Sloan, Charlotte Border, Jane Klein, Houston, Aug. 18, 2000
 
Sloan (center): "We were at Little Woodrow's for the pre-party of Bellaire High School's 10th reunion. You go to the reunion to catch up on gossip, just like in high school. Gossip is gossip. You want to hear the dirt. A lot of girls that all the boys had crushes on in high school were all happily married. As for the boys, I definitely noticed that sense of, 'Are we at that age?' It's that old high school metaphor: once one guy asks someone to the prom, then everybody has to run out and ask. We were mad when our first friend got married. Not because of her -- we liked her -- but because he was putting pressure on all the other guys." 

Border (second from right): "Everything was very superficial. The people who come to reunions are not 'I'm unemployed and still living with my parents' kind of people. So you hear the same things from everybody: 'Oh, I've got a great job.' It seems like such a cookie-cutter type of thing. The smartest guy in the class -- you know what? He's a doctor. And the cheerleaders were pregnant. I think the people who did have some good scoop -- people who were divorced or had big things happen -- didn't come to the reunion and didn't get to talk about it. And nobody wanted to dance. They did play Vanilla Ice, though; that was probably one of the better moments."
 
Klein (right): "Everything was different than I thought it would be. For one thing, not that many people showed up. I would have to think that the people who did come were there because they were happier, they had something to show off, they had kids or a great husband. Maybe the ones who didn't come are the ones who didn't have a whole lot to say. So I was surprised at how many of the people in school who were maybe less popular were there. There were more of those types of people there than the popular crowd. It was nice because you would talk to all of them. It wasn't like you avoided any of them." Interviews by Catherine Saint Louis

HEADLINE: Wilmington Adapts After a Mainstay Cuts Back

BYLINE: By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
WHEN the DuPont Company said in early 1999 that it was selling three of its buildings, about 10 percent of the city's office space, the announcement shook the community to its industrial foundations. But a vibrant economy has helped smooth the transition.
The $25 million sale of the three headquarters buildings -- known as the Nemours, Brandywine and Tatnall buildings -- to a development partnership had some residents of this company town wondering whether the mainstay citizen for almost a century was packing up. 
 The sale capped a decade of real estate divestiture by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the country's largest chemical concern. As the company strives to reinvent itself for the 21st century, in part as a global life sciences business, real estate investments are not felt to be the best use of corporate assets said William A. Sullivan, a former real estate manager at DuPont. All that remains in DuPont's real estate portfolio of its headquarters complex is the DuPont Building, built in stages beginning in 1906 and one of the country's earliest multipurpose buildings, with restaurants, theater, hotel, shops and offices.
"It makes sense from a business point of view for DuPont not to have such a large headquarters, but for the city it's sad," said Carol E. Hoffecker, a historian and the author of "Corporate Capital: Wilmington in the Twentieth Century." "It seems like such a dramatic symbol of the company's changing relationship with the community."
But with more than half of a $100 million redevelopment of the buildings completed and DuPont leasing back a big part of the Brandywine Building, city promoters see the divestiture as a necessary regeneration. At a million square feet, City Center @ Wilmington, as the project is called, is by far the largest redevelopment of office space in the city's history.
With a New Economy name, City Center will add 100,000 square feet of retail space, 890,000 square feet of Class A office space, 75 apartments and 674 parking spaces to the city. "It's brought in new blood, new capital and DuPont stayed," said William C. Wyer, managing director of the Wilmington Renaissance Corporation, an economic development group made up of city officials and top business leaders.
From a leasing standpoint, the timing could not be better. Tenants have been having difficulty getting big blocks of space, said Daniel R. Reeder, a senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis in Wilmington. The city's overall downtown vacancy rate is 5 percent, but it drops to 4 percent for Class A space -- large newer buildings with amenities and in good locations.
Because plans call for a retail and residential mix, City Center is expected to transform 11th Street.
For decades, this main thoroughfare from Interstate 95 to the downtown's Rodney Square has been without significant public spaces other than the Hotel du Pont and the center lobby of the Nemours Building. Office workers did not have to go outside since the buildings are connected by underground tunnels. This led architects to criticize Wilmington for its lack of human scale.
"It's big, cold stuff," said Charles M. Weymouth, owner of Weymouth Architects and Planners in Wilmington. "There's no relief, no landscaping, just the repetitiveness of windows, one floor to the next."
Adding colorful awnings and flags, huge landscape planters and lighting will make the area feel more hospitable, said Robert E. Buccini, a partner in Wilmington's Buccini/Pollin Group, which signed the deal with DuPont. Barrow Street Capital L.L.C., a private New York real estate investment company, is providing the financing.
The 75 apartments in a section of the Nemours Building should also go a long way toward making Wilmington a round-the-clock city, Mr. Sullivan said.
The 18-story Brandywine Building, built in 1972 on a triangular plot, was the first to be renovated as offices. Kling Lindquist of Philadelphia, the original designer of the D-shaped building, was hired as project architect.
CITY CENTER was given a boost at the start when DuPont agreed to take 266,000 square feet for 10 years in the Brandywine Building, which is still topped by DuPont's oval logo, in neon. Last month, the company moved 649 people into the renovated space. Several law firms have signed leases on remaining space, including Young, Conaway, Stargatt & Taylor.
A steakhouse is expected to open this fall in space that was formerly a bank branch. The steakhouse, to be called the Vault, is operated by two restaurateurs who opened a Mediterranean restaurant at Market Street Mall in Wilmington last year.
It will have dining room seating for 115, a bar with space for live entertainment and a mezzanine lounge with seating for 30. There will also be tables for outdoor dining between the Brandywine and Nemours Buildings.
Investors in the restaurant include Charles M. Cawley, head of MBNA America Bank, a giant credit card bank that moved its headquarters to Wilmington in the early 1990's, as well as two other top MBNA executives. The investment is a message not lost on a city accustomed to being dominated by DuPont.
While DuPont was selling off buildings in the 1990's and cutting its work force, MBNA put up five buildings on the northeast side of Rodney Square and employs thousands there. "I think it certainly has demonstrated very powerfully the transformation Wilmington has been undergoing from a DuPont to MBNA town," Ms. Hoffecker said.
The third building that DuPont sold -- the Tatnall Building on 11th Street, across from the Brandywine Building -- was demolished to make way for a parking garage. DuPont had used the 90,000-square-foot building as a mail center.
Tunnels will be available to Nemours and Brandywine tenants, while a sky bridge that connects Nemours Building to the DuPont Building will be torn down for security reasons, Mr. Buccini said.
Now the developers have turned their attention to perhaps the toughest part of the project, the 14-story Nemours Building, built in stages from 1935 to 1942. Earlier this month, the Buccini/Pollin Group began gutting the 600,000-square-foot building.
The Juniper Financial Corporation, a four-month old Internet financial services company founded by several former executives at the Bank One Corporation, has already leased 65,000 square feet. The traditional hallways lined with marble and individual office doors will give way to open floors that characterize the information age.
An apartment wing will be carved out of 124,000 square feet on the corner facing 10th and Orange Streets. It will have its own entrance lobby separate from the office lobby. Up to half of the 75 apartments could be leased for corporate use, with DuPont agreeing to lease eight apartments.
The floor plans call for studios to two-bedroom units. Rental rates for the apartments will be firmed up nearer the opening in 2001, but a one-bedroom apartment is expected to cost approximately $1,000 a month.
Part of the plan is to have the Hotel du Pont supply room service, dry-cleaning pickup and other amenities for apartment dwellers.
The hotel will also cater to office tenants. A small auditorium in Nemours could be converted to a movie theater, Mr. Buccini said. Negotiations are under way for a first-floor restaurant in Nemours.
The developers decided not to rename the buildings, believing their DuPont heritage was an important part of the city's history. Indeed, three du Pont cousins -- Alfred I., Pierre S. and T. Coleman -- single-handedly transformed the city from an aging industrial hub to an office center when they made the decision in 1904 to build the company headquarters in Wilmington rather than in New York or Philadelphia.
As the major shipbuilding and railroad-car manufacturing industries waned, the du Pont cousins built a new business that earned Wilmington the name Chemical Capital of the World.
"Wilmington has been fortunate that when one of its Old Economy businesses has been on the rocks, something new comes along," Ms. Hoffecker said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
For Newark's South Ward, Homes on Vacant Lots

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
THEY number in the hundreds, the scattered vacant lots that like ugly bruises mar the streets of this city's South Ward, which sits in the shadow of Newark International Airport. But that situation may soon change.
Under a redevelopment plan approved by the Newark City Council last spring a majority of the lots -- 680 of 923 -- are to be redeveloped into mostly two-family homes, with some one-or three-family houses. The 680 lots, of varying sizes, are to yield 625 homes. 
 The city owns the lots -- some contiguous ones make up nearly entire blocks -- and has designated 17 private developers for the rebuilding.
(Two-thirds of the remaining lots are owned by the city's Public Housing Authority and are to be used for public housing. Most of the other lots are to be used for industrial development.)
All the homes are to be developed in the next two to three years without any public money. They will be sold at market-rate prices, generally ranging from $135,000 to $200,000, with the three-family homes rising to $249,900. Potential buyers will not be subject to any income eligibility requirements.
Planners said that the houses would be affordable to families with annual household incomes of $50,000 to $60,000 and would draw interest from both Newark residents and others. Among the reasons cited for the interest is the area's location next to several highways, including I-78 and I-95, the New Jersey Turnpike. The local Routes 1-9 and 22 are nearby as well.
The city's hope is that the housing will help bring new economic life to the neighborhood, which is still struggling to recover from the flight of residents and businesses after the 1967 race riots.
"It's been 30 years in the coming," Donald Bradley, who represents the South Ward and is the president of the Newark City Council, said of the redevelopment plan. "Except for some sporadic building of low- and moderate-income housing there has been no real new development in the South Ward since the 1967 disturbance."
The new housing is the centerpiece of the South Ward redevelopment plan. Mr. Bradley, a 36-year resident of the neighborhood, said that future phases included renovating abandoned buildings as well as helping existing homeowners improve their homes. There are also plans for a new high school and an athletic center. An industrial park, with 100,000 square feet of space, was also recently completed in the neighborhood, at Bergen Street and Hawthorne Avenue, and up to 80,000 more square feet of space is planned for the park. "This development is a jump start," Mr. Bradley said, "but in order for the neighborhood to come back we can't just build new housing, or just low- and moderate-income housing."
Mayor Sharpe James, who lives in the South Ward, said the plan was "all part of a holistic approach" to reviving Newark, as well as to increasing the homeownership rate in the city, which has risen since 1984 to 26 percent from 16 percent. The goal is 50 percent, Mayor James said, without indicating a deadline.
The new market-rate homes in the South Ward, the mayor said, are part of the city's plan to encourage the development of 2,000 such homes citywide this year. He said that to ensure that the South Ward houses are built, the lots will be released to the developers in clusters, and the developers will be required to build the homes in those clusters within a year to 18 months.
"If they succeed they will get more lots," he said, noting that after the South Ward, the intent is to move into the West Ward.
Of the 680 lots in the South Ward, Summit Real Estate Developers of Westfield is to develop 302 into up to 280 mostly two-family homes, with possibly a few one-family houses. The rest of the lots are divided among the remaining 16 developers, including A&A Construction of Colonia and Triple A Developers of Newark. Most of the developers have signed contracts with the city and are moving forward to secure site plan approvals for the homes from the city.
Model homes are expected to begin to take shape as early as next month, with initial construction to start before year's end. Some of the houses will be traditionally constructed, while others will be developed using panelized construction or manufactured in a factory and assembled on site.
Alfred L. Faiella, the city's deputy mayor for housing and economic development, said that to keep the homes affordable the city would sell most of the developers the lots, which average 33 by 100 feet, for $1 a square foot, or $3,300 each. Summit, which is planning to put up modular homes, has agreed to pay more.
BECAUSE most of the homes are two-family, he said, the rental apartments will provide buyers with income to help with mortgage payments and other expenses.
Real estate taxes on the houses, Mr. Faiella said, will be abated for the first five years, reducing them on average to $3,000 a year from the $4,500 to $5,000 they would be without the abatement. The abatement may also be extended for up to 20 more years, he said. And mortgages at or below market-rate interest and with low or zero down payments will also be made available to qualified buyers through several banks.
The sale of the lots is expected to generate about $5 million, and their redevelopment to bring in about $1.8 million in tax revenues a year to Newark, Mr. Faiella said. He said the lots had reverted to city ownership because of nonpayment of taxes. The tidy row houses that once stood on the lots were razed long ago.
Through the 1960's the South Ward was primarily a residential neighborhood where many professional families lived in grand houses, mainly in the Clinton Hill and Weequahic areas. Today, many middle-class black families live in well-kept parts of the neighborhood. Other parts, such as the far eastern sector, where many of the vacant lots exist, have suffered greatly from abandonment.
In recent years, as the national and state economies blossomed, Newark's long-awaited revival started to take hold. Much activity has centered on the city's downtown, with the construction of its new performing arts center, a minor league baseball stadium and the promise of more, including a sports arena, residences and shops.
The development push has filtered into the neighborhoods, primarily the Central Ward, which was ground zero for the riots as well as hub for much of the city's high-rise public housing. Many of those towers have been or are being demolished and replaced with low-rise town houses. That replacement program, along with new construction, has brought some 1,400 new housing units into the Central Ward over the last two years, Mr. Faiella said.
The concentration of residential activity in that area was done by design to "show enough of an impact to start a ripple effect in commercial development," he said, pointing to possible plans by Kmart to open a store on an 11-acre triangular site bounded by Jones, Springfield and South Orange Avenues. The objective is to have the same thing happen in the South Ward, he said.
That approach appealed to the principals of Summit Real Estate Developers. "Bringing so many houses to an unproven area will create a critical mass and, in turn, reduce the risk," said Arthur Fefferman, a partner in Summit with Peter Weissbrod, Stuart Fuchsman and Richard Goldberger.
The partners are no strangers to such projects. They are developing 69 scattered lots in Plainfield into one- and two-family homes and plan to build similar projects in other cities. Mr. Fefferman said the partners were also drawn to Newark because "the city is going through a renaissance, and the demand for housing is strong, but there is a lack of supply, especially of affordable housing."
The two-family homes, generally with 2,400 to 2,500 square feet, will cost $184,900 to $200,000, depending on house and lot size. The one-family houses, with 1,350 square feet, will sell for $149,900. They will take shape in 18 clusters, each with 7 to 20 homes. All the houses are two stories, with garage, and will be built in a factory, mainly by Simplex Industries of Scranton, Pa., and assembled on site. The overall cost of developing the up to 280 homes is in excess of $60 million, Mr. Fefferman said.
Mr. Faiella said Summit was designated to develop so many lots because "they have a good track record and are well financed." He added that because Summit wanted the opportunity to test selling modular homes in Newark at market prices, the developer had agreed to pay more for its 302 lots: five percent of the selling price of each home.
Mr. Fefferman said that Summit, as it has done in Plainfield, would develop two model homes to use to market the rest of the homes, which are to be built as they are sold. The model homes are to go up on Hillside Avenue at Runyon Street and are scheduled to open in mid-October.
The homes being planned by Triple A Construction and A&A Developers are to be traditional construction. Triple A is to build 33 two- and three-family homes, and A&A is to build 25, said Manny Rosa, who is a consultant for both developers and runs the Rosa Agency, a residential real estate company in Newark.
Mr. Rosa said that the two-family homes would generally have 3,000 square feet and, depending on lot size, cost from $165,000 to $224,900, and that the three-family houses would have 4,500 square feet and sell for $239,000 to $249,900. All the homes will have brick facades, either front or back balconies and one- or two-car garages.
He said that both developers are expected to start construction in January and will build the houses in phases even before they are sold. "We believe in the Newark market and that there is a demand in the South Ward for new housing from middle-class families," Mr. Rosa said. "This is a new era for the city."

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Towns Battle Over Density-Affordability Tradeoff

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE quiet residential town of Trumbull, founded in 1797, arguably tops the list of battle-scarred Connecticut municipalities that have lost legal skirmishes with developers of luxury housing who attempt to increase the allowable size of their projects by including lower-income apartments. These projects use a Connecticut law permitting higher density in exchange for offering some units at lower cost to people with lower incomes.
Developers whose projects were denied by Trumbull and other communities around the state have taken the towns to court under the Connecticut Affordable Housing Appeals Law of 1989, winning the right to build market-rate housing at negotiable densities that are greater than allowed by existing zoning regulations. In return, the developer sets aside a percentage of the units at below-market rates for qualified buyers or renters. 
 Almost invariably, the towns were not able to mount effective defenses, which the law limited to proof that such projects should be rejected as detrimental to the community or that the town's interests outweighed the need for moderate-income housing or that the project could not be altered to meet the town's interests.
On Oct. 1, a new amendment to the law becomes effective allowing towns that have added 2 percent to their moderate-income housing stock since 1990 to declare three-year moratoriums on construction of moderate-income housing. (After each 2 percent increase, a town may declare additional moratoriums until it reaches the state's goal of 10 percent of a town's dwellings, when it is exempt from the law.) Despite Trumbull's history of resistance, it has complied with court orders to build enough low-cost units to qualify for relief by declaring a three-year moratorium on such housing.
The term affordable applies to housing that costs up to 30 percent of the tenant's or owner's income, which cannot exceed 80 percent of the area or state median, whichever is lower. The state's median income is $66,000. In the Trumbull-Bridgeport area it is $67,700 and in the Stamford-Greenwich-Norwalk area it rises to $102,400.
Only 32 of Connecticut's 169 towns and cities have moderate-income housing of 10 percent or more. Trumbull, in eastern Fairfield County, had been one of the remaining 137 towns with little or no such housing. But during more than eight years of litigation with various developers it acquired under court orders one apartment complex and four single-family developments with a total of 312 affordable units. With 11,500 dwellings in town, 1,150 units would make up the target of 10 percent, and 312 brings it past the 2 percent level.
Over the years growing dissatisfaction with the law prompted the formation more than a year ago of Gov. John G. Rowland's Commission to Study Affordable Housing. Recommendations promulgated by the commission in February are being put into regulations by the Department of Economic and Community Development. They then must be ratified by the Legislature.
In addition to the moratoriums, the amendment contains features that may appease some opponents of the law by serving to curb development, but developers and advocates of moderate-income housing are concerned that production of such units will be curtailed when the need is high and the cost of market-rate housing is at a peak.
A report earlier this year by the Connecticut office of Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of mortgage funds, says that 68,000 new units are needed to meet current demand in the state and that 48,000 households pay half or more of their income for housing.
The amendment is expected to increase the number of affordable units in a development from the current 25 percent level to 30 percent. The income ceiling for half of those units would be 60 percent of the area or state median, while the rest would stay at the 80 percent ceiling. Income limits would remain in effect for 40 years, up from 30.
Some who are familiar with the efforts to deliver more affordable housing have expressed concern about some changes being brought about by the amendment. "With the increase to 30 percent of units and 40 years' duration," said Timothy Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who specializes in affordable housing law, "you are decreasing the amount of rent and reducing the amount realized from sales. In Fairfield County, with land prices going up, that is not likely to produce more affordable housing."
"Changes in the statute," said Mark Forlenza, vice president for development for the Connecticut-New York region in the Wilton office of AvalonBay Communities of Alexandria, Va., one of the most active developers in the New York City suburbs,"were definitely directed at the larger developer. They just make it harder to create an economically viable project. Originally, the affordable housing law was put in place to get around exclusionary zoning. The more they fool with it, the less affordable housing will be provided in Connecticut."
UNDER the Connecticut regulations, Mr. Forlenza said, "In some of the more affluent communities we would not even be able to build all market-rate housing because of zoning that restricts rental housing."
Resistance to the affordable housing law has been strongest in affluent suburban towns, where it is seen as an assault on the traditional independence of Connecticut's local planning and zoning commissions. Last year the law suffered its first substantial setback when state courts upheld the positions of Glastonbury, Newtown and Bridgewater against developers. The three towns had successfully argued that applications they had received for moderate-income housing under the law should be denied for reasons involving potable water, septic tanks and open space.
Opponents of the law charge that it has not been having the effect it was designed to bring about. "Developers have been coming in and zone-busting areas for windfall profits," said Kenneth S. Halaby, Trumbull's first selectman. "My own daughter makes $40,000 a year and couldn't afford an 'affordable' apartment here," he said, adding that Trumbull's teachers, firefighters and police could not afford to live in the town. "It isn't that the people don't want affordable housing," Mr. Halaby said. "They object to a well-intentioned but flawed state mandate."
Martin Shapiro, a Trumbull resident who has opposed the law from the start, said the flaws mainly involved density and unaffordability. "There are no affordables at Avalon Springs," he said, referring to the 340-unit AvalonBay apartment complex, where market-rate rents for 180 units are $1,100 to $1,900 and rents for the 68 reduced-rate units are $800 to $1,050 plus utilities. It is one of 19 similar projects built in the state by AvalonBay and described as "beautiful" by Mr. Shapiro.
But, he said, "it's a shame for the state to force the suburbs into high density." Under a 1992 court order, the town was obliged to accept the 340 units or comply with AvalonBay's original plan for 600 units.
Mr. Halaby's solution is "to discourage for-profit developers by doing it ourselves." He ended six years of litigation over a 66-unit project proposed by the nonprofit Mutual Housing Association of Stamford by striking a deal with it for two affordable housing developments. "Doing it nonprofit," Mr. Halaby said, "fills the need with units that are less expensive than any for-profit developer can build and they are 100 percent affordable."
According to Larry Kluetsch, executive director of the Mutual Housing Association, the project was negotiated down from 66 to 43 town houses in seven two-story buildings and it will break ground in March on a six-acre site. Completion is scheduled for the end of 2001 at prices ranging from $105,000 for one-bedroom, one-bath units to $150,000 for three bedrooms and two baths. Garages, patios, landscaping, the standard number of kitchen appliances and a community clubhouse are included. Buyers will get their own mortgages and form an association to maintain landscaping and common areas.
With strong town support for the project, Mutual Housing has obtained site acquisition and construction financing from People's Bank, and an application for subsidies is pending at the state's Department of Economic and Community Development. The Neighborhood Reinvestment Corporation, a nonprofit organization chartered by Congress in 1978 to assist other nonprofit groups on housing projects, will be a joint-venture partner with Mutual Housing.
The second project, to be undertaken at an undetermined date, is to be a 25-unit complex for older adults on a 3.4-acre site given to the town by the state.
Mutual Housing has created 117 units of low-cost housing in Stamford and 76 units in Bridgeport since 1990. Median rents for the group's homes in both towns are $600 to $700 a month. Mr. Kluetsch believes that the Trumbull development will be a model. "Planned development with the town as an active partner," he said, "gives the town more control and can create 100-percent affordable units, moving toward more affordables and a moratorium."
Mr. Hollister, who represented Mutual Housing for six years in its bid to build in Trumbull, said: "For-profit developers are not going to follow that model, and nonprofits can't follow anything else. It may not be a breakthrough, but it's a good result for everyone concerned."
