HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
Changing the Philanthropic Model

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

DATELINE: ARMONK

 BODY:
PHILADELPHIA elementary school students are learning grammar with software that listens and talks back. North Carolina parents are holding confidential chats with teachers about high school seniors online. And Texas school administrators are planning curriculums with the click of a mouse.
Each of these ideas was developed in a Westchester County laboratory, where scientists from the International Business Machines Corporation gathered after spending months on the road, brainstorming with teachers, students and administrators. 
 Since 1994, more than 500 sites have asked for the company's help. I.B.M. specialists responded with technology ideas in 21 cases. Together, scientists and educators found solutions through a program called Reinventing Education, a cornerstone of the company's philanthropic effort, which has invested $40 million in programs in 16 states and in Brazil, Ireland, Italy and Vietnam.
Leaders in business, government and education say the initiative stretches the idea of traditional corporate philanthropy, which usually involves legions of volunteers or money and gifts.
Stanley Litow, the vice president of corporate community relations and president of the I.B.M. Foundation, the company's philanthropic arm, said Reinventing Education captures the firm's philanthropic goal not merely to pour out cash. Rather, he said, I.B.M. views philanthropy as a way to prove how technology can make a difference in people's lives.
"Grant money, even in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, is not going to change what you do for children," Mr. Litow said. "It can be helpful. It can provide supplemental services. On the other hand, what school systems really need is the tools that will make more valuable what they do with their own money."
Of the $125 million in total contributions by I.B.M. last year, 66 percent, or $82 million, was given in the form of technical assistance compared with 34 percent, or $43 million, given in cash.
Of all the issues I.B.M. has earmarked for charity -- the environment, health and culture -- education receives the largest share. Three-quarters of the company's corporate philanthropy was directed to education beneficiaries last year, up from 70 percent in 1998, I.B.M. officials said.
Rosabeth Moss Kanter, the Ernest L. Arbuckle professor of business administration at Harvard Business School, said I.B.M. is blazing a new trail in the world of corporate giving.
"What is different about what I.B.M. does -- and I think it should be a model, they are definitely pioneers -- is not just that they are putting in volunteer labor of a casual kind," she said. "They are putting talented scientists and professionals on large-scale, full-time problems to create an innovation. I.B.M. is trying to change things."
Providing volunteers to do manual labor like painting walls or landscaping has a purpose, but using what Ms. Kanter called the "highest skills" a firm has to offer is also valuable, because it creates long-term solutions to problems.
Peter G. Fairweather, an I.B.M. scientist who was also a public school teacher in Chicago in the 1970's, put it this way:
"If a school district is having trouble teaching people to read," he said, "if we simply drove a truck full of computers there and dropped them off, we would never be able to get to the technology to remedy the reading problems."
Of course, helping educators is good for business, I.B.M. officials said. A well-educated community will invest in technology, and partnerships with academia could pave the way for some Reinventing Education ideas to be marketed to a wider audience.
Mr. Fairweather has made more than 100 trips to schools around the country, gathering information to take back to the T. J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights. In developing one program, called Watch Me Read, he and others recorded the voices of 1,800 children to capture a variety of intonations and accents to enable the computer program to communicate with children from a wide range of backgrounds.
The Watch Me Read program was used in 1995 at the Will Rogers Elementary School in Houston, where school officials applied for an I.B.M. grant because they saw that students needed help understanding language, Ronald M. Dominy, the school principal, said. In four years, Mr. Dominy said he has watched first graders' test scores edge upward. Bilingual students' English-speaking ability has also improved, since the children are asked to repeat words they have mispronounced and can hear themselves saying things correctly.
"The bilingual students, economically, don't have the resources the other families have and don't have access to computers at home," Mr. Dominy said. "They took to it."
At Vance High School in Charlotte, N.C., Ann B. Clark, the principal, said that another I.B.M. program, called Wired for Learning, has been in place since 1997 and has gotten everyone more excited about education. The program helps pull teachers out of isolation and gets parents and students more involved, she said.
"We have survey results from teachers and parents and students that definitely attribute the technology to better ongoing communication," Ms. Clark said. "Parents feel more informed. And I think the teachers feel the instructional planning tool has enhanced their ability to plan and collaborate with other teachers and have a planning template."
Still, Mr. Dominy and others said that computerized lessons cannot replace the traditional school setting of classrooms and teachers. Instead, skilled, caring teachers in combination with computer technology provide the best learning scenario, he said.
Last year, Mr. Litow said he stood in a first-grade classroom in Philadelphia as a Vietnamese girl who had been in the country for about a year read aloud the story of her life, which she had written earlier and loaded into a classroom computer.
The girl's grandfather was there to watch her read the story as the rest of the children in the class read along with her. In simple, stark sentences, the girl talked about how her grandfather walked her to school, and Mr. Litow said the older man was clearly proud. The children were learning, on many fronts, he said.
"The story was so poignant," Mr. Litow said. "You think, 'What would have happened to this girl?' Somebody would have walked in and she would have been labeled as someone with a learning problem and that would get carried to grade three or four. And now, you have a new way of doing things."

HEADLINE: What's Entertainment? That Depends . . .

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA KUEHL

 BODY:
REMEMBER what fun it was rushing Snowball to the vet after he gulped down a badminton birdie? Hey, you protest, that was not fun. Nevertheless, that's entertainment, according to the United States government.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which annually surveys Americans about their spending habits, includes veterinary expenses in its "entertainment" category. Not classified as entertainment: reading, dining out and using a home computer, omissions that might give the bibliophile, the gourmand and the chat-room addict pause. The bureau also leaves out gambling, which some experts say is the most popular form of outside-the-home recreation in America. 
 The bureau's sometimes curious choices prompt the question: What is entertainment, anyway? And what factors -- genetic, geographic, chronologic, socioeconomic -- determine that some people, like Beth Henderson of Ashford, Conn., meet their entertainment needs through contemplative pursuits like reading and gardening, while others, like Rina Isaac of White Plains, embrace pulse-pounding activities like mountain biking and archery? What impels Dr. Alfred Scherzer of Hampton Bays, N.Y., to travel to Somalia to gaze at maribou storks, or Donald Wayne of Piscataway, N.J., to amass 100,000 postcards, including one made out of kangaroo skin?
Social scientists say the human hunger for entertainment may be as old as society itself. "I don't know that we have any sort of archaeological evidence of entertainment, per se," said Daniel Fessler, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of California at Los Angeles, whose research fields include evolutionary psychology and psychological anthropology. "But what we do have is the observation that all known human societies have entertainment of some fashion, and that suggests that it's very old indeed."
A society without entertainment "would be a pretty frightening thing," said Frank A. Salamone, a professor of sociology at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., and the author of "Society, Culture, Leisure and Play: An Anthropological Reference" (University Press of America, 2000).
Entertainment "lets us dream," he said.
"It's imagination," he added. "Play at its best gives us a million options."
As a noun, "play" commonly refers to the games of children. Adults, too old to zip into playsuits, instead put on "leisure wear" to "recreate." But whether it's called leisure, recreation or entertainment, when an activity is "nonproductive, in other words, the aim is not a product, the aim is the experience," that's play, and adults need to do it, said John R. Kelly, a sociologist and the author of 11 books about leisure.
"We are working creatures, we are bonding creatures," he said, "and we are playing creatures."
In the New York metropolitan statistical area -- which includes New York City, Westchester, Long Island, most of northern and central New Jersey, and southwestern Connecticut -- households spent an average of $1,835 annually on entertainment in 1997-98, according to the Consumer Expenditure Survey conducted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
That number, though, is misleadingly low. Besides pet care, the bureau's list of entertainments includes movies and sporting events; hobbies, toys and games; television sets, videos and stereos; and sporting and exercise equipment. But add items like dining out, alcoholic beverages and reading, and the amount jumps to almost $5,200 a year, or more than 10 percent of the average household's pretax income. Add still more -- lottery tickets, Internet access, the incalculable costs of recreational shopping, and major investments, like the room Mr. Wayne added onto his New Jersey home to accommodate his collections -- and entertainment costs can soar.
In some years, Dr. Scherzer, 71, spends more than $5,000 to watch birds in exotic locales. A practicing pediatrician and emeritus professor of pediatrics at Cornell Medical College, he is a co-president of the Moriches Bay Audubon Society, which has more than 750 members and covers a territory extending from Patchogue to the tip of the South Fork.
In 35 years as a birder, Dr. Scherzer said, he has logged 1,500 to 2,000 species, many in his backyard, figuratively speaking. "Eastern Long Island is very unusual, because the land mass involves the Atlantic Ocean on the east and the bays on the west, and it's right on the flyway of the eastern migration of birds that come down virtually from the North Pole on their way to South America," he said.
According to Dr. Kelly, who is a co-author with Rodney B. Warnick of "Recreation Trends and Markets: The 21st Century" (Sagamore, 1999), bird-watching is increasingly popular, especially among older adults, a population that grows with each aging baby boomer. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, membership in National Audubon Society chapters has climbed almost 17 percent in the last decade, to nearly 72,000, an Audubon Society spokesman said.
At the Morton National Wildlife Refuge, a slender peninsula west of Sag Harbor, N.Y., that includes both upland and shore habitats, naturalists have documented roughly 280 species, and last year people flocked to see them. Attendance for 1998-99 reached almost 82,000, more than double the number of a decade ago, said Bob Parris, the deputy project leader for the Long Island National Wildlife Refuge Complex, which includes Morton and eight other sites.
Dr. Scherzer said he liked to visit Morton in the off-season, when the crowds are sparser. There, he holds out his hand to the black-capped chickadees, which, secure in their protected area, boldly peck sunflower seeds from a human palm. "It's just a nice experience," Dr. Scherzer said, "that little furry thing on your finger."
 
Variety of Influences
Economics, education, sex, religion, family background and age all influence entertainment choices. Up to 20 percent of Americans have no discretionary income for entertainment, while 10 percent can afford to spend "significant amounts" on fun, according to "Recreation Trends and Markets." Further, some Americans have little discretionary time, Dr. Kelly said, citing people who hold two jobs to support a family, mothers who shoulder a full-time job and take care of their families, too, and workers who may lose hours of recreation time to commuting.
Choices also spring from living in a particular time and place. "What was incredibly amusing in 1890 is now seen to be no longer funny, for the most part," said Dr. Salamone, the Iona professor. "See two minutes of a German film, and you know it's German. Broadly speaking, English jokes aren't funny in the United States, no matter what background people have. Why do the French like Jerry Lewis? I never understood that."
People also choose activities that balance their lives. "If you work in a steel mill all day, you don't rush out to play tennis when you leave the job," Dr. Kelly said. And for reasons that are still little understood, he said, some people are risk takers who like to play on the edge, others are intensely self-protective and need a comfort zone, and the majority fall between the two extremes.
Ms. Isaac, 38, who teaches first graders in Manhattan, said that skiing, hiking, biking and archery help keep her balanced. "When I leave the city, I need to revive my soul," she said. "I make sure I am with nature."
The bow and arrow, which she took up three years ago, require a concentration and focus that send her deep into herself. "You only hear your pulse, your heartbeat -- you can feel your sweat," she said. "It's a competition between my physical self and my mind."
Games generally fall into one of two categories: those that combine physical skill and strategy, and those that combine strategy and chance, said Garry Chick, an associate professor of leisure studies at Pennsylvania State University. Players who excel in the first category reap more prestige, he said.
Ms. Isaac said one benefit from her archery is a new identity. "People call me Rina the Archer, Pocahontas," she said. "They say, 'The wild woman is here.' People see you on another level: 'Hey, that person shoots, and that's awesome.' "
 
The Couch Potato
If archers inspire awe, couch potatoes draw sneers. But watching television remains Americans' prime pastime at night, a Gallup Poll reported in March 1999. Results of another Gallup Poll in January show that 57 percent of Americans watch three or more hours of television a day.
Television delivers story after story, feeding the human need for narrative, which, along with dance, is a universal form of entertainment, said Dr. Fessler of U.C.L.A. Some theorists say that entertainment, like cooking, may be a tradition passed down from ancestral societies. But Dr. Fessler said it may instead be an evolved psychology, a desire that became embedded in the human mind through evolution.
Unfortunately, Dr. Fessler said, evolved psychologies can become insatiable. "If you could afford it, and I guess some people can," he said, "you can just plug yourself into entertainment all of your waking hours and never leave the house."
Meanwhile, more narratives await at the local multiplex. Between 1989 and 1999, the number of movie screens in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rose 60 percent, to 3,470, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. Box offices nationwide took in $7.49 billion in 1999, and Americans spent an additional $17.36 billion renting and buying movies, according to the Video Software Dealers Association.
Luckily for literacy, the stories on library shelves still beckon. According to "Recreation Trends and Markets," more than 90 million adult Americans read books, and the number is rising. In early September, Ms. Henderson, 57, said she was reading six: a memoir, a biography, a travelogue, two local histories and a Harry Potter. A former teacher and school administrator who is now a sculptor, Ms. Henderson said that she spent $75 to $100 a month on newspapers, magazines and books, and combed the library stacks in Ashford and Mansfield, Conn., for free riches. "One of the things I like about reading is that it really promotes the use of your imagination, a lot more than watching a movie, for example," she said.
In contrast, gambling, which Professors Kelly and Warnick describe as "the largest single 'recreation' activity outside the home," doesn't so much promote imagination as feed off it, as gamblers imagine themselves rich.
Their imaginations were working overtime in 1999 as Americans wagered more than $742 billion, according to an industry analyst, Christiansen Capital Advisors. That's 99 times last year's national movie box-office receipts, and almost triple the amount people wagered in 1989.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, dreamers spent $6.2 billion on lottery tickets in 1998-99, 73 percent more than a decade ago, according to figures provided by state lottery officials. And gamblers wagered $43.5 billion in Atlantic City casinos in 1999, about twice what they spent in 1989, according to New Jersey Casino Control Commission figures.
Gambling, which falls into the strategy-and-chance category of games, creates "a kind of an artificial excitement," Dr. Kelly said.
"You don't have to gain any skill to pull levers and push buttons," he said, "but something is happening and you're involved in it and you have a certain stake in it." Gambling choices and styles vary. Some play bingo for fun, others buy lottery tickets out of financial desperation. "That isn't play," he said. "That's waiting to be struck by lightning."
Hooked On Collecting
Gamblers and collectors are both treasure seekers, but collectors rarely go home empty-handed.
There are four clubs in New Jersey for postcard collectors, known as deltiologists, and Mr. Wayne belongs to three of them, including the Central Jersey Deltiological Society, of which he is president. A serious collector since the mid-1960's, Mr. Wayne, 65, said he went "a little berserk" over novelty cards. Besides the kangaroo-skin oddity, he owns cards made of Irish peat, celluloid, aluminum, leather, macerated money and woven silk.
But his acquisitive days are winding down, Mr. Wayne said, because even with the extra room, "the house is full." Still, a collector can dream. At a recent postcard show in Clark, N.J., Mr. Wayne pointed out a man who claimed to own a million cards. "People revere him as one of the icons of the postcard world," Mr. Wayne said. "At least, I do."
Somewhere in the United States is someone who collects just about every kind of object, Dr. Kelly said. Add up all the collections -- stamps, coins, rocks, bones, thimbles, Hummel figurines, comic books, ice cream scoops, barbed wire and everything else -- and "you probably have a fairly significant part of the adult population," he said.
Collectors form groups, attend meetings and publish journals. "The social aspects become very important," Dr. Kelly said.
Mr. Wayne, a retired math teacher who also collects slide rules and books about space, said he couldn't expect people to appreciate the thrill of postcards unless they saw his treasures. Even then they might not understand. Such passions develop over time, and the impulses behind them are often complex.
Although it is easy simply to mock somebody else's idea of fun, the Bureau of Labor Statistics contends that it has valid reasons for each omission from the Consumer Expenditure Survey's entertainment category. For example, the bureau deems reading more informational than entertaining, said Bill Passero, a senior economist. Dining out is a subcategory under food, and gambling is a miscellaneous expenditure, Mr. Passero said, noting that many people regard it not as entertainment but as an investment with a possible return.
As for pet care, it's been part of entertainment (formerly "recreation") since at least 1950, according to bureau records. Where else would you put it? Mr. Passero wondered.
Mr. Wayne, for one, said the notion of pets as entertainment made sense. He and his wife have two Shetland sheepdogs. "They're a riot," he said.

HEADLINE: A New Approach to Unclogging the Highways

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED with traffic problems that grow worse even as billions of dollars are spent on road improvements, a coalition of elected officials, business leaders and commuter groups will try a radically new approach to developing a transportation plan in Connecticut at an all-day summit in West Hartford on Thursday.
The meeting is likely to propose specific projects, its backers said, including the widening of Interstate 95 in the eastern part of the state, a better commuter rail link between New Haven and the Hartford-Springfield area, a better network of mass transit in Fairfield County, and the further development of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks as a transportation hub. 
 "The last time we took a substantive look at transportation in this state was when the Mianus River Bridge fell down, and it's time to do it again," said Christopher P. Bruhl, president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association. "This is a real moment of decision. And if we don't do it right, the world will pass us by."
There are 2,349,051 licensed drivers in Connecticut, and almost all of them have their own cars, Federal Highway Administration statistics show, with each car traveling an average of 10,500 miles a year. And it feels as if they are all on I-95 at once.
That highway, designed for 70,000 to 80,000 cars a day, is carrying 155,000 cars a day in the New Haven area and 150,000 in Bridgeport. The morning and afternoon rush hours are a well-known nightmare.
And I-95 isn't the only problem. The Bureau of Planning at the State Department of Transportation said 40 percent of the state's limited access highways, and 20 percent of all other state highways, were classified as congested.
"There is growing unanimity that if we don't do something it will choke off economic growth," said R. Nelson "Oz" Griebel, director of the Connecticut Regional Institute for the 21st Century, a research group, and a co-chairman of the meeting, called "Strategic Solutions: From Gridlock to Growth." "The summit is just another reflection of the fact that this issue is being taken ever more seriously from every side, not just the department of transportation but the business community, environmental groups, regional planning agencies, and a lot of other organizations."
But more important than specific projects, organizers of the summit said they are seeking to develop a process that will remove politics from decisions about which area gets a road or a bridge, a bus route or some rail lines. The state can no longer afford to think of public works projects as pork, because the transportation infrastructure is increasingly tied to economic development and quality of life, said State Representative Moira Lyons, the Democratic House Speaker who was chairwoman of the Transportation Committee for eight years.
"We want a policy that takes all of the political infighting out of the process," Ms. Lyons said. "In doing that, it may mean that the project in your area may not be the immediate priority. That doesn't necessarily mean that we won't get to it, it might just mean it takes longer. But we need a rational basis for these decisions."
Representatives of regional planning agencies, chambers of commerce, and councils of government from across the state have worked most of the summer on three committees to prepare for the summit, an invitation-only event where there are two people on a waiting list for every one of the about 800 people who are attending.
Peter M. Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said increasingly, there is a realization about how much transportation is tied to the economic health of a state.
"When you look at where traffic flows are within Connecticut, an enormous obstacle for Connecticut businesses is getting into John F. Kennedy Airport or the Port of New Jersey, because there's such a bottleneck at the lower end of the state," he said. If that traffic could be redirected to Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks, it would relieve some congestion.
Already, backers of the summit said, some of the traditional political barriers are starting to fall. John C. Markowicz, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Enterprise Region, said that widening Interstate 95 to three lanes in each direction and completing Route 11 between Hartford and New London, and a few other priority items, will cost an estimated $1 billion. But groups in that region are working with their counterparts in southwestern Connecticut on a $1.5 billion plan for improving mass transit, and also working with the Hartford area on a $1.5 billion rail line along the Interstate 91 corridor.
"Rather than everybody beating up on each other and trying to get their piece, we're saying we have a comprehensive plan, a $4 billion package deal," Mr. Markowicz said. "The three corridors have put this on the table publicly, we have our councils of governments involved, and these are the priorities."
With federal funding, the package would require about $240 million a year for 10 years to cover the state's share.
"The current surplus is more than that," Mr. Markowicz said. Or, an additional gasoline tax of 7 cents a gallon would generate $1 billion.
"There may also be other sources of revenue. Let's have a debate, let's talk about it," Mr. Markowicz said. "There will be people running around saying that it's too expensive. But the question you have to ask is, if we don't start today and we're stuck in traffic today on Interstate 95, what do you think it's going to be like in 10 years."
James J. Finley, associate director of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, said even a statewide approach would be too limited.
"Decisions that New York City and New York State make regarding bridges over the Hudson or rail lines will have a dramatic impact on Connecticut, and we need to make sure that they're taking into account the needs of the rest of New England and the northeast states," Mr. Finley said. Years ago when federal government changed its formula for financing of transportation, members of Congress from New England, New York and New Jersey formed a coalition to make sure money was not redirected out of the Northeast. "That coalition needs to be revived."
Norman W. Garrick, director of the Connecticut Transportation Institute at the University of Connecticut, said some of the state's transportation problems could also be addressed by better land-use planning. Cities such as Portland, Ore., are trying to revitalize their core downtown districts, creating places where people want to work, shop and live. They are slowly creating enclaves where people don't need a car.
"They faced the same argument you hear in Connecticut about people being wedded to their car, but it's changing," Dr. Garrick said. "I think it could change here, too, but we need vision to start doing things differently."
One reason for the clogged highways: 96 percent of all travel to work is done by automobile, and 90 percent of work commuters travel in single-occupancy vehicles.
"We only capture about 4 percent of commuting trips on transit, split about 2 percent on rail and 2 percent on bus," said Richard A. Martinez, the chief of the Bureau of Planning at the State Department of Transportation. "We have high incomes in the state, so more people can afford to drive, and we tend to be more ruralized in our housing patterns."
People will use mass transit when it makes sense, however, Mr. Martinez said. About 80 percent of commuters into New York City take the train, because it is faster, and they can get a pass for a couple of hundred dollars, depending on where they pick it up, about half what they would pay for parking in the city.
There are other factors adding to congestion, he said. The average trip on Interstate 95, for instance, is eight to nine miles, reflecting that people are using it for local trips. Currently, there are 48 interchanges in the 50 miles of highway from New York to Bridgeport, which allows that kind of use.
Some battles are already shaping, such as the competition between commuters and freight haulers on the highway. Almost 80 percent of freight in Connecticut is moved on highways, and only 2 percent on rail. Some 12 to 13 percent of vehicles on Interstate 95 each day are trucks, the transportation department said, compared with 8 percent on Interstate 84 near Waterbury.
One suggestion to come out of the process has been to establish rail hubs where trucks could pick up freight within the state, or to develop ports for ships to bring it in. But Michael J. Riley, president of the Motor Transport Association of Connecticut, which represents 1,200 companies, cautioned that shipping patterns can't change overnight.
"I don't have any problem with the suggestions, except trains don't go to your front yard or to Stop & Shop or to Home Depot," Mr. Riley said. "The economy decides how things move, not government, and that's how it should be."
But any changes are likely to be controversial, he acknowledged.
"The way trucks move on Interstate 95 just doesn't make sense. We're banned from operating in the left hand lane and we can't operate in the right hand lane, or we don't want to, because everyone is entering and exiting," Mr. Riley said. "Let us operate in the left hand lane and you won't have this line of trucks moving down the middle of the highway."
For many years the charter of the transportation department has been to build and maintain roads and bridges as directed by the legislature, and it has done it well, Mr. Griebel said.
"But we need to get them to think and act in a broader way, we need to look at the way we make decisions about transportation funding," Mr. Griebel said. "You wind up with something where everybody gets a nickel along the way, but we don't spend the transportation dollar as well as it should be. We need to come up with a way to allow department to do its job as planners and engineers, to figure out what's best for the transportation system statewide, without any political heat."

HEADLINE: Tilles Begins 20th With High Hopes

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE

 BODY:
WITH a celebratory nod to the past and a major push to ensure the future by creating new audiences, the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts begins its 20th season next month.
While no new series will be in the offing, the anniversary year will feature house debuts by performers like the violinist Gidon Kremer and Ballet Folklorico de Mexico; two mid week concerts by the Billy Taylor Trio, and the customary sprinkling of international stars like Itzhak Perlman, the Tokyo String Quartet, James Galway and the San Francisco Symphony. 
 In addition, the center is going to focus on outreach, "making sure that every child has a chance to experience and feel the arts," said Elliott Sroka, the center's executive director since 1986.
Arts-in-education programming will be expanded to include 19 performances by 10 different groups. These daytime shows at Tilles are only for schools and can, at the schools' discretion, include in-house training for teachers and pre-performance workshops for the students. Last year 12,000 students from 49 school districts throughout the Island saw 13 shows by 8 groups.
Tilles, on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, is also entering into a partnership with the Lincoln Center Institute, a pioneer in arts in education. Working in the Manhasset and Freeport districts, the institute will help Tilles train 30 teaching artists based on Long Island who will eventually be available to go into the schools on a regular basis, not just to prepare students for specific programs.
All told, the outreach program will cost Tilles about $500,000; last year $275,000 was spent. "One of our missions is to educate future audiences, nurture audiences and performers for and of the next generation," he said.
But Tilles officials have more on their minds than what is on stage. About $4 million has already been raised toward a $10 million to $15 million capital plan. That includes a $1.1 million grant from New York State that Mr. Sroka said would mostly be used to "maintain, upgrade and improve the center physically."
Some of that work involves projects that got pushed aside in the rush to open for the 1981 season.
For that first season, which had a budget of $507,000, the hall presented 12 events seen by 20,000 people. For the 1998-99 season, the last year for which figures are available, more than 102,000 people attended 90 events. This season, the budget of $6.3 million will cover a comparable number of shows.
"Without a doubt it has had a positive influence on the cultural life of Long Island," said Teddy Bookman, the executive director of Friends of the Arts. "It has been a catalyst to bring extraordinary performers to the Island."
The Friends, a group that began presenting dance and classical music on the Island in 1973, was one of Tilles's initial tenants for its Great Performances series. But with "the graying of the audience," Ms. Bookman said, by 1996 "there wasn't enough of an audience for both us and Tilles, so we decided to concentrate on other aspects of our programming."
The Sea Cliff Chamber Players and the National Grand Opera, which used to be major renters, are no longer in business, so the only arts groups still using the hall are the Long Island Philharmonic and the Eglvesky Ballet. The bulk of each season is programmed by Tilles.
Before Tilles, promoters like Friends of the Arts used school auditoriums or movie houses for their concerts. While the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University opened in 1975, with its 1,000-seat main stage and smaller theaters it was considered too small to make the presentation of large orchestras and major performers economically feasible -- and too far east to accommodate Nassau residents.
Recognizing a need for a more centrally located professional concert venue, in the 1970's Long Island University officials built the Dome Concert Hall at C. W. Post. When the Dome collapsed after a heavy snow in 1978, the current building, with a main theater that seats 2,200 and the 491-seat adjacent Hillwood Recital Hall, was built at the cost of $4.4 million. It was originally known as the C. W. Post Concert Theater but took the name of Gilbert and Rose Tilles in 1986 after the family donated $1.1 million.
Tilles has found traditional classical music audiences graying out or retiring off the Island, so it began programming pop, jazz and special events to appeal to younger people. It found that children's concerts also brought their parents, all potential ticket-buyers, to the hall, and it booked ethnic performances meant to attract newcomers to the Island.
The theater must be doing something right, Mr. Sroka believes, because eight weeks before the anniversary season opened, about 85 percent of their audience members were subscribers.
Last year, 16 percent of subscriptions were sold to people from Suffolk communities as far away as Stony Brook and Hauppauge and 7 percent went to residents of Queens and Brooklyn. Even within Nassau, Mr. Sroka said, the reach has increased dramatically to South Shore communities like Baldwin, Freeport, Massapequa and Long Beach.
"We've created an institution that's constantly reinventing itself and perpetuating itself, one that the public supports," Mr. Sroka said. "We're close to raising a $10 million endowment, because we're meeting the growing demands for lively and vital arts."
The Tilles Center's 20th anniversary season opens on Oct. 6 with "An Evening With Marvin Hamlisch." Information: (516) 299-3100.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Westport Awards
Each year about this time Westport honors a group of artists, writers, actors, musicians and photographers who have lived or worked in the town during the course of their careers.
The seventh annual public awards presentation will be held today at 2 p.m. in the Westport Town Hall, 110 Myrtle Avenue. 
 On the list of living recipients is the composer and musician Norman Dello Joio; the actress Haila Stoddard; Max Wilk, the writer, producer and teacher; and George Silk, the photographer.
Posthumous recognition will be given to Lucille Lortel, one of the theater's most dedicated advocates and producers; the artist Kerr Eby; the musician Heida Hermann; and the children's writer P. D. Eastman.
A short video presentation will precede the awards ceremonies and a performance of a Dello Joio work will end the program, followed by a reception at the Westport Historical Society.
The event is open to the public free of charge.
 
Appraising Collectibles
You did save those Pez dispensers, and some of that Silly Putty you used to have, didn't you? Your mother's tin school lunch box? All manner of junk might now be worth the price of at least one pair of Manolo Blahniks.
Pack up one prized thing and take it to the Connnecticut Historical Society in Hartford on Wednesday at 7 p.m., when Gary Sohmers, an appraiser for the "Antiques Roadshow" television show, will tell you its worth.
During his lecture on "What's Hot, What's Not," Mr. Sohmers will offer sage advice on the collectibles craze and where you might find a fortune among the detritus in the attic, basement and garage.
The society is at 1 Elizabeth Street, and admission is $5, $5 for people over 64 and children 6 through 17 years of age. The number to call for more information is (860) 236-5621.
 
Mark Twain
It took Samuel Clemens seven years to write "Huckleberry Finn" with the help of his wife, Olivia, only to face scorn and verbal abuse from many quarters when it was published. The public library in Concord, Mass., for example, called it trash and refused to have the book on its shelves. To which the author's response was, "that will sell 25,000 copies for sure."
All this will be brought to life in a program of dramatic readings on Thursday at 7 in the Carriage House of Samuel and Olivia Langdon Clemens' Hartford home, now a museum, at 351 Farmington Avenue.
"Mark My Words: Twain and the Creative Process" will be performed by the actors John Pogson and Lisa Steier as the 19th-century writer and and his wife. The material was gleaned from the couple's personal correspondence and private papers.
The book remains among the top five titles on the "100 Most Challenged Books 1990-1999," a list compiled by the American Library Association. "Mark My Words" has been appropriately scheduled during the association's 16th annual Banned Book Week. Admission is $10. The number to call for reservations or more information is (860) 247-0998, extension 23, or charge reservations to Visa or MasterCard by e-mailing rachel_rogers@hartnet.org.
 
The Black Press
"Frederick Douglass's 'Colored Newspaper' " is the title of the first in a series of four lectures on the black press in America. Organized by Trinity College, the Connecticut Historical Society and Curbstone Press, the talks will be held at 4:30 p.m., free of charge, at the Historical Society, 1 Elizabeth Street in Hartford.
The opening program on Tuesday will be conducted by Robert Fanuzzi, an associate professor of English at St. John's University and a widely published author on Douglass.
Subsequent lectures are titled "African-American Literary Societies and the Black Press," to be delivered on Oct. 19 by Elizabeth McHenry, assistant professor of English at New York University; "Photojournalism at Ebony Magazine" on Nov. 21, with Maren Stange, professor of American studies at Cooper Union; and "Literature, Journalism and the Black Middle Class in Chicago 1930-1950" on Nov. 30, with James C. Hall, author and associate professor of African-American Studies and English at the University of Illinois in Chicago.
The number to call for more information is (860) 236-5621.
 
Ireland and Conflict
Ireland's internecine conflict, frequently called "the troubles," may be seen as the end-product of a tangled earlier history, outlined in an exhibition called "Ascendancy: Irish Religion and Politics 1500-1800."
The exhibition, on view at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale through Oct. 14, can be seen Monday through Friday from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is free.
A major portion of the material is from the library's own James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection. It includes paintings and engravings from the 16th through the 18th centuries as well as maps, correspondence and manucripts.
Among them are a 1599 letter in which Elizabeth I instructs Robert Earl, Governor-General of the Kingdom of Ireland, on aspects reharding the suppression of insurgents in Ulster.
Edmund Spenser's 1597 prose work, "A Viewe of the Present Estate of Ireland" was an exceptionally authoritative summary of knowledge about Ireland at that time.
Letters by Cromwell, petitions by Irish bishops against the papacy, anonymous manuscripts urging harsher measures against Catholics and manuscripts petitioning for relief for Catholics, correspondence by Sir Robert Peel, and letters, treatises and petitions by numerous nobles, high officals and commoners offer insights into Ireland's history.
In a 1797 letter Edmund Burke wrote, "Nothing can equal the madness and folly of all the proceedings in England, except the madness and folly of the proceedings in Ireland, which not only equal but far exceed them in every particular of insanity and absurdity."
 
Book Discussions
The Friends of New Haven's Free Public Library have organized another season of weekly noontime book discussions at the United Church on the Green, at the corner of Temple and Elm Streets. The opener on Thursday is "My Life With Benjamin Franklin," discussed by its author, Claude Anne Lopez, consultant editor of Franklin's papers at Yale.
Admission is free and visitors are welcome to bring a bag lunch. Coffee and cookies are available for purchase from 11:30 a.m. to noon.
Books under discussion are always current and discussion leaders are always faculty members, former faculty, deans or others having some connection with Yale. On Oct. 5, Robert J. Shiller, professor of economics at Yale, will talk about his book, "Irrational Exuberance."
Begun in 1972, the series runs through November and resumes again in the spring. The number to call for more information is (203) 288-1900 or (203) 230-0847.
 
Another Andrew Wyeth
There is another Andrew Wyeth, with the middle name of Nathaniel separating him from his grandfather, the original Andrew Wyeth. The younger Andrew, known as A.N., is a watercolorist following the realist tradition of the family.
An exhibition of his landscapes and vintage buildings may be seen at the Geary Gallery, 576 Post Road, in Darien through Oct. 13.
The landscapes may be seen on Tuesday through Saturday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The number to call for more information is (203) 655-6633.
 ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In Bridgeport, Demolish or Preserve?

BYLINE: By REGINALD JOHNSON

 BODY:
ONCE, the Elijah Hubbell building was a focal point of downtown Bridgeport. With a hotel on the top floors and businesses on the first floor, the building (which dates from 1871) was abuzz with activity for years while Bridgeport thrived in the industrial era.
Now, the big brick building is vacant, its windows boarded up, its copper cornice stained from years of neglect. And it is surrounded by similar buildings in similar condition in the heart of downtown. Now, too, in an effort to remake the center of the city and ease court overcrowding, officials have come up with a plan to build a court complex on a 20-acre site. The plan calls for a state juvenile court and detention center, a criminal court building, a parking garage and retail development. The entire project is expected to cost more than $100 million, with the state paying most of the bill. 
 "We've had plans for the downtown coming out of every entrance and exit of City Hall for the past 30 years, and nothing has happened," the City Council president, John Fabrizi, said. "Now we have a chance to make things happen, and solve the problems of the court overcrowding."
In all, 48 buildings on the north side of downtown will be razed to make way for the project, and it is that destruction that is causing second thoughts. Because in those 20 acres, an area that is on the National Register of Historic Places, are buildings like the Elijah Hubbell, and preservationists are asking the city to slow down.
"The city's in danger of losing its soul," the city's historian, Charles Brilvitch, said. "Taking out the better part of downtown for this ill-conceived idea will be the death knell for downtown."
Opponents see the overall plan, called the Congress Plaza Renewal Project, as inappropriate and unnecessary, one that will further destroy Bridgeport's heritage, force out small businesses and bring in an institution (the detention center) that will hurt the downtown's image, at a time when perception of the city was beginning to improve.
A group called the Downtown Preservation Task Force has been organized to fight the plan. A letter-writing campaign has begun, petitions are being circulated, and a Web site set up. Opponents are asking the City Council for a nine-month moratorium on the project and asking state officials to stop support for the project.
Charlie Shanner and Judith Miller, members of the task force who want to stop the project, said the Elijah Hubbell building is far from an empty old hulk. To them, the building is a treasure that must be saved. They believe the structure -- along with several other downtown buildings -- could be renovated and help revitalize the center of the city.
"I see the potential for offices and apartments here," said Ms. Miller as she stood at the corner of Golden Hill Street and Main Street. "You could have shops all along the first floor that would be part of a beautiful streetscape."
"And apartments on the top floor would get a magnificent view," Mr. Shanner said. "Buildings like these are marvelous because you can go into them and pretty much make them anything you want, and still keep the historic character." The mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, the economic development director, Michael Freimuth, and other municipal leaders like Mr. Fabrizi, the City Council president, see the picture very differently. The downtown has been declining for years, they said, and the project presents an opportunity to build something new finally. It is simply not economically feasible, they said, to preserve the old buildings and make them useful.
City officials say the construction of the new judicial buildings, together with the parking garage, accomplishes several objectives: The criminal court building will modernize and streamline Superior Court operations, now handled by two older courthouses nearby. The new structure also will make over the two-block area of Main Street and Middle Street just south of Congress Street, where there are buildings that are empty and decaying. The juvenile detention center and court will solve the overcrowding at an existing institution on the West Side of Bridgeport,a problem the city was under court order to correct.
In the area south of the planned new court buildings, Mr. Freimuth said, some dilapidated buildings will be cleared for new retail development -- although no developers have made commitments.
Some demolition of 19th-century brick buildings has already taken place on the northern end of the redevelopment tract. In June, a building on Gold Street was removed because bricks were falling, said Patrick Coyne, the director of the city's Clean and Green Program, which is handling the demolitions. In July, officials said the roof collapsed on a building on Middle Street and that, too, was taken down for safety reasons. In the process of demolishing the building, the wrecking equipment damaged a nearby building. That structure was immediately declared a safety hazard, and Mayor Ganim issued an emergency demolition order.
Except for emergency demolition, a municipality that wants to tear down a building listed on the National Register of Historic Places to make way for a state or federally funded construction project must submit their plans for review before the State Historical Commission. The director of the state commission, John Shannahan, said local officials must prove there is no alternative site for the planned project or show that existing buildings couldn't work.
City representatives in June appeared before the panel to make their case. They presented arguments made in a consultant's report that the area was severely blighted and that renovation of the existing buildings was not financially viable.
Commission officials decided they needed to do their own check of the condition of the buildings, and the city agreed to hold off on any nonemergency demolitions for a three-month period, until Oct. 6.
Preservationists dispute that all of the buildings are derelict. One building slated for demolition that aroused concern is the Bridgeport Boys Club, at 227-41 Middle Street. The turn-of-the-century building is constructed of heavy masonry and brick, with the steps up to the top floors constructed with cut stone. The former owner of the building, Marshall Lewis, whose family has a business next door and owned the building for years, said the roof is in solid shape.
Mr. Shanner, in fact, had inquired about buying the building at one point to move in his graphic design business and rent out store and restaurant space. But he was told by city officials that the building was going to be demolished.
"That building could withstand a nuclear attack," said the preservation task-force member Judith Miller. Cleaning up the brick and cornices on the exterior, and renovating the interior, Ms. Miller said, would make it an exemplary building.
Several people who want to save the old buildings said the city should be following the model of South Norwalk and the area of Washington Street, which has a line of historic buildings that have been converted into offices, bookstores, craft shops, restaurants and pubs. The area is one of the most popular night spots in southern Connecticut.
"Twenty years ago, the buildings on Washington Street were dilapidated and decaying, too," Mr. Brilvitch said. "And look what they did."
State Representative Robert T. Keeley Jr., a Democrat of Bridgeport and a preservation task-force member, also complained that the idea of bringing a juvenile court and detention center into the downtown area runs counter to the city's attempt to lure more people downtown for entertainment. "I don't know of any other cities that are putting detention facilities in their downtowns," he said. "It's not usual to use this as a marketing tool," he said sarcastically.
Mr. Keeley and others said there are other places in the city where the juvenile detention center could be built. "I'm going to be talking to the governor's office and let them know there is no planning down here."
Mr. Freimuth said the city looked for other locations for the juvenile center. Some two dozen sites were considered and rejected -- for zoning problems, resistance from property owners, or noncompliance with state guidelines for being accessible to other judicial centers and a transportation network.
"We have to balance the historic with economics," Mr. Freimuth said. "We have to balance the fact that these buildings just cannot produce and perform today."
Mr. Freimuth also denied that the city had no interest in historic renovation -- citing the restoration work on the old McLevy Hall, conversion of an old bank into the Polka Dot Playhouse, the planned renovation of Read's Department store into artists' studios, and restoration of the Arcade Building. All those buildings are south of the Congress Plaza area, and a few blocks north of the city's sports development area, which includes the Bluefish baseball stadium and new sports arena.
Several small-business owners in the area targeted for demolition are also bitter about the city's plan.
One of those is the Aquarion Beauty Salon at 1218 Main Street, owned by Dionne Wilson. She said she's been told she has to move by October. "I don't know if I can find a place," she said. "The city hasn't given much help in finding another place. Rents are much higher in other places, or there are no vacancies. Also, you don't know if there will be enough parking," she said.
Lance Lewis, owner of one of Bridgeport's oldest businesses, Davidson's Fabrics, at 1240 Main Street, said he does not want to leave. He said the store has been there for more than 50 years, caters to many people of modest means, and has employees who have worked with them for years.
"We saw this area deteriorate for 30 years and we stuck it out. We held on," he said. "Now there's a plan to make it come back, and I have to leave."

HEADLINE: Bus Driver Shortage Leaving Students At the Curb

BYLINE: By NANCY DONIGER

 BODY:
THE shortage of school bus drivers resulting from the expanding economy and the state's low unemployment rate has made the first few weeks of the school year chaotic ones. Buses in many towns are regularly late, routes have been expanded so students have to leave for school earlier and get home later, and in some cases, most notably in Stamford where the shortage has been acute, buses haven't come at all.
The problem has gotten so bad, and the search for new drivers so futile, that some bus companies have offered up to $2,000 signing bonuses for drivers, increased wages by more than 30 percent, and have put their office staff on the road. In at least two cases, company presidents have had to get behind the wheel to keep the buses running. 
 Many parents are getting fed up, demanding meetings with school and bus officials and often abandoning the bus altogether, driving their children to school instead. Of course, that has led another frustration: traffic jams at pick up and drop off as more cars head to school.
"We're getting calls about bus driver shortages from all around the state," said Thomas Murphy, spokesman for the State Department of Education. "This should come as no surprise. We have a very strong economy. People who might in the past have been interested in becoming bus drivers have other options.
Like working for the casinos in Ledyard and Uncasville, an area of the state feeling the shortage. Or jobs at the corporations and new high-tech companies that fill Fairfield County. With well-paying jobs seemingly so available, and with a statewide unemployment rate of about 2.5 percent, bus companies are having difficulty finding drivers to work for pay ranging from $9 to $18 an hour or more, depending on the area. That's up from an average of $8 to $10 five years ago. In Thomson, a particularly hard-hit area, bus drivers earn $21 an hour, said Robin Leeds, executive director of the Connecticut School Transportation Association.
Still, while wages are rising, driving is still a part-time job, and a stressful one at that, considering the responsibility of caring for dozens of children. Drivers work an average of five hours a day, so even in Thomson, drivers are making only $525 a week. That's about $20,000 a school year in a state where the median annual income is $62,800.
The shortage of bus drivers in Connecticut mirrors a nationwide problem. Richard Fischer, a school bus consultant in Peyton, Colo., estimates the national shortage at 20 percent. Schools across the nation have begun staggering their start times as one method to permit fewer drivers to make more runs.
Stamford was the hardest hit at the start of this school year. The district was already short drivers, when 24 failed to show up for the first day of school, bringing the shortfall to 40 drivers.
Responding to a crisis in Stamford that left many students stranded during the first weeks of school, the Laidlaw Bus Company, with 800 routes and 900 to 950 drivers statewide, is offering sign-up bonuses of $2,000 for already certified drivers, and $1,000 for people who are willing to complete the approximately four-week training program, required for certification, said Ronald Timula, general manager of Laidlaw. State law requires school bus drivers to get a commercial drivers license, along with a criminal-background check and drug and alcohol testing, he said.
The company has also dramatically increased wages. New drivers in Stamford, who previously were paid $22 for a 2 1/2-hour run and a $7 a day as an incentive bonus just for showing up, now earn $30. So new drivers make $67 a day if they drive two shifts, totaling about five hours. The wages of experienced drivers (those who have been with the company for three years or more) rose from $31.75 to $38 a shift, allowing them to make, with the $7 bonus, $83 for the entire day. The company is also offering fully paid health insurance immediately, rather than the previous one-year waiting period.
 Mr. Timula also said that Laidlaw reached an agreement with the Teamsters Union in Stamford this month and has brought in 40 drivers from out of state, 30 of whom are still in training.
"We still have some glitches, but expect to have them solved very soon," he said, "once we get more new drivers on the road. We intend to fulfill our obligations to the Stamford School District and make it unnecessary for the district to desire to break the contract."
Rosa Rastegar of Stamford was livid when the bus failed to pick up her three children, and she had to drive them. She and her husband, Saiid, are also irked by the very early pick-up time for her high school daughter, which was pushed from 7:05 a.m. last year back to 6:35 a.m. this year. Her daughter will soon be waiting for the bus in the dark, she said.
"They had all summer to work things out," Ms. Rastegar said. "We feel it's time to change bus companies. Laidlaw has constant problems and ups and downs."
Lisa Arons, whose sons, Noah, 5, and Jonathan, 7, attend Roxbury Elementary School in Stamford, found the bus so erratic that she now drives
"We're driving our children to school, but there are major problems when pickup time comes," she said. "There isn't enough space allocation for all the cars. Pick up is a nightmare. There's nowhere to put all the cars that are getting there early."
Under pressure from the Board of Education and parents, Laidlaw had agreed to relinquish its contract at the end of the year.
At least two hard-pressed bus company presidents have been getting behind the wheel since the start of the school year, covering routes when enough drivers can not be found. Clerical workers and mechanics who have the necessary certification are also driving.
John Sylvanie, president of the Greenwich and New Canaan Bus Companies is one of them. He is driving, despite a wage scale his company offers of $12 to $14 an hour, 401(k) plan, and vacation time. Mr. Sylvanie has managed to cover his bases without disruption to his customers by "getting as creative as we could and rerouting all the schools, making some routes shorter and others longer. We work very closely with our customers, but we're still short of drivers."
Because Greenwich and New Canaan do not have a large pool of people willing to work as school bus drivers, he has done aggressive recruiting in urban areas and imports drivers from New York, and where the parent company, the Suburban Bus Company, is situated.
Even with all those measures, he has no spare drivers and admitted the system could confront severe disruptions with an outbreak of the flu this winter. "More resources have to go into the system," Mr. Sylvanie said. "My costs have gone up two or three times. Fuel is way up, auto liability insurance and health insurance are up."
He does not believe firing bus companies will solve the problem, since the shortage of drivers is so widespread. "The school systems have to put sufficient resources into transportation," he said. "Money doesn't grow on trees. They can't keep going with the lowest bidder to save money, and think things will work. The whole system needs to be rethought."
Rising school enrollment across the state is compounding the problem. The state's student population this September followed a 12-year growth cycle, adding 4,000 new children, or a total of 558,860.
School districts may have to appeal to the community for more money if the trend continues, he said.
"There's no short-term fix," Ms. Leeds said. "From what I've heard, people are looking to the labor shortage continuing until 2025."
Some Wilton middle school parents are so fed up with their children's long bus routes, they are car-pooling them to school instead. One Ridgefield teacher said most of her students are tardy, due to late bus arrivals, disrupting the school day.
West Hartford has also felt the crunch of late arrivals, according to the school transportation director, Olivia Harry. The school district is served by the Double AA Transportation Company, which was awarded the contract this year for the first time. First Student Inc. previously served the district.
Double AA was unexpectedly short 24 drivers at the start of the school year, but has hired more drivers and used company staff to cover all its runs. The company president, Tony Autorino, has been driving a regular route, in addition to running the bus company. "We didn't feel the shortage until the fall," he said. "We have mostly young mothers driving, because they can bring their preschool children on the bus. Not everyone wants to be a bus driver because it's an ultra high responsibility." His company pays drivers $11.50 per hour.
Gene Garriepy, 66, of Newtown has been driving for Laidlaw's Brookfield terminal for 11 years. He generally likes the job, he said, because he cares about the children and feels he is able to make a contribution to their well-being through the relationships he forms with some families. Mr. Garriepy started in 1989 at $9 an hour, was earning about $9.75 an hour five years ago and now brings home $12.60 an hour for an average of 25 to 28 hours a week.
"If my wife wasn't working, and we didn't have income from investments, I wouldn't be able to do it," he said. Drivers receive few benefits, aside from three paid personal days and a 401(k) they must fund themselves, without company contributions.
Ms. Leeds cited several solutions for the driver shortage, including staggered start times to allow fewer drivers to cover more routes and raising their hours to full-time. She also recommended using school buses for other purposes in the community, since Connecticut has little mass transportation.
This would give drivers more hours and put the buses to greater use, benefiting the bus companies and the communities.
Mr. Murphy and Mr. Garripey agree with Ms. Leeds that staggered hours would help solve the problem. All-year school and better working conditions for the drivers would also help, Mr. Garriepy said.
Not all areas of the state are hurting, however.
School officials in Waterbury, Danbury, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven, where the labor pool is larger and the cost of living is lower than in other parts of the state, said they had enough drivers.
Gary Levine, contract manager for First Student Inc., with routes in Bethel, Easton and Redding, said the situation looked precarious this summer, but he was able to bring in drivers in July and has enough to cover the routes.
"We have 46 routes and 46 drivers, but we don't have spares," he said. "We're very fortunate to have drivers back from last year, but we need spares."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Decision Nears on Much-Debated Mall at Oyster Bay

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
WHEN the last speaker sat down sometime after 4 a.m. on Sept. 8, ending one of the longest public hearings ever in the town of Oyster Bay, there was agreement on only this: the former Cerro Wire and Cable Company plant near Syosset was a blight and had to go.
What should rise next on the industrially zoned acreage, which is next to the Long Island Expressway but also at the borders of residential communities, has remained, in the days since the hearing, at the center of one of the most stubbornly fought development battles on Long Island in years. 
 Consultants and representatives for Taubman Centers, a mall developer based in Bloomfield, Mich., which is seeking to make its debut in Long Island's rich retail market, argued at the hearing that nothing could be better or economically wiser than replacing the derelict industrial plant on the 39-acre site with a top-of-the-line shopping mall. Taubman has been trying for six years to gain approval, and a Town Board decision is now expected within two months.
The property was acquired in 1989 by the Tribune Company of Chicago as a potential site for a printing plant for The Daily News. The Tribune company no longer owns The Daily News but now owns Newsday.
Built in 1950's, the Cerro plant manufactured electrical conduits and copper rods. In 1993 the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation declared the site, by then unused, an inactive hazardous waste site. It was removed from the list after a cleanup in 1994.
To be called the Mall at Oyster Bay, the 860,000 square-foot retail center -- scaled back from nearly one million square feet in an earlier proposal -- would hold Long Island's first Neiman-Marcus, other major stores whose identity Taubman has yet to disclose and an array of expensive smaller stores and shops.
"We are talking about a mall the likes of which Long Island has never seen," said Gary Lewi, a public relations professional from Syosset and a spokesman for Taubman, speaking in the days after the hearing.
More than just shopping is at stake, Taubman says. The mall would mean more than 2,000 construction jobs and tens of millions in tax revenues -- including more than $6 million for financially ailing Nassau County -- during construction. Once operating, Taubman estimates, the mall would directly generate more than $45 million annually in salaries, $7.3 million in property taxes and $14.3 million in sales tax revenues. Annual property taxes would include $375,181 for the town of Oyster Bay and $3.9 million for the Syosset School District. And, incidentally, the Cerro blight would be wiped away.
But the neighbors and their supporters are adamantly opposed to Taubman's project and came by the hundreds to the marathon hearing, presenting their own consultants, who urged rejection of the plan.
Leaders of local civic groups said they would prefer a high-tech park, light industry, an office complex, senior-citizen housing, even a recreational facility. Traffic from the mall, they said, would wreak havoc on their middle- and upper-middle-income neighborhoods. The generally accepted estimate of the traffic generated by the mall is 24,000 cars on an average day.
The site, the opponents said, is particularly ill suited for a mall because poor access would inevitably funnel large volumes of traffic through local streets and, dangerously, over a grade-level Long Island Rail Road crossing. Mall traffic would also overburden larger commercial thoroughfares like Jericho Turnpike, they said.
"The neighborhoods' entire quality of life will be forever destroyed," said Howard Avrutine of Syosset, a lawyer for the Birchwood Civic Association, a group representing a neighborhood near the proposed mall.
In a well-organized and dogged campaign, the opponents say they have broadened their ranks to include more than 20 civic associations, two local school boards -- including the Syosset school board -- and, by their count, 25,000 families in a wide radius around the proposed mall site.
THE Nassau County Chambers of Commerce, representing 6,000 businesses, has also joined the opposition. Members fear the mall will hurt existing retailers, including smaller businesses along Jericho Turnpike.
"They all recognize the devastation this project would cause," said Kevin Ryan, president of Ryan & Ryan, a public relations firm in Farmingdale, who has worked two years for the Birchwood Civic Association.
The opponents are unimpressed by Taubman's assertions that the mall would fill a high-end shopping need in Nassau County beyond that already filled by the Americana at Manhasset and other malls.
"There are so many malls in every direction," said Leonard A. Gutterman of the West Birchwood Civic Association. "We just question the need for another."
The seven members of the Oyster Bay Town Board must now decide whether to grant Taubman a special permit to allow construction of the mall in an industrial area, the subject of the hearing. Supervisor John Venditto said last week he expected the board would act within two months.
But Mr. Venditto and principals for and against the mall said that regardless of the board's decision, they expected appeals in the courts. Mr. Venditto said the board would strive to write a decision that would withstand a legal challenge. "We are elected to make decisions about zoning," Mr. Venditto said. "We should be the ones to decide what goes on in the streets of this town."
Residents opposing the mall vowed to defeat town board members if they fail to heed antimall sentiment.
Taubman's representatives said groups that have opposed the mall were using public relations techniques to make themselves look bigger and influence the outcome.
Morton Weber, a lawyer on Long Island for Taubman, said the number of opponents had swelled in recent months by no more than "maybe a hundred people or so" despite the groups' recruiting efforts. The opponents scoffed at this. "It sounds like he is getting desperate," Mr. Ryan said.
But Mr. Weber said he believed the primary opponent to the mall was not nearby residents, but rather Simon Properties of Indianapolis, the largest mall owner in the country and a Taubman competitor.
Mr. Weber said Mr. Ryan still represented Roosevelt Field in Garden City, a Simon property, and suggested that Simon might be helping to finance residents' opposition, which has included a direct mail campaign and a full-page advertisement in Newsday. On Long Island, Simon also owns the Mall at the Source in Westbury, Walt Whitman in Huntington and Smithhaven Mall in Lake Grove.
Billie Scott, a Simon spokeswoman in Indianapolis, said, "The suggestion that we are manipulating the situation for a competitive purpose is an attempt to divert attention away from the real issue, namely traffic." She said Simon retained Mr. Ryan about two years ago to do public relations work for the four Simon-owned malls but had no part in his work on behalf of the Birchwood Civic Association in opposing the Taubman mall.
Asked if Simon had made any financial contribution to the opponents, she replied, "I can't comment on the level of support, if any, that has been provided by Simon."
Mr. Ryan said he was not being paid by Simon for his work with the civic association. "This whole Simon thing is smoke and mirrors," he said.
A leader of residents opposing the Taubman mall, Todd Fabricant of the East Birchwood Association in Jericho and a Cerro Wire coalition committee, said he had "no communication with the Simon organization." He said financing for the fight against what he called "a very poor plan for this site" had come from dues residents paid to organizations opposed to the project.
Mr. Ryan said Taubman had enlisted union construction workers in its efforts by "selling them a bill of goods" about union jobs the project would provide. "We have never been antidevelopment; we have just been antimall," Mr. Ryan said. He said whatever was built at the site would provide construction jobs.
Construction workers favoring the Taubman mall were among more than 1,500 people who attended the Oyster Bay hearing. John M. Kennedy, the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, said that Mr. Weber and another Taubman official had "made a commitment to use local union contractors and craftspeople."
Taubman, like Simon a real estate investment trust, was founded by A. Alfred Taubman in 1950 and owns shopping malls with a combined total of 27 million square feet of retail space in 12 states.
In New Jersey, Taubman owns the Mall at Short Hills, with 1.35 million square feet of retail space. The company's malls in Connecticut include the 573,000-square foot Stamford Town Center, and Westfarms, near Hartford, with 1.29 million square feet.
As residents vow that Taubman will never build a mall at the Cerro site, a wild card has yet to be played. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has powers of condemnation, has named a portion of the property as the possible site of a new rail storage yard that will be needed to store trains overnight as the Long Island Railroad increases service.
Mr. Weber said a rail yard would make the mall impossible but suggested that residents would prefer the mall to the trains. The residents were not ready to concede that. "We are open to many other types of development," Mr. Fabricant said.
