SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 3026 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property;
An Up Cycle Just Keeps Rolling

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
OFFICE vacancies are approaching record lows and rental rates reaching record highs in Manhattan. Despite the demand, there is no speculative construction in the city, with the few buildings that are being constructed substantially preleased before a shovel went into the ground.
Across the Hudson River along the New Jersey waterfront, buildings are being occupied as fast as they can be built as securities firms are moving their back-office operations one stop west of Manhattan on the PATH rail line. Even in Westchester, which has tended to lag the rest of the area in occupancy, growth by local companies is filling up long-vacant space. 
 The business of leasing to retailers in New York is booming, with areas like 14th Street and Madison Avenue in the upper 20's attracting new attention. The city's hotels are packed despite the addition of new rooms.
The real estate business in the metropolitan area is in the midst of a period of prosperity so extended that it has prompted people with long memories to ask "How long can this go on?"
The consensus answer appears to be: For the next two or three years at least, provided the national economy does not swoon. With lenders still exerting firm discipline on developers, there is little danger of overbuilding and even slowed growth is still growth, which means more jobs and a need for space to put people.
"I must tell you this all makes me very nervous, but I can't see any clouds in the sky," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company. She said that history demonstrates every upsurge in rental rates and property prices has been followed by a downturn, but that in the current market "there is no new supply and demand is overwhelming."
According to a report by Insignia/ESG, the vacancy rate in Manhattan is under 4 percent for the first time in memory, and the average asking rental for all transactions of more than 10,000 square feet at midyear was $48.66, which the report describes as an all-time high. (A year ago it was $38.43.)
Internet-related companies, which did not exist a few years ago, were the largest leasers of new space in the first half of this year, accounting for 20 percent of the total, up from 3 percent a year earlier. The city's traditional mainstay, the financial industry, was nudged out of first place, accounting for 19.8 percent of space leased.
The growth of this new industry and the consequent diversification of the city's economy have some people suggesting that the rules have changed and that the old boom-and-bust real estate economy has been permanently changed. "New York's real estate industry has had its share of busts and booms over the past few decades, but the current real estate cycle is unlike any other seen since the dawn of the industrial age," said a report prepared by Colliers ABR, a real estate services company. "The abundance of current economic and real estate data suggests that not only does this recovery still have room to grow, but that the real estate cycles as most people remember them may be a thing of the past."
But many seasoned executives said they were not ready to accept a relentlessly rosy future. "Something is going to happen -- it always does," said Steven Swerdlow, executive managing director for the eastern division of CB Richard Ellis, the brokerage and services company. He said if the national economy were mismanaged, interest rates could soar and the value of stocks decline.
"We could have a hard landing rather than a soft one and a plunge in the stock market," he said. "New York is much more sensitive to the stock market than other cities."
Barry Gosin, chief executive of Newmark & Company Real Estate, a brokerage and management company, said New York is much more sensitive to faraway events then it once was because of the links among financial markets.
"It will probably be something that nobody predicted," he said. "Some event somewhere in the world will have an impact here." He recalled that problems with foreign currencies and the near-collapse of a large investment fund roiled capital markets in the fall of 1998, including the one for commercial mortgage-backed securities. This dried up financing for sales transactions and put a temporary cap on the prices offered for properties.
Indeed, some real estate executives argue that the stumble in 1998 helped to prolong the good times by squelching any possibility of a new wave of speculative building. Such a wave of building in the mid- and late 1980's prolonged the downturn of the early 1990's by bringing large blocks of new office space to a market where demand was dropping.
"We might have had lending for speculative building but for the crunch of the fall of 1998 and early 1999," said Robert Billingsley, an executive vice president of Colliers. "That gave pause to potentially irrational behavior and in hindsight was a good thing."
Other executives added other notes of wariness. Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W&M Properties, an investor and development company, said: "Whatever happens to change the market will be unexpected. You have a situation where the average apartment in Manhattan costs over $700,000. How is that sustainable? There is inevitably going to be a shakeout."
Bruce E. Mosler, the president for United States operations for Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company, said he expected the real estate cycle to endure, but with the peaks not as high and the valleys not as low as before.
"We are still adding jobs in the city, which means growth, even if we will slow to about 75,000 new jobs this year from 89,000 in 1999," he said. He predicted the remaining industrial property on the far west side of Manhattan would be redeveloped and the exodus to New Jersey would continue.
Because developers still cannot get financing for speculative building, he said, any such projects will be of modest size. "You have to tie up too much equity to do a one million square foot building, so if there is any speculative building, it will be in the 150,000 to 300,000 square foot range," he said.
Although space will remain scarce, the recent run-up in rents may not be sustainable, some executives say. "The rise in rents will have to level off because they are beginning to run into people's ability to pay," said Mr. Swerdlow. He said small and medium-size service organizations, like law firms, would be forced to leave the city or to enter into unwanted mergers.
Mr. Gosin agrees. "We are getting to a point where some tenants cannot afford the rent," he said. "There are high-margin businesses and low-margin business, and it is the low-margin service companies that are being affected."
Some corporate executives, political officials and urban planners fear that allowing economics to force certain types of business out of the city could unbalance the economic mix and make it difficult to attract new businesses. Some are trying to devise incentive programs that would keep the companies pushed out of Manhattan in the city by encouraging development in the boroughs outside of Manhattan.
Some real estate executives say that rents will continue to increase in locations that are considered desirable and that the tenants who are unable to pay will consider moving across the Hudson or to other areas of the city.
Ms. Tighe pointed to the recent decision by a publishing house, John Wiley & Sons, to leave its longtime location on Third Avenue at 39th Street for a new building to be developed in Hoboken by SJP Properties. Wiley will move 800 people into 400,000 square feet of the building, which is expected to be completed in early 2002.
"That company was in Manhattan for 94 years, but Hoboken is only one stop away on the PATH train," Ms. Tighe said. "What is happening is that the boundaries of the city are being redefined. There was a time when downtown was dead; now downtown is wonderful. There were other areas that were considered unacceptable; now the island is seamless from 60th street south."
This process of adding outlying areas to what tenants perceive as the central business district continues with each up cycle, she continued. "It took several cycles," she said, "to establish Metrotech in Brooklyn and the Jersey coast," referring to the west bank of the Hudson River. "Maybe this is the cycle that makes Long Island City acceptable."
Although Long Island City in Queens is closer to the east side of Manhattan than the New Jersey riverfront is and has good transportation links, its buildings are mostly former factories or distribution centers and not as attractive as the new buildings going up in Jersey City and Hoboken.
Nevertheless, the area has been designated by planners for decades as the site of the fourth concentration of office space, after midtown and downtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn.
"Queens is probably next," said Ross Moskowitz, a partner in the law firm of Stroock, Stroock & Lavan and a former official of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "Queens West is ready for bid, with two million square feet of commercial space with retail and entertainment components," he said, referring to the waterfront development jointly controlled by the city, state and Port Authority. "The project is ready to go, and I expect that we will see active bidding."
The strong rental market is being reflected in the price of buildings being sold, said James D. Kuhn, the president of Newmark. He said that Class A buildings -- the newest, most modern buildings -- were selling at more than $400 a square feet in Manhattan, compared with $300 a square foot just a few years ago. He noted that Equity Office Properties, whose chairman is Sam Zell, the Chicago-based real estate investor, paid more than $400 a square foot for the building at 1301 Avenue of the Americas at 52nd Street.
"Sam Zell was a bottom fisher in the early 90's," buying distressed properties at low prices, Mr. Kuhn said. "Now he has sent a signal to the marketplace that rent levels in New York are sustainable."
Some blockbuster deals are likely in the coming year, he said, with Rockefeller Center, the World Trade Center, the Seagram Building and other trophies on the block in one fashion or another. He predicted that a New York area real estate investment trust would eventually win the bidding for Rockefeller Center. "That is the best real estate in the world," he said.
Following are descriptions of the state of the market in other sectors:
 
The Suburbs
A Riverfront Boom In New Jersey
The western shore of the Hudson River facing Manhattan is in the throes of development as Wall Street companies are building space for their back office operations that support the money-making front office activities that are still in Manhattan. And the buildings are filling up as fast as they can be built or renovated.
"We have no space," said Seena Stein, president of Newmark's New Jersey operations. "The vacancy rate in Class A on the waterfront is 0.2 percent, and rents are at a record high of $36.25 a square foot."
Ms. Stein said anyone wanting space on the waterfront would have to wait at least a year until a construction project is finished. She said this delay has pushed some deals west to Newark, the next stop on the PATH line.
One big New York financial house that is changing the skyline in Jersey City is the Goldman Sachs Group, which purchased land in Colgate Center near the southern end of the city's waterfront across the water from the World Trade Center.
The group plans to build three structures totaling about three million square feet of space. Work is already under way on the first building, which will have about 1.3 million square feet of space.
Merrill Lynch and Chase Bank are also expanding their support operations in Jersey City, and each could eventually have thousands of employees working across the Hudson from Manhattan.
Development spread north to Hoboken this year, when the Wiley deal was signed in August. The publisher will occupy one of two SJP Properties in what is being called the Waterfront Corporate Center. The development is to include offices, retail space, a hotel and housing.
Elsewhere in New Jersey the office market is strong, but the obstacles to development are preventing any hint of overbuilding, said Donald Eisen, the director of the suburban operations of Cushman & Wakefield. In New Jersey, "you have a market of about 150 million square feet of space and maybe one to two million square feet going up," he said. "That's minuscule."
He said he hoped efforts to develop established cities like Jersey City, Hoboken and Newark represented a trend that might halt or slow the endless sprawl of development across the state. "New Jersey needs to push development where the infrastructure is -- and that is in urban areas," he said. "You just have to be creative."
He said one good example of creative redevelopment was the conversion of an old IT&T industrial site along Route 3 in Essex County to a new shopping mall called Clifton Commons.
Westchester County, which had appeared to be lagging behind the rest of the metropolitan area in leasing activity, is experiencing an upsurge as locally based companies began to expand. Some real estate executives said the vacancy statistics in the county had been distorted by the presence of former corporate headquarters buildings that have been difficult to divide for new tenants.
"There are buildings like the former Kraft headquarters that add 500,000 square feet to the vacancy numbers, but don't reflect what is actually happening in the market," said Kenneth M. Krasnow, a regional managing director at Cushman & Wakefield. "Westchester suffered a lot from corporate downsizing, but now homegrown companies are beginning to take space. The company that had 5,000 or 10,000 square feet of space three or four years ago now needs 25,000 to 30,000 square feet."
Jeffrey H. Newman, an executive vice president of W&M Properties, which owns 1.5 million square feet of property in Westchester County and Fairfield County in Connecticut, said, "Companies like Sara Lee and Chock Full o' Nuts have been leaving Manhattan and moving to Westchester." .
He said his company had concentrated in buying existing buildings and then renovating them to bring them up to Class A standards. In White Plains, "at 500 Mamaroneck we had to pull shag carpeting off the walls," Mr. Malkin, the president of W&M Properties, said.
As vacancies have diminished, rental rates have risen, although they are still low compared with Manhattan. "Space that was renting for $17 a square foot a year or so ago is now $26 to $30 a square foot," Mr. Newman said.
Long Island, Mr. Krasnow said, is in the midst of a transition from defense companies to a new high-tech economy. The buildings that once housed companies making airplanes and other military goods are being transformed into locations for software and telecommunications organizations.
 
Retail
Retailers Try Areas Previously Shunned
Retailers are balking at paying higher rents in fashionable areas of Manhattan and instead are looking for stores in areas once considered less desirable, brokers specializing in store leasing said. According to a survey conducted by Garrick-Aug Associates, the average asking rent at midyear was $77.50 a square foot, up just 0.6 percent from $77 a square foot in the first six months of 1999.
"Rents are at all-time highs, and people don't want to look stupid, especially the national chains," said Faith H. Consolo, vice chairman of Garrick-Aug. "So they are looking at new areas, such as Madison Avenue north of Madison Square Park."
Ms. Consolo said this area was bolstered by the decision by Credit Suisse First Boston to move into the building at 11 Madison Avenue at 25th Street, the influx of new restaurants and the renovation of hotels. "What happened to the Flatiron district is moving north," she said, referring to the area near the famous triangular building at 23rd Street and Broadway.
"I have had retailers asking me to look at locations on 14th Street," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a retail broker. "They want to be there because they think it is new and fresh and young."
He said retailers are looking at places like 14th Street, which was known in the past for its downscale stores, because the rents in preferred locations have become prohibitive. "You are talking $600 a square foot on Madison Avenue and $500 to $600 a square foot on Fifth Avenue, if you can find it," he said.
He said retailers often had a difficult time negotiating with landlords because there were multiple bidders for space.
 
Hotels
Occupancy Jumps, Along With Prices
Even though the millennium was a bit of a bust for hotel owners and operators, with demand well below what some had hoped for, occupancy rates in the city's hotels remained near historic highs and revenues grew quickly as room rates rose.
"We have seen revenue growth of an average of 13 percent in the first half of this year and 20 percent in some segments of the market," said Sean Hennessey, director of the New York hospitality and leisure practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm.
The occupancy rate at midyear was 89.2 percent, up from 82.9 percent a year earlier. And analysts say the strong statistics do not fully reflect the intensity of demand, because many hotels are so full on some nights they have to turn away prospective guests. "I had some clients come into town, and they had to stay in Stamford because there was nothing available for them in the city," Mr. Hennessey said.
Although some 1,400 hotel rooms have recently been added to the city's supply of approximately 70,000, the unceasing demand has pushed up daily rates. The average daily rate at midyear was $215.55, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers, up from $200.23 a year earlier.
As an indication of how far New York is ahead of the rest of the country, the firm reported that the average daily rate nationally is $84.51.

HEADLINE: What's Entertainment? That Depends...

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA KUEHL

 BODY:
REMEMBER what fun it was rushing Snowball to the vet after he gulped down a badminton birdie? Hey, you protest, that was not fun. Nevertheless, that's entertainment, according to the United States government.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which annually surveys Americans about their spending habits, includes veterinary expenses in its "entertainment" category. Not classified as entertainment: reading, dining out and using a home computer, omissions that might give the bibliophile, the gourmand and the chat-room addict pause. The bureau also leaves out gambling, which some experts say is the most popular form of outside-the-home recreation in America. 
 The bureau's sometimes curious choices prompt the question: What is entertainment, anyway? And what factors -- genetic, geographic, chronologic, socioeconomic -- determine that some people, like Beth Henderson of Ashford, Conn., meet their entertainment needs through contemplative pursuits like reading and gardening, while others, like Rina Isaac of White Plains, embrace pulse-pounding activities like mountain biking and archery? What impels Dr. Alfred Scherzer of Hampton Bays, N.Y., to travel to Somalia to gaze at maribou storks, or Donald Wayne of Piscataway, N.J., to amass 100,000 postcards, including one made out of kangaroo skin?
Social scientists say the human hunger for entertainment may be as old as society itself. "I don't know that we have any sort of archaeological evidence of entertainment, per se," said Daniel Fessler, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of California at Los Angeles, whose research fields include evolutionary psychology and psychological anthropology. "But what we do have is the observation that all known human societies have entertainment of some fashion, and that suggests that it's very old indeed."
A society without entertainment "would be a pretty frightening thing," said Frank A. Salamone, a professor of sociology at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., and the author of "Society, Culture, Leisure and Play: An Anthropological Reference" (University Press of America, 2000).
Entertainment "lets us dream," he said.
"It's imagination," he added. "Play at its best gives us a million options."
As a noun, "play" commonly refers to the games of children. Adults, too old to zip into playsuits, instead put on "leisure wear" to "recreate." But whether it's called leisure, recreation or entertainment, when an activity is "nonproductive, in other words, the aim is not a product, the aim is the experience," that's play, and adults need to do it, said John R. Kelly, a sociologist and the author of 11 books about leisure.
"We are working creatures, we are bonding creatures," he said, "and we are playing creatures."
In the New York metropolitan statistical area -- which includes New York City, Westchester, Long Island, most of northern and central New Jersey, and southwestern Connecticut -- households spent an average of $1,835 annually on entertainment in 1997-98, according to the Consumer Expenditure Survey conducted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
That number, though, is misleadingly low. Besides pet care, the bureau's list of entertainments includes movies and sporting events; hobbies, toys and games; television sets, videos and stereos; and sporting and exercise equipment. But add items like dining out, alcoholic beverages and reading, and the amount jumps to almost $5,200 a year, or more than 10 percent of the average household's pretax income. Add still more -- lottery tickets, Internet access, the incalculable costs of recreational shopping, and major investments, like the room Mr. Wayne added onto his New Jersey home to accommodate his collections -- and entertainment costs can soar.
In some years, Dr. Scherzer, 71, spends more than $5,000 to watch birds in exotic locales. A practicing pediatrician and emeritus professor of pediatrics at Cornell Medical College, he is a co-president of the Moriches Bay Audubon Society, which has more than 750 members and covers a territory extending from Patchogue to the tip of the South Fork.
In 35 years as a birder, Dr. Scherzer said, he has logged 1,500 to 2,000 species, many in his backyard, figuratively speaking. "Eastern Long Island is very unusual, because the land mass involves the Atlantic Ocean on the east and the bays on the west, and it's right on the flyway of the eastern migration of birds that come down virtually from the North Pole on their way to South America," he said.
According to Dr. Kelly, who is a co-author with Rodney B. Warnick of "Recreation Trends and Markets: The 21st Century" (Sagamore, 1999), bird-watching is increasingly popular, especially among older adults, a population that grows with each aging baby boomer. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, membership in National Audubon Society chapters has climbed almost 17 percent in the last decade, to nearly 72,000, an Audubon Society spokesman said.
At the Morton National Wildlife Refuge, a slender peninsula west of Sag Harbor, N.Y., that includes both upland and shore habitats, naturalists have documented roughly 280 species, and last year people flocked to see them. Attendance for 1998-99 reached almost 82,000, more than double the number of a decade ago, said Bob Parris, the deputy project leader for the Long Island National Wildlife Refuge Complex, which includes Morton and eight other sites.
Dr. Scherzer said he liked to visit Morton in the off-season, when the crowds are sparser. There, he holds out his hand to the black-capped chickadees, which, secure in their protected area, boldly peck sunflower seeds from a human palm. "It's just a nice experience," Dr. Scherzer said, "that little furry thing on your finger."
 
Variety of Influences
Economics, education, sex, religion, family background and age all influence entertainment choices. Up to 20 percent of Americans have no discretionary income for entertainment, while 10 percent can afford to spend "significant amounts" on fun, according to "Recreation Trends and Markets." Further, some Americans have little discretionary time, Dr. Kelly said, citing people who hold two jobs to support a family, mothers who shoulder a full-time job and take care of their families, too, and workers who may lose hours of recreation time to commuting.
Choices also spring from living in a particular time and place. "What was incredibly amusing in 1890 is now seen to be no longer funny, for the most part," said Dr. Salamone, the Iona professor. "See two minutes of a German film, and you know it's German. Broadly speaking, English jokes aren't funny in the United States, no matter what background people have. Why do the French like Jerry Lewis? I never understood that."
People also choose activities that balance their lives. "If you work in a steel mill all day, you don't rush out to play tennis when you leave the job," Dr. Kelly said. And for reasons that are still little understood, he said, some people are risk takers who like to play on the edge, others are intensely self-protective and need a comfort zone, and the majority fall between the two extremes.
Ms. Isaac, 38, who teaches first graders in Manhattan, said that skiing, hiking, biking and archery help keep her balanced. "When I leave the city, I need to revive my soul," she said. "I make sure I am with nature."
The bow and arrow, which she took up three years ago, require a concentration and focus that send her deep into herself. "You only hear your pulse, your heartbeat -- you can feel your sweat," she said. "It's a competition between my physical self and my mind."
Games generally fall into one of two categories: those that combine physical skill and strategy, and those that combine strategy and chance, said Garry Chick, an associate professor of leisure studies at Pennsylvania State University. Players who excel in the first category reap more prestige, he said.
Ms. Isaac said one benefit from her archery is a new identity. "People call me Rina the Archer, Pocahontas," she said. "They say, 'The wild woman is here.' People see you on another level: 'Hey, that person shoots, and that's awesome.' "
 
The Couch Potato
If archers inspire awe, couch potatoes draw sneers. But watching television remains Americans' prime pastime at night, a Gallup Poll reported in March 1999. Results of another Gallup Poll in January show that 57 percent of Americans watch three or more hours of television a day.
Television delivers story after story, feeding the human need for narrative, which, along with dance, is a universal form of entertainment, said Dr. Fessler of U.C.L.A. Some theorists say that entertainment, like cooking, may be a tradition passed down from ancestral societies. But Dr. Fessler said it may instead be an evolved psychology, a desire that became embedded in the human mind through evolution.
Unfortunately, Dr. Fessler said, evolved psychologies can become insatiable. "If you could afford it, and I guess some people can," he said, "you can just plug yourself into entertainment all of your waking hours and never leave the house."
Meanwhile, more narratives await at the local multiplex. Between 1989 and 1999, the number of movie screens in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rose 60 percent, to 3,470, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. Box offices nationwide took in $7.49 billion in 1999, and Americans spent an additional $17.36 billion renting and buying movies, according to the Video Software Dealers Association.
Luckily for literacy, the stories on library shelves still beckon. According to "Recreation Trends and Markets," more than 90 million adult Americans read books, and the number is rising. In early September, Ms. Henderson, 57, said she was reading six: a memoir, a biography, a travelogue, two local histories and a Harry Potter. A former teacher and school administrator who is now a sculptor, Ms. Henderson said that she spent $75 to $100 a month on newspapers, magazines and books, and combed the library stacks in Ashford and Mansfield, Conn., for free riches. "One of the things I like about reading is that it really promotes the use of your imagination, a lot more than watching a movie, for example," she said.
In contrast, gambling, which Professors Kelly and Warnick describe as "the largest single 'recreation' activity outside the home," doesn't so much promote imagination as feed off it, as gamblers imagine themselves rich.
Their imaginations were working overtime in 1999 as Americans wagered more than $742 billion, according to an industry analyst, Christiansen Capital Advisors. That's 99 times last year's national movie box-office receipts, and almost triple the amount people wagered in 1989.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, dreamers spent $6.2 billion on lottery tickets in 1998-99, 73 percent more than a decade ago, according to figures provided by state lottery officials. And gamblers wagered $43.5 billion in Atlantic City casinos in 1999, about twice what they spent in 1989, according to New Jersey Casino Control Commission figures.
Gambling, which falls into the strategy-and-chance category of games, creates "a kind of an artificial excitement," Dr. Kelly said.
"You don't have to gain any skill to pull levers and push buttons," he said, "but something is happening and you're involved in it and you have a certain stake in it." Gambling choices and styles vary. Some play bingo for fun, others buy lottery tickets out of financial desperation. "That isn't play," he said. "That's waiting to be struck by lightning."
 
Hooked On Collecting
Gamblers and collectors are both treasure seekers, but collectors rarely go home empty-handed.
There are four clubs in New Jersey for postcard collectors, known as deltiologists, and Mr. Wayne belongs to three of them, including the Central Jersey Deltiological Society, of which he is president. A serious collector since the mid-1960's, Mr. Wayne, 65, said he went "a little berserk" over novelty cards. Besides the kangaroo-skin oddity, he owns cards made of Irish peat, celluloid, aluminum, leather, macerated money and woven silk.
But his acquisitive days are winding down, Mr. Wayne said, because even with the extra room, "the house is full." Still, a collector can dream. At a recent postcard show in Clark, N.J., Mr. Wayne pointed out a man who claimed to own a million cards. "People revere him as one of the icons of the postcard world," Mr. Wayne said. "At least, I do."
Somewhere in the United States is someone who collects just about every kind of object, Dr. Kelly said. Add up all the collections -- stamps, coins, rocks, bones, thimbles, Hummel figurines, comic books, ice cream scoops, barbed wire and everything else -- and "you probably have a fairly significant part of the adult population," he said.
Collectors form groups, attend meetings and publish journals. "The social aspects become very important," Dr. Kelly said.
Mr. Wayne, a retired math teacher who also collects slide rules and books about space, said he couldn't expect people to appreciate the thrill of postcards unless they saw his treasures. Even then they might not understand. Such passions develop over time, and the impulses behind them are often complex.
Although it is easy simply to mock somebody else's idea of fun, the Bureau of Labor Statistics contends that it has valid reasons for each omission from the Consumer Expenditure Survey's entertainment category. For example, the bureau deems reading more informational than entertaining, said Bill Passero, a senior economist. Dining out is a subcategory under food, and gambling is a miscellaneous expenditure, Mr. Passero said, noting that many regard it not as entertainment but as an investment with a possible return.
As for pet care, it's been part of entertainment (formerly "recreation") since at least 1950, according to bureau records. Where else would you put it? Mr. Passero wondered.
Mr. Wayne, for one, said the notion of pets as entertainment made sense. He and his wife have two Shetland sheepdogs. "They're a riot," he said.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 26; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1400 words

HEADLINE: Candlebra and Crayons: Fine Dining With Children

BYLINE: By DAVID CORCORAN

 BODY:
FIRST, a confession. David C. (his real name) and his wife once took two young children to dine in a fancy restaurant.
It was a lovely place, on a seashore, with sweeping views and dramatic lighting and romantic silences and hand-printed menus and hand-painted place settings and . . . he remembers nothing about the meal except Daniel, 7, and Katie, 4, filling every one of those silences with giggles, shrieks, whimpers, howls, multiple restroom visits, wrestling holds and even more extreme behavior, involving croutons and water glasses, that cannot be described here until we are sure the statute of limitations has expired. 
 Mistakes were made, all right?
In the seven summers since that regrettable incident, David has become a restaurant critic, and Daniel and Katie, now 14 and 11, have matured into paragons of patience and decorum. Now he'll take them anywhere -- well, almost anywhere.
As it turns out, more has changed in those seven years than just that everyone is older.
The dining world is changing too, becoming far more hospitable to children, even the very young. And parents, learning from their peers or from their own instinct and experience, seem to be getting smarter about managing their meals out.
These changes are driven by a perceptible shift in the culture -- a gradual but welcome lightening of the solemn mood that used to cling to "fine dining" like an ermine cloak -- as well as by demographics and economic necessity.
"You have to realize what's going on and change with it," said Ken Gebhardt, who with his brother, Buddy, owns the highly regarded Park and Orchard restaurant in East Rutherford. "The couples who used to go out to eat four or five times a week 10 years ago are having kids. You have to welcome them, or they won't go out."
A few definitions are in order here. "Dining" is not the same as "eating." We are not talking about McDonald's or Chuck E. Cheese, indispensable as those places are, but about restaurants where adults might reasonably expect to spend an hour or more eating individually prepared dishes, perhaps with a glass of wine, having adult conversations about adult topics (like their daughter's latest soccer game) and gazing into each other's eyes.
"Children," for the purpose of this article, means preschool children. By the age of 6 or 7, most children can sit still for most of a meal without lapsing into aggressively annoying behavior, particularly if no younger brother or sister is around to egg them on.
Indeed, for a first or second grader, an evening at a fine restaurant can be an overwhelmingly positive experience for everyone involved.
"There's something wonderful about taking a 6- or 8-year-old out for dinner," said Dr. Joy Browne, the call-in psychologist on radio station WOR in New York, whom I interviewed because I'd once heard her taking a hard line against young children in restaurants. "Different food, different setting, fancy silverware, and someone who treats them very well and puts a napkin in their lap. It teaches patience, good manners, elegance -- all those grown-up things that are in short supply. The problem is people who take very young children, who can't sit still, make a lot of noise and run through the restaurant, ruining everyone else's romantic night out."
And of course, all children are different. Your 3-year-old, for example, is far better behaved than your best friend's twins, who regularly throw tantrums when they aren't removing articles of clothing.
Leslie Brenner, a novelist and food writer in Brooklyn who responded to a query for this article on the Web site Chowhound.com, says she has had reasonable success with her 3 1/2-year-old son, Wylie, but she marveled one night at a 3-year-old girl in the high-end Manhattan restaurant Daniel, "sitting there very primly between her parents, looking just like a doll."
Within those limits, here are some tips, gleaned from interviews with restaurant owners, veteran diners and others, for baby-sitter-challenged parents warily contemplating a night out with a small child or two.
CHOOSING A RESTAURANT These days, almost all restaurants but those at the highest end claim to be child-friendly; they can hardly afford not to be. Many offer children's menus; many have high chairs and booster seats. "A co-worker who used to wait tables says keeping the kids happy is one of the best ways to get a higher tip," noted John Piekarski of Denville, an online editor who with his wife often takes their 2-year-old out to eat.
Apart from any economic motivation, many restaurant owners, chefs, managers and servers genuinely like children and do their best to make them feel at home. Mr. Gebhardt, of Park and Orchard, says that when children finish eating before their parents do, waiters will happily taken them on a tour of the kitchen, which includes carnival attractions like giant mixers and a refrigerator big enough to stand up in.
(On the other hand, an e-mail correspondent told me of a headwaiter at a snooty restaurant in Greenwich Village who was overheard telling a customer: "Yes, madam, we do serve children here. On pita bread.")
But while most restaurants are at least tolerant of small diners, some kinds of places seem to have a higher batting average than others. "Ethnic" restaurants -- a term that encompasses African-American, Asian, Latino and Middle Eastern but not, for some reason, French or Italian -- are generally comfortable with young children, perhaps because they tend to be family-run. Such restaurants often incorporate their own amusements: fish tanks, tortilla makers, fortune cookies.
Some parents look for restaurants with banquettes, where a child can lie down without attracting other diners' attention. And high noise levels, so often an impediment to an enjoyable meal, can be great camouflage for the fussing of an impatient toddler. Jon Shure of Ewing, the president of a policy think tank in Trenton, remembers taking his son, then 1 year old, to Obrycki's, the famed crab house in Baltimore. "Everybody was talking loudly and pounding the tables with mallets," he said. "Joseph fit right in."
PLANNING AHEAD Most children eat early. So it pays to reserve early -- 5 p.m., if that's when the restaurant opens -- and to call ahead to warn the staff that children will be along. That way, you can be seated in a corner, out of harm's way, said Sam Nativo, chef and owner of Uptown in Long Branch, who added, "If a family comes in at 8 with three little kids, we seat them, but we try to calm the other customers."
Virtually every parent who responded to my Internet query suggested carrying along some tools of the trade: crayons, drawing paper, Magna Doodle, even a small reseaable bag of Legos. Others recommended a pre-emptive strike against the crankiness that comes with hunger pangs. "Go to the drive-through window at McDonald's, get her a Happy Meal and make sure she finishes it before we get to the restaurant," said Pete Feliz, a Bronx man who works as a doorman in Manhattan, about his daughter, Vicky, now 9. "She becomes more cooperative and adventurous if she's got a Happy Meal under her belt."
SETTING AN ATTITUDE Long before the evening out, it may be possible to find out whether the child and fine dining are ready for each other. "Set up a table in the kitchen," said Dr. Browne, the psychologist. "Put out candles, silver, china, water glasses, and bring in the neighborhood baby sitter to serve. If the kid behaves well, fine. If not, don't even think of taking her out for another year."
Attitude matters in the restaurant, too.
"Parental control is key," said Deborah Roark, the food and beverage director of the Birmingham Athletic Club in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., who has a 3-year-old daughter of her own. "If the parent is not willing to supervise the child, no one has a good experience."
Several parents echoed that thought, but Ms. Brenner, the writer in Brooklyn, offered a variation. When she and her husband take 3-year-old Wylie out, they try to get everyone on their side: staff, fellow diners and, of course, Wylie himself.
"Taking a hard edge is exactly the wrong approach," she said. "Kids are so willful, they're going to react against you. If you can generate some enthusiasm, make the child excited, he'll rise to the occasion. He'll see it as a special experience and want to do it another time."

HEADLINE: VENTURES;
They're on the Scene When Tires Go Pffft

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN

 BODY:
It's a tough job but somebody's got. . . .
Actually, nobody really has to do it. But in the service economy that thrives in New York, more flat tire repair shops are able to survive than one might guess. Several businesses that will fix a flat tire for $5 to $10 are situated along a strip of west Midtown occupied by gas stations, parking lots and turn-of-the-century tenements. 
 One of these businesses, Frank's Tires, occupies the ground floor of a three-story, red-brick apartment building at 449 10th Avenue. The shop is situated between 10th Avenue Taxi Parts and 35th Street. If no customers have pulled up, a passer-by might see Juan Flores, Mario Lael and other employees sitting in grease-stained office chairs, chatting and watching the traffic head uptown.
On a recent afternoon, Brian Ramos, a Flushing resident who works at Chelsea Piers, pulled up in his '91 Honda Accord with a flat right rear tire.
"I was going down 23rd Street," he said, "and some guy in a truck was like, 'Yo, you got a flat.' I knew there were a lot of these places on 10th Avenue."
Most of the cars that use the service -- about 85 percent according to the shop's owner, Frank Im -- are taxis, which he said take much more abuse and are much more likely to get a flat than private cars.
Mr. Im charges taxis $5 to fix a flat, which usually takes 5 to 10 minutes. Private cars, which return less often, are charged $10.
Mr. Im, 24, a recent graduate of the State University of New York at Albany, inherited the store from his father, George, who owned it for more than 25 years.
"I used to come here when I was 7 or 8 years old," the younger Mr. Im said. "Back then, we used to see crack heads, drug dealers, prostitutes, syringes on the floor. But ever since they built the Javits Center, everything has just gotten better."
On a Monday morning, a driver for the Concord Limousine Company of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, pulled up in a shiny black Lincoln Town Car.
"Slow leak," he said, as Mr. Lael, 20, who lives on Northern Boulevard in Queens, stepped out to see what needed to be done.
Just then, another driver with the same company pulled up behind him.
"What's up, 300," said the driver, who would identify himself only as Alex.
"The new car got a flat tire," said the driver of car No. 300, Hany Elshafei. "What's wrong with you?"
"A new car can't get a flat tire?" Alex asked.
Mr. Elshafei had been driving on his spare that morning, after discovering a flat at Newark Airport the night before.
"Last night I'm taking a customer to Metuchen, 1 o'clock in the morning," he said. "When I come back. . . ." his voice trailed off, no need to state the obvious. AARON DONOVAN

HEADLINE: Thriving Despite AIDS

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Judge's Ruling Puts City AIDS Agency Under U.S. Monitor" (front page, Sept. 20): 
 I commend Housing Works, the AIDS advocacy group that brought the suit resulting in the court's ruling, for its efforts in trying to improve access to services for people with H.I.V.-AIDS in New York City. But the comment by the group's staff lawyer, Armen Merjian, that most people living with AIDS "have no choice but to be on the dole" is a fallacy.
Thousands of people with AIDS are able to work and engage in the same daily activities as people who are free of H.I.V. To equate an AIDS diagnosis with an inability to provide for oneself feeds a dangerous misconception and does a disservice to the countless people with H.I.V.-AIDS who are living, working and thriving despite their diagnosis.
 
MARLA HASSNER
Brooklyn, Sept. 21, 2000

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
Preserving the Forest By Leasing the Trees

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
IT'S a hard sell.
In trying to persuade developing nations to protect their wilderness areas, environmentalists often meet strong resistance. Why would any country forgo badly needed revenue and the chance to foster economic activity by creating a national park rather than allowing the commercial development of its land? 
 One environmental group thinks it has come up with a way to spare governments from such a choice. The Conservation International Foundation, based in Washington, is in the final stages of buying the long-term logging rights to 200,000 acres of pristine South American rain forest. The group expects to spend several million dollars over the next 25 years to protect the land, in southern Guyana, with what it calls a "conservation concession."
And Guyana is just the start. Peru, Bolivia, Brazil and Cambodia may be next.
Concessions -- development rights to land -- are often sold by governments to timber or mining companies and are readily available for huge stretches of tropical rain forest. Desperate for development, many governments are willing to lease the logging rights to public lands at an extraordinarily cheap price -- often just a few dollars an acre.
"Too many of the great ecosystems of the world have a low price on their head," said Craig McCaw, the telecommunications entrepreneur and a member of the Conservation International board. He has given $5 million toward the creation of the group's new fund to help conserve wilderness areas.
Conservation International has always favored using business strategies to protect the environment and has been aggressive in promoting economic alternatives, like ecotourism, to traditional development. In the late 1980's, the group pioneered the concept of swapping debt owed by a government for commitments to conserve land. Its board also includes business luminaries like Gordon E. Moore, a co-founder of Intel; Michael Eisner, the Disney chairman; and Barry Diller, the chairman of USA Networks.
"If you don't do the economics, you don't win, you don't succeed in the long term," said Peter Seligmann, the chairman and chief executive of Conservation International.
The group worked with Hardner & Gullison Associates, a consulting firm in Palo Alto, Calif., to come up with the idea of competing directly with private businesses to win long-term concessions for public lands. By paying an amount that compensates the government for any lost jobs or economic activity, Conservation International hopes to ensure that local people still benefit -- usually through job-creation or education programs. "Unless the local people are committed to it, it just isn't going to work," Mr. Seligmann said.
ENVIRONMENTAL groups have had limited success with other approaches to protecting wilderness areas. While countries have created some national parks, the process of convincing governments to set aside the land -- and to ensure that it remains undisturbed -- can be slow. The World Bank has spent years trying to help Guyana create a system of national parks, but has only started making some progress.
Groups like the Nature Conservancy have had success buying land in the United States but have had difficulty acquiring large wilderness areas elsewhere. In some countries, large sales to outsiders are viewed as threats to sovereignty, although the Nature Conservancy says it tries to prevent such problems by working with local environmental groups on purchases.
 Conservation International and the Nature Conservancy have also bought out private owners of timber rights in Bolivia, where they were able to add the land to the national park system.
The idea of buying concessions directly from governments has "great potential," said Elizabeth Losos, the director for the Center for Tropical Forest Science at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. "There are far more lands slated for timber than for protected areas," she said.
She cautioned, however, that no single approach was the answer to saving rain forests. "Everyone is looking for the silver bullet," she said, adding that environmentalists were often quick to back away from ideas if they did not prove to be clear successes.
In Guyana, which has encouraged timber cutting as a way to stimulate its struggling economy, the idea of encouraging conservation without sacrificing badly needed cash and jobs is appealing.
"If there is no economic benefit, there may be a populist sentiment that we should use it for other purposes," said Bharrat Jagdeo, the president of Guyana, the only English-speaking country in South America.
He said that his country is committed to conservation and has established an environmental protection agency. But, he added, it needs the support and advice of international conservation groups. Guyana is also working with the Carter Center, created by former President Jimmy Carter, to create a foundation to explore alternatives to resource exploitation.
Guyana recently approved a three-year exploratory lease for Conservation International; the term could be extended to 25 years once the parties have agreed to various terms, including price. The group had already identified an additional 800,000 acres that it would be interested in protecting if the government views the first concession as a success.
Conservation International is pursuing similar arrangements in countries like Peru, where the government will auction concessions for some of its land in the Biabo forest.
Conservation concessions, unlike national parks, might also allow the limited use of public lands for activities like hunting or fishing, by local people who might depend on the area for their livelihood. "With a simple concept, this is very accommodating to those uses and users and dodges some of the debilitating conflicts that have stymied a lot of traditional conservation efforts," said Dan Martin, the director of ecosystems conservation and policy for the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, which has helped to finance the group.
The calculus also has wide appeal to potential donors, many of whom are increasingly interested in seeing tangible results of their gifts, according to Lewis Coleman, the chairman of Banc of America Securities and a board member of Conservation International.
As promising as the concept may be, it is clearly untested. Shifting political winds in a developing country could undo any long-term agreement that Conservation International managed to reach. And any preserved land must be monitored to prevent unauthorized use.
Conservation International is quick to acknowledge that these concessions are only a part of the effort to save the world's wilderness areas, but it says they are important. "One of the biggest problems with parks," said Richard Rice, an economist for the group who helped to develop the concept, "is that governments don't want to make more of them."
By trying a market-based idea, the group hopes to compete more effectively with commercial interests vying for the same land.
Conservation International is "wonderfully entrepreneurial," said Thomas E. Lovejoy, the chief biodiversity adviser for the World Bank.
"There is no reason," he added, "that the conservation business can't be as creative with financing mechanisms as the normal business world."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The New Entrepreneurs of Silicon Heights

BYLINE: By SETH KUGEL

 BODY:
APROSYS COMPUTER, a tiny business above the Amir Barber Shop on West 181st Street in Washington Heights, is easy to miss in this neighborhood where beauty salons and discount stores with bins of $10 jeans are more common than computer shops.
That is changing. 
 In the last two years, five computer-related businesses have appeared in the area bordered by Broadway, Amsterdam Avenue and 179th and 186th Streets, providing tangible proof of how technology is weaving itself into the local fabric.
"The computer is becoming just another household utensil, like a television or a blender," said Alex Rodriguez, a technician at another new computer business, Compus Electronics Center, a repair shop on West 179th Street wedged between a bodega and an auto parts shop.
A year ago, Compus mostly repaired two-way radios for livery-cab drivers. Noting how many local residents were buying computers, the owner, Justo Peguero, decided to offer computer repairs.
"When I saw his store, I just went in," said Jose Reynoso, a recent customer. "I liked being able to get repairs done in the neighborhood."
The growing local demand in part reflects a wider trend. Despite worries that minorities are on the wrong side of the digital divide, Forrester Research, which reports on technology issues, says low-income Hispanics of any race or ethnicity are more likely to be online than low-income whites nationwide.
Local computer businesses still have a long way to go before they take over the market from downtown or suburban superstores. At Mr. Peguero's store, computer repairs rank a distant second to the two-way radio business.
Even the oldest store, six-year-old Castle Computer, on Broadway and 192nd Street, sells only about 10 computers a month and focuses on repairs, upgrades and training. There is also a Radio Shack, on 181st Street, between Broadway and Bennett Avenue, which sells some computers as part of its electronics business.
But the growing interest in computers has encouraged entrepreneurs with a distinct neighborhood flavor in this heavily Dominican area. Their businesses are often family owned and unmistakably Latino. Marketing is generally by word of mouth, fliers passed out in the street and advertising on local Spanish-language cable.
The hours can be unpredictable, although it is a pretty sure bet that the doors at Aprosys will close by noon on Sundays so Hector Marmolejos, the owner, can get to his weekly softball game.
At Aprosys, which moved from the Bronx 20 months ago, Mr. Marmolejos specializes in systems design, mostly for local Hispanic-owned businesses, while his son handles hardware sales and repairs.
A few blocks away, on St. Nicholas Avenue, a white sign with red block letters hangs from the awning of Taveras Beauty Supply with a simple message: "Computer." Down a narrow stairway is the 18-month-old Computer Multi-Service Center, a bare-bones operation whose main attraction is a narrow laboratory with a dozen PC's where classes are held in the evenings.
The business is run by Genis Guzman and his wife, Maribel, who lived in Washington Heights for 11 years before recently moving to New Jersey. Manuel Feliz, was sent by his employer, a local money-wiring service, to take two introductory lessons. He ended up paying for three more months of Word and Excel lessons and also bought a printer.
"Everything is computers," he said. "If you're not trained in Excel, Powerpoint, you're not prepared. Everything I do here I apply at work."
Raul Aquino leads the classes in an animated Spanglish.
"Tenemos aqui el menu bar, y aqui el standard tool bar," he explained to an introductory class as a merengue by the Latin Grammy winner Juan Luis Guerra played in the background.
On a recent evening, Alfonso Guerrero, 41, a security guard, was leaving the center after an Excel class when Ms. Guzman yelled out to him, "When are you buying the computer?"
"Not yet," Mr. Guerrero replied sheepishly. "I don't have the money."
When he does, he said, he will probably buy the machine there.
"They have a good payment plan," he said. "They give you up to a year to pay."
Edward Atristain owns Channel PC, which has a full storefront on Broadway. Mr. Atristain has been selling and servicing computers in Jackson Heights, Queens, since 1993. He opened the Washington Heights branch of his store seven months ago. His customers include two community groups, the Dominican Women's Caucus and the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans.
"I would prefer to do business with someone who is local and small," said David Sang, the association's fiscal officer, explaining why he used Channel PC.
Mr. Atristain has stocked his shelves with educational software and set up online terminals for customers to rent in 20-minute blocks. He hopes to attract people like Rene Marte, a 27-year-old music promoter who recently waited for hours at the local public library to check his e-mail after his father took the family laptop with him on a trip to the Dominican Republic.
The fifth new business was started eight months ago, by Hector Anderson, a Pentecostal minister. When his Spanish-language Christian bookstore, Fuente de Vida, was going through tough times, he began selling used PC's from a back room, calling the secondary business Antel Computer.
But Mr. Anderson's lease had a clause restricting sales to religious items. The solution: install a free CD-ROM bible in each computer. But that is one service no longer available in Washington Heights. A property tax dispute forced him to move both businesses to the Bronx in August.
The remaining stores are counting on drawing local residents with convenient and familiar settings. The prices won't hurt, either. Luis Madrigal is commissioning a computerized management system for Madrigal Executive Transportation, a new car service, from Aprosys.
"If I went downtown, it would cost me 50 times more than it's costing me here," Mr. Madrigal said.
"Seriously," he said, only half-seriously. "I'm not exaggerating."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Alfred Harrison;
Alliance Premier Growth Fund

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
THESE days, Alfred Harrison lives in Minneapolis and presides over about $80 billion of investments for Alliance Capital Management. But he developed a horse sense for arbitrage during his youth, when his father took him on trips from their home in Nottingham, England, to the Newmarket racetrack.
Back then, Mr. Harrison could have used the help of the region's most famous legend, Robin Hood. His parents were classical pianists, and sometimes it was a struggle just to put food on the table. But life was not without its pleasures -- his father had a love of horse racing that he shared with his son. 
 The son proved to be a lucky bettor, and a good analyst of chance.
"In those days, each bookmaker offered different odds," Mr. Harrison explained. "The weight of money would bring down the price as you got closer to the race. I would bet on a horse at 5 to 1.
"But this horse might come down to 2 to 1 right before the race, and another horse that had been at 4 to 1 had moved to 7 to 1," he said. "So I'd have two bets. Both are done at the most propitious price."
He said he was "almost arbitraging between bookmakers, between the different odds."
Such calculations helped Mr. Harrison, now 62, pay his way through Cambridge University, where he studied economics. But they also "got me keenly aware of the importance of price," he said.
That is not to say that Mr. Harrison invests like a riverboat gambler. He has obtained solid returns in his Alliance Premier Growth fund, which has $21.4 billion in six share classes. For a manager of a growth fund, he is quite measured in his approach, and last year he cautiously loaded up on value stocks.
Of course, value investing -- the search for bargain stocks that have fallen out of favor, in hopes of riding a rebound -- was not the path to shoot-out-the-lights returns last year. The big winners were growth investors who piled into technology stocks, some of which had dubious earnings or revenue pictures.
But if Mr. Harrison did not jump wholeheartedly onto the technology bandwagon last year, he did not ignore it, either. At the end of November, 27.6 percent of his portfolio was in technology stocks, led by big positions in Dell Computer and Cisco Systems.
That percentage was far below that of some other growth funds, which kept more than half their assets in technology. But Mr. Harrison's fund still managed a gain of 29 percent in 1999, a bit behind the average large-company growth fund, though about eight percentage points ahead of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. He has beaten the S.& P. in four of the last five years.
"Last year, prices got silly, particularly in the fourth quarter," Mr. Harrison said. And when prices get silly, he gets more conservative, looking at companies for the right blend of fundamentals and price.
He also uses an approach Alliance calls the V-factor -- the "V" being a visual representation of the strategy. When the market heads south, Mr. Harrison becomes more aggressive. When the market goes up, he becomes more cautious.
Not surprisingly, during the technology sell-off in April, Mr. Harrison was a buyer, and by the end of June, the fund had a 39.9 percent weighting in technology. This year, the fund is up 3.3 percent, a couple of percentage points ahead of the S.& P.
Since its inception in 1992, Alliance Premier Growth has gained 24.5 percent, annualized, about 4.5 percentage points above the S.& P. 500 and in the top 15 percent of its peer group, according to Lipper Inc.
The ride has not always been smooth. In 1994, the fund lost nearly 6 percent and ranked in the bottom quarter of its peer group. It rebounded with a sterling performance over the next four years, however, ranking among the top 15 percent of its group each year.
Besides managing Alliance Premier Growth, Mr. Harrison is a vice chairman at Alliance, overseeing its large-company investment team. He leads a group of money managers and analysts who preside over institutional and private accounts and a $2 billion hedge fund.
"Growth to me is multifaceted," Mr. Harrison said. "It's basically companies you believe have a balance sheet, industry position and management to support a 20 percent or better growth rate over the next two to three years."
About two-thirds of the portfolio is invested in the management team's favorite 25 stocks, "the names most people recognize," he said. The top holdings include Intel, Pfizer and Cisco. He is also building a position in Viacom, the media conglomerate that owns CBS and MTV.
The other third of the portfolio is dedicated to "areas that aren't traditional growth stocks," he said. In that value vein, Mr. Harrison has been mining two beaten-down sectors this year: energy and airlines.
"The energy stocks are making an enormous amount of money given their prices," he said. "Airlines are doing well, earnings-wise, notwithstanding all of their problems."
A new holding is BP Amoco. "BP has the enormous strengths of the combination of BP, Amoco and Atlantic Richfield, superb management and has had a major cost cutting program," he said. "They are using earnings to step up their exploration and development."
Mr. Harrison bought Atlantic Richfield in the first quarter as a cheap way to get into BP Amoco, which completed its takeover of Atlantic Richfield in April. He bought into the combined company between $46 and $47 a share. It closed at $52.88 on Friday. He is bullish on its earnings projections over the next three years but would not hesitate to sell if market conditions shift.
As for his hobbies, Mr. Harrison now prefers art to horse racing. He and his wife, Ingrid Lenz Harrison, collect German Expressionist art. But when it comes to an appreciation of price, he prefers the hardscrabble lessons of the racetrack and, he said, "the value of a working-class upbringing in England."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
As Indexes Fall, Some Musings on the Downside

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
AS the last week of the third quarter begins, the three major stock indexes are down for the year. And if they finish the quarter this way, it will be the first time since 1990 that all three have been down at this time of the year. So let's think some bearish thoughts.
One of the threats to the stock market is the retirement of the baby boomers. As they leave the work force, will they also choose less risk, moving money from stocks into bonds? 
 Paddy Jilek, the director of United States economics at Credit Suisse First Boston, thinks so.
He acknowledges that the life-expectancy data shows that people who are retiring at 65 can now expect to live to 75 or 80. That makes it difficult to say when retirees' investment horizons will shorten enough to make them demand investments that are less risky than stocks. Still, he said, "eventually the baby boomers will become risk averse like every retiree, and that means, other things being equal, the stock market could struggle over a 10-year period."
For the first baby boomers, the age of 65 doesn't come for 10 years. So what's the worry? Mr. Jilek thinks that the previous generation, which is reaching 65 now, is ready to begin making the portfolio shift to less risky assets like bonds. And he argues that this group, which dates from 1935 -- 10 years before the beginning of the baby boom generation -- was the pace setter at two other crucial points for markets.
One was the surge in home buying that he believes reached its inflection point around 1965, while many baby boomers were still in grade school. Before then, housing prices had been falling, relative to the Consumer Price Index. Afterward, housing prices began to rise in real terms.
The second key point was at the beginning of the 1980's. That, Mr. Jilek argued, was when this older group began the accumulation of financial assets to help pay for college educations for their children and eventual retirement for themselves.
If this group is leading the way again, investors may have more to worry about now than they are aware of. "A sprinkle now, a drizzle soon, and a torrent in 15 year's time," Mr. Jilek wrote in a recent report on this issue. "It's the sprinkle that marks the inflection point relative to asset prices."
Mr. Jilek thinks that there is another threat to the stock market -- one that means it may not be able to match the wonderful returns of the last half of the 1990's. And if it coincides with the shift of risk preference by those born in 1935 who are now retiring, it could aggravate the portfolio shift away from equities, putting downward pressure on stocks.
That threat, he says, is from abroad.
In his report, Mr. Jilek argued that foreign demand for American stocks played a crucial role in the second half of the 1990's -- and that a switch in sentiment could hurt. In 1999, according to Federal Reserve data, foreign investment funds bought a net $98.1 billion of American stocks. And that number has taken off this year, despite the poor performance of the major stock indexes. Net purchases surged to $176.4 billion in the first half.
American stock has also been gobbled up in the form of foreign acquisitions of United States companies. There were about $153 billion in cross-border deals in 1999, almost double the $78 billion in 1998.
So with the stock market in a position it has not seen for a decade, think of influences that go beyond corporate earnings, whose growth appears to be slowing, and whether the Federal Reserve is finished raising interest rates for this cycle.
Even if it is not a factor tomorrow, Mr. Jilek said, it would be wise to be a little more cautious about the potential for stocks in the years ahead. "I think it is an issue you really need to keep in mind," he added. "It's there all the time and can be a pretty powerful force."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Style Desk

LENGTH: 1846 words

HEADLINE: Hot Wheels: Can They Light America's Fire?

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN

 BODY:
EDDIE IRVINE, winner of four Formula One Grand Prix races, left no doubt at Saks Fifth Avenue's breast cancer benefit on Tuesday night that he is one of the fastest men on earth. In less than 20 minutes, he hit on Christy Turlington and Miss Universe.
"Are you Miss World?" asked Mr. Irvine, who is Irish and not shy. 
 "No, I'm Miss Universe."
"Oh, I was a judge at the last Miss World," he said. "I'm Eddie."
Mr. Irvine, 34, was without a doubt the biggest celebrity at the Saks party whom nobody knew. The 17 Formula One Grand Prix races this year will be watched by a cumulative audience of five billion people. But here in this fishbowl of New York media and society he went virtually unrecognized. Ms. Turlington knew who he was: supermodels and Formula One drivers belong to the same global V.I.P. club. They had met once, in Dublin eight years ago. Eager to renew their acquaintance, Mr. Irvine elicited a promise from her to watch him race his Jaguar in the first Grand Prix in the United States since 1991.
The race is today. A sinuous Formula One track has been cut into the big oval of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, where a sold-out crowd of more than 200,000 will fill the stands. Cable's Speedvision and the Fox Sports Network will cover the event live at 2 p.m.
How many viewers will tune in is another question. And will a country that let Grand Prix racing fizzle out nine years ago and that has no American-born Formula One drivers care?
Mr. Irvine's appearance at Saks during Fashion Week and on "The Late Show With David Letterman" the previous week are part of a promotional push by Jaguar, Formula One and some of its major sponsors into the only market that has eluded them: the United States. Auto racing has never been bigger in the United States, but Nascar and Indy-style ovals have eclipsed road racing.
Strange. Formula One may be the most glamorous, extreme and richest sport around, and yet it is literally foreign to a nation that prizes all those things. These are the most technologically sophisticated race cars. Their screaming roar is the unforgettable sound of engines running at 19,000 revolutions per minute, that go from 0 to 125 miles an hour in less than seven seconds and decelerate so fast the carbon brakes glow red. In 200-mile-an-hour turns, drivers sustain a G-force almost as great as a fighter pilot's. A Village Voice article on the death of the great Brazilian driver Ayrton Senna in 1994 noted that Formula One cars generate enough downforce in theory to be driven upside-down across a ceiling.
The drivers' heart rates can pound at more than 200 beats a minute; a driver can lose 10 pounds in a 90-minute race. And like bullfighters, drivers chance death every time they step in front of a crowd. Michael Schumacher of the Ferrari team, considered by many the sport's best driver, was listed in March by Forbes magazine as the highest paid athlete in the world, at $49 million a year.
What more, a Formula One proselytizer might ask, do you want from a sport?
To distinguish itself from Nascar's good-old-boy following, the current Formula One campaign in the United States has been very high end. Luxury brands are pushing the Grand Prix as the LMVH of motor racing, polo on wheels.
Tag Heuer, the official timekeeper for Formula One, took out a six-page advertising spread in the September issue of Vanity Fair, juxtaposing images of its sports watches with the McLaren-Mercedes racing car. At this year's Oscars, Tag Heuer gave out 100 of its $1,700 Formula One 2000 Grand Prix Chronogaphs to performers and presenters. And this summer, Tag Heuer, Hugo Boss and Mercedes were the hosts of parties at the Guggenheim Museum and in Southhampton. The guest list aimed at the kind of young, rich, beautiful people who have always been moths to the Formula One flame in Europe. A McLaren show car was on display, so people could gawk and marvel at the surprising smallness and coolness of the fastest car on the circuit.
Before today's race, Ferrari, the only serious competitor for McLaren, will run its usual exhibition race with amateur drivers wealthy enough to own Ferrari sports cars.
By far the most aggressive campaign to raise Formula One awareness in this country has been Jaguar's, which is in its first year of competition. On the morning of the Saks party, Mr. Irvine drove a Formula One Jag down Broadway -- traffic had been cleared from 48th Street to 44th. A Formula One team can cost $200 million to $300 million a year to run. For Jaguar -- and its parent company, Ford -- the expense is part of a long-term plan to build a winning team. For the moment, it's a loss leader.
"We are moving Jaguar toward a performance-oriented brand, trying to appeal to a slightly younger customer," said Simon Sproule, vice president of public affairs for Jaguar North America. "There's no better platform than Formula One, with the caveat that the U.S. is the best market for our cars but the one that knows the least about Formula One."
The challenge for Jaguar, Mercedes and Honda, companies that use Formula One as a platform to promote their consumer lines, is to penetrate beyond "the guys who are watching Speedvision at 3 a.m.," said Mr. Sproule. "What we as a car manufacturer are concerned with is the nonpetrolheads."
Hence, Mr. Irvine's appearance on the Letterman show. David Letterman declined to be interviewed for this article, but he's the only late-night talk-show host who books Formula One drivers. David Cronenberg, the film director and a fellow racing fanatic, said Mr. Letterman once told him, "I only care about two things: broadcasting and Formula One."
Between Mr. Irvine's Irish accent and offhand jokes about a sport most viewers haven't a clue about, he and his host seemed almost to be speaking in code. Mr. Irvine said his father was such a racing nut that he had almost named his son "Moss Irvine." Mr. Letterman chuckled, getting a reference to the legendary British driver, Stirling Moss, that probably sailed clear over his millions of viewers.
Cocky, charming and stylish in his black suits and bleached hair, Mr. Irvine is an America-friendly celebrity. As a rookie he once provoked Senna, at the time the champion, to take a swing at him. At Ferrari, he publicly complained that being the No. 2 driver to the exacting, teutonic Mr. Schumacher was like being hit every day on the head with a cricket bat. He seems like the kind of bad-boy toy Madonna might seek out to father a love-child.
Sexy stars aside, there are still a few roadblocks to winning over the United States market. Aside from the Letterman show, mainstream media coverage has been minimal. And most fans of international sport are more likely to watch the Olympics right now, especially with a local hero to root for.
Mario Andretti, who raced Formula One from 1968 to 1982, was the last American champion, but he was born in Trieste and never fully lost his Italian accent. Michael Andretti, Mario's son, competed in 1993, unsuccessfully. The last United States Grand Prix was held in Phoenix in the dead of summer.
"Totally the wrong place," said Thomas L. Bryant, the editor in chief for Road & Track. The Indy speedway "is probably the best place to do it," he said. "It's the mecca of automobile racing in America."
Roger Werner, the president of Speedvision, said his channel usually gets 150,000 to 300,000 viewers for a live Grand Prix telecast. Today's race, he said, could attract 400,000 to a million. "It's never going to be as large an audience as Nascar," he said. But it is a desirable audience for advertisers because Formula One fans have higher income and education levels and "tend to be skewed toward the major metropolitan markets -- its more cosmopolitan."
To the uninitiated, Formula One is not the most accessible of sports. Two teams, Ferrari and McLaren, are laps ahead of the pack technologically, and their drivers almost always win. (After 14 races, Mika Hakkinen of Finland, who drives a McLaren, leads Mr. Schumacher by 2 points in the drivers' standings.) Passing is too difficult, and too dangerous, and so the car that starts out in front, in the pole position, which is determined by time trials, and wins the drag race into the first turn, frequently finishes in the same position.
Nascar drivers, like country music stars, spend hours signing autographs. Formula One drivers are hermetically sequestered from their fans. Entry to the Paddock Club, the equivalent of box seating, is restricted to corporate sponsors or the very rich. Admittance to the paddock itself, the sanctum sanctorum of the drivers and their teams, is akin to a papal audience.
Even media access can be difficult. This restrictiveness is a deliberate strategy of Bernie Ecclestone, the man who runs Formula One racing, to enhance its exclusive aura. Mr. Ecclestone controls Formula One Management, which in June was granted all commercial rights to Formula One by the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile (of which he is vice president) until the year 2110 for about $360 million. This is roughly his company's revenues in a single year. There were no other bidders, according a recent article in The Economist about Formula One's murky finances, which can make professional boxing, by comparison, look like a union shop. (The European Union is investigating whether racing concerns owned by Mr. Ecclestone broke competition laws.)
Mr. Ecclestone has a reputation as an obscure and eccentric figure. In a telephone interview from London, he started whistling when asked about The Economist story, calling journalists "fiction writers."
The assertion that he has monopolistic control over Formula One is "probably true," he said, adding, "What it amounts to in reality is that I've been able to do the things I want to do with the sport." But, he said, "I'm not a criminal, no."
Sylvester Stallone alluded to Mr. Ecclestone's controlling influence as the reason he changed the hero of his next movie, "Champs," from a Formula One driver to an Indy-style driver. "There is a certain person in charge of that series who has his own agenda," Mr. Stallone said in February. "Making an F1 movie has become impossible." Mr. Ecclestone offered no comment.
Mr. Cronenberg, the film director, has written a script called "Red Cars," about the American driver Phil Hill's championship season for Ferrari in 1961, but he can't find anyone to produce it. "People seem to love to read it," he said on the phone from his home in Toronto. "I've been asked to turn it into a novel." But not a movie.
Mr. Cronenberg, who raced cars as an amateur, named Jeff Goldblum's scientist in "The Fly" after the British driver Martin Brundle.
How does he rate the sport's chances of finding an audience in the United States? "America likes extremes and Formula One is the most extreme sport there is," he said. "The missing piece of the puzzle is a brilliant American driver."
Until then, Mr. Irvine offers another reason to watch today's race:
"It's the thrill, isn't it?"
