HEADLINE: U.S. and Others Press for Cuts In Price of Oil

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Sept. 23

 BODY:
The top financial officials of the United States, fresh from an unprecedented synchronized plunge into world oil and currency markets, joined other rich nations today in vowing to fight what they described as double jeopardy for the global economy.
In a communique issued after Group of 7 financial leaders met here, ministers said they would monitor currency markets to see whether they needed to follow Friday's coordinated central bank action to shore up the euro, Europe's battered common currency, with further interventions. But they used stronger language on oil prices, saying it was "crucial for the world economy" that oil-producing nations take steps to reduce prices, which have tripled since early 1999. 
 "Oil prices are the largest dark cloud in the blue sky of the global economy," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said after the Group of 7 meetings, speaking of a recent run-up in the price of crude oil to a 10-year high of more than $30 a barrel. "Prices need to return to a more historical range."
The Clinton administration's decision on Friday to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to help dampen oil prices won praise in the communique. Other Group of 7 nations are considering releasing oil from their reserves, and ministers discussed ways of breaking oil distribution bottlenecks and ways of putting diplomatic pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, officials said in describing the talks.
The attempts to correct currency and oil prices cast the United States, which often argues that such markets should take care of themselves, as an aggressive interventionist, evoking expressions of surprise from other Group of 7 ministers. Several said Friday's concerted buying of euros and selling of dollars, yen and other currencies had gone smoothly, though some traders expressed doubts that the American, British, European, Canadian and Japanese central banks would continue to do whatever it took to push the euro up against the dollar if sentiment turned negative again. "It was surprising how well the action went," said Germany's finance minister, Hans Eichel. "Especially before the U.S. election, it was surprising the U.S. even participated."
The high-level talks on how best to corral market prices underscored how officials had come to view the euro's weakness and oil's strength as major inflationary threats that pose an immediate and largely unanticipated danger to global growth, which according to recent forecasts was keeping the fastest annual pace in more than a decade.
Broad political considerations also played a role. The relentless decline of the euro challenged the concept of European integration generally, especially as Denmark prepares to vote on Thursday on whether to join the euro zone.
Longer term, Europe faces a paradox: Its drive to expand both the geographical and political reach of the European Union depends in good measure on the euro, the showpiece of the region's economic common interest. But currency traders increasingly lost faith in the euro, European Central Bank officials argued to their Group of 7 counterparts, because they saw insufficient political weight behind the currency, which was introduced 21 months ago.
American officials largely accepted those arguments when discussing whether to join the European Central Bank in defending the currency in the open market, a decision that Mr. Summers and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made in the middle of last week. It was the first such intervention the United States has undertaken since it helped Japan raise the value of the yen in 1998.
The United States has long lent its support to European integration because it is seen as a way of ensuring stability in a region where America has fought two world wars.
The attempt to rescue the euro was closely intertwined with the Clinton administration's decision to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Several European nations, including Britain and France, have had sustained protests by truck drivers and others hurt by oil prices.
Prices at the pump, already far higher in Europe than the United States because of heavy tax, have risen even more sharply here than across the Atlantic because oil is bought and sold in dollars, which have been rising in value against the euro almost in tandem with the oil price spike. American officials were counting on an uptick in European growth rates to extend the American-led economic expansion of recent years, something that seems less likely if Europe is hit by an inflationary shock.
There was also growing trans-Atlantic concern that the weakness of the European currency and the inflationary impact of high-priced oil gave Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, his best opportunity since the Persian Gulf war to wreak havoc on his Western adversaries. With oil supplies already short, the Western world depends on Iraq continuing crude production, something he could cut off at any time.
Group of 7 ministers in effect dismissed a French proposal to organize a summit meeting between the Western powers and OPEC. But they agreed to pursue bilateral contacts with OPEC counterparts, including a coming French session with Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Summers said he hoped that the United States' decision to provide 30 million barrels of oil from its reserves would persuade traders to stop snapping up forward contracts for oil in anticipation of severe winter shortages, a key factor behind the rising price.
In comments the currency markets will have to decipher this week, Mr. Summers also stressed that there was "no contradiction" between his decision to sell dollars to buy euros and his oft-repeated view that a strong dollar is vital to American interests. His insistence that America has not changed its currency policy suggests that Mr. Summers does not foresee the euro's rising sharply against the dollar -- and, further, that any continued United States intervention in currency markets would be limited unless the euro resumes its plunge.
Meanwhile, as the Group of 7 ministers met in private sessions, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic invited about 100 people representing charity and pressure groups concerned about globalization to debate the heads of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund at Prague Castle. The officials and protesters have gathered here for the annual meetings of the Washington-based lending agencies, which will continue for several days.
During the two-hour session, followed by a walk through the gardens of the sprawling Prague Castle, many environmental and social activists peppered the World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, and the International Monetary Fund managing director, Horst Kohler, with an extensive list of demands.
Several called for the complete abolition of the two Washington-based lending agencies, which were founded just after World War II to finance the reconstruction of Europe and stabilize world currencies. They have recently been under heavy pressure to improve the economic performance of poor and middle-income nations that receive most of their loans.
On the streets, where protest organizers have vowed to stage major demonstrations beginning on Sunday, the biggest march today was by some 500 anarchists, many dressed in black with black masks.
The crowd briefly blocked a highway. There was also a skirmish between anarchists and neo-Nazi skinheads, who were staging a rival demonstration near Prague's main railway station. At least one person was injured before the police arrived.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO;
Gore Takes an Approach Both Risky and Calculated

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
They are bad. Really bad. Malevolent even. And not just bad. They are big. Big and bad, like those nightmarish, saw-toothed meanies that lurk beneath the bed.
They are Vice President Al Gore's bogeymen -- big oil, big drug companies, big health insurers, big polluters. For good measure, Mr. Gore still throws in big tobacco from time to time. They are out there, threatening America's prosperity. And like politicians before him, Mr. Gore hopes to ride the public's trepidation about them all the way to the White House. 
 America has a tradition of populist politics, and in most cases the strategy has worked best when the enemy has been given a face. For William Jennings Bryan it was the banks. For Theodore Roosevelt it was the railroads and other "malefactors of great wealth." William Howard Taft, Woodrow Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt busted the trusts. John F. Kennedy took on U.S. Steel.
But it has been decades since a politician denounced such a broad array of corporate targets with such pointed language. For Mr. Gore, it is all part of the broader positioning of his campaign as "for the people," and the other side -- Gov. George W. Bush and the Republicans -- as "for the powerful."
"I have never hesitated," Mr. Gore said on Friday, "to take on big oil or the big pharmaceutical companies or the H.M.O.'s or whoever was operating in a way that was not in the best interest of the middle-class families of this country."
Like most campaign messages these days, Mr. Gore's assault is rooted in extensive polling and focus-group surveys that suggest deep public frustration with rising prices and, in the case of health maintenance organizations, confounding red tape. Populism has proven most effective, historians say, in times of economic inequality, and Mr. Gore's target audience includes those who feel they have not shared in the good times.
But Mr. Gore's tactic is not without risk. Another important component of his message is the taking of credit for the country's economic health, including the 22 million jobs created in the Clinton years. By setting his sights on central industries, Mr. Gore may create the perception that he is fighting the very businesses that have generated those jobs.
Then there is the risk of being branded a hypocrite. One major industry that Mr. Gore does not group with his litany of corporate offenders is big entertainment, which he condemns separately in speeches for marketing violence to children even as he solicits its executives for hefty campaign contributions.
Because it has been so long since any prominent politician tried Mr. Gore's approach, it is hard to predict how it will be received, said Alan Brinkley, a presidential historian at Columbia University.
"Gore is using it very carefully, making attacks against specific targets and not more broadly against concentrated economic power," Mr. Brinkley said. "I don't see how he could be perceived as antibusiness given the very centrist economic policy he's promoting and has been identified with over time."
But Jerry J. Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said Mr. Gore had convinced the business sector, particularly leaders of small companies, that he is against private enterprise.
"We know in an election that things are said and done that wouldn't happen in normal times," Mr. Jasinowski said. "But words mean something, and these words are irresponsible."
Clearly, Mr. Gore long ago discarded any instinct to soft-pedal his message. In speeches about oil pricing on Thursday and Friday, he pledged to "work toward the day when we are free forever of the dominance of big oil and foreign oil."
Because Mr. Bush and his running mate, Dick Cheney, both served as executives in the oil business, Mr. Gore said the Republican ticket was "of big oil, for big oil and by big oil."
When Mr. Gore turns his sights on managed care, he laments that doctors' decisions are being "overruled by some bean counter" who "doesn't have a right to play God." When the target is the prescription drug manufacturers, he describes them as having "so much power and so much wealth -- by all odds the most profitable industry in America."
That claim is true, according to a Fortune magazine survey that placed pharmaceutical profits in 1999 at 18.9 percent. The industry responds that it spends a hefty portion of profits on developing new drugs, though studies show that a larger share is devoted to marketing.
"While this pattern of attack may be good politics for the vice president," said Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, "it misleads the public about the industry that continues to develop important new medicines."
Oil industry officials and analysts said this week that they were distressed by Mr. Gore's offensive because, they maintain, domestic petroleum pricing is primarily a product of foreign supply. Profits are up this year, but the industry was battered last year by plummeting prices. Oil profit rates for the first half of this year were 6.8 percent, according to Business Week, compared with 7 percent for all United States industries.
"Mr. Gore is either extremely badly informed or he's being extremely disingenuous," said J. Robinson West, the chairman of Petroleum Finance Company, which provides strategic advice to oil companies.
Karl Rove, the chief strategist for the Bush campaign, said the primary effect of Mr. Gore's "screechy left-wing populism" was to stem the flow of liberal support to Ralph Nader and the Green Party. And he pointed out that Mr. Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, had received heavy campaign contributions from the insurance and pharmaceutical industries, and that Mr. Gore's family had profited from Occidental Petroleum mineral leases.
But Mark D. Fabiani, Mr. Gore's deputy campaign director, said the vice president had credibility because he fought against price-fixing in the oil and natural-gas industry in Congress and was an early supporter of generic drugs.
"In good times," he said, "you have economic power built up and sometimes it builds up to excess. Now it's time to make sure that elements of the economy that are blocking the prosperity of others, primarily families, is brought under control."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
TUCKER, RALPH W.

 BODY:
TUCKER-Ralph W., 56. Died on Feb. 26, 2000, at Mt. Sinai Hospital of complications of multiple myeloma. A free-lance writer, director and producer of industrial films, he learned film-making at the Army Pictorial Center in Astoria after a year's tour of duty in Vietnam. He was born in Bradenton, Fla, graduated from Maryville College in Tennessee, and lived all over the U.S. and in Europe and Asia before settling in New York in 1967. Tucker worked in New York and the U.S. on hundreds of sponsored theatrical films, prizewinning corporate videos, multimedia shows & business theater. Abroad he worked for the Truk Red Cross in Chuuk, Micronesia, and for the Association Internationale des Etudiants en Sciences Economiques et Commerciales. Among his personal works in progress when he fell ill were a play based on Huckleberry Finn, a science-fiction novel and a photojournalism book about the great harbor explosion in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He had planned to begin a book called "Spine" about his adventures as a multiple-myeloma patient. The New York Women in Film and Television screenplay reading committee staged a reading, on February 28 at the Cherry Lane Theatre, of "The History of an Unremarkable Life." The play, based on the novel "Ships That Pass in the Night" by Beatrice Harraden, was written by Tucker and Heather M. Winters and directed by John Steber. Tucker is survived by his wife, Helen Anne Easterly, and son, Guy, both of New York; his parents, LTC (Ret.) Walter F. and Roberta P. Tucker of St. Petersburg; a sister, BethAnn of Atlanta; and two brothers, Kenneth of St. Petersburg and Robert of Anchorage.

HEADLINE: Poaching May Kill Fish That Lay the Golden Eggs

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: ASTRAKHAN, Russia

 BODY:
On a dusty finger of land in the sprawling delta where the Volga River drains into the Caspian Sea, Vera Visokogorskaya is a Mary Poppins figure in a white smock, hovering and fussing over 75,000 baby sturgeon she is raising in a rundown state hatchery.
On another finger of the Volga delta, a fisherman named Aleksei is knocking back shots of vodka at the table of his friend, Boris, describing their lives as poachers. Like tens of thousands of other fishermen in the hinterland of the delta, they slaughtered a mountain of sturgeon this spring under the cover of darkness to eat the meat and sell caviar ripped from the females to black marketeers. 
 These two residents of Russia's caviar-producing region represent the intensifying clash of interests among Russians and their newly independent neighbors: along the shores of the Caspian, the world's largest inland sea, competition for resources threatens extinction of the last great sturgeon population on earth. Just two centuries ago, sturgeon were abundant throughout the Northern Hemisphere.
Aleksei -- who would only give his first name -- admits that he is part of a problem that no one in Russia is doing much to solve. "I am not Greenpeace," he said with mock bravado. "My anxiety will not change the fate of this fish."
Ms. Visokogorskaya is proud to be a nurturer, part of the solution. But the destroyers are legion, and the damage they are inflicting may soon be irreversible.
After a century of supplying the world with caviar, which fetches as much as $2,000 a pound in Geneva, Paris and New York, the Caspian sturgeon population, 70 percent of the world's reserves, is being harvested at a rate that can be sustained for only a few more years, experts and law enforcement officials say.
Though Russia and Iran have been stocking the Caspian Sea with up to 100 million baby sturgeon a year since the 1960's, the fish population is plummeting. This spring's official sturgeon catch of 400 tons was the lowest in a century and represented a 60 percent drop from 1999, the State Fishing Committee said. Scientists estimate that the adult sturgeon population, which numbered 1.5 million in 1986, has fallen below 300,000. And the health of many fish is in decline.
Caviar production is expected to drop to 40 tons this year, down from 1,200 tons in 1985.
"No one wants to have caviar banned," said Uldry Thierry, the chief executive of the Geneva-based Caviar House, one of Europe's largest retailers, which processes 25 tons a year in a market estimated at 80 to 100 tons. (Americans consume 40 to 50 tons a year.) "But the Russian government has got to find an answer, and the only answer is stricter controls against poaching."
The illegal sturgeon catch is estimated at 5 to 10 times the official catch. Strict export licensing and DNA testing of caviar samples has led to some spectacular hauls of illegal shipments to the United States in the last year, but the black market has grown phenomenally over the last two decades.
Besides the depredations of poachers, up to a third of the female sturgeon are suffering from chemical poisoning severe enough to render them infertile, scientists report. And the proportion of female sturgeon reaching spawning grounds has also fallen, to just 20 or 30 percent.
"The situation is very serious," said John Sellar, the chief of enforcement for the secretariat of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, in Geneva. With caviar bars and restaurants multiplying in the West, Mr. Sellar suggested that "people are behaving in a very irresponsible manner."
In December, scientists from the convention that regulates trade in endangered species will meet in West Virginia to decide whether to declare the Caspian sturgeon so endangered as to warrant a total ban on trade until the species recovers.
To stop fishing would be an economic and political catastrophe feared by all the Caspian governments -- Russia, Iran, Azerbaijan, Turkmenistan and Kazakhstan -- but it may be inevitable if the species is to survive.
The Soviet Union rigorously policed the fishing grounds of the Caspian, but also sowed the seeds for the current decline. Sixty years of dam building eliminated 70 to 80 percent of the sturgeons' spawning grounds along the Volga, where since prehistoric times belugas, the largest sturgeon, whose plump gray caviar is most prized, ranged 1,000 miles inland to spawn.
As Soviet planners diverted water supplies to artificial reservoirs, the level of the Caspian declined nearly 10 feet. The spread of agriculture and industrialization dealt another blow, as pesticide runoff killed thousands of fish.
The discovery of huge oil and gas reserves off Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan represents an added potential danger.
Given the general poverty, poaching sturgeon is simply a means to survive for countless thousands of families here, who send their men out in small boats at night to kill fish for the table and, with luck, sell a little caviar on the black market.
Seated at Boris's table in a rundown apartment on the outskirts of Astrakhan, Aleksei described their business.
Many of the 50,000 people in the area once worked at a paper mill, he said. "When it closed, these people had no other way to earn money or to eat, and so the river feeds them."
In wooden boats, the poachers lay submerged lines dangling hundreds of hooks to snag the migrating sturgeon.
"The night is what hides us," Aleksei said. "If you hear the sound of a motor boat, you hide among the bushes on the shore." The motorboats are usually the police, who regularly drag an anchor behind them to pull up as many poacher lines as they can. But the lines are quickly laid again.
"We keep our catch in the water on a rope and the rope is in my hand," Aleksei said. "If the police come to my side of the boat to inspect us, I just let it go. Few poachers are ever caught, and, when they are, they face a light fine and confiscation of their fish.
The damage from small-scale poachers is compounded by the organized poaching that occurs out at sea by criminal gangs with fast boats, satellite navigation systems and the protection of corrupt police or military officials.
But at Bios, a state hatchery and research center 25 miles southwest of Astrakhan, the director, Lidia M. Vassileva, is in charge of one of 13 fish farms that try to sustain the sturgeon population by releasing 60 million palm-sized fish into the Volga and the Caspian every year.
"Sturgeon are like a living relic, and the reason they are on the brink of extinction is that you have two natural resources that cannot coexist -- oil and fish," she said.
The state company for which she works has developed a modest business in selling fertilized caviar -- which is, after all, just eggs -- to fish farms in Russia, China, Europe and the United States, where the fish are raised for meat and sold to restaurants and food-processing industries.
More ambitiously, Bios is trying to raise sturgeon until they are sexually mature, a process that takes 10 to 20 years, and then harvest caviar without killing the females. The technique has been demonstrated at a handful of fish farms, but requires long investment before there is any return.
Ms. Vassileva's assistant, Ms. Visokogorskaya, each year supervises the fertilization of 20 million sturgeon minnows for release into the Volga, and helps raise 75,000 sturgeon.
Moving among their tanks like a matriarch, she snatched a six-pounder out of one tank. She looked with pride over what she calls her flock and said, "In Russia, we have an economic crisis, but in the world, they only want caviar."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
As Season Ends, Some Managers Are in Danger of Losing Their Jobs

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Larry Dierker managed Houston to division championships in each of his first three seasons with the Astros. In this, his fourth season, the Astros have played badly, and Dierker is said in baseball circles to be in danger of losing his job.
Buck Showalter managed the Arizona Diamondbacks to a division championship in their second season, making them the most successful baseball expansion team in history. The Diamondbacks, however, have not only failed to repeat, but have also played too poorly to make the playoffs as the wild-card team, and Showalter is said to be in danger of losing his job. 
 Johnny Oates managed the Texas Rangers to division championships three of the past four seasons. This season, however, the Rangers are in last place, and rumors say Oates is in danger of losing his job.
As the regular season begins its final week, more than half a dozen managers, Dierker and Showalter among them, are perilously perched on the precipice of dismissal. Oates, however, is not teetering there. Tom Hicks, the Rangers' owner, said recently that Oates would continue as the manager.
Felipe Alou, the venerable manager of the Montreal Expos, is another whose status was rumored to be in question, but Jeffrey Loria, the team's managing partner, said that was news to him.
"I've never said that," Loria said. "I've never said I want to make a change. Felipe's the manager. He's under contract, an enormous contract. I've never entertained any other ideas other than saying we'll take a look at everything at the end of the season."
Loria added, "He's not in trouble."
Dusty Baker and Lou Piniella are not in trouble, either. In fact, they are managers in the enviable position of being free agents after the season. Their contracts expire, and they have not signed extensions.
San Francisco wants Baker to remain, and he most likely will stay. He has been wise, though, to see how far the Giants go in the postseason before signing. The farther they go, the higher his salary figures to go.
"Dusty has made it clear he prefers to wait until the end of the season to focus on his business issues," Jeff Moorad, Baker's adviser, said. "We're acutely aware of his attraction around the major leagues and I'm certain if he showed himself to be available that we'd have a number of teams interested. I'm not sure that's the intent. In fact, it's fair to say he's inclined to stay in San Francisco as long as the terms of a deal were fair and appropriate."
The only negative aspect of continuing the relationship was suggested by another club's executive. "I've heard rumblings that Dusty doesn't want to be with Barry Bonds," the executive said.
Piniella is not so certain to remain in Seattle, where he has managed for eight years. He has not said what he prefers, but the most popular speculation has him desiring to manage at home, meaning Tampa Bay. The Devil Rays, however, are not the contending team Piniella has become accustomed to managing.
"His focus is totally on winning the pennant and hopefully getting to the World Series," said Alan Nero, his agent. "We've all agreed not to think about it or talk about it now. Lou has incredible loyalty to the Seattle ownership and fans. He would like to hear what they have to say first and then decide what he's going to do."
Seattle's Pat Gillick sounded like a general manager who wanted to retain his manager.
"If you're grading guys on the type of season they've had," Gillick said, "Lou's had a great season, not only from the standpoint of handling players but running the games. He's had an all-star year. I've never seen him so much under control. He has mellowed and matured."
Part of the Piniella speculation involves Jimy Williams of Boston. Piniella, the scenario goes, would leave the Mariners, whose general manager, Gillick, has a good relationship from their Toronto days with Williams, who would ask out of the remaining year of his contract with the Red Sox or be fired because he and the Boston general manager, Dan Duquette, are less than friendly.
When the scenario was mentioned to Williams recently, he said he knew nothing about it. "I have a contract for next year," he said.
But the relationship between Williams and Duquette became more strained in recent days when Duquette defended Carl Everett, Boston's center fielder, after he arrived late for a game. "If I was the general manager, I would back the manager," Williams told reporters in Boston yesterday, "and if you can't, you probably need to get rid of me."
 In about every instance where a manager's position is precarious, the team owner or general manager has said the club will evaluate or address everything at the end of the season. That statement covers Dierker, Showalter, Gene Lamont of Pittsburgh, Terry Francona of Philadelphia, Larry Rothschild of Tampa Bay and Davey Johnson of Los Angeles.
Jim Bowden, the Cincinnati general manager, offered a variation on the theme when asked about Jack McKeon. "Jack's our manager, and I have no other comment," he said.
Baseball executives would consider it a major upset if McKeon, Francona, Rothschild, Johnson or Lamont survived. In Lamont's case, Kevin McClatchy, the owner, has reportedly already told him he will not remain in the Pirates' job.
"We'll address Geno's situation at the end of the season, which is not that far away," McClatchy said. "Any discussions between Gene and me are confidential."
Ed Wade, general manager of the last-place Phillies, said the club had "had high expectations coming off our offensive performance last year," adding: "Things have not developed the way we expected. We're hugely disappointed."
The situation in Los Angeles is interesting because the apparent desire of General Manager Kevin Malone to change managers is compounded by the possibility that Malone himself could be fired.
"Our situation is being evaluated at this time," Malone said. "There's been no decisions made. We're pleased with the way we've performed the last week or two. Unfortunately, we waited until this late date."
Gerry Hunsicker of Houston sounded like a general manager who wanted to keep his manager, but Dierker's future will be determined by the owner, Drayton McLane Jr.
"I think sometimes we can jump to conclusions before we know what the real issues are," McLane said. "We want to take everything into consideration. We'll make a decision very quickly, in the first week after the season."
Dierker's position could be undermined by reports that some of his players don't take him seriously and don't want to play for him.
"It's not any different from any clubhouse," Hunsicker said when asked about the reports. "I think it's the nature of the beast. These things surface when you lose."
Players do not apparently like Showalter in Arizona, even though, like Dierker, he managed them to a first-place finish. Jerry Colangelo, the Diamondbacks' managing partner, has said he will wait until the end of the season before making a decision, but the team's collapse the last five weeks can't help Showalter.
Even the elder statesman among managers is not certain of his status. Tom Kelly has managed the Minnesota Twins for 14 seasons, winning the World Series in 1987 and '91, but does not know if he will make it to 15.
"They haven't informed me if they want me to come back," said Kelly, who is in the last year of his contract and wants to stay with the Twins. "Three years ago, they asked me to stay and take on this undertaking. Now we're starting to see some light at the end of the tunnel and I feel like I'd like to do this some more. But we haven't heard anything. I'm hoping to hear something in the next few days, because I have some coaches I need to take care of. Whether we're staying or leaving, I'd like to get it resolved in the next few days or a week. If they don't want us back, fine; we'll get along. If they do, good; let's get going."
 
No In-Season Changes Yet
Barring an unexpected development, the season will end without any teams changing managers. It would be the first time since 1942 such a development occurred, and there were only 16 teams then.
Jim Bowden of Cincinnati attributed the novelty to baseball economics.
"I think a lot of it has to do with the economic disparity we have right now," he said. "The expectations for each manager are different from what they have been in the past. Small-market teams can't have the same expectations for those managers as you once did. Before, most of the teams had a chance to win, and expectations were greater for each manager. People are more realistic now."
Gerry Hunsicker of Houston said clubs might be viewing the job more rationally than before.
"Maybe they're realizing that firing managers doesn't change a whole lot of the results," he said. "It's amazing how managers become extremely smart when they have talent and extremely stupid when they don't have talent."
Doug Melvin, the Texas general manager, suggested that some clubs might not have acted because they could not come up with suitable replacements. "A lot of guys don't want to take jobs on an interim basis," Melvin said. "They want the job from Day 1 of spring training."
It is entirely possible that if one team had fired its manager sometime this season, others would have followed. Often in the past clubs wanted to make a change but did not want to be the first to do it. When another team fired its manager, those other teams then did likewise.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Grunt as President? History Salutes a Few Good Men

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MUCH has been made in the presidential campaign about Vice President Al Gore's stint with the Army in Vietnam, but one striking fact has gone largely unnoted: If elected, Mr. Gore would be the first president in a century to have served as an enlisted man and one of only four ever.
The presidency, of course, has been replete with men who served their country in uniform -- 27 of the 42 presidents -- but the overwhelming majority did so in the officer corps. 
 There have been 12 generals (Washington, Jackson, Harrison, Taylor, Pierce, Andrew Johnson, Grant, Hayes, Garfield, Arthur, Harrison and Eisenhower), though no admirals. And there has been a colonel (Theodore Roosevelt), a commander (Lyndon B. Johnson) and a lieutenant commander (Ford), a major (Truman), a captain (Reagan) and three lieutenants (Kennedy, Nixon and Bush).
But not since William McKinley, who was president from 1897 until his assassination in 1901, has there been a president who served in the humbler ranks.
McKinley enlisted as a private in the 23rd Regiment of the Ohio Volunteer Infantry during the Civil War. (He went on to receive a battlefield promotion to lieutenant after the Battle of Antietam from a colonel who went on to become a general and a president, Rutherford B. Hayes.)
In addition to McKinley, only two other presidents had served in the enlisted ranks, according to several presidential reference books.
James Buchanan served in a company of dragoons -- essentially cavalrymen -- in the defense of Baltimore during the War of 1812. And Abraham Lincoln volunteered as a private when the
Illinois militia mobilized to fight in the Black Hawk Wars in 1832. His company promptly elected him captain, but when that unit stood down, he reenlisted as a private.
As for Mr. Gore, in August 1969, he walked into a draft center in Newark, N.J. and enlisted as a private. And a private he remained through basic training at Fort Dix, a tour at Fort Rucker, and five months as an Army journalist in Vietnam. (He was granted an early discharge to attend divinity school.)
Mr. Gore, of course, was no ordinary buck private. His father was a senator, and G.I.'s
like him were on what one Army general and Vietnam veteran called "a watch list," a sort of unwritten order to keep them out of trouble.
Charles C. Moskos, a sociologist at Northwestern University who has long studied the military, said that the dearth of enlistees among the presidents reflected the social and economic backgrounds of the nation's politicians and officers, who with few exceptions were of the educated elite.
"The typical military experience is to be an enlisted man," he said. "It has not been shared by our presidents."
Mr. Gore's campaign has made the most of his military record, which starkly contrasts to the lack of service by President Clinton, but it remains to be seen how much it will help him on Election Day.
His opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, scores higher in the polls on military matters, and in recent years people in uniform, particularly in the officer corps, have tilted increasingly toward the Republican Party. The tradition in which the majority usually considered themselves independent is weakening, a trend that has raised concerns about the increasing politicization of the military.
A survey last year of up and coming officers found that 64 percent identified themselves as Republicans, compared to only 8 percent who were Democrats.
As if to underscore the point, an array of veterans, including senior officers who served under Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore, last week endorsed Mr. Bush, who served as a fighter pilot in the Texas National Guard during the Vietnam War and was, for the record, a lieutenant.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: October 1, 2000, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last week about the military service of United States presidents included an incomplete list of those who served as officers. James Monroe was a lieutenant colonel under George Washington, John Tyler a captain in the Virginia militia, and Jimmy Carter a lieutenant in the Navy. Millard Fillmore served as a major in the New York Home Guard during the Civil War, but only after he left the presidency.
The article also misstated the number of American presidents. Because Grover Cleveland's two terms were nonconsecutive, there have been 42 presidencies, but only 41 presidents.

HEADLINE: China's Threat to Labor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is a pity that the discussion over legislation on trade with China (front page, Sept. 20) does not distinguish between the liberalization of our trade with China and China's easing of restrictions on our investment there. The two have very different consequences.
Increasing trade is all to the good and allows both countries to specialize in what they do best. Increasing the outflow of American capital, however, can lower productivity here and cost workers their jobs. This explains the opposition to the bill by labor unions. 
 Increased investment abroad is also responsible for the mixed results of the North American Free Trade Agreement alluded to in your article. Opening up China to a flood of American investment is a daunting thought.
 
PEGGY B. MUSGRAVE
Santa Cruz, Calif., Sept. 20, 2000

HEADLINE: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned on Wednesday.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 5.97 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.95 percent.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.03 percent.

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Latin America is a difficult -- but attractive -- region for e-marketplaces that are trying to enlist small businesses.

BYLINE: By Jennifer L. Rich 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
AT the recent Florida Trade Expo in the American Chamber of Commerce here, a middle-aged man in a crumpled business suit stepped up to a lectern that held a laptop computer and, with two fingers, began to tap out responses to the onscreen questionnaire. Name. Company. Number of employees.
As he filled in the form, the staff from 1hemisphere.com -- a Miami-based Internet company specializing in hemispheric trade -- explained the benefits of his free membership: free e-mail; Web service for his company's site; and a free virtual storefront to transact business. 
 With his registration complete, the small-business man, whose Brazilian company exports technological components to Europe, shrugged. "We'll see what it is going to do for me," he said.
Employees from 1hemisphere.com, along with one of its competitors, latintrade.com, had come from Florida to Brazil to participate in the trade show and try to convince the local small and midsize businesses that a revolution is afoot. Operators of these so-called e-marketplaces -- Internet portals through which companies do business with one another -- are betting on the democratizing power of the Internet to break down the traditional information and trade barriers that confine most small companies in Latin America to doing business within 30 miles of home.
The benefits of e-marketplaces for Latin America are potentially enormous. With help from the Internet, sellers could reach a significantly wider base of clients, raising profits for 10 million small companies that still serve as the main employers and drivers of growth throughout the region.
With greater access to information, buyers, in turn, might get a better price in a more globalized market, increasing competitiveness all around. And everyone could save money, compared with the costs of closing the same deals in a world based on faxes and phone calls.
But revolutions don't happen in a day. E-marketplaces are still struggling to work out the kinks that so far have impeded Latin America's small businesses from reaping the benefits of Internet-based trade. The payoff, if it comes at all, may not happen for years.
But the obstacles are not deterring Internet companies from racing to stake a claim in the market for business-to-business e-commerce in Latin America -- a market that is forecast to reach $5.5 billion a year by 2003, according to figures published in a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter report in February.
"We have just had the big bang," said Anna Giraldo Kerr, research manager for IDC Latin America, an Internet consulting firm. "Since we are still going through the whole evolutionary period right now, B to B still has a grace period," Ms. Kerr said, using industry shorthand for business to business. "Once that settles, though, there is definitely going to be a shakeout."
Some marketplaces, like adquira.com by the Spanish giant Telefonica and artikos .com by Commerce One of the United States, may have the resources to survive a shakeout. Other independent start-ups like 1hemisphere.com may be under more pressure to use revenues to pay as they go.
For the most part, hemispheric portals are following the lead of various e-marketplaces already in operation in the United States. The owner of a zipper company in Rio de Janeiro, for example, can post his products on a bulletin board on the 1hemisphere.com Web site. While surfing the site, a jeans maker in Lima, Peru, finds that the Rio zippers are cheaper than those available locally, clicks over to the zipper maker's Web site via 1hemisphere.com and places an order. From the 1hemisphere.com site, the zipper maker lines up a shipping company, calculates the price of import duties, converts the whole thing into Peruvian currency and e-mails a bill to the jeans maker.
Meanwhile, 1hemisphere.com earns a commission on the completed deal.
"Over the last two years, we have seen that small businesses in Latin America are finding out that they get a better return on their money if they export, especially if they send their products into the North American market," said Jose Matto, president and chief executive of 1hemisphere.com. "Part of what we are doing is just match-making."
But the challenges are huge, starting with the typical mind-set of the very professionals who are expected to use the service -- business executives who are battle-scarred by the region's history of economic troubles, like the sky-high inflation that once plagued Brazil.
"During hyperinflation, you had to have an accounting system that was just the basics because if you forgot to actualize a price monthly or biweekly, you could lose 20 percent," said Jose Augusto Correa, director of the technology department at the Federation of Industries of the Sao Paulo state. By comparison, he said, the 2 or 3 percent in cost savings from adopting new technology had hardly seemed worth the effort.
Mr. Correa said that greater economic stability had only recently encouraged companies to consider technical innovations. That may help explain why, among the 10 million or so small and midsize businesses in Latin America, only about a million have any kind of Internet connection.
While substandard networks and high costs can partly be blamed for the delay to adopt new information technology, much of the reticence may also be psychological. The Internet may still be seen as too cold and anonymous in a region where many people are more comfortable sealing deals with a handshake and a thump on the back.
To overcome such resistance, some portals are signing up large corporations to serve as anchor buyers. The premise is that small companies will be eager for the opportunity to land a big contract with a big customer they might not otherwise have access to. For example, Asista.com, another of the Miami crop of e-marketplaces, recently signed a letter of intent with the Mexican conglomerate Axa S.A. de C.V. to buy all its office supplies and equipment through the site.
"It is not going to start from the small guys getting religion all of a sudden," John Mein, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Sao Paulo, said of the e-marketplace movement. "It is going to push through the economy from the top down. For the small companies to compete, they are going to have to step up their investments in technology."
But even if more small Latin American companies do venture online, they will still face other obstacles to cross-border commerce. Shipping companies are few. Export financing is hard to come by. Legal issues can be confusing. And many costs remain hidden within stacks of bureaucratic paperwork. Through strategic agreements with banks and logistics companies, the region's e-marketplaces are just now starting to find ways to confront these problems.
"All these models have to be proven, and they require the backing of banks and other institutions to prove that they are going to be done in the proper way," said Jaime Vargas, chief executive of Mercantil.com. "It will require some time."
Time, of course, takes money. Which is why the region's e-marketplace players will need to fine tune their approaches and marshal their resources, if they hope to be still in business when the revolution finally catches up with them.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Trademarks gain attention as passports to the Internet and for a critical vote ahead in Congress.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
IN the world of intellectual property, the business of trademarks exists in the shadow of patents. Patent owners are inventors, while trademark owners are simply people who control brand names, slogans and logos.
Trademark experts -- lawyers, lobbyists and others -- think few people understand that establishing and protecting brand names is a critical part of the economic success of many patented devices or systems, and that trademarks are increasingly important to companies competing in the global, digital marketplace. 
 Some big trademark owners are particularly worried that Congress does not grasp the importance of brands. While Congress recently extended the life span of patents to conform with standards in Europe and Japan, it has not acted to adopt similar changes to trademark law contained in a 1989 international agreement known among specialists as the Madrid protocol.
That agreement which updates an international trademark treaty negotiated in 1891, allows anyone to apply for or to renew a trademark anywhere in the world by submitting one form in one country. The amendment took effect in many nations in 1995, but not in the United States because of a dispute whether the European Union should have a vote as well as each of its 15 member nations.
Last week, a phalanx of officials from the International Trademark Association went to Capitol Hill to try to persuade Congress to adopt the trademark agreement. The United States Patent and Trademark Office supports it, as does the Clinton administration. The dispute over voting rights is resolved. The trademark association officials said there was no opposition in Congress to the Madrid protocol, but they still were not sure the vote would occur. Evidently, trademark law is not a front-burner issue.
So they took to the hallways of Congress, seeking to ensure that their bill was not lost in a last-minute flurry of voting on sexier legislation. Indeed, the vote is now scheduled this week.
"We need to strike while the iron is hot and make sure it moves before the end of this session," said Michael Heltzer, the trademark association's government relations manager, just before the officials left for Capitol Hill.
The International Trademark Association was established in 1878 as the United States Trademark Association and changed its name 10 years ago to reflect its global membership. Lately, the issues that most concern trademark owners -- such as the counterfeiting of designer handbags, or determining the rights to Internet domain names -- have become increasingly international. For this reason, inducing the United States to join the 48 countries already signed onto the Madrid protocol is the group's top priority.
"Now we'll have a centralized way to submit one application, pay one fee in one currency and get quicker action," said Kimbley Muller, the trademark association's president and senior counsel for intellectual property at Shell Oil. He said the new regulations are more important for midsize and small businesses than for companies like Shell.
"If I get a trademark approved and then I change my address, I only have to send one letter instead of 180 letters around the world," he continued. "Big companies like Shell can afford those administration costs, but for a small company, that could be a life-or-death difference in their worldwide business."
If the bill passes, the trademark association would be able to focus more attention on counterfeiting and domain-name disputes, issues important to some of its largest members. Both affect brands that are worth hundreds of millions of dollars to their owners.
"For Warner Brothers, first and foremost, the concern is for the cartoon characters we protect around the world through trademark and copyright," said Nils Montan, a vice president and senior counsel for intellectual property of the studio. "We have thousands and thousands of registrations, from Bugs Bunny to Fred Flintstone and now to Harry Potter. We spend a lot of time, effort and money in the registration process around the world."
Secure trademarks are increasingly important because they are becoming the key to obtaining easily recognizable Internet addresses. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers in December began arbitrating disputes over the ownership of Internet addresses based on trademarked brands. About 1,000 cases have been heard, and 75 percent have been won by trademark owners.
Controlling a brand name is "more important when you go into cyberspace because there's no salesperson there, nobody to reassure you," Mr. Muller said. "All you have is the name."
If the United States adopts the new standards, the next goal will be to sign up as many smaller countries as possible, said Alan Drewsen, the trademark group's executive director.
"In many jurisdictions, they're just beginning to appreciate the value of intellectual property," he said. "We have to educate officials in those countries to understand how it affects their own economic development, both for local businesses and for their attractiveness to foreign investment."
If the trademark association was wooing Congress in hopes of winning a vote on the Madrid protocol, it may soon be back to battling over a perennial issue -- funds for the Patent and Trademark Office. Congress has taken a chunk of the agency's income every year for the last several years, leaving it with a budget deficit.
"They don't have enough trademark examiners, the examiners are not getting training, then you have something like the Madrid protocol which is not in the budget, so they have to divert funds," Mr. Drewsen said. "So we've made this a priority till it gets straightened out."

HEADLINE: Hideo Sasaki, 80, Influential Landscape Architect, Dies

BYLINE: By ANNE RAVER 

 BODY:
Hideo Sasaki, an internationally renowned landscape architect who was as admired for his teaching and critical abilities as for his multidisciplinary approach to design, died on Aug. 30 at a hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 80 and lived in nearby Lafayette, Calif.
Mr. Sasaki founded Sasaki Associates, in the Boston suburb of Watertown, in 1953 while teaching at Harvard University's Graduate School of Design, where he was chairman of the landscape architecture department from 1958 to 1968. He believed in throwing his students right into the design problems of the real world, where they worked alongside civil engineers, urban planners and contemporary giants like the architect Eero Saarinen and the sculptor and landscape designer Isamu Noguchi. 
 "A lot of us were working as many hours in his office as school," said Peter Walker, who joined the firm right after earning his degree in landscape architecture from Harvard.
"He changed this field, he reinvented it," added Mr. Walker, who now practices in San Francisco. "It wasn't just loosey-goosey. He believed in theory, and you had to defend your position."
In the boom years after World War II, Mr. Sasaki's team built some of America's first corporate parks, as companies like Upjohn and John Deere moved their headquarters from city to country. As whole neighborhoods were demolished in the urban renewal fever of the 1960's -- a movement much criticized now for erasing cultural history -- Mr. Sasaki's designers produced Copley Square in Boston, Constitution Plaza in Hartford and Washington Square Village in Manhattan. The designs played with earth shapes, using hard materials, and juxtaposed what Mr. Sasaki called biomorphic shapes against geometric ones, celebrating yet set apart from the modern buildings they framed.
The firm also designed college campuses that fit the geology of their sites, mounding the land around Foothill College in Los Altos, Calif., to echo the foothills for which it is named and expanding the campus of the University of Colorado with bold modern architecture that blended with the smaller Italianate buildings of the school's early days. And the firm designed the master plan for a brand new campus for the State University of New York at Buffalo.
"As a planner he understood demographics; he knew colleges were going to grow and that people would be moving out of the city," said Gary Hildebrand, an associate professor of landscape architecture at Harvard. "And he organized his firm to match the corporate culture. They had the ability to organize, to develop ideas as research, to implement efficiently with accountability."
New Yorkers have spent many an hour in Mr. Sasaki's smaller, more intimate spaces, like Greenacre Park, on 51st Street, between Second and Third Avenues, where a stream tumbles over rocks to meet a waterfall among woodland plantings and magnolia trees; and the International Paper Plaza, where a grove of redwoods, weeping cherries and magnolias bring a breeze and welcome shade to nature-starved Midtown workers.
Such versatility came not from one man, but from the many minds Mr. Sasaki nurtured and encouraged to design collaboratively, building models in the parking lot, going back to the drawing board as the master critic made some gentle but astute suggestion.
"Hideo almost never did any of the design work himself," said Prof. Charles Harris, who has taught at Harvard for 42 years. "He was a master teacher and design critic. He was able to inspire people to pursue ideas and explore things without drawing a line."
Professor Harris first studied with Mr. Sasaki as an undergraduate at the University of Illinois, where he and other students fell in love with his international perspective.
"He was calling for the need for more contemporary design and collaboration at a time when landscape architecture was still caught up in the Beaux-Arts," Professor Harris said. "He didn't subscribe to any particular design aesthetic. He wanted people to understand the human needs and natural forces that were working on the landscape."
In the 1950's Mr. Walker was just a greenhorn when Mr. Sasaki named him principal landscape architect for the 100-acre Upjohn headquarters just outside Kalamazoo, Mich., when the company moved from town to a farmer's field. The design, with its courtyards and terraces, groves of trees and artificial lakes -- which provided water to cool the buildings -- was built in collaboration with the architects Bruce Graham, Noguchi and Gordon Bunshaft. While other factories in the country were surrounded by parking lots, this one stood in a giant garden.
"That's why they were called villas," Mr. Walker said of these new corporate Versailles.
When Stuart Dawson was still a student at Harvard in the 1950's, he was meeting with Eero Saarinen, the architect for the John Deere headquarters, which was moving from downtown Moline, Ill., to a ravine on the edge of town overlooking miles of cropland.
"Hid was back teaching at Harvard," Mr. Dawson recalled. "You'd come back and go over everything with him, and he'd say, 'That's good, maybe you should try that.' Basically, he let us hang ourselves, but I guess he figured we wouldn't."
Mr. Sasaki was honored by Harvard last year at the department of landscape architecture's 100th anniversary celebration, which featured a symposium on his work. The university awarded him the Centennial Medal, honoring extraordinary achievement in landscape architecture.
Though a longtime resident of Massachusetts, he was born on Nov. 25, 1919, in the San Joaquin Valley town of Reedley, Calif. He grew up on his parents' truck farm and worked in the beet fields in Arizona when he was relocated to a World War II internment camp there for Japanese-Americans. He eventually made his way to Chicago, where he discovered landscape architecture at the University of Illinois, and later earned his master's degree in landscape architecture at the Harvard Graduate School of Design.
He was appointed to the United States Commission of Fine Arts by President John F. Kennedy in 1961 and again by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1965.
He was the first recipient of the American Society of Landscape Architects' medal in 1971, and in 1973 he received the Allied Professions Medal from the American Institute of Architects.
Mr. Sasaki is survived by his wife, Kisa, and two daughters, Rin and Ann, all of Northern California.
